site_title: UK's Truss says 'closing in' on free trade agreement with New Zealand
summary: Britain's trade minister Lizz Truss said the UK is "closing in" on a free trade agreement with New Zealand, citing "great progress" in the sixth round of discussions. The agreement in principle is expected to be finalized soon.

site_title: Beijing's crackdown ruins July for investors everywhere
summary: China's regulators are attempting to calm markets following a significant downturn in the country's stock market, with the Hang Seng Index falling nearly 20% below its February peak. The crackdown on for-profit school tutoring is part of a broader re-shaping of the tech economy in China, and investors are concerned about the potential for further regulatory measures. The impact is expected to be felt globally, with emerging markets and currencies, such as the New Zealand dollar and South African rand, potentially facing significant risks.

site_title: Keppel shares gain after return to profit; analysts cheer growth initiatives
summary: Keppel Corp shares rose 1.9% on Friday after the conglomerate announced a return to profitability for the first half of the year, posting a net profit of S$299.8 million. Analysts praised the company's growth initiatives, including new energy projects, and raised their target prices. CGS-CIMB raised its target price to S$6.90, while DBS maintained a "buy" call with a target price of S$6.20, citing the company's operational improvements and potential merger with Sembcorp Marine.

site_title: Economists optimistic on Q3 employment outlook despite Q2 setback
summary: Economists in Singapore are optimistic about the third quarter's employment outlook, despite a Q2 setback due to tightened Covid-19 curbs. Total employment rose in Q1 after a year of declines, but fell by 15,700 in Q2 due to slower resident employment growth in domestically-oriented sectors. Non-resident employment declined more sharply, mainly in the construction industry. Unemployment rates improved, with overall unemployment edging down to 2.7% and resident unemployment falling to 3.7%. Economists expect employment to improve if border controls are eased in the coming months, with some predicting a 50,000 to 100,000 increase in total employment for the full year.

site_title: Singtel rejects energy player's offers for its Thai telecoms investments
summary: Singtel has rejected Thai energy player Gulf Energy's offers to buy stakes in its Thai telecom investments, Advanced Info Service (AIS) and Intouch Holdings. The telco stated its "continued commitment" to the companies, citing strategic transformation plans. Singtel deemed Gulf's offer for AIS "significantly undervalued" and plans to reinvigorate their core businesses through digital services and infrastructure assets. The decision was made after considering factors such as offer terms and independent financial advice.

images.alt_text: Singtel's stake in Thai telco Advanced Info Service (AIS) is 23.3 per cent; its interest in Intouch Holdings is 21.2 per cent.

site_title: US: Nasdaq, S&P 500 fall as Amazon earnings disappoint
summary: The US stock market fell on Friday, with the Nasdaq and S&P 500 indexes declining 0.71% and 0.35% respectively, following Amazon's disappointing quarterly earnings report. Amazon's sales growth is expected to slow in the next few quarters, and shares of other technology companies, such as Apple and Alphabet, also fell. Despite this, data showing a strong rise in June consumer spending reinforced optimism about a steady economic rebound.

site_title: ecoWise and listing sponsor Zico Capital to part ways 'for commercial reasons': Board
summary: ecoWise Holdings, a waste management company listed on Catalist, has parted ways with listing sponsor Zico Capital due to commercial reasons. ecoWise issued a written termination notice to Zico Capital on July 29, with Zico Capital's sponsorship set to cease on August 29 or when a new sponsor is appointed. The company will suspend trading and may risk delisting if it doesn't have a sponsor for three consecutive months. ecoWise is finalising the appointment of a new continuing sponsor and will update shareholders when this new sponsor is appointed.

site_title: US resumes fast-track deportation flights of Central American migrant families
summary: The US has resumed fast-track deportation flights for Central American migrant families, with the goal of removing those who do not qualify to remain in the country. The flights will transport Guatemalan, Honduran, and Salvadoran families who could not be immediately expelled due to the coronavirus-related public health policy and lack of a legal basis to stay. Migrant crossings at the southern border have increased, with June seeing the highest level of arrests since April 2000, and July's numbers expected to be similar or higher.

site_title: Australia's third-largest city of Brisbane to enter Covid lockdown
summary: Brisbane, Australia's third-largest city, will enter a three-day Covid-19 lockdown starting Saturday due to an emerging Delta strain outbreak. The lockdown, the city's strictest to date, restricts residents from leaving their homes except for essential reasons. The outbreak, linked to a school cluster, has raised concerns about the country's low vaccination rate, with only 14% of the population fully vaccinated. Authorities are racing to contain the spread, with Prime Minister Scott Morrison setting a target of 80% full vaccination before borders can reopen.

images.alt_text: Born in London and brought up in Nigeria, Yinka Shonibare showcases his multicultural influences as well as theme of international trade in this sculptural work titled Wind Sculpture I.

site_title: China outbreak spreads as WHO sounds alarm on Delta
summary: China is experiencing a surge in Delta variant cases, with over 200 linked to a cluster in Nanjing city. The outbreak has spread to two more areas, Fujian province and Chongqing, prompting stricter COVID-19 restrictions. The World Health Organization (WHO) is urging the world to quickly contain the mutation before it becomes deadlier. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers, as the Delta variant continues to spread.

site_title: Aspen guides for half-year net loss, citing expenses in glove-making business
summary: Aspen (Group) Holdings expects a net loss for the half-year to June 30, citing significant pre-operating expenses from its glove-making arm, Aspen Glove Sdn Bhd. Despite this, the group's healthcare sector is expected to perform better in the second half of 2021. The property development segment recorded a pre-tax profit, while the company's shares lost 0.1 Singapore cent. The results are expected to be released by August 14, with shareholders advised to exercise caution when dealing with the company's shares.

site_title: Senate heads toward passage of infrastructure deal next week
summary: The US Senate is set to pass a bipartisan $550 billion infrastructure bill next week, a cornerstone of President Joe Biden's economic agenda. The bill, which includes $110 billion in new spending for roads and bridges, has broad bipartisan support, with 66 senators voting to move forward in a 28-16 vote. Senate passage would pave the way for consideration of a budget resolution that could facilitate the rest of the Biden economic agenda, including a $3.5 trillion overhaul of policies on climate change, taxes, and healthcare.

site_title: 131 new locally transmitted Covid-19 cases; 28 linked to Jurong Fishery Port
summary: There were 131 new locally transmitted Covid-19 cases in Singapore, with 28 linked to the Jurong Fishery Port cluster and one linked to the KTV cluster. The total number of cases in the Jurong Fishery Port cluster is now 997.

site_title: June bank lending sees fastest monthly growth since 2018
summary: Singapore bank lending in June saw the fastest monthly growth since 2018, up 1.5% to S$703.92 billion, driven by stronger business loans. Business loans grew 1.9% in June, marking the first positive growth since July 2020. This growth is attributed to a 1.5% increase in business loans, surpassing the 0.2% increase in May and April.

site_title: Protests, accusations against Myanmar junta ahead of coup anniversary
summary: Small groups of students in Mandalay, Myanmar, protested against the military junta on Saturday, waving red and green flags and rejecting any possibility of talks to negotiate a return to civilian rule. A human rights group accused the armed forces of crimes against humanity ahead of the six-month anniversary of the army's takeover. The protesters, primarily university students, rode motorbikes and displayed signs, including "There's no negotiating in a blood feud."

site_title: Walmart, Disney impose vaccination mandates on some staffers
summary: Walmart and Disney have implemented vaccination mandates for some of their staff members. Walmart requires its US headquarters and regional staff to be vaccinated by October 4, while Disney has also set a similar policy. The moves are part of efforts to combat the spread of the delta variant, and both companies are offering incentives for employees to get vaccinated. The mandates apply to approximately 1.5 million Walmart employees, although the exact number of affected staff is not specified.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. US stocks opened lower due to Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained an employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and PBOC agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Philippines to place Manila area in lockdown to curb Delta variant
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte approved a lockdown in the Manila capital region to curb the spread of the Delta coronavirus variant. The lockdown, effective from August 6 to 20, will affect over 13 million people in 16 cities. The move aims to shield the country's medical system from the strain caused by the variant. The lockdown is seen as a painful but necessary measure to protect public health, according to presidential spokesperson Harry Roque.

images.alt_text: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte on Friday approved the imposition of lockdown measures in the capital region, in a bid to contain the spread of the Delta coronavirus variant and to shield the country's medical system.

site_title: US: Wall Street falls with Amazon; S&P 500 posts sixth straight month of gains
summary: US stocks fell on Friday, with the Dow Jones and Nasdaq Composite declining 0.4% and 0.7% respectively, while the S&P 500 lost 0.5% to close at 4,395.26. Amazon's shares dropped 7.6% after the company forecast lower sales growth, while other tech giants like Alphabet and Facebook also fell. Despite this, the S&P 500 still recorded a sixth consecutive month of gains, with a 2.3% increase for the month.

site_title: Singapore visitor arrivals, hotel takings fall further in June
summary: Singapore's visitor arrivals fell to 10,030 in June, down from 14,190 in May, and hotel takings declined as hotels converted rooms to stay-home-notice purposes. This marks a significant drop from 2,170 visitors in June last year during stricter Covid-19 curbs. Industry analysts expect hotels to focus on welcoming back staycation guests and foreign visitors later this year as the pandemic situation improves and border reopenings become possible.

images.alt_text: There were 10,030 arrivals in June, down from 14,190 in May, though this was still more than four times the mere 2,170 visitors a year ago, during stricter Covid-19 curbs.

site_title: Optimism for next six months cools for Singapore's manufacturing sector
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector has seen optimism cool for the next six months, with a net weighted balance of 20% of firms expecting a favorable business situation. The services sector has also plateaued, with 20% of firms optimistic about the next six months. The electronics cluster remains the most optimistic, while the chemicals cluster is the most pessimistic. Overall, the economy is expected to continue expanding at high single-digit rates in the third quarter, with most industries expecting business conditions to improve.

site_title: Europe: Shares slide from peak as Asian worries sour mood
summary: European stocks fell 0.8% on Friday, marking a decline from record highs, due to concerns over the Delta variant and regulatory actions in China. Despite this, quarterly earnings season and economic recovery optimism supported the benchmark, which was on track to end July with its sixth consecutive month of gains. Asian shares were set for their biggest monthly drop since the pandemic, with China-exposed miners being the top decliners. Some companies, such as UniCredit and Renault, posted higher-than-expected results, providing a glimmer of hope for the market.

site_title: SEC blocks Chinese IPO filings until risks are better disclosed
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has blocked initial public offerings (IPOs) of Chinese companies until they provide more disclosures about investment risks. SEC Chair Gary Gensler cited the Chinese government's crackdown on foreign listings and enhanced cybersecurity reviews as reasons for the halt. He emphasized the importance of providing crucial disclosures for informed investment decision-making. The SEC staff will seek additional disclosures from Chinese firms before approving their registration statements to sell shares.

images.alt_text: The US Securities and Exchange Commission has halted initial public offerings of Chinese companies until they provide more disclosures about investment risks.

site_title: Mizuho net profit doubles in Q1
summary: Mizuho Financial Group reported a net profit of 250.5 billion yen in the first quarter of its financial year, doubling from 122.4 billion yen in the same period last year. The bank attributed the increase to declining credit-related costs. For the current financial year, Mizuho reiterated its forecast of a 510 billion yen profit, slightly lower than the average of nine analyst estimates compiled by Refinitiv.

images.alt_text: Mizuho Financial Group on Friday said its net profit doubled in the first quarter of its financial year as credit-related costs declined.

site_title: Fed's taper timing depends on progress on jobs, Brainard says
summary: Federal Reserve Governor Lael Brainard said the Fed will not taper its $120 billion monthly asset purchases until the US labor market shows more improvement, particularly in employment. Brainard expects to be more confident in assessing progress once September data is released, which could be around the end of 2021. The Fed is also watching inflation, which has risen above the 2% target, but Brainard believes it is likely to be transitory. The Fed's decision to taper will depend on a three-part test: full employment, 2% inflation, and a sustained inflation rate above 2%.

site_title: Next stage of developing Tuas integrated water and solid waste treatment facility begins
summary: The next stage of Singapore's Tuas integrated water and solid waste treatment facility has begun, with the development of a 400-tonnes-a-day food waste treatment facility and an 800-tonnes-a-day sludge incineration facility. This expansion aims to maximize energy and resource recovery and optimize land use, supporting Singapore's efforts to become a more sustainable and environmentally friendly nation.

site_title: France's BNP posts profit rise as retail rebounds, provisions fall
summary: France's BNP Paribas reported a 26.6% rise in second-quarter net income to 2.91 billion euros, driven by a rebound in French retail banking activity and a fall in loan loss provisions to pre-pandemic levels. Revenue rose 0.9% as retail banking offset a drop in corporate and investment banking revenue. Deposits increased 7.5% and mobile app connections rose 25.1%. Analysts praised the bank's cost control and new provisions guidance. BNP Paribas will pay an additional dividend of 1.55 euros per share this year.

site_title: US cities try to head off eviction wave as federal ban expires
summary: US cities are implementing diversion programs to prevent eviction waves as a federal ban on evictions expires. Cities like Philadelphia require landlords to apply for rental assistance, seek mediation, and wait 45 days before filing for eviction. The programs aim to buy time for tenants to access federal coronavirus relief money. Experts warn of a mass displacement crisis and generational poverty consequences if the ban expires.

site_title: Apple supplier TSMC reports gas contamination at key chip plant
summary: Apple supplier Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSMC) reported a gas contamination incident at its key chip plant in southern Taiwan, specifically at Fab 18, where the latest processors for upcoming iPhones and Mac computers were produced. The company stated that the incident is not expected to significantly impact operations and is conducting stringent follow-up operations to ensure production quality. Apple did not immediately respond to the news.

site_title: Haidilao is Hang Seng's worst-performing stock
summary: Haidilao International Holding, a popular Chinese hotpot chain, has become Hang Seng's worst-performing stock, plummeting 32% over five days after issuing a first-half profit warning. The company cited higher expenses from new restaurant openings and a negative impact from the pandemic. Haidilao's stock has fallen 66% from its February peak, reflecting the challenges faced by the global restaurant industry due to changing consumer habits amid the pandemic.

site_title: Singapore shares fall 0.4% on Friday but rise slightly for the week
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.4% on Friday, closing at 3,166.94, but still rose 0.3% for the week, marking the fifth consecutive week of gains. Keppel Corp and Jardine Cycle & Carriage rose 1.9% and 1% respectively after reporting earnings and declaring dividends. Dairy Farm International declined 5.5% due to a 69% decline in underlying net profit. Markets in the region, including Japan, South Korea, China, and Hong Kong, also closed lower due to concerns over Covid-19 and regulatory crackdowns.

site_title: California orders state of emergency to avert blackouts
summary: California Governor Gavin Newsom declared a state of emergency to address projected power-supply shortfalls due to wildfires and heat waves. The state faces a possible 3.5-gigawatt shortfall during late afternoons under extreme conditions. The emergency declaration aims to free up energy supplies and speed development of new power plants, as California transitions away from fossil fuels and climate change intensifies heat waves. The state's historic drought has depleted reservoirs needed for hydropower, exacerbating the energy crisis.

images.alt_text: "When you get a gold medal, it's worth it," says Zhang, who secured victory in the synchronised 10 metre platform in Jakarta.

site_title: Aztech Global H1 profits more than double to S$29.4 million as tech market heats up
summary: Aztech Global's first-half profits more than doubled to S$29.4 million, driven by a surge in sales volume in the smart devices market. Revenue rose 93.4% to S$249.7 million, primarily from its distribution and trading business. The company attributes the growth to increased demand for IoT devices and data communication products.

site_title: Debt-laden China Evergrande hit by lawsuit over late construction payment
summary: China's Evergrande Group is being sued by Huaibei Mining's construction unit over a 400 million yuan (S$84 million) overdue payment. The dispute stems from Evergrande's project company in Anhui province repeatedly citing a lack of money despite six requests for repayment. Evergrande has objected to the court case, stating it has no legal basis due to its flagship unit not being a party to the contract. The lawsuit has intensified concerns over Evergrande's debt and potential systemic financial risk, with Fitch downgrading its credit rating earlier this week.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall more than 1%, post worst month since March 2020
summary: South Korea's stocks plummeted more than 1% on Friday, posting its worst monthly decline in over a year, due to concerns over the Chinese government's regulatory crackdown and the Covid-19 pandemic. The Kospi index fell 1.24% to 3,202.32, ending its eight-month winning streak. Asian peers also slumped, with the Hang Seng index declining near 2%. The country reported 1,710 new Covid-19 cases, despite tougher distancing measures.

site_title: Property agents tap buyers' FOMO, claim price hikes at slew of condo, EC projects
summary: Real estate agents in Singapore are capitalizing on the popularity of Pasir Ris 8 by advertising increased prices at various private residential projects. Agents claim prices may rise by 1-5% as developers prepare to increase them. This comes as the Q3 condo launch wave approaches, which may test demand for prime projects above the S$3,000 per square foot benchmark.

images.alt_text: BT understands that Normanton Park (pictured) raised prices by 2 per cent plus another S$5,000 for the two-bedroom units in July 2021.

site_title: SMFG Q1 net profit more than doubles
summary: Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group Inc (SMFG) reported a net profit of 203.2 billion yen (S$2.5 billion) in the first quarter, more than doubling from 86.1 billion yen in the same period last year, due to a sharp decline in credit-related costs. The company reiterated its full-year forecast of 600 billion yen.

site_title: Australia sets 70% vaccination target to start reopening
summary: Australia's government has set a 70% vaccination target to start reopening the country and avoid snap lockdowns. Once this target is reached, restrictions on vaccinated residents will be eased, with lockdowns implemented only in extreme circumstances. A full reopening to all travel is expected once an 80% vaccination rate is achieved, but a specific timeline is uncertain. The country's slow vaccine roll-out has hindered plans to reopen, with only 23% of the population vaccinated.

site_title: Fullerton Health shareholder spat clouds US$1 billion sale
summary: A dispute among three co-founders of Singapore-based Fullerton Health Corp has raised concerns over the company's US$1 billion sale process. Majority shareholder David Sin accuses minority shareholders Michael Tan and Daniel Chan of influencing the bidding process and breaching their fiduciary duties. The trio, who are also doctors, had a falling out after Tan and Chan stepped down as CEO and deputy CEO in 2019. The dispute may imperil the sale process, which has received non-binding offers from several firms, including Platinum Equity.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down on virus concerns
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower, with the Nikkei 225 index dropping 1.80% and the Topix index losing 1.37%, amid concerns over the expansion of a virus state of emergency in Japan and rising new cases of the virus. The Japanese government is set to extend the measures to the end of August. Traders also weighed corporate earnings reports, with some shares falling despite favorable earnings.

site_title: Yangzijiang gets orders for 12 vessels worth US$1.08b, sounds rosy note on LNG research
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding announced orders for 12 vessels worth US$1.08 billion, including 10 dual-fuel containerships and 2 medium-range tankers, with deliveries expected between 2023 and 2024. The orders, placed by Seaspan Corp, are the largest in the group's history, with a total contract value of US$1.58 billion. The company's order book now stands at US$8.74 billion for 170 vessels, and executives expressed confidence in securing more orders amid favorable market sentiments.

site_title: China's factory activity expands at a slower pace in July
summary: China's factory activity expanded at a slower pace in July, with the manufacturing Purchasing Manager's Index easing to 50.4 from 50.9 in June. Higher raw material costs, equipment maintenance, and extreme weather contributed to the slowdown. Despite remaining above the 50-point mark, analysts had expected the index to slip to 50.8. China's economy has largely recovered from the pandemic, but manufacturers face new challenges from global supply chain bottlenecks and a fresh Covid-19 outbreak in the eastern city of Nanjing. The government's zero-tolerance approach to Covid-19 could pose significant risks to the economic recovery.

site_title: Olympics-Triathlon-Britain win first-ever mixed relay gold
summary: Britain won the first-ever Olympic gold in the triathlon mixed relay with a time of 1:23:41 at Tokyo's Odaiba Marine Park. Jessica Learmonth led the team, followed by Jonny Brownlee, Georgia Taylor-Brown, and Alex Yee. The United States took silver and France finished third. Competitors collapsed on the course due to exhaustion, but the British team held on to secure the historic gold medal, adding to their triathlon haul at the Tokyo Olympics.

site_title: Singapore's total employment down in Q2 on Covid-19 curbs, but unemployment rates improve
summary: Singapore's total employment fell by 15,700 in Q2 due to Phase 2 (Heightened Alert) measures, mainly affecting domestically-oriented sectors. However, unemployment rates improved, with overall unemployment at 2.7%, resident unemployment at 3.7%, and citizen unemployment at 3.8%. Non-resident employment declined sharply due to border restrictions. Despite this, employment growth in outward-oriented sectors continued, and hiring intent remained dampened due to Covid-19 concerns.

site_title: Dover Forest to be used for both housing and nature; first housing project to be launched in 2022
summary: Singapore's Dover Forest will be developed for public housing in the eastern 11ha, with the first flats expected to be launched in the second half of 2022. The western half, rich in biodiversity, will be preserved for now and reevaluated in about a decade. A 5ha park with a natural stream will be built, and parts of the western half will be safeguarded as a nature park. The decision was made after scientific studies and public feedback, with the goal of balancing housing needs with conservation of the site's biodiversity.

site_title: Mini One 5-Door review: This is the One to get
summary: The Mini 5-Door One is the best value among Mini's small models, offering a more practical and delightful driving experience compared to the 3-Door One. With its new facelift, the car features a larger black frame and an 8.8-inch infotainment screen. The 1.5L turbocharged engine provides 102 horsepower, and the car can reach 0-100km/h in 10.6 seconds. While it may not be ideal for family duties, the Mini 5-Door One is a great option for those seeking a fun and sporty driving experience at an affordable price.

site_title: Good cholesterol, bad cholesterol: hype and hope
summary: Recent data suggests that the relationship between "good" and "bad" cholesterol is more complex than previously thought. Studies have shown that high LDL-C and low HDL-C levels increase heart disease risk, while low LDL-C and high HDL-C levels decrease risk. However, new findings indicate that the cholesterol story is not as simple, with potential interactions and nuances between different cholesterol levels and heart disease risk.

site_title: Australia: Tech, energy losses drive shares lower
summary: Australian shares closed 0.3% lower on Friday, driven by declines in tech and energy stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 7,392.6 points, despite a 10th consecutive monthly gain. Origin Energy fell 7% after warning of a steep earnings decline, while tech stocks dropped 2.5%, led by Afterpay's 5% drop. Energy stocks also fell, with oil prices slipping, and healthcare stocks were lower, with CSL down 0.9%. The decline was seen as a brief pause in the market's recent winning streak.

site_title: Nomura Q1 net profit dives 66%
summary: Nomura Holdings, Japan's largest brokerage and investment bank, reported a 66% drop in first-quarter net profit to 48.5 billion yen due to a slowdown in trading business and a previously flagged loss from the Archegos debacle. This marks a significant decline from the same period last year, when US trading revenue drove the bank to its best quarterly earnings in nearly two decades. The result fell short of analyst estimates, with an average of 42.98 billion yen.

site_title: Covid-19 Delta variant is as contagious as chickenpox: CDC internal report
summary: The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has described the Delta variant of the coronavirus as "as contagious as chickenpox" and potentially severe, citing an internal CDC document. The variant is more transmissible than viruses causing Mers, Sars, Ebola, and smallpox, but vaccines remain effective in preventing serious illness and hospitalization. CDC director Rochelle Walensky stated that vaccinated people infected with the Delta variant carry high amounts of the virus. The agency is expected to publish additional data on the variant on Friday.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust's Dallas hotel to be sold to at lower price to buyer that made earlier, aborted offer
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) is selling its Crowne Plaza Dallas Near Galleria-Addison hotel for $15.5 million to original buyer Lockwood Development Partners, a lower price than an earlier $18.5 million deal that fell through. The sale, which is expected to close on August 27, will help repay debts and fund capital needs for EHT, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in the US. The deal was deemed the most attractive by the independent director of the seller-owner's parent, citing a "critical" need for execution amid debt issues.

site_title: From outdoing himself to bonding with others
summary: Tan Chin Hwee, APAC CEO of a Fortune 25 company, has shifted his focus from intense individual competitiveness in sports to family and social bonding activities. He now prioritizes flexibility and enjoyment over personal bests, allowing his body to dictate his exercise routine. This approach has made him and his loved ones happier, and he's even completed a Certified Personal Trainer course with his son during the pandemic, creating a new history in the process.

site_title: Japan's household spending likely rebounded in June, new curbs cloud outlook: poll
summary: Japan's household spending likely rebounded in June, with a 2.0% increase from May, according to a Reuters poll. The recovery was driven by a temporary drop in coronavirus infections, but fresh state of emergency curbs declared in July are expected to drag on consumption, particularly during the Olympic Games and summer holiday season. Analysts warn that the measures may discourage people from going out, leading to a cautious outlook for consumption. The data will be released on August 6.

site_title: Scientists create embyros to save northern white rhino
summary: Scientists have successfully created three additional embryos of the northern white rhino, bringing the total to 12, as part of a project to bring back the functionally extinct subspecies. The embryos were created using eggs from 90,000-acre Ol Pejeta wildlife conservancy's female Fatu and sperm from two deceased males. The project, led by Biorescue, aims to preserve the subspecies and has already seen the creation of nine embryos in previous rounds. The embryos will be preserved and potentially used for future cloning efforts, offering a glimmer of hope for the survival of the northern white rhino.

site_title: Hong Kong man sentenced to 9 years in prison in first national security case
summary: A Hong Kong man, Tong Ying-kit, 24, was sentenced to 9 years in prison for terrorist activities and inciting secession under the city's national security law. He was convicted for driving his motorcycle into riot police while carrying a flag with the slogan "Liberate Hong Kong. Revolution of our times." Human rights groups have criticized the conviction, saying it imposes new limits on free speech and sets precedents that contrast with Hong Kong's common law traditions.

site_title: Philippines says US military deal 'in full force again'
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has reversed his decision to end a key military deal with the US, known as the Visiting Forces Agreement (VFA). The deal has been prolonged three times since the initial decision in February last year, following the US cancellation of a visa for a Philippine ally who led the country's war on drugs. Pentagon chief Lloyd Austin's visit to the Philippines helped to negotiate the agreement's extension. The VFA allows US military personnel to train and conduct operations in the Philippines.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 18.33 points to 1,494.60. The market saw 665 losers outweigh 300 gainers in terms of volume.

site_title: Sheng Siong to buy New World Centre strata unit from TA Corp for S$17.25 million
summary: Sheng Siong Group, a Mainboard-listed supermarket operator, is acquiring a strata-titled shop unit at New World Centre for S$17.25 million, a below-market value. The 1,790 sqm unit, with 72 years left on its 99-year leasehold tenure, is currently leased to Sheng Siong from Sino Holdings, a unit of builder TA Corp. The tenancy agreement will end upon the transaction's completion.

site_title: Biden hosts Cuban-American leaders to discuss Cuba protests
summary: US President Joe Biden hosted a meeting with Cuban-American leaders to discuss the recent protests in Cuba, which have led to 500-600 arrests, according to human rights groups. The administration is considering additional sanctions against those involved in the regime's abuses and is exploring ways to enable remittances from Cubans in the US to relatives on the island. Biden also discussed providing internet access to Cubans to monitor the government's treatment of protesters. The meeting comes amid a challenge to Biden's handling of the issue, with Republicans claiming Democrats are soft on the communist regime.

site_title: Optimism for next six months cools for Singapore's manufacturing sector
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector has cooled in optimism for the next six months, with a net weighted balance of 20% of firms expecting a favorable business situation, down from 38% in the previous quarter. The services sector, however, remains optimistic, with a net weighted balance of 11% of firms expecting better business conditions. The electronics cluster remains the most optimistic, driven by demand from the 5G market, while the chemicals cluster is the most pessimistic due to concerns over product prices and margins.

site_title: Concerns over clean energy stock bubbles are misplaced
summary: Concerns over "clean energy stock bubbles" are misplaced, according to the article. While MSCI has warned of concentration risks in clean energy ETFs, the author argues that responsible investing is a structural evolution in the industry, driven by the need to create sustainable wealth for investors. By focusing on ESG factors and stewardship, investors can create value and sidestep bubbles, rather than simply mirroring an index. The author sees responsible investing as a critical component of long-term wealth creation for investors and the health of the planet.

site_title: iFast launches US, Hong Kong stockbroking services in Malaysia
summary: iFast Capital has launched stockbroking services for US and Hong Kong-listed securities in Malaysia via its FSMOne platform. The services, available at a 0.08% commission fee, aim to provide a comprehensive wealth management platform in Malaysia. This move is part of iFast's objective to expand its services globally, similar to its existing markets in Singapore and Hong Kong.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore property agents are urging buyers to purchase units before price hikes of 1-5% at various condo and EC projects. The manufacturing and services sectors remain optimistic for the next six months, despite pandemic pressures. Singapore visitor arrivals and hotel takings fell further in June. Singapore bank lending saw the fastest growth since 2018, with a 1.5% increase in June. The Straits Times Index fell 0.4% on Friday, but rose slightly for the week.

site_title: Costa Rica's central bank lifts growth forecast amid manufacturing rebound
summary: Costa Rica's central bank raised its growth forecast to 3.9% from 2.9% due to a rebound in manufacturing activity and a slight rise in the tourism sector. The forecast also includes a 6.2% GDP deficit this year, down from 8.7% in 2020. Approximately 46% of the eligible population has been vaccinated, with 16% having received two doses. The improved economic activity is attributed to progress in vaccinations.

site_title: US personal spending strengthened in June along with prices
summary: US personal spending increased 1% in June, exceeding expectations, driven by a rebound in services spending and rising wages. The personal consumption expenditures price gauge rose 0.5% for the second month, as inflation remains elevated. Despite the strong spending, the labor market remains short of a full recovery, and the Federal Reserve may keep monetary support for the economy. The shift to services spending, fueled by consumer confidence, has outpaced supply, leading to higher prices and reduced buying power.

site_title: Winners and losers from the surge in commodity prices
summary: Commodity prices have surged over 20% this year, with crude oil rising 50%, benefiting big energy exporters like Russia and Saudi Arabia. In contrast, Asian countries like Vietnam and Bangladesh are struggling due to higher fuel and food costs. The US, China, and India are also feeling the strain, with Russia expected to benefit the most, with a net export rise of nearly $120 billion. The shift in commodity trade is expected to favor exporters, with an estimated $550 billion shifting from importers to exporters in 2021.

site_title: Jurong Fishery Port reopens for tenants but few workers return
summary: The Jurong Fishery Port in Singapore reopened on Saturday for tenants after a two-week closure due to a Covid-19 outbreak. Only nine workers, mostly tenants' employees, were seen at the port's entrance, with most arriving in their own vehicles. The workers were required to wear protective clothing and undergo a seven-day rostered testing regime. The port will resume unloading and wholesale activities on Monday, with no further arrangements made for tenants to return on Saturday.

images.alt_text: The Jurong Fishery Port had been closed since July 17, after multiple Covid-19 infections were detected there.

site_title: US oil giants to keep a lid on spending even as profits surge
summary: US oil giants ExxonMobil and Chevron reported strong profits in the second quarter, with ExxonMobil earning $4.7 billion and Chevron earning $3.1 billion, despite heavy pandemic restrictions last year. Both companies pledged to keep a lid on spending, with ExxonMobil maintaining its 2021 capital spending budget at the low end of projections and Chevron resuming share repurchases in the third quarter. Investors, including those focused on environmental, social, and governance issues, are pressuring the companies to prioritize renewable energy over fossil fuels.

site_title: Singapore bank lending logs fastest growth since 2018; up 1.5% in June: MAS data
summary: Singapore's bank lending grew 1.5% in June, the fastest growth since 2018, driven by stronger demand for business loans. Total business loans increased 2.6% year-over-year, with consumer loans rising 5% and housing loans growing 0.6%. Loans to financial institutions and general commerce also saw significant growth. This marks the eighth consecutive month of loan growth, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore attributing the increase to stronger demand for business loans.

site_title: Gold rallies on FOMC indecision on tapering timelines
summary: Gold prices rose to a two-week high after US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's comments indicated the central bank is unlikely to hike interest rates soon. The metal's price gained as investors sought safe-haven assets amid ongoing COVID-19 concerns and potential dollar asset diversification in Asia. The Comex Gold for December delivery closed at $1,498.50 an ounce, its highest level since July 15. This move was driven by investors buying the dips below $1,800, as other central banks are expected to hold off on increasing interest rates.

site_title: Brokers' take: RHB slashes target prices for plantation stocks amid ESG concerns
summary: RHB Investment has downgraded its sector rating for plantation stocks to "underweight" due to environmental, social, and governance (ESG) concerns, citing concerns over permanent devaluation of plantation stocks' price-to-earnings (P/E) ratios. The research house lowered its valuation targets for all plantation stocks, with Golden Agri-Resources seeing its target price slashed by 26.7% to S$0.22. Despite maintaining "buy" calls on Wilmar International and First Resources, RHB cut target prices by 10.9% and 6.3%, respectively.

images.alt_text: RHB has lowered its valuation targets for all the plantation stocks under its coverage.

site_title: Philippines' PLDT said to weigh US$800m telecom towers sale: sources
summary: PLDT, the Philippines' largest telecommunications provider, is considering selling its local telecom towers in a deal worth approximately US$800 million. The company is working with an adviser on the planned disposal, which could involve selling the towers and leasing them back. Deliberations are ongoing, and PLDT can decide to keep the business. This move comes amid a surge in digital infrastructure sales globally, following recent transactions involving data centers and telecom towers.

site_title: Hong Kong police investigate Olympic chants, China anthem booing
summary: Hong Kong police launched an investigation into fans who booed China's national anthem and chanted "We are Hong Kong" during a public Olympic screening. The incident occurred amid China's crackdown on dissent in Hong Kong, where the city's unique identity and Cantonese culture are often celebrated. Hong Kong authorities passed a law banning insults to the national anthem and flag, and police are now examining whether the Olympic fans broke the law. The incident highlights the city's ongoing struggle for autonomy and free speech under China's authoritarian rule.

site_title: Malaysia's Axiata seeks 66% stake in Indonesia's Link Net
summary: Malaysia's Axiata Group is exploring a potential acquisition of 66.03% of Indonesia's PT Link Net Tbk shares, worth 1.82 billion shares, through its Indonesian subsidiary. The deal aims to facilitate discussions and negotiations. Link Net is a cable television and high-speed broadband internet service provider based in Jakarta. The non-binding term sheet was entered into with Asia Link Dewa Pte Ltd and PT First Media Tbk, but no further details were provided.

site_title: Record-setting 'super shoes' are here to stay
summary: "Super shoes," featuring advanced technology, are revolutionizing track and road running, helping athletes achieve record-breaking performances. Since the 2016 Rio Olympics, numerous world records, national records, and personal bests have been set, showcasing the effectiveness of these innovative shoes. The technology has significantly improved biomechanics, allowing athletes to perform at new levels, solidifying the shoes' place in the running world.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Meanwhile, Creative Technology warned of potential revenue below target and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and People's Bank of China (PBOC) plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks rallied for a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Sydney Covid-19 cases ease amid tightening of lockdown rules
summary: Sydney, Australia reported 170 new locally acquired Covid-19 cases, a slight easing from a record high of 239, amid tightened lockdown rules. The Delta variant continues to spread, with 42 cases in the community while infectious and 53 under investigation. The city of 5 million is in its sixth week of an extended lockdown, set to run until August 28, with tougher new rules affecting eight local council areas. The military will assist police in enforcing compliance from Monday, amid concerns about healthcare strain and rising hospitalizations.

site_title: Jeff Bezos loses US$13.5b after Amazon disappointment
summary: Amazon's founder Jeff Bezos lost US$13.5 billion after the company's weaker-than-expected second-quarter results missed Wall Street's expectations. The drop erased 80% of his year-to-date wealth gains. Despite the loss, Bezos remains the world's richest person, with a net worth of US$193.6 billion, ahead of Tesla's Elon Musk by US$8 billion. The disappointing results also affected other tech billionaires, including Mark Zuckerberg, who lost US$5.4 billion due to Facebook's falling shares.

site_title: Cheung Woh Technologies to delist on Aug 3
summary: Cheung Woh Technologies will delist from the Singapore Exchange on August 3 after Woh Seng Holdings, a company owned by the company's finance and administrative director, exercised its right to compulsory acquisition. The offer was made in June at a cash consideration of 28.5 Singapore cents per share, with 97.1% of shares accepted. The delistment will occur upon completion of the acquisition.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip but log sixth straight month of gains
summary: European stocks fell 0.5% on Friday, marking the sixth consecutive month of gains, despite concerns about the Delta variant and regulatory actions in China. Travel and leisure stocks, along with miners, were the top decliners. However, many companies beat analyst profit estimates, with 67% of Stoxx 600 companies surpassing expectations. The euro zone economy grew stronger than expected in the second quarter, and some companies raised their full-year guidance, including EssilorLuxottica and UniCredit.

site_title: Malaysia extends emergency rule in Sarawak state to stop polls
summary: Malaysia has extended a state of emergency in Sarawak state until February 2, 2022, to suspend regional elections amid the Covid-19 pandemic. This move comes as the national emergency rule is set to expire on Sunday. The decision aims to prevent the spread of the virus and allow for more effective management of the pandemic. The regional elections had been scheduled to take place in August, but have now been postponed.

site_title: US Vice-President Kamala Harris to visit Singapore and Vietnam
summary: US Vice-President Kamala Harris will visit Singapore and Vietnam next month to strengthen relationships and expand economic cooperation. During the trip, she will discuss regional security, climate change, and a rules-based international order with leaders. This will be her first trip outside the Americas since taking office and the first visit by a US Vice-President to Vietnam. The visit aims to deepen engagement in South-east Asia and reaffirm cultural ties between the US and these countries.

site_title: Singapore stocks dip slightly at Friday's open; STI down 0.04%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dipped 0.04% to 3,179.18 at 9:01am on Friday, following a rally by banks on Thursday. RH PetroGas led the gainers, while Singtel and Keppel Corp also saw increases. In the US, Wall Street stocks advanced, driven by solid growth data and earnings, while European stocks hit all-time highs on Thursday. Asian markets, including Tokyo, opened lower due to cautious trade and rising coronavirus cases in Japan.

site_title: About 50 KTVs and other nightspots not allowed to reopen; others must first clear inspections
summary: Around 50 KTVs and other nightlife establishments in Singapore that flouted Covid-19 rules since October last year will not be allowed to reopen. Others that pivoted to food and beverage operations must pass inspections and receive a conditional permit before reopening. The establishments were ordered to close for two weeks from July 16 to July 31 to break community transmission of the virus from clusters at KTV lounges and nightclubs.

site_title: Five-room HDB DBSS flat in Bishan sold for record S$1.295m
summary: A five-room HDB flat in Bishan's Natura Loft DBSS project has sold for a record S$1.295 million, surpassing the previous high of S$1.268 million. The 120 sq m unit, which has 89 years left on its lease, was sold just three weeks after being put up for sale. This transaction marks the most expensive HDB resale unit sold so far, with 124 flats selling for at least S$1 million this year, a record high.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares fall at start of Friday's trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell at the start of Friday's trade, with the Hang Seng Index slipping 1.04% due to investor concerns over China's regulatory crackdown. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also eased, with declines of 0.40% and 0.14%, respectively. The market downturn follows a previous day's rally of over 3%.

site_title: Big tech has outgrown this planet
summary: Big tech companies, including Apple, Microsoft, Google, Amazon, and Facebook, have surpassed the combined value of the next 27 most valuable US companies, with a total market value of $9.3 trillion. These companies have seen significant growth in profits, with Amazon's e-commerce revenue increasing by $109 billion in the past year, and Google's ad revenue reaching $50 billion in just three months. Despite economic challenges, these companies have maintained or increased profit margins, leading to concerns about their invincibility and dominance in the tech industry.

images.alt_text: Perhaps even more surprising than the size and scale of these companies is how they have mostly grown more profitable in what could or should have been economic conditions that hurt their profits.

site_title: DBS, Temasek launch US$500m growth stage debt financing platform for Asia's tech firms
summary: DBS and Temasek have launched EvolutionX Debt Capital, a US$500 million growth stage debt financing platform for Asia's tech firms. The platform will provide non-dilutive financing to growth stage tech companies in China, India, and Southeast Asia, focusing on sectors such as financial services, consumer, healthcare, education, and industrial development. The joint venture aims to support high-growth technology companies and foster partnerships with these companies, with a full-time CEO to be appointed in the coming months.

site_title: As Covid cases hit record high in Tokyo, can the Olympic bubble hold?
summary: Tokyo's record-high Covid cases are putting the Olympic bubble to the test. Despite the city's state of emergency, new infections continue to emerge, with 3,865 cases reported on Thursday. The bubble, which isolates athletes, officials, and staff, has seen fewer than 200 positive cases, mostly among Japanese residents. Experts say the presence of the Games may be psychologically influencing the public, leading them to believe they can relax despite the emergency. The Delta variant, which has spread rapidly, has left hospitals struggling to secure beds, raising concerns about the Paralympics next month.

images.alt_text: The number of infections in Japan directly connected with the Olympic Games has so far been relatively low, but Tokyo and its surrounding areas are experiencing their worst-yet wave of infections from the corona virus.

site_title: UN warned of 'dire' Covid situation in Myanmar
summary: The UN has warned of a "dire" Covid-19 situation in Myanmar, where half of the population of 54 million could become infected in the next two weeks. The UK convened a meeting at the UN Security Council to address the crisis, citing the military's seizure of power in February and its impact on the healthcare system. The junta has been accused of detaining medical officials and carrying out attacks on medical personnel and facilities, with the UN estimating that only 40% of healthcare facilities are still operational.

site_title: Elon Musk's Neuralink raises over US$200m from Google Ventures, others
summary: Elon Musk's Neuralink, a brain-chip startup, has raised $205 million in funding from Google Ventures and other investors, including Dubai-based Vy Capital. The company aims to develop implantable wireless brain computer chips to treat neurological conditions and merge humans with artificial intelligence. Neuralink plans to use the funds to bring its first product, N1 Link, to market and for research and development. The company's CEO, Elon Musk, has stated that the device will enable people with paralysis to control smartphones with their minds.

site_title: Exxon posts highest profit in more than a year as demand recovers
summary: Exxon Mobil reported its highest quarterly profit in over a year, with a net income of $4.69 billion, or $1.10 per share, in the second quarter. The company's cost cuts, which began in 2020, allowed it to capitalize on rebounding demand for oil, gas, and chemicals. Exxon's capital spending is expected to be at the lower end of its previously forecast range, and the company aims to achieve total cost savings of $6 billion through 2023. The company's earnings beat analysts' expectations, with its chemicals business seeing a nearly five-fold increase in earnings.

images.alt_text: Exxon Mobil on Friday posted its first quarterly results following a contested board fight over its direction, registering its biggest profit in more than a year on rebounding demand for oil, gas and chemicals.

site_title: Malaysia regulator takes enforcement action against Binance
summary: Malaysia's Securities Commission has taken enforcement action against cryptocurrency platform Binance, ordering it to disable its website and mobile applications, cease media and marketing activities, and restrict Malaysian investors from accessing its Telegram group. The regulator also urged users to immediately cease trading and withdraw investments. Binance has announced plans to wind down its futures and derivatives products offerings across Europe due to growing pressure from regulators worldwide.

site_title: Peru's Castillo names moderate leftist as finance minister in olive branch to markets
summary: Peru's President Pedro Castillo appointed moderate economist Pedro Francke as finance minister, an attempt to soothe jittery investors after naming hardliner Guido Bellido as prime minister earlier in the week. The move came after bond markets and the sol currency plummeted, and Francke's appointment appears aimed at calming investor concerns. Francke, a close confidant of Castillo, had previously been considered for the finance job, and his appointment is seen as a sign of a shift towards a more moderate cabinet.

site_title: Japan's factory output rises, job availability at near one-year high
summary: Japan's factory output rose 6.2% in June, rebounding from a 6.5% drop in May, and job availability reached a near-one-year high of 1.13 jobs per applicant. However, retail sales remained flat, suggesting a slower recovery compared to other advanced nations. The mixed data comes as the country hosts the Olympic Games amidst rising coronavirus infections, dashing hopes for strong growth in the July-September quarter. Japan's economy is expected to have shrunk 3.9% in the first quarter.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower with eyes on earnings, virus
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, July 30, 2021, amid cautious trade and concerns over corporate earnings and rising coronavirus cases in Japan. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.58% and the Topix index lost 0.31%. Investors are closely watching corporate earnings and the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Japan to expand virus emergency one week into Olympics
summary: Japan's government will extend a virus state of emergency in Tokyo and impose the measure in four more regions for a week into the Olympics, amid a surge in new cases nationwide. The emergency, initially set to end on August 22, will be extended until the end of the month, with restrictions including shortened restaurant hours and bans on alcohol sales. Despite the measures, experts warn that the Olympics are having an "indirect impact" on Japan's virus situation.

site_title: Hot stock: Keppel, Sembmarine rise amid heavy trading after H1 results release
summary: Keppel and Sembmarine shares rose amid heavy trading after releasing their financial results for the half-year period ended June 30. Keppel returned to profitability with a net profit of S$299.8 million, reversing a loss of S$537.1 million in the previous year, and raised its interim dividend to S$0.12 a share. Sembmarine, however, posted a loss of S$647.2 million, but expects losses to narrow in the second half of the year. Analysts predict Keppel's dividend per share to be S$0.25 for the full year, while maintaining a "buy" rating on the company.

images.alt_text: Sembmarine shares rose to a high of 11.4 Singapore cents as at 10.41am, up 3.7 per cent or 0.6 cent after some 48.1 million shares changed hands.

site_title: Tesla agrees to pay US$1.5m to settle claims over battery voltage reduction
summary: Tesla has agreed to pay $1.5 million to settle claims that a software update temporarily reduced maximum battery voltage in 1,743 Model S sedans. Owners will receive $625 each, which is considered "many times the prorated value of the reduced voltage." The voltage limitation was temporary, lasting about three months, and was later corrected in software updates. The settlement includes $410,000 in fees for plaintiffs' attorneys.

site_title: Gold set for biggest weekly gain in over two months on dovish Fed
summary: Gold prices rose near a two-week high, poised for their biggest weekly gain in over two months, due to the US Federal Reserve's dovish stance on economic support and interest rates. Spot gold was steady at $1,827.70 per ounce, while the dollar index hit a one-month low. A weaker dollar makes gold cheaper for holders of other currencies. The US economy grew solidly in the second quarter, but fell short of analysts' expectations, supporting gold prices.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge lower as tech stocks weigh, Origin Energy top loser
summary: Australian shares fell slightly on Friday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index down 0.1% to 7,407.9, as tech stocks weighed on the market. Origin Energy dropped 8.1% after issuing a grim outlook for its core earnings, while rival AGL Energy declined 4%. Tech sector heavyweights Afterpay and Xero fell 2.9% and 0.5%, respectively. Meanwhile, energy stocks were down 0.5%, and heavyweight miners rose 1% on strong copper prices.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks cap week with a loss
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed the week with a 1.35% loss, shedding 354.29 points, due to investors' concerns over China's crackdown on tech and private tuition firms. Despite officials' reassurances, the Hang Seng Index fell to 25,961.03. In contrast, China's Shanghai Composite Index edged 0.42% lower, while the Shenzhen Composite Index on the second exchange rose 0.06%. The losses come as investors await further developments on US-China trade tensions and the potential impact on global markets.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Cheung Woh Technologies will delist from the Singapore Exchange on August 3 after completing its compulsory acquisition. Accordia Golf Trust is expected to delist on or soon after August 17, following its final distribution. Aspen (Group) Holdings is forecast to post a net loss for the half-year to June 30, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding secured orders for 12 vessels worth US$1.08 billion. Sheng Siong Group acquired a shop unit for S$17.25 million, while NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: Economists upbeat on Q3 labour outlook despite Q2 setback
summary: Singapore's total employment rose in Q1 after a year of decline, but fell in Q2 by 15,700 due to slower resident employment growth and continued declines in non-resident employment. Despite this, economists expect the labour situation to improve in Q3 if border controls are eased. Unemployment rates continued to improve, falling to 2.7% in Q2, and retrenchments were comparable to pre-Covid levels. Hiring intent has been dampened due to tightened measures, but some economists expect a turn in the labour market if restrictions are relaxed.

site_title: Swiss Club celebrates its 150th anniversary
summary: The Swiss Club in Singapore is celebrating its 150th anniversary, marking a milestone in the country's rich history. Founded in 1871 as the Swiss Rifle Shooting Club of Singapore, it has grown into a diverse and international club with members from over 40 nationalities. The club's president, Rolf Gerber, attributes the club's success to its strong presence in Singapore since the 19th century. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, the club has continued to operate with reduced capacity and has invested in renovations, including a $7.5 million upgrade of its historic clubhouse and facilities. The club's membership numbers have increased, and it remains a popular destination for families and individuals alike.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 9.44 points or 0.62% to 1,503.49. Losers outnumbered gainers 208 to 107, with a total volume of 191.97 million lots worth RM103.04 million.

site_title: US charges Nikola founder with fraud
summary: US officials have charged Nikola founder and former executive chairman Trevor Milton with "brazenly" defrauding investors through false claims about the company's electric vehicles. Milton allegedly made false statements about the status of Nikola technology to induce retail investors to purchase the company's stock, resulting in tens of thousands of dollars in losses for shareholders. Milton was taken into custody and released on a $100 million bond, while the Securities and Exchange Commission has also filed civil fraud charges against him.

site_title: Pelosi's bid to extend eviction moratorium collapses
summary: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's bid to extend the US eviction moratorium for renters collapsed, leaving millions at risk of losing their homes after the ban lifts on Saturday. The moratorium, which was set to expire on Saturday, was not extended until October 18, as proposed by Pelosi. Despite efforts by Democrats and the White House, the measure failed to gain enough votes in the House, with some lawmakers blaming the Supreme Court's recent opinion on the issue. Millions of Americans, including 3.6 million households at risk of eviction, are now facing uncertain futures as the deadline for the moratorium's expiration approaches.

images.alt_text: Mr Trump also threatened Canada with auto tariffs this week if the country failed to join his trade deal with Mexico to replace Nafta.

site_title: Volkswagen's top brands flag chip risk in months ahead
summary: Volkswagen's top brands, including Porsche and Audi, warn of an ongoing semiconductor chip shortage that may worsen in the coming months. The shortage, which began in 2020, has resulted in lost production of over 600,000 vehicles. Despite managing record profits in the first half of 2021, the brands expect a challenging third quarter due to supply constraints. Audi and Porsche express concerns about the situation, with Audi stating it may not be able to compensate for lost production throughout the year. The shortage affects Volkswagen and its rivals, including Daimler, BMW, GM, and Ford.

site_title: Far East Hospitality Trust DPS up 6.8% to S$0.011 in H1
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust (FEHT) reported a 6.8% increase in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.10 Singapore cents for the half year ended June 30, 2021. Gross revenue fell 6.1% to S$41.6 million, with NPI and total distributable income easing 6.2% and 1.4% respectively. Despite the decline, the trust attributed the modest decline in distributable income to reduced finance expenses and Reit manager fees. The trust remains optimistic about the recovery of the hospitality industry, driven by government and corporate contracts.

site_title: China Aviation Oil posts 3% rise in H1 net profit
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) posted a 3% rise in H1 net profit to US$24.3 million, driven by an increase in earnings from associate companies. Revenue rose 61.6% to US$8.68 billion, primarily due to higher oil prices and trading volume. The company's chief executive noted the ongoing impact of the Covid-19 resurgence on the global aviation industry, but remains cautiously optimistic about its performance. No interim dividends were declared, and vice-president Zhang Xingbo resigned following his secondment term.

site_title: Thinking about your future self? Start planning now
summary: A recent retirement survey in Singapore highlights the challenges of saving for the future, particularly among younger generations. The survey found that 68% of Singaporeans aged 51-60 rely on CPF for their retirement sum, while 46-59-year-olds feel it may be too late to start retirement planning. To encourage retirement savings, experts suggest making public commitments and emphasizing the "losses" of not saving. The average retirement savings goal is estimated to be around S$1.4 million, but only 38% of respondents are confident they can reach this amount. Experts advise adopting a goal-based approach to saving, enjoying the journey, and learning to live within one's means.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Singapore Airlines, FEHT, CDLHT, Jardine Matheson
summary: Keppel Corp reported a net profit of S$299.8 million for the first half, reversing a loss of S$537.1 million in the previous year. Singapore Airlines narrowed its first-quarter net loss to S$409.2 million. Far East Hospitality Trust's distribution per stapled security rose 6.8% to 1.10 Singapore cents. CDL Hospitality Trusts' distribution fell 19.2% to 1.22 Singapore cents. Jardine Matheson Holdings reported a net loss of US$117 million, while Hongkong Land narrowed its net loss to US$863.2 million.

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trusts posts 19.2% lower DPS of S$0.0122 for H1 despite higher NPI
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts reported a 19.2% lower distribution per stapled security (DPS) of S$0.0122 for the first half of 2021, despite a 24.4% increase in net property income (NPI) to S$37 million. The decline in DPS was attributed to post-rent restructuring, a low base effect from earlier losses, and the absence of one-off contributions from a divestment in the first half of 2020. The trust's revenue per available room (RevPAR) declined 9.5% year-over-year to S$72.

site_title: WTO says disparities in vaccine rates can hit economic rebound
summary: The World Trade Organization warned that disparities in coronavirus vaccine rates could impact global economic recovery. According to WTO chief Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, unequal access to vaccines is a major factor in regional trade disparities, particularly for low-income countries. The WTO forecast expects 8% increase in merchandise trade in 2021 and 4% in 2022, while the International Monetary Fund also sounded a similar warning, citing vaccine access as a key factor in the split between two global recovery blocs.

site_title: Japan proposes adding four regions to Covid-19 emergency: minister
summary: Japan's government has proposed adding four regions to its Covid-19 emergency states, including three prefectures near Tokyo and Osaka, to combat a record spike in cases. The proposal, led by Economy Minister Yasutoshi Nishimura, aims to suppress the virus spread and ease pressure on the healthcare system. Existing emergency states in Tokyo and Okinawa will be extended to August 31, and Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga will announce the proposal later. Japan has struggled with low vaccination rates, with less than 30% of residents fully vaccinated.

site_title: Robinhood falls in Nasdaq debut
summary: Robinhood, a Silicon Valley online trading app, fell 5.6% in its Nasdaq debut, closing at $35.86 after initially trading at $38. The company raised $1.9 billion in its initial public offering, despite growing popularity during the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Scarlett Johansson sues Disney over 'Black Widow' streaming release
summary: Scarlett Johansson is suing Disney over the simultaneous release of "Black Widow" on Disney+ and in theaters, alleging a breach of contract that cost her millions of dollars. Johansson, who was entitled to a percentage of box office receipts, claims Disney's decision was made to boost the company's stock price and hide behind the Covid-19 pandemic. The lawsuit accuses Disney of devaluing Johansson's agreement and enriching itself. The decision has been criticized, with rival studio Warner Bros paying out $200 million to compensate for similar losses.

site_title: Amazon quarterly profit jumps but shares slide
summary: Amazon reported a 48% increase in second-quarter profit to $7.8 billion, but its shares fell 6% after missing revenue forecasts. Total revenues rose 27% to $113.1 billion, below analyst expectations. CEO Andy Jassy attributed the focus on consumer delivery and cloud computing to the pandemic. Despite the disappointing revenue, Amazon's cloud division AWS saw significant growth. The company's shares fell as tech rivals like Facebook, Apple, and Microsoft reported higher revenues and profits.

site_title: TikTok CEO buying GCB for S$86m
summary: TikTok CEO Chew Shou Zi is buying a Good Class Bungalow (GCB) in Singapore's Queen Astrid Park area for S$86 million, with a land area of 31,800 sq ft and a 999-year leasehold tenure. The price works out to S$2,700 per square foot, higher than market expectations. This deal reflects the ongoing escalation in GCB prices amid strong demand from both new citizens and local buyers. The property is expected to be redeveloped, and Chew's purchase is the latest example of tech heads buying GCBs, with others including Razer co-founder Tan Min-Liang and technopreneur Tommy Ong.

site_title: Family of Henrietta Lacks, unwitting medical heroine, takes on Big Pharma
summary: The family of Henrietta Lacks, a Black woman whose cells were taken without her knowledge in 1951, plans to sue pharmaceutical giants that profited from her cells. The cells, known as HeLa cells, have enabled medical breakthroughs, including vaccines and cancer treatments. The family, represented by civil rights attorney Ben Crump, aims to seek compensation for exploitation and announce plans to file a complaint on October 4, the 70th anniversary of the disputed samples. The lawsuit targets companies that have profited from the use of HeLa cells without reaching an agreement to compensate the family.

site_title: Swiss embassy's new look for growing ties
summary: The Swiss embassy in Singapore is undergoing a major renovation to accommodate growing bilateral ties and new staff. The embassy, which has been in use since 1987, will be upgraded to modern standards with a new design showcasing Swiss architecture and sustainability. The project, led by architectural firm Berrel Krautler Architekten, will feature a bright and functional office space, transparent rooms, and environmentally friendly features. The renovation is part of the Swiss government's efforts to upgrade its missions worldwide and is expected to be completed by early 2023.

site_title: Oil rises as US supplies tighten and dollar weakens
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday, with global benchmark Brent topping $75 a barrel, as US supplies tightened and the dollar weakened. US crude inventories fell by 4.1 million barrels, and the Cushing storage hub saw its seventh consecutive stockpile draw. A weaker dollar boosted investor demand for dollar-denominated commodities, including oil. Additionally, Iran's pause in nuclear talks could delay the return of Iranian barrels to the market, further supporting tighter supplies.

site_title: The world we live in, is the world that we invest in
summary: Thematic investing is a strategy that future-proofs portfolios by incorporating ideas that are actionable, secular, and long-lasting. This approach has gained popularity, particularly in responsible investing, which focuses on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors. ESG investing pays off for shareholders and stakeholders in the long term, as companies that adopt responsible practices can adjust in an agile manner and reduce risks. Two key themes are cryptocurrencies and digital assets, which have created opportunities and are expected to coexist with traditional currencies. Regulatory hurdles will be the main obstacle for cryptos to navigate.

site_title: Furloughed jobs in UK plunge to pandemic low as economy opens
summary: The UK's Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme has reached its lowest level since the pandemic, with 1.86 million people receiving support as of June, a decline of almost 600,000 from the previous month. The number of furloughed jobs fell to 971,200, with a further drop expected in July. The decline is a boost to the UK government, which has spent £70 billion supporting nearly 12 million jobs. However, economists warn that the reduction in government support could lead to higher unemployment and wage pressures, with the jobless rate expected to reach 5.2% by the end of the year.

site_title: National Australia Bank to launch US$1.9b share buyback
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) plans to launch a US$1.9 billion share buyback, returning A$2.50 billion to shareholders. The move is part of the bank's efforts to reduce its common equity tier 1 ratio and increase its spare cash reserves. This is the third major Australian bank to announce a share buyback, with a total of A$26 billion expected to be returned to investors over the next two years. The buyback will reduce NAB's CET1 ratio by around 60 basis points, bringing it within a target range of 10.75-11.25%.

images.alt_text: National Australia Bank will return as much as A$2.50 billion (S$2.50 billion) to shareholders by buying back its stock in August, the country's third-largest lender said on Friday.

site_title: Vaccinated Americans are getting angry at holdouts
summary: Vaccinated Americans are growing frustrated with unvaccinated individuals, feeling they are prolonging the pandemic and disrupting their lives. Despite 60.2% of US adults being fully vaccinated, the country is still far from the 85-90% rate epidemiologists believe is necessary. The CDC's recommendation to vaccinated people wear masks nationwide has fueled the anger, with some calling for mandates and consequences for those who refuse. The mood is shifting from understanding to impatience, with momentum building for mandates and measures like paid vaccine leave.

site_title: Pindan subsidiary gets creditor's nod for restructuring: Oxley
summary: Oxley Holdings' subsidiary Pindan Asset Management has received creditor approval for a deed of company arrangement (DOCA), paving the way for restructuring and returning the company to solvency. The move comes after Pindan experienced pandemic-related challenges, including delays in construction activities and project completions. The approval is a significant step forward for Pindan, which is an 85%-owned subsidiary of Oxley. The company's restructuring plan aims to address the challenges and ensure its financial stability.

site_title: The champions and (of) mental health
summary: International sporting stars Naomi Osaka and Simone Biles have taken a bold stand on mental health, prioritizing it alongside physical health. Osaka's statement "It's OK to not be OK" and Biles' emphasis on mental resilience have raised awareness about the importance of self-care and seeking help. The Olympics, traditionally focused on physical achievements, has been reminded of the need to acknowledge mental health. Past Olympics champion Michael Phelps has also spoken out about mental health, sharing his own struggles with depression and the need for mental health resources. Their efforts aim to promote greater mental health awareness and challenge the stigma surrounding mental illness.

site_title: St Gallen Symposium holds first hub meeting in Singapore
summary: The St Gallen Symposium held its first hub meeting in Singapore, featuring 50 participants in an intergenerational dialogue on "Trust Matters." The event was organized in May and brought together Singaporean attendees who met in person while participating through local, hybrid, and digital sessions. The symposium was a milestone in Switzerland's prestigious student-organized event, with a strong focus on Singapore's role in fostering international dialogue. The event's success marked the beginning of a new chapter in the SGS's growing relationship with Singapore, with Fabian Karst, a student organizer, set to become the symposium's new permanent representative for Asia based in Singapore.

site_title: Hong Kong's urban farms sprouting gardens in the sky
summary: Hong Kong's urban farms have sprouted over 60 gardens across the city since 2015, using rooftops and public spaces to grow crops like radishes, carrots, and rhubarb. Initiatives like Rooftop Republic promote urban farming, providing a sustainable solution to the city's space constraints. These rooftop gardens offer a vibrant contrast to the city's financial district, providing a unique green oasis for office workers and residents.

site_title: US economy grows solidly in Q2; labour market healing
summary: The US economy grew solidly in Q2 with a 6.5% annualized rate, below expectations, due to a sharp inventory drawdown amid supply chain constraints. Consumer spending, boosted by demand for services, grew at an 11.8% rate, while business investment on equipment was tempered. The economy contracted 3.4% in 2020, and despite revisions, the expansion is expected to remain solid for the remainder of the year. Risks to the outlook include a resurgence in Covid-19 infections, higher inflation, and ongoing supply chain disruptions.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close at new highs on earnings lift
summary: European stocks reached new highs on Thursday, driven by strong earnings from commodity majors Airbus and Royal Dutch Shell, as well as record high euro zone economic sentiment. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.5% to a closing high of 460.57 points, with miners and consumer stocks benefiting from rising prices. Despite concerns about inflation and China's regulatory crackdown, central banks' supportive stance and positive economic sentiment lifted investor confidence, with 67% of Stoxx 600 companies beating analyst profit estimates.
