images.alt_text: European stocks hit all-time highs on Thursday after strong earnings from commodity majors, Airbus and a clutch of other companies, while data showing record high euro zone economic sentiment in July added to the positive mood.

site_title: Firmenich opens food innovation hub
summary: Firmenich, the world's largest privately-owned fragrance and taste company, has opened a Culinary and SmartProteins Innovation Center in western Singapore's Tuas. The center will be a regional R&D hub for Asia and a global centre of expertise in alternative proteins for meat and dairy, a rapidly growing global market. Firmenich aims to address the nutritional needs of the region by developing sustainable and innovative solutions. The center will be close to markets and consumers, enabling the company to better address their demands.

site_title: Switzerland Tourism promotes 'Clean & Safe' label
summary: Switzerland Tourism has launched a "Clean & Safe" label to promote tourism establishments that adhere to protection measures, following the country's reopening to tourists. The label, displayed at most tourism facilities, indicates that businesses have committed to complying with federal and industry protection plans. The initiative aims to boost confidence in Switzerland as a clean and safe destination, particularly in light of the pandemic. The label is provided by industry associations and includes six specific labels for hotels, restaurants, and public transportation.

site_title: India equity deals set to pick up pace as investors hunt post-pandemic bets
summary: India is set to see a surge in equity deals as investors hunt post-pandemic bets, with a record $30 billion raised so far this year. Foreign investors, particularly those from China, are flocking to India's tech start-ups, with $13.21 billion invested in the first half of 2021. This has led to a boom in initial public offerings (IPOs), with $71.6 billion raised in Asia, double the rate of growth in the same period last year. Analysts attribute the trend to India's large middle class, digital consumerism, and a regulatory clampdown on China's technology firms.

site_title: Trust matters, now more than ever
summary: The 50th St Gallen Symposium in Switzerland focused on the theme "Trust Matters" as public trust in institutions has eroded, especially among younger generations. The two-day conference brought together key decision-makers from various fields to discuss and act on trust in five main areas: Resilient Health Systems, Effective Governance, Sustainable Transformation, Responsible Technology, and A New Social Contract. The symposium aimed to preserve and strengthen institutional and interpersonal trust, a crucial aspect of a sustainable recovery amidst unprecedented global challenges.

site_title: US: Stocks gain on 'spectacular' earnings season
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, driven by solid growth data and earnings, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.4% to 35,084.53. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also rose, with the S&P 500 gaining 0.4% to 4,419.15. Companies such as Ford and Comcast reported better-than-expected results, while Facebook and Robinhood experienced declines due to disappointing outlooks and regulatory concerns. The US economy returned to pre-pandemic levels in the second quarter, with a 6.5% annualized expansion rate.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks advanced on Thursday following solid US growth data and earnings, but Facebook dropped on disappointment over its outlook and Robinhood sank in its Nasdaq debut.

site_title: Champagne with no bubbles? Thank climate change
summary: Climate change is contributing to the rise of still wines in Champagne, as warmer temperatures allow grapes to ripen fully and produce wines with more weight and flavor concentration. This shift is evident in the growing production of "coteaux Champenois" wines, with most being red from pinot noir, meunier, or both. While some are delicious, others are works in progress, and most are not a bargain. Producers like Charles Heidseick and Jacques Lassaigne are experimenting with new styles, and climate change is seen as a driving factor behind this change.

site_title: Bernina joins hands with NIE for training
summary: Swiss sewing machine manufacturer Bernina has partnered with the National Institute of Education (NIE) to develop training programs for students to acquire 21st-century skills through a multidisciplinary approach. The program, in collaboration with a Swiss university, aims to equip students with essential skills targeting the textile industry. Bernina's director, Katharina Ueltschi, stated that the partnership offers students solid training on both theoretical and practical levels, promoting their integration into the professional world.

site_title: Gold demand for 2021 to be below pre-pandemic levels
summary: Gold demand for 2021 is expected to be below pre-pandemic levels, according to the World Gold Council. However, Asian countries, particularly China and India, have driven up demand for gold bars and coins. Despite this, the global price of gold has remained relatively stable, trading between $1,677 and $1,900 per ounce. The current price is $1,820 per ounce. Western investment and speculative sales have also contributed to the stable price.

site_title: Covid-19 pandemic spurs conversion of offices in US into labs
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in office-to-lab conversions in the US, with over 20% of lab spaces being built from former office buildings in the six largest life sciences markets. This trend is driven by the industry's record-breaking growth and the need for specialized lab space. However, conversions can be complex and costly, requiring significant upgrades to building codes, electrical systems, and ventilation. Despite these challenges, many life sciences companies are turning to conversions to capitalize on inflated rents and be closer to talent.

site_title: Nestle's Singapore R&D Centre celebrates 40th anniversary
summary: Nestle's Singapore R&D Centre is celebrating its 40th anniversary, marking a key milestone in the company's presence in Asia. Established in 1980, the centre has developed expertise in areas like fermentation and plant-based food, resulting in patented technologies and product launches. The renovated centre features state-of-the-art facilities, including an R&D Accelerator and sensory evaluation rooms. As the regional innovation hub for plant-based dairy alternatives in Asia, the centre collaborates with global R&D networks and academic institutions to drive innovation and sustainability in the food industry.

site_title: SwissCham Business Excellence Awards
summary: SWISSCHAM Singapore has expanded its Business Excellence Awards to include a new Digital Transformation Award (DX), receiving 43 applications from various organizations in Singapore and the Asean region. The award aims to recognize best-in-class digital transformation initiatives, facilitating the exchange of best practices, access to expertise, and networking. An international jury of experts will screen applications to select an overall winner and subcategory winners, promoting digitalization efforts in the region.

site_title: The smart car buying guide
summary: There is no article about "The smart car buying guide" provided. The provided articles are about various topics including criminal investigations, law firms, project management, digital assistants, and business expansions.

site_title: We're Ben and Jerry. Men of ice cream, men of principle
summary: Ben & Jerry's, the ice cream company co-founded by the authors, has ended business in the occupied territories due to its support for the international community's view of the occupation as illegal. This decision, made despite the potential backlash, aligns the company with its progressive values and advances justice and human rights, core tenets of Judaism. The company maintains its support for the State of Israel and distinguishes its stance from the Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions movement.

site_title: Hotel group Accor upbeat on recovery after lower H1 loss
summary: Accor, Europe's largest hotel group, reported a smaller operating loss for the first half of the year, with a 120 million euros loss compared to a 227 million euros loss in the same period last year. The company attributes the recovery to the rollout of Covid-19 vaccines and the reopening of borders, particularly in Europe. Revenue per available room fell 60% compared to 2019, but improved by about 5 points per month since April. Accor's Ebitda is expected to benefit from recurring cost savings and a positive impact of 70 million euros this year.

site_title: Rare rebuke from Malaysia's king deepens Muhyiddin's troubles
summary: Malaysia's King Sultan Abdullah Sultan Ahmad publicly rebuked Law Minister Takiyuddin Hassan for misleading parliament, sparking renewed calls for Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin to resign. The king's statement contradicts Hassan's remarks that emergency laws had been revoked, prompting protests from opposition lawmakers. Opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim urged Muhyiddin to take responsibility and step down, with the United Malays National Organisation ordering its MPs to withdraw support. The government still holds support from over 110 MPs, but public calls for resignation are growing, with experts questioning the legitimacy of the crisis-ridden government.

site_title: Australia central bank set to defer bond buying taper: survey
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia is likely to delay its planned reduction in bond buying, with 13 out of 18 economists polled expecting a delay. The decision comes as prolonged lockdowns triggered by the Delta virus variant are expected to send the national economy back into reverse. Economists forecast a 2.7% contraction in the current quarter, with unemployment peaking at 5.6% in October. The RBA will review its taper plan in a couple of months, with some predicting an increase in buying to A$6 billion through to November.

site_title: US-China tech race will change global economy whatever the outcome
summary: The US and China are engaged in a high-stakes tech competition, with both nations vying to outdo each other in emerging fields like artificial intelligence, data networks, and quantum computing. The rivalry is expected to shift the global economy and daily lives of billions, but scholars say it's unlikely to become an economic death match like the Cold War. Both countries are restricting sensitive imports and exports, and the competition is expected to expand to include additional technologies with coordinated efforts with allies and partners worldwide.

site_title: The business of fertility
summary: About 15% of couples in Singapore struggle to conceive within a year of trying, amid growing demand for fertility services. The pandemic disrupted fertility plans, while others seek alternative treatments. The fertility business has been steadily growing, with calls for social egg-freezing and employee benefits. Experts highlight the need for better support and resources for those struggling with infertility.

site_title: Fashion designers push on digitally
summary: Singapore's digital fashion festival, The Front Row, is back for its second year, featuring 10 homegrown brands and eight regional and international labels. The festival highlights sustainability, with brands such as Jude by Jude Ng, which upcycles unused cloth, and ITT Swim, which makes swimwear from recycled plastics. Virtual influencer Rae, with over 500,000 followers, will also be featured, promoting the digital trend. The festival is supported by the Singapore Tourism Board and aims to promote independent labels internationally. Three Singapore-born designers, Jude Ng, Deva & Gabo, and Celest Thoi, will also debut in the festival, showcasing their unique designs and commitment to sustainability.

images.alt_text: Five models fronting the 2021 Front Row digital fashion festival includes virtual influencer Rae (bottom, left). The other models are (clockwise from top left) supermodel Diya Prabhakar, Alexis Cooke, Lisa Van Duren and Srri Raam.
Eponymous label of Dubai-based Filipino designer Michael Cinco is one of several overseas labels featured in The Front Row.

site_title: Bonds rally in Indonesia with little help from global funds
summary: Indonesia's sovereign bonds have rallied, with a 10-year yield dropping 29 basis points this month, despite a resurgence in COVID-19 cases hindering economic recovery. Total bond returns rose to 1.6%, the highest among emerging-Asian nations. Bank Indonesia's buying of debt and limited supply have contributed to the rally. Despite outperforming regional peers, foreign inflows remain scarce, indicating the bonds' appeal to global investors remains limited.

site_title: Swiss Club the place to make friends, says past president
summary: Swiss Club's past president, Martin Silberstein, emphasizes the club as a perfect place to make friends, relax, and engage in sports and activities. He attributes the club's 150-year presence in Singapore to a strong relationship between Swiss businessmen and Singapore, a rare feat. Silberstein praises The Swiss Club's resort-like atmosphere, good food, and drinks, making it an ideal spot to socialize and grow friendships.

site_title: Evergrande supplier sues amid word of overdue bills, further slump in share price
summary: China Evergrande Group is facing a cash crunch after two suppliers, Huaibei Mining Holdings and Peace Tree Wood, filed lawsuits alleging the company missed payments. Huaibei Mining Holdings is demanding 401 million yuan (S$84 million) for fees and breach of contract, while Peace Tree Wood is seeking 2 million yuan for commercial bills. The latest developments add to signs of financial strain on the world's most indebted developer, which has already seen a slump in its share price. The situation raises concerns about Evergrande's ability to meet its debt obligations.

site_title: Europe's football market shrinks after multi-billion dollar Covid hit: Deloitte
summary: Europe's football market contracted by 13% in the 2020-2021 season, with revenue falling to €25.2 billion, due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. The decline was felt across the region's largest leagues, with the "big five" countries seeing a 11% drop in revenue. The pandemic disrupted competitions, with hundreds of matches postponed or cancelled, and led to a significant loss for clubs, particularly in England's Premier League. Revenue is expected to recover, with Deloitte predicting a record €5.5 billion for the 2022-2023 season.

site_title: Singapore continues to draw British companies looking for a regional hub
summary: Singapore solidifies its position as a regional hub for British companies, with 90 businesses supported by the British Chamber of Commerce Singapore since the UK-Singapore Free Trade Agreement was signed in December 2020. The city-state's strategic location, competitive economy, and digital connectivity make it an attractive location for companies to base their regional hubs, create jobs, and utilize Singapore's connectivity with the rest of the Asean region. European companies, particularly those from the UK, are also actively looking to expand in the region, with 77% of respondents expecting to leverage Singapore as a regional headquarters.

images.alt_text: According to David Kelly, executive director at the British Chamber of Commerce Singapore (BritCham), the chamber helped around 90 companies since the UK-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (UKSFTA) was signed in December 2020.

site_title: German inflation surges to 3.8% in July, highest since 2008
summary: German inflation surged to 3.8% in July, the highest since 2008, according to preliminary data from Destatis. The increase was driven by higher energy prices and the full base effect from a 2020 sales tax cut. This marks the first time inflation has breached the 3% mark since 1993. The federal statistics agency attributes the hike to these factors.

site_title: Dollar falls after Fed says rate hikes not on the horizon
summary: The US dollar fell to a one-month low after the Federal Reserve stated interest rate hikes are "a ways away," providing a boost to other currencies. The dollar slipped 0.2% against a currency basket, marking the fourth straight day of decline. The euro rose to a two-week peak at US$1.188, while the Australian and New Zealand dollars, Chinese yuan, and Canadian dollar also gained ground. China's efforts to calm stock market jitters contributed to the dollar's decline, with the yuan rising for the second day in a row.

site_title: Didi shares surge after report that it's considering going private
summary: Didi Chuxing shares surged 49% in pre-market trading after a report that the Beijing-based company is considering going private to placate Chinese regulators and compensate investors for losses. The move comes amid discussions with bankers, regulators, and key investors to resolve regulatory woes. Chinese regulators are weighing potential punishments, including a fine, suspension of operations, or introduction of a state-owned investor. A take-private offer could be funded with IPO money, with a possible price around or above the US$14-per-share IPO price.

site_title: European stocks close at new highs on earnings lift
summary: European stocks closed at new highs on Thursday, driven by strong earnings from commodity majors such as Royal Dutch Shell and TotalEnergies, as well as a surge in oil and gas prices. The STOXX 600 index rose 0.5% to a closing high of 460.57 points. Other sectors, including miners and aerospace manufacturer Airbus, also saw gains. Strong quarterly earnings and optimism around European reopening contributed to the positive mood, despite concerns about inflation and China's regulatory crackdown.

site_title: Fed says US economy showing progress but 'not fully recovered'
summary: The Federal Reserve announced that the US economy is showing signs of progress, but not yet fully recovered. The Fed stated that it is not ready to end its easy money policies, citing risks to the economic outlook and the need for "substantial further progress" on maximum employment and inflation targets. Despite the economy recovering millions of jobs and lowering unemployment, inflation has surged to 5.4%, above the Fed's 2% goal. Fed Chair Jerome Powell acknowledged that inflation could continue higher and is ready to act if needed to bring prices under control.

images.alt_text: The US economic recovery is showing signs of progress, but the Federal Reserve said on Wednesday that it is not yet ready to end the easy money policies it implemented as the pandemic began last year.

site_title: European sanitary leader launches new innovations
summary: Swiss-based Geberit, a European sanitary industry leader, has launched new innovations in the market, including the Geberit ONE technology in Singapore, a comprehensive solution for bathroom cleanliness, space, and flexibility. The company also introduced Geberit FlowFit, a drinking water piping system designed for plumbers, and Geberit Alpha cistern, which offers upgrades from its previous model. Geberit aims to value-add in sanitary technology, bathroom ceramics, and OEM mechanisms in the north and South-east Asia region, with a goal of establishing a strong presence in the region.

site_title: VW lowers car deliveries outlook over chip woes
summary: Volkswagen reported strong first-half profits, with adjusted operating profits reaching 11.4 billion euros, despite cutting its car deliveries forecast due to a worsening semiconductor chip shortage. The company now expects deliveries to be "noticeably up" on 2020, but the impact of the shortage will be more pronounced in the third quarter. Volkswagen's operating return on sales target was raised to 6.0-7.5%, and the company lifted its profit target for 2021. Despite the challenges, VW's premium segment performed well, driving a "record" performance over the first six months.

site_title: A blue ocean compass for your post-Covid strategy
summary: Managers globally are adapting to a post-Covid world, challenging long-held industry assumptions. To succeed, they must rethink industry logic and practices using the Four Actions Framework: eliminate factors that no longer add value, reduce overdesigned products or services, raise factors that improve customer experience, and create entirely new kinds of value. Examples like Zwift, a virtual biking app, show how creating unique value propositions can thrive in a transformed world. Companies must assess what sets them apart and how to capitalize on the crisis by focusing on factors that customers will not give up, even during difficult times.

site_title: Tetsuya Wakuda to open two more restaurants in Singapore and the US
summary: Chef Tetsuya Wakuda is set to open two new restaurants, Wakuda, in Singapore and the US, in early 2022 and the spring, respectively. The joint venture between Wakuda, Las Vegas Sands, and 50 Eggs Hospitality Group brings Wakuda's "next-level" Japanese cuisine to both markets. Despite the ongoing pandemic, Wakuda remains enthusiastic about the future of dining and believes vaccination rates and international travel will lead to a steady recovery of the F&B industry. Wakuda will oversee the construction and culinary teams of both locations, marking his US debut.

site_title: 129 new locally transmitted Covid-19 cases in Singapore, 30 linked to Jurong Fishery Port
summary: Singapore reported 129 new locally transmitted COVID-19 cases, including 30 linked to the Jurong Fishery Port cluster. The total cases in the cluster now stands at 962. Two new cases were also linked to the KTV cluster, bringing its total to 249. Four seniors aged above 70, unvaccinated or partially vaccinated, were among the new cases. The total number of cases in Singapore now stands at 64,722.

site_title: Swiss-Singapore ties growing stronger: envoy
summary: Switzerland and Singapore continue to strengthen their bilateral relations, despite the Covid-19 pandemic. The two countries maintain regular contact on digitalisation, cybersecurity, and other issues. In 2020, high-level meetings and conferences were held, including a virtual exchange between Swiss and Singaporean officials, and a phone call between the Swiss President and Singapore's Prime Minister. The Swiss Ambassador to Singapore, Fabrice Filliez, notes that the countries have enjoyed "excellent bilateral relations" and will continue to work together closely.

site_title: Swiss-Singapore business ties expanding: SwissCham chief
summary: Switzerland's business ties with Singapore continue to expand despite the COVID-19 pandemic, with bilateral trade growing steadily and Swiss foreign direct investment reaching a new high. Singapore remains Switzerland's most important trading partner in South-east Asia and Asia, with exports of chemical and pharmaceutical products and imports of gold and other precious metals increasing. SwissCham Singapore reports that 74% of Swiss companies believe the Singapore government's support for the economy is sufficient and effective, but some industries, such as F&B and tourism, struggled financially during the pandemic. The Swiss embassy estimates around 400 Swiss companies operate in Singapore, employing 25,000 staff.

images.alt_text: Mr von Wattenwyl says Swiss direct investment in Singapore rose by 12.9% to S$68.5 billion in 2019.

site_title: Three ways to give your mind and body a boost
summary: A brain mapping session at the MindLab can provide insights into what's happening in the brain, helping individuals address memory loss, insomnia, depression, anxiety, and stress. Founder Santiago Brand uses specialized equipment to analyze brain waves, heart rate, and muscle tension, and provides personalized brain training programs with biofeedback and neurofeedback. Clients see improvements after 3-6 sessions, and the MindLab offers a range of wellness services, including yoga, osteopathy, and sound healing therapy.

site_title: Shooting the breeze
summary: A two-and-a-half storey home in Bukit Timah, Singapore, was designed by RT+Q Architects to be a well-ventilated, multigenerational dwelling. The homeowners, a trader couple and their family, including three kids and their mother-in-law, requested a home that encourages interaction. The design features an unconventional "free section" where spaces flow vertically, allowing for a fluid and airy atmosphere. This unique design helps keep the residents cool, creating a comfortable living environment.

site_title: Covid recovery drives US credit rating upgrades to record high
summary: The US has experienced a record number of corporate credit rating upgrades this year, with 121 upgrades in the second quarter and 220 since the start of the year. The strong economic recovery, driven by vaccine roll-outs, reopenings, and low borrowing costs, has boosted firms' finances and made debt more manageable. Most upgrades were of lower-rated firms, particularly in sectors hardest hit by the pandemic, with the proportion of firms at risk of downgrades falling to 19%, below its long-term average.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust says outlook is 'challenging'; RevPAR still a fraction of year-ago levels
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust reported a challenging outlook for its hotels, with average daily rates and revenue per available room (RevPAR) lower year-over-year to June 30. Despite a slight improvement in performance from the start of the financial year, occupancy rates remain depressed due to the ongoing coronavirus impact. However, the manager notes a potential rebound in domestic tourism could benefit the trust's assets in Australia, Japan, and Britain.

site_title: Swiss foreign direct investment in Singapore hits record S$68.5b
summary: Switzerland's foreign direct investment (FDI) in Singapore reached a record $68.5 billion in 2019, a 77% increase from 2017. Swiss FDI rose 12.9% in 2019 compared to 2018, driven by Singapore's finance and insurance industry. The Swiss National Bank reports a 32% return on investment in Singapore, making it the top destination for Swiss FDI.

site_title: Jardine Matheson narrows H1 net loss to US$117m
summary: Jardine Matheson Holdings reported a net loss of US$117 million for the first half of 2021, narrowing from US$775 million in the same period last year. The group's underlying net profit rose 65% to US$615 million, driven by recovering business performance and the impact of privatising Jardine Strategic Holdings. A semi-annual revaluation of Hongkong Land's investment properties contributed to the loss.

site_title: Top Swiss hotel university opens campus here
summary: Switzerland's Ecole hoteliere de Lausanne (EHL) has opened its first international campus in Singapore, offering a bachelor's degree program in international hospitality management. Over 50 students from diverse nationalities will start the program in September. The campus will provide a similar learning experience to EHL's Swiss campus, with faculty members from Lausanne teaching and guest speakers from the industry. The program is tailored to Asia-Pacific needs, with a focus on local context and industry partnerships. EHL aims to expand opportunities for future leaders in the hospitality industry, with a goal of elevating the sector in Singapore and the region.

site_title: Tesla battery supplier CATL debuts cheaper sodium-ion batteries
summary: CATL, China's largest battery maker, unveiled a cheaper sodium-ion battery that uses lower-density cells with cheaper raw materials than lithium-ion batteries. The first-generation sodium-ion battery has reached 160 watt-hours/kilogramme, with plans to exceed 200 Wh/kg in future generations. This development could help alleviate cost challenges for Chinese renewable energy developers and contribute to China's carbon-neutral target.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hit record high on earnings from Airbus, commodity majors
summary: European stocks reached a record high due to strong earnings from commodity majors, including Airbus, which rose 3.6% after raising forecasts for full-year deliveries and earnings. The Stoxx 600 index increased 0.3% to 463 points, with mining and healthcare sectors contributing to the gains. Concerns about China's regulatory moves also faded, allowing the market to reach an all-time high.

site_title: Small-time traders turn 'dip buyers' in China share selloff
summary: Individual traders, known as "dip buyers," have been buying Chinese stocks during the sell-off triggered by China's regulatory crackdown, contrary to institutional investors. According to research, US retail investors attracted $194 million in net inflows for shares of Nio, Xpeng, and Alibaba, which have fallen 12-17% this week. This behavior marks a shift from retail traders, who previously drove rallies in heavily shorted stocks. Despite this, JP Morgan analysts believe there may be more pain for Chinese equities in the medium term.

site_title: Credit Suisse profit misses estimates
summary: Credit Suisse reported a 78% decline in second-quarter profit, with a US$653 million Archegos-related loss and a slump in trading. The advisory business saw a 33% decline in revenues, while billions of outflows occurred in Asia due to reduced ties with clients. The bank's net income was dragged down by these factors, highlighting the aftershocks of scandals affecting the investment bank and wealth management businesses.

site_title: Olympics: Schooling struggles to rediscover speed
summary: Singaporean swimmer Joseph Schooling failed to qualify for the Tokyo Olympics after finishing 44th in the 100m butterfly heats with a time of 53.12 seconds. Schooling, who won the gold medal in the same event at the 2016 Rio Olympics, attributed his poor performance to a lack of spark and vowed to bounce back. He also failed to qualify for the 100m freestyle heats. Despite the disappointment, Schooling remains optimistic and is determined to regain his form for future competitions.

site_title: OUE C-Reit bumps up H1 DPU to 1.23 Singapore cents after earlier retention
summary: OUE Commercial Real Estate Investment Trust (OUE C-Reit) has announced a first-half distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.23 Singapore cents, a 23% increase from the previous year. The trust's distributable income rose 3% year-over-year to S$67.2 million, driven by stable income from its hospitality segment. The DPU increase comes after the trust retained S$10.8 million in the previous year to preserve financial flexibility. The trust's net property income and revenue fell 3.1% and 6% respectively, primarily due to the divestment of OUE Bayfront.

site_title: Dow scale all-time highs as economy picks up pace
summary: The S&P 500 and Dow indexes reached record highs on Thursday as strong corporate earnings and US economic growth data reinforced optimism about a post-pandemic recovery. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 0.49%, while the S&P 500 was up 0.44%. Ford Motor Co jumped 5.9%, while JPMorgan Chase & Co and Bank of America Corp gained between 0.4% and 1%. Data showed a 6.5% annualized increase in gross domestic product in the second quarter, while jobless claims fell to 400,000.

site_title: Sembmarine reports loss of S$647.2m for H1, but company sees improvement in H2
summary: Sembmarine reported a loss of S$647.2 million for the first half of FY2021, primarily due to provisions for labour and other costs. However, executives expect losses to narrow in the second half, barring unforeseen circumstances. Revenue fell 6.8% to S$844.2 million, and the company's net order book stood at S$1.78 billion. Despite the challenges, Sembmarine is actively tendering for new projects and has not seen any cancellations of existing ones.

site_title: Sheng Siong H1 profit down 11.9% from year-ago high base as grocery frenzy eases
summary: Sheng Siong Group, a Singaporean supermarket operator, reported a 11.9% decline in net profit to S$65.9 million for the first half of 2021, due to a subdued market after the COVID-19 pandemic's initial buying frenzy. Revenue slipped 8.8% to S$681.7 million. Despite a possible increase in demand in the third quarter, the company expects a tapering of demand in the second half of 2021. Sheng Siong also announced plans to expand in China and inked lease agreements for two new stores.

site_title: Retailer Dairy Farm pares dividend as H1 earnings fall 69.5% to US$32.1m
summary: Dairy Farm International, a Jardine-owned Asian retail giant, reported a 69.5% decline in underlying net profit to US$32.1 million for the first half of the year due to lower contributions from its grocery segment and a loss of US$43.6 million from associates. Sales fell 13.4% to US$4.54 billion, largely due to divestments and pandemic-related restrictions. The company has warned that the outlook for the year remains uncertain, and its board has declared a reduced interim dividend of US$0.03 per share.

site_title: Astra profit contributions propel Jardine Cycle & Carriage to H1 earnings growth
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage reported a 149% increase in underlying profits to US$346.5 million for the first half of 2021, driven by Astra's contributions. Revenue rose 25.7% to US$8.29 billion, but net profit fell 24.8% to US$226.3 million due to non-trading items. The company declared an interim dividend of US$0.18 per share and announced a board reshuffle, including the appointment of Samuel Tsien as an independent director.

site_title: US charges Nikola founder with fraud
summary: US prosecutors have charged Nikola founder and former executive chairman Trevor Milton with three counts of fraud for making false claims about the company's electric vehicles, resulting in significant losses for investors. Milton allegedly claimed a "full-functioning" semi-truck prototype when it was inoperable, inducing retail investors to purchase Nikola's stock. The indictment states that Milton's false claims led to tens and hundreds of thousands of dollars in losses for shareholders, including some who lost retirement savings. Nikola has cooperated with the Justice Department investigation, and shares of the company plummeted 7.5% in pre-market trading.

site_title: Keppel's H1 dividend up 4 times, profits rebound to S$300m from pandemic slump
summary: Keppel Corp, a Singaporean diversified conglomerate, reported a net profit of S$300 million in the first half of FY2021, a significant rebound from a loss of S$537 million in the same period last year. The company's operating performance improved across all key segments, excluding asset management, which was boosted by gains from reclassifications and sales in the previous period. Keppel's interim dividend was quadrupled to 12 Singapore cents per share, and the company hinted at more mergers and acquisitions (M&A) action. Revenue rose 16% to S$3.7 billion, driven by property trading projects in China and higher acquisition fees in asset management.

images.alt_text: Phillip Securities has raised its target price for Keppel Corporation to S$7.07 from S$6.28 after incorporating Keppel Capital into its valuation model, it said in a research note on Tuesday (Oct 19).

site_title: US dollar at one-month low after Fed knock
summary: The US dollar slipped to a one-month low, falling 0.3% to 92.005, following the Federal Reserve's reassurance that interest rate hikes remain distant. Despite solid US economic growth, GDP increased at a 6.5% annualized rate, below economists' expectations. The dollar's decline was partly attributed to the Fed's dovish rhetoric and lower US Treasury yields, while the Australian and New Zealand dollars edged higher due to increased economic growth expectations.

site_title: US economy contracts 19.2% during Covid-19 pandemic recession
summary: The US economy contracted by a record 19.2% from its peak in the fourth quarter of 2019 to the second quarter of 2020, marking the worst Covid-19 recession. The economy rebounded at a historic 18.3% average annual rate between the second and fourth quarters of 2020. The National Bureau of Economic Research declared the pandemic downturn ended in April 2020, citing massive fiscal stimulus, the Fed's monetary policy, and vaccinations. The economy is expected to grow 7% this year, the strongest performance since 1984.

site_title: Singaporean's fairytale run to Tokyo table tennis semis ends in tears, pain
summary: Singaporean table tennis player Yu Mengyu, the 26th seed at the Tokyo Olympics, ended her fairytale run in tears after a 6-11, 8-11, 7-11, 6-11 defeat to China's top-seeded Chen Meng in the semi-finals. Yu, 31, had been struggling with injury problems, including a recent flare-up that left her in a wheelchair just months ago. She had previously talked about retiring after Tokyo, but was determined to complete the match despite her injuries. Yu lost the bronze-medal match to Japan's Mima Ito.

site_title: Rare rebuke from Malaysia's king deepens Muhyiddin's troubles
summary: Malaysia's King Sultan Abdullah Sultan Ahmad publicly rebuked Law Minister Takiyuddin Hassan for misleading Parliament about the cancellation of emergency laws, sparking renewed calls for Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin to resign. The king's statement contradicts the minister's remarks, undermining the government's authority and legitimacy. Opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim has submitted a motion for a no-confidence vote against Muhyiddin, and the United Malays National Organisation (Umno) has ordered its MPs to withdraw support for the prime minister. The king's intervention has intensified public calls for Muhyiddin's resignation amidst the ongoing pandemic crisis.

site_title: Hongkong Land narrows H1 loss, declares 6 US cent interim dividend
summary: Hongkong Land narrowed its net loss to US$863.2 million for the half-year ended June 30, from US$1.8 billion a year ago. Underlying profit increased 11.8% to US$394.4 million, driven by higher development properties profits. The board declared an interim dividend of 6 US cents per share, unchanged from a year ago. Despite negative rental reversions in Hong Kong, investment properties remained resilient. The group expects higher second-half underlying profits from its development properties business due to more sales completions on the Chinese mainland.

site_title: Big Tech starts requiring vaccines; Twitter closes reopened US offices
summary: Big tech companies, including Google, Facebook, and Twitter, are requiring on-campus vaccinations for US employees amid the Delta Covid-19 variant resurgence. Twitter has also paused future office reopenings, while others like Lyft and Netflix have implemented vaccination mandates. Health authorities have advised Americans to wear masks in indoor public places where the coronavirus is spreading rapidly. Many tech companies, including Microsoft and Uber, expect employees to return to offices, with Google extending its work-from-home policy through October.

site_title: Credit Suisse 78% Q2 net profit slide shows Archegos hit
summary: Credit Suisse reported a 78% fall in second-quarter net profit to 253 million Swiss francs, missing forecasts of 334 million Swiss francs. The decline was attributed to steep drops in investment banking revenues and losses at Archegos and Greensill. An investigation into Archegos found no evidence of fraudulent or illegal activity, but highlighted poor risk management practices. Despite this, CEO Thomas Gottstein expressed determination to learn lessons from the incidents.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close higher on upbeat earnings, benign Fed
summary: Japanese shares closed higher on Thursday, driven by strong earnings from Nissan Motor and semiconductor firms. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.73% to 27,782.42, while the Topix index gained 0.41% to 1,927.43. The US Federal Reserve's decision to delay tapering monetary policy support also boosted the market, with Fed chair Jerome Powell stating the US job market still had "some ground to cover" before pulling back on support.

site_title: Didi shares surge after report it's considering going private
summary: Didi Global Inc shares surged 49% in pre-market trading after The Wall Street Journal reported the company is considering going private to placate Chinese regulators and compensate investors for losses. The Beijing-based ride-hailing firm has been in discussions with bankers, regulators, and key investors about resolving its regulatory woes since its troubled listing. A take-private offer could be funded with money from Didi's initial public offering and could involve a tender offer for publicly traded shares, with a potential price around or above its IPO price of $14 per share.

site_title: Singapore shares rise on Thursday amid regional rally; STI up 1.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.2% to 3,180.61 on Thursday, tracking a regional rally. Local bank stocks gained, with DBS, OCBC, and UOB rising 1.4-2.1%. The Monetary Authority of Singapore lifted dividend restrictions, a positive surprise for analysts. Singtel was the top gainer, while Sembcorp Industries was the worst performer. Regional markets also rose, with the Hang Seng Index up 3.3% and the Shanghai Composite Index up 1.5%.

site_title: Shell's profit soars as it boosts dividend and launches buybacks
summary: Royal Dutch Shell's second quarter profit surged to US$5.5 billion, its highest in over two years, driven by a sharp rise in oil and gas prices. The company raised its dividend and launched a US$2 million share buyback program. Adjusted earnings exceeded an average analyst forecast of US$5.07 billion. Shell's CEO, Ben van Beurden, stated that the company is increasing shareholder distributions while investing for the future of energy.

site_title: Nokia lifts full-year forecast as turnaround takes root
summary: Nokia reported a stronger-than-expected second-quarter operating profit of 682 million euros, beating analyst estimates, and raised its full-year outlook due to a turnaround of its business. The company attributed the improvement to shifting geopolitics and cost-cutting measures, gaining ground on rival Ericsson in the 5G rollout race. Nokia now expects full-year net sales of 21.7-22.7 billion euros and an operating profit margin of 10-12%, up from previous estimates of 7-10%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 2.46 points lower at 1,512.93 on Thursday, with 4.476 billion lots traded worth RM2.857 billion. Losers outpaced gainers 636 to 350, as investors reacted to mixed global market trends.

site_title: Panel advises wholesale market to replace SOR exposures by year-end, retail market by October 2022
summary: The Steering Committee for SOR and Sibor Transition to Sora (SC-STS) has recommended wholesale market participants to replace SOR exposures by December 31, 2021, and retail market by October 2022. The wholesale market is advised to use the SOR-Sora basis swap market, which provides market-determined pricing, while retail customers will be offered Sora loans at no additional fee or lock-in. The SC-STS aims to facilitate the industry-wide transition of financial contracts away from SOR by the end of 2024.

site_title: Jump in quarantine orders leaves hundreds anxious and frustrated as protocols come under strain
summary: Singapore's COVID-19 protocols are under strain, with hundreds of residents anxious and frustrated over delayed pickups for quarantine. The number of quarantine orders issued has surged, with over 29,000 issued between July 15-28. More hotels are being contracted by the government to house those in quarantine, with about 70 hotels serving as isolation facilities. Residents have reported difficulties in getting through hotlines and receiving clear instructions, while frontline workers are also showing signs of strain. The government is considering shifting healthcare protocols to focus on vaccination and hospitalization for the very ill.

site_title: Record US$4.9b raised in South-east Asia IPOs in first half of 2021: Bloomberg
summary: South-east Asia saw a record US$4.9 billion raised through initial public offerings (IPOs) in the first half of 2021, with Thailand leading the way with US$2.8 billion. Indonesia ranked third with US$503 million, while the Philippines came in second with US$1.3 billion. Newly-listed firms recorded an average return of 59% in their first months of trading, with the majority using funds to repay debt or loans. The region is poised to resume record bond issuance after the COVID-19 disruption.

site_title: SIA narrows Q1 net loss on higher passenger and cargo volumes
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) narrowed its first-quarter net loss to $409.2 million, down from $1.1 billion a year ago, driven by a 52.2% increase in revenue to $1.3 billion. Passenger traffic rose 9,324% to 362,000, while cargo capacity and loads carried also increased. The airline's operating fleet is one of the youngest in the industry, improving efficiency and lowering carbon emissions. SIA expects passenger capacity to reach 33% of pre-Covid-19 levels in Q2 and 50% by September.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines (SIA) narrowed its first-quarter net loss after a boost in passenger and cargo flown revenue, and the absence of non-cash impairment charges for the NokScoot liquidation.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise with mining, tech in lead
summary: Australian shares rose 0.52% to 7,417.4, driven by miners Fortescue Metals and BHP Group, which jumped 3% and 1.6% respectively. Iress led tech stocks higher after rejecting two takeover bids, while gold stocks rose due to bullion prices. The country's biggest city, Sydney, reported its highest daily Covid-19 cases, but the Australian central bank is likely to reverse its decision to trim bond buying due to the economic impact of virus-led restrictions.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end higher as China stocks rebound
summary: South Korean shares ended 0.18% higher at 3,242.65, driven by China's efforts to calm investor nerves after a recent market rout. The Kospi extended its gains for a third straight session. The Federal Reserve's policy meeting was met with muted reaction, while South Korea's exports were seen growing at a slower pace in July. The won rose 0.71% to 1,146.5 per dollar, and the benchmark 10-year yield increased 2.4 basis points to 1.887%.

site_title: Delta variant drives virus spread to three China provinces
summary: China reported small coronavirus outbreaks driven by the Delta variant in three provinces, with 171 cases detected in Jiangsu province. The outbreak, linked to an eastern airport, has spread to at least four other provinces, challenging China's containment efforts. The Delta variant's large geographical spread is the largest in several months, raising concerns about the country's aggressive containment measures.

images.alt_text: The flare-up, which began after nine workers at the Nanjing airport tested positive on July 20, has seen 171 cases detected in Jiangsu province, while infections have spread to at least four other provinces.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore is set to deploy an AI robot named Oscar to enforce safe distancing at Paya Lebar Quarter (PLQ) 1 and 2 by the fourth quarter of 2021. Oscar will patrol the open plaza area and be able to enforce safe distancing measures, marking the first deployment of an AI robot for this purpose.

site_title: URA awards Lentor Central GLS site to GuocoLand
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has awarded the Lentor Central site to GuocoLand's indirect subsidiary, GLL D Pte Ltd, with a bid of S$784.1 million (S$1,204 per square foot per plot ratio). The 99-year plot, measuring 17,279.9 square metres, will be developed into a 25-storey mixed-use project with around 600 residences, commercial spaces, and childcare facilities. This comes after a tender closed with nine bids on July 22. The site is located next to the upcoming Lentor MRT station on the Thomson-East Coast Line.

site_title: Asia: Markets advance after Federal Reserve meeting, Hong Kong rebounds
summary: Asia markets advanced on Thursday after the Federal Reserve acknowledged the US recovery is well on track but won't taper monetary policy yet. Hong Kong rebounded after China sought to reassure investors over its regulatory crackdown. The Fed maintained its massive bond-buying and record low interest rate scheme, with no decision on tapering expected until the end of the year. Meanwhile, progress in Washington on President Biden's trillion-dollar infrastructure bill boosted traders.

images.alt_text: Tokyo, Sydney, Singapore, Wellington, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta all rose, though Seoul was flat.

site_title: Robinhood, gateway to 'meme' stocks, raises US$2.1b in IPO
summary: Robinhood Markets raised US$2.1 billion in its initial public offering (IPO), valuing the company at US$31.8 billion. The IPO priced at the low end of the company's indicated range, and Robinhood sold 55 million shares at US$38 apiece. The company's monthly active users surged to 21.3 million as of June, and it plans to reserve 20-35% of its shares for users. Robinhood's IPO comes amid concerns over the company's business practices and regulatory probes, including an investigation into potential insider trading and a settlement with the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority.

site_title: Gold hits one-week high after Fed fails to signal taper timeline
summary: Gold prices reached a one-week high after the US Federal Reserve failed to provide a timeline for tapering its pandemic-era monetary policy support, citing the US job market still having "some ground to cover". This led to a 0.5% increase in spot gold to $1,815.56 per ounce, while US gold futures rose 0.9%. The Fed's statement also downplayed the risk of the Delta variant on the economic recovery, supporting gold as a hedge against inflation and currency debasement.

images.alt_text: Gold prices rose to its highest level in over a week on Thursday after the US Federal Reserve failed to give a timeline for its tapering plans and said it was "ways away" from considering raising interest rates.

site_title: Airbus raises delivery and profit forecasts after strong first-half
summary: Airbus has raised its full-year forecasts for deliveries and earnings after reporting strong first-half results. The company now expects to deliver 600 aircraft in 2021, doubling its previous forecast, and predicts 4 billion euros of operating income and 2 billion euros of free cash flow. This is a significant increase from its previous forecast of 566 deliveries and 2 billion euros of operating profit. The improved outlook is attributed to better-than-expected half-year results.

site_title: Keppel Corp interim dividend up 4 times as group returns to profitability
summary: Keppel Corp reported a net profit of S$299.8 million for the first half of the year, reversing a loss of S$537.1 million in the same period last year. The company's operating profit rose to S$188.0 million, driven by revenue growth of 15.5% year-over-year to S$3.68 billion. Positive contributions from the urban development, asset management, and energy and environment segments attributed to the turnaround.

site_title: J&J contractor plans to resume Covid-19 vaccine production at Baltimore plant: WSJ
summary: Emergent Biosolutions Inc, a Johnson & Johnson contractor, plans to resume Covid-19 vaccine production at its Baltimore plant after receiving FDA approval. Production was halted in April due to contamination concerns from AstraZeneca's vaccines. The US FDA and Johnson & Johnson have not commented on the matter.

site_title: 'Freedom Day' was a 'damp squib', says London taxi company
summary: Londoners' interest in returning to offices remains low, with "Freedom Day" earlier this month having little impact on shifting workers. According to Addison Lee, a minicab and courier company, passenger bookings to financial hubs in London recovered less than expected, with City of London bookings at 48% of pre-pandemic levels and Canary Wharf at 32%. Many workers, including those in the financial sector, prefer to continue working from home, citing a need for flexibility and the potential for a pay rise to return to the office full-time.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks surge at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged at the open on Thursday, extending the previous day's gains as Chinese officials reassured investors over the education sector crackdown. The Hang Seng Index rose 2.68%, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices climbed 1.26% and 1.89%, respectively. The gains came despite US tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: China regulator talks to investment banks to calm market jitters: sources
summary: China's Securities and Regulatory Commission held a meeting with top global investment banks to calm market jitters, following a brutal sell-off in shares of Chinese companies after Beijing's rules banning for-profit tutoring in core school subjects were published. The new rules aim to curb competition and raise concerns among investors. The meeting aims to reassure investors and stabilize financial markets, which have been pressured by China's economic slowdown and regulatory changes.

site_title: Certis to deploy AI robot at PLQ to enforce safe distancing
summary: Certis will deploy an AI robot, Oscar, in Paya Lebar Quarter (PLQ) by the fourth quarter of 2021 to enforce safe distancing. The robot can detect and alert on illegally-parked bicycles, fires, people smoking in non-designated areas, and loitering after hours. Oscar will patrol PLQ 1 and 2, as well as the open plaza area. Certis' smart solutions, Security+, have been silently working in retail spaces at PLQ since May 2021.

site_title: Tesla setting up shop at Toa Payoh Lorong 8 property with lease term of up to 20 years
summary: Tesla has leased a 58,743 sq ft property in Toa Payoh Lorong 8 for up to 20 years to house its Singapore showroom, corporate office, and service centre. The lease was acquired by Firmus Capital, a private equity real estate investment manager. This move is seen as a concrete step towards Tesla's entry into the Singapore market, following years of founder Elon Musk's complaints about the authorities being "not supportive."

site_title: Hot stock: Samudera Shipping up 5.9% after posting H1 profit jump
summary: Samudera Shipping's shares surged 5.9% after the company posted a significant jump in its first-half net profit, reaching US$36.7 million. The company attributed the increase to higher freight rates and cost-management measures. An interim dividend of 0.5 Singapore cents per share was also declared, marking a fivefold increase from the previous period. The stock's trading volume reached near its highest level since April 6.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index up 0.63% or 172.60 points at 27,754.26. The gains followed positive news from the US, where the Federal Reserve decided against major changes to its monetary policy, boosting investor confidence in tech shares. The Topix index also rose 0.51% or 9.82 points to 1,929.47.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Thursday amid rally in banks; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.6% in early trade on Thursday, driven by gains from local banks. The Straits Times Index (STI) reached 3,160.79, with 89 gainers and 31 losers. 35.4 million securities worth S$69.4 million changed hands. This marks the fifth consecutive day of gains ahead of GDP data scheduled for release.

site_title: ESR-Reit trustee prices S$125m fixed-rate notes due 2026 at 2.6%
summary: ESR-REIT's trustee priced S$125 million of unsecured fixed-rate notes at 2.6% per annum, the lowest-ever bond coupon. The notes will be issued under the S$750 million multicurrency debt issuance programme and listed on the Singapore Exchange on Aug 5. OCBC is the sole lead manager and bookrunner for the offer. The notes are expected to be issued on Aug 4.

site_title: Australia: Miners, tech firms boost shares
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% on Thursday, led by tech stocks and miners. Fortescue Metals beat its annual forecast with record fourth-quarter shipments and firmer commodity prices, driving the iron ore miner to a 3% gain. Rivals Rio Tinto and BHP also hit all-time highs, with tech stocks advancing 2% and gold stocks climbing 1%. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 7,412.1 points, despite New South Wales recording its biggest daily rise in Covid-19 cases since the pandemic began.

site_title: Broaden and enhance meritocracy to give Singaporeans hope and opportunity: Ravi Menon
summary: Singapore's central bank chief Ravi Menon emphasized the need to refine and enhance the country's meritocracy system to provide Singaporeans with hope and opportunity. The current meritocracy has worked well, but there is a risk of it becoming narrow and rigid. Menon's comments come as he spoke at the Institute of Policy Studies, highlighting the importance of refining the system to ensure it remains inclusive and offers opportunities for all.

site_title: Tencent is world's worst stock bet with US$170b wipeout
summary: Tencent Holdings, a Chinese internet giant, has suffered its worst month ever, wiping out about $170 billion in market value, with shares tumbling 23% in July. The company is a key casualty of China's crackdown on its technology industry, which targets tech behemoths perceived as a threat to data security and financial stability. Despite concerns of further regulatory measures, analysts say the stock is undervalued and could rebound if the company achieves 20-30% growth, with most recommending a "buy" rating.

images.alt_text: China's unprecedented crackdown on its technology industry has turned Tencent Holdings from a market darling into the world's biggest stock loser this month.

site_title: Australia PM says vaccinations alone will not end Sydney's Covid-19 lockdown
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison stated that vaccinations alone cannot end Sydney's Covid-19 lockdown, which has been in place since June 26. With only 17% of people above 16 fully vaccinated in New South Wales, the Delta variant continues to spread, leading to over 2,500 cases and 165 hospitalizations. The lockdown is expected to take a heavy toll on the country's A$2 trillion economy, with many businesses forced to close, raising recession concerns.

images.alt_text: With only about 17 per cent of people above 16 years fully vaccinated in New South Wales state, which Sydney is the capital of, infections have steadily risen despite Greater Sydney being in lockdown since June 26.

site_title: US goods trade deficit widens in June
summary: The US goods trade deficit widened in June, driven by strong economic activity and increased imports. Despite a faster-than-expected recovery from the pandemic, trade remains a drag on growth. The US economy's rebound is attributed to massive fiscal stimulus, low interest rates, and vaccinations against Covid-19. This suggests the second quarter saw trade as a limiting factor to growth.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars lift from one-week lows on benign Federal Reserve
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose against the US dollar on Thursday, reaching a one-week high, after the Federal Reserve expressed confidence in the US economy but indicated rate increases were still far off. The Fed's comments boosted riskier assets, including the Aussie and kiwi dollars. The Australian dollar rose to US$0.7381, while the New Zealand dollar reached US$0.6962. Investors are now focusing on US GDP data and the ongoing COVID-19 lockdown in Sydney, which is expected to impact the country's economy.

site_title: Digital comics platform INKR raises US$3.1m in pre-Series A funding round
summary: Digital comics platform INKR has raised US$3.1 million in a pre-Series A funding round led by Monk's Hill Ventures. The platform, which hosts over 800 manga, manhua, and graphic novels, uses AI tech to streamline content localization and distribution. INKR has grown its monthly active users by 200% since its inception in October 2020 and works with over 70 comic publishers and creators. The funding round is seen as a potential game-changer for the comics industry, enabling creators and publishers to reach a global audience more efficiently.

site_title: Think-tank urges UK government to manage Bank of England debt sales
summary: The UK government should take on hundreds of billions of pounds of hard-to-sell bonds held by the Bank of England to prevent accusations of the central bank being bailed out by the government and to maintain credibility. The National Institute of Economic and Social Research suggests the Treasury could give the BoE short-term bills and gilts in return for less liquid bonds, reducing the risk of interest rate hikes. This plan would disentangle monetary and fiscal policy after the BoE weans the economy off its support.

site_title: Ford posts surprise quarterly profit on rising prices
summary: Ford reported a surprise quarterly profit of $1.1 billion, driven by strong vehicle pricing and robust demand in the reopening economy. Revenues jumped 38% to $26.8 billion, exceeding analysts' expectations. The company cited strong demand for its new Mustang Mach-E and F-150 Lightning models. Ford shares rose 3.9% to $14.40 in after-hours trading, and the company raised key forecasts for the year, expecting increased volume in the second half of 2021.

site_title: SoftBank to offer US$2.1b Uber stake via Goldman: sources
summary: SoftBank is selling US$2.1 billion of its Uber stake through Goldman Sachs, trimming its 184 million-share stake to 139 million shares. The block trade involves selling 45 million shares between US$44.15 and US$46.14 per share, with Uber shares falling 5.1% in post-market trading. The sale comes ahead of Uber's quarterly earnings report on August 4.

site_title: Qualcomm optimistic on 5G, connected device sales as supply bottlenecks ease
summary: Qualcomm reported a 63% increase in total revenues to nearly $8 billion, driven by soaring sales of chips for connected devices, including 5G phones. The company expects sales of those chips to hit $10 billion this fiscal year, with adjusted profits of $8.24 per share. Qualcomm's efforts to mitigate supply bottlenecks are easing, with the first shipments of significant volume expected in the fiscal third quarter. The company's shares rose 3.1% in after-market trading following the results, alleviating concerns about the impact of the global chip shortage on the smartphone market.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed as market digest earnings, Fed decision
summary: US stocks experienced a mixed performance on Wednesday as investors digested strong earnings reports from major companies such as Apple and Alphabet, while also considering the Federal Reserve's accommodative monetary policies. The Nasdaq rallied, while the Dow fell. Investors appear to be pricing in concerns about sustaining growth, with some companies declining despite strong earnings.

site_title: Singapore banks up on MAS lifting of dividend curbs
summary: Singapore banks saw gains on Thursday following the Monetary Authority of Singapore's lifting of dividend payout restrictions. DBS shares rose 1.43% to close at S$30.50, while OCBC shares increased 2.07% to S$12.32. The move is seen as a positive reaction to the MAS's easing of curbs, allowing banks to distribute more dividends to shareholders.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise as earnings lift sentiment
summary: European stocks rose 0.7% on Wednesday, lifting sentiment after strong earnings reports from Barclays and Kering. Barclays jumped 2.0% after beating profit expectations and resuming shareholder payouts, while Deutsche Bank edged up after delivering better-than-expected quarterly profit. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose despite concerns about China's regulatory crackdown.

site_title: Keppel unit divests stake in Chengdu Shengshi Jingwei Real Estate for 1.6b yuan
summary: Keppel Land China will divest 100% of its equity interest in Chengdu Shengshi Jingwei Real Estate for approximately 1.6 billion yuan (S$324 million) through its subsidiary Hillwest. The sale includes a residential development project in Mumashan, Chengdu, China. The divestment is expected to result in a gain of about 668 million yuan for Keppel and is expected to be completed by the second half of 2021.

site_title: Sony says PS5 sales top 10 million as demand surges
summary: Sony Interactive Entertainment announced that PlayStation 5 sales have surpassed 10 million units worldwide since its release in November. Demand for the console continues to outpace supply due to a global computer chip shortage. The company's chief, Jim Ryan, emphasized the need to improve inventory levels to meet growing demand. This milestone marks the fastest-selling unit in US history, with spending on video games in the US reaching $28.9 billion in the first half of the year, a 15% increase from the same period in 2020.

site_title: UK car output up a third after slump but sector warns of chip shortage
summary: UK car production rose by 31% in the first half of 2021 to 498,923 vehicles, a rebound from last year's slump due to the pandemic. Despite protective measures, staffing and supply problems persisted, including a global semiconductor chip shortage. The sector warned that production could remain below 1 million this year due to the chip shortage, and is pushing for more battery gigafactories. Industry body SMMT chief Mike Hawes noted the "unpredictable effect" of the chip shortage on manufacturers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CLCT, Keppel, Keppel Infrastructure Trust, Ascendas India Trust
summary: CapitaLand China Trust (CLCT) announced a 40.1% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for the first half, driven by new contributions from its business park portfolio. Keppel Corp divested a residential development project in China for S$324 million, while Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) reported a DPU of 1.86 cents, despite a 11.2% fall in free cash flow. Ascendas India Trust announced a 4.2 cent DPU for the first six months, down 9% from the previous year.

site_title: Will Powell be reappointed?
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome "Jay" Powell is likely to be reappointed by President Biden despite being a target of attacks by former President Trump, who had threatened to demote or fire him. Powell, a conservative economist, highlighted his independence during his tenure and became a target of Trump's criticism over his monetary policies. Despite Trump's dislike, Powell's reappointment is probable, as he has maintained his independence and aligned with Biden's policies.

site_title: Morgan Stanley raises pay for junior bankers, capital markets employees
summary: Morgan Stanley has raised the base pay for junior bankers in its investment banking and global capital markets division. Starting August 1, first-year bankers will begin at $100,000, and second-year bankers will earn a minimum of $105,000. The raises were announced internally to adjust pay with market conditions, following a review of annual compensation. This move comes weeks after Citigroup announced similar base pay increases for its junior bankers.

site_title: Facebook doubles profit, but sees cooling growth
summary: Facebook reported a 56% increase in profit to $10.4 billion in its second quarter, driven by digital advertising growth, but warned of cooler growth due to regulatory actions and changes to Apple's iPhone operating software. The company's shares fell 4% after the earnings release. Despite this, Facebook's ad revenue is expected to reach over $100 billion annually, and the company is focusing on expanding e-commerce and the "metaverse."

site_title: Oil settles up near US$75; sharp US inventory drop counters virus worry
summary: Oil prices rose near US$75 a barrel on Wednesday, driven by a sharp drop in US crude inventories to pre-pandemic levels. US West Texas Intermediate crude settled up 1% to $72.39, while Brent crude ended the session up 0.4% at $74.74. The US Energy Information Administration reported a 4.1 million barrel decline in inventories, partly due to lower imports and production. Despite rising Covid-19 cases, the market's focus remains on tight supplies, with oil prices up 45% this year.

site_title: Olympics can still showcase Japan's success, despite gloom
summary: The 2020 Tokyo Olympics could still showcase Japan's success despite the pandemic, projecting the country as a respected international leader, technological innovator, and cultural powerhouse. Originally conceived by Shinzo Abe to rejuvenate Japan after two decades of economic stagnation, the games aim to alter a narrative of Japan's declining influence. Japan's long-standing strengths in technology, trade, and climate policy will be highlighted, with a concerted strategy needed to maximize the event's benefits. Japan's reputation can be enhanced, but the country faces the risk of underutilizing the games' potential, as seen in the case of Greece's post-2004 Olympics.

site_title: Apple's Q3 profits nearly double as pandemic drives device sales
summary: Apple's Q3 profits nearly doubled to $21.7 billion, exceeding expectations, driven by strong device sales, particularly iPhones, which rose 50% to $39.6 billion. The company's sales also increased 36% to $81.4 billion, with growth in every geographic area, led by the Greater China region. Apple's gross profit margin reached 43.3%, its largest ever, due to cost savings and a greater reliance on internet-services revenue. However, the company expects slower sales growth in the current quarter due to a global chip shortage affecting iPhone and iPad production.

site_title: Fed to stress patience on scaling back as virus threat lurks
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to emphasize patience on scaling back its massive policy support due to the growing risk posed by the Delta variant. The Federal Open Market Committee is likely to hold interest rates near zero and continue buying bonds at the current $120 billion monthly pace. The committee will focus on a positive outlook for growth and acknowledge higher inflation, with the potential to tweak its inflation language and specifically mention the Delta variant. Fed Chair Jerome Powell is expected to emphasize patience and a commitment to achieving full employment.

site_title: MAS chief on wealth tax, minimum wage, foreign labour and other thorny political issues
summary: MAS chief Ravi Menon has shared his personal views on contentious topics such as wealth tax, minimum wage, and foreign labor in a series of lectures at the Institute of Policy Studies. Menon, who has emphasized that his views are his own and not the MAS or Singapore government's, has expressed support for a possible wealth tax and minimum wage to address inequality. He also highlighted the need for a higher carbon tax to meet climate-change commitments. Menon's comments signal the government's evolving position on these issues and may pave the way for him to become a key thought leader in Singapore.

images.alt_text: In a series of recent lectures as a visiting scholar at a local university's think tank, Ravi Menon has tackled several top issues facing policy makers in the city-state and globally: a possible wealth tax and minimum wage to address inequality; the economic case for foreign labor and immigration; and the need for a higher carbon tax to meet climate-change commitments.

site_title: British house prices fall in July as buyers' tax break is scaled back
summary: British house prices fell 0.5% in July, their first decline since March, due to the scaling back of a coronavirus tax break for buyers. The annual increase slowed to 10.5%, down from 13.4% in June. Despite this, Nationwide's chief economist Robert Gardner expects underlying demand to remain solid, citing improved consumer confidence and low borrowing costs. The market may continue to support prices due to shifts in housing preferences caused by the pandemic, even if unemployment rises.

images.alt_text: In monthly terms, British house prices fell by 0.5% from June, their first fall since March, slowing the annual increase to 10.5% from June's leap of 13.4% which was the steepest rise in 17 years.

site_title: Most economists say inflation won't last, but CEOs beg to differ
summary: Economists and CEOs disagree on the duration of US inflation, with CEOs warning that prices may continue to rise through 2021 and beyond, affecting company margins and profits. The International Monetary Fund believes inflation pressures are transitory, returning to pre-pandemic ranges in 2022. CEOs cite supply-demand mismatches and reopening economies as factors contributing to the surge.

site_title: Regulation needed to weed out 'greenwashing' in funds
summary: Investors in sustainable funds have seen significant growth, with total assets rising 19% to nearly $2 trillion, but concerns over "greenwashing" - false claims of sustainability - are growing. Regulators, such as the European Union's Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation (SFDR), are taking action to weed out greenwashing, with specific rules on sustainability disclosures and penalties for non-compliance. The US Securities and Exchange Commission has also signaled a tougher stance on greenwashing, with an enforcement task force to identify ESG-related misconduct.

site_title: The commodities bull run: not all that glitters is gold
summary: A commodities bull run has driven prices across various product types to unprecedented levels, defying expectations. However, the surge is attributed to a combination of supply disruptions and unexpected demand surges, influenced by global trade changes and shifting consumer behavior. The pandemic exposed supply chain inefficiencies, while the move away from fossil fuels and changes in trade flows have created a perfect storm of scarcity. As the world recovers, supply chain bottlenecks are being addressed, and production capacity is returning, leading to a potential rebalancing of demand and prices.

site_title: US dollar stands firm with Fed decision in focus
summary: The US dollar remained stable on Wednesday, trading at 92.474 after earlier losses, ahead of the Federal Reserve's meeting. The dollar has rallied for a month after the Fed's hawkish shift in June. Analysts expect the Fed to maintain its policy stance due to concerns over transitory inflation and the global recovery. The dollar index moved into positive territory, while the Japanese yen, Swiss franc, and euro held onto gains. The Fed publishes its statement and chair Jerome Powell's news conference later today, with markets awaiting clues on tapering.

site_title: Federal Reserve says US economy showing progress but 'not fully recovered'
summary: The Federal Reserve stated that the US economy is showing progress in its recovery, but not fully recovered. Widespread vaccinations have boosted business activity and employment, particularly in sectors hardest hit by the pandemic. However, the Fed decided not to end its easy money policies, citing that the sectors still need more time to recover. The central bank cut its benchmark lending rate to zero and implemented a massive bond-buying program to provide liquidity during the pandemic.

site_title: CapitaLand China Trust's H1 DPU rises 40.1% to S$0.0423 following mandate expansion
summary: CapitaLand China Trust (CLCT) reported a 40.1% increase in first-half distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0423, driven by a 72.9% rise in distributable income to S$64.1 million. The increase comes despite an enlarged unit base, following the expansion of its investment mandate to include offices, business parks, logistics facilities, data centers, and integrated projects. Gross revenue grew 74.2% to S$176.9 million, while net property income (NPI) increased 84.4% to S$120.3 million.

site_title: Confusion reigns as Singapore's electricity spot prices spike
summary: Singapore's electricity spot prices have surged, with market players baffled by the sudden spike. Prices have risen significantly in the last two days, potentially affecting business margins of electricity retailers and leading to "bill shocks" for consumers. Experts attribute the unusual trend to the current global energy market conditions, with fluctuations in oil prices and tariffs affecting energy costs.

images.alt_text: The surge in electricity prices coincided with a planned "gas curtailment" of 16-20 per cent on Tuesday, which market players were notified about over the weekend, a key executive of a power firm told BT.

site_title: Pasir Ris 8 frenzy raises policy risks for developers even as they eye richer margins
summary: Pasir Ris 8, a 99-year leasehold site in Singapore, has seen 415 units sold in just one weekend, with prices ranging from S$1,400 to S$2,000 per square foot. The frenzy has raised concerns about policy risks for developers, who may be tempted to push prices higher in anticipation of government intervention. The OCR segment, which caters to many HDB upgraders, is likely to be closely monitored by authorities, and some experts warn that aggressive price hikes could prompt the government to introduce property cooling measures.

site_title: Singapore real estate agencies may consolidate further: IREUS
summary: Singapore's Big Four real estate agencies are likely to attract more salespeople, while smaller agencies face higher attrition rates and costs. The industry's consolidation trend is expected to continue, according to the Institute of Real Estate and Urban Studies (IREUS). This could lead to increased competition among the remaining agencies, potentially preventing oligopolistic manipulation. The trend is driven by salespeople seeking better opportunities, with smaller agencies struggling to retain talent.

site_title: Britain's climate getting warmer, sunnier and wetter: Met Office
summary: Britain's climate has warmed, with the country experiencing its third warmest year on record in 2020, according to a report by the Met Office. Temperatures have risen nearly a degree over the past 30 years, while precipitation has increased by 6 degrees. The year was also the fifth sunniest on record and the eighth wettest. Experts warn that extreme weather events will increase due to global warming, and the UK is set to host the UN's Climate Change Conference COP26 in November to make more ambitious commitments to achieve net zero emissions by 2050.

images.alt_text: Recent decades in Britain have been warmer, wetter and sunnier than in the last century, with last year the third warmest on record, a report by climate scientists said on Thursday.

site_title: Deutsche Bank lifts revenue target after riding out fixed-income slump
summary: Deutsche Bank raised its revenue target for 2022 after beating analyst estimates in fixed-income trading, despite a 11% slump in the second quarter. The bank scrapped a cost target due to unexpected expenses, including a court-voided fee increase and increased business volumes. Despite this, Deutsche Bank's fixed-income traders outperformed Wall Street peers, with revenue exceeding 25 billion euros, driven by a strong performance in credit trading. The bank's CEO, Christian Sewing, is nearing the end of a four-year turnaround plan.
