GM claims Ford's system is less advanced and could tarnish its Super Cruise brand. Ford calls the claim "meritless and frivolous," noting that "cruise" is a common term for automated driving systems. The dispute comes as automakers compete to deploy hands-free driving technology.

site_title: 6.7-magnitude quake hits Philippines
summary: A 6.7-magnitude earthquake struck the Philippines on Saturday, causing no damage due to its deep depth of 112 kilometers. The quakes occurred in the same region, with a 5.8-magnitude quake shortly after. Local authorities and residents were prepared for the earthquakes, with some reporting minor shaking and no damage. The Philippine seismological agency and US Tsunami Warning System did not issue any warnings. The country is prone to earthquakes due to its location on the Pacific "Ring of Fire".

site_title: Surprise swimming wins for Tunisia, Japan
summary: Tunisia's 18-year-old Ahmed Hafnaoui stunned swimming superpowers with an incredible win in the men's 400m freestyle, while Japan secured its second Olympic gold with Yui Ohashi's victory in the 400m women's medley. The wins were a surprise on a dramatic Sunday in Tokyo, where the shadows of the pandemic continued to hang over the Games. The International Olympic Committee emphasized the importance of masks at medal ceremonies amid Covid-19 cases, and temperatures soared above 30 degrees Celsius in Tokyo.

images.alt_text: Japan secured its second Olympic gold with Yui Ohashi's victory in the 400m women's medley.
Japanese tennis superstar Naomi Osaka, who lit the Olympic cauldron last Friday at the opening ceremony, won her first match against China's Saisai Zheng.

site_title: South Korean TV apologises over opening ceremony broadcast
summary: A South Korean TV network, MBC, has apologized for using offensive and inaccurate images and captions during the Tokyo 2020 opening ceremony, describing Italy with a pizza image, Ukraine with the Chernobyl disaster, and other countries with incorrect or derogatory terms. The network acknowledged the mistake and apologized to the affected countries and viewers. The incident has sparked criticism online, but MBC has taken responsibility for the error.

site_title: Deal to create US$22b German property giant stumbles
summary: Germany's Vonovia warned that it likely didn't secure enough shareholder backing for its $22 billion takeover of Deutsche Wohnen, with only 47.6% of shares tendered. The deal needs 50% support to proceed, and a final result is due Monday. The proposed merger would create Europe's largest property giant, with 550,000 apartments. Despite executives' assurances that the deal would provide affordable housing, tensions over soaring rents ahead of German general elections in September have complicated the process. Vonovia will now "carefully consider all options available to it".

site_title: Jubilee Industries to raise up to S$3m in proposed placement, warrant issue
summary: Jubilee Industries Holdings has entered conditional placement letters with seven individuals to raise up to S$3 million through the issue of shares and warrants. The seven placees will subscribe to 30 million shares at S$0.05 each, a 5.66% discount to the counter's volume weighted average price. The funds will be used for general working capital purposes. CEO Terence Tea stated that the placement will strengthen the company's financial position and enable it to capitalize on growth opportunities as demand recovers from Covid-19.

site_title: ECB lifts Covid-era curbs on banks' dividends
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has lifted pandemic-era restrictions on banks' payouts to shareholders, ending its recommendation that banks limit dividends beyond September 2021. The ECB urged eurozone lenders to remain prudent in their dividend decisions, citing potential risks from further pandemic fallout. The move comes as the eurozone recovery gains momentum, and other central banks, including the US Federal Reserve and Bank of England, have also recently lifted their Covid-era restrictions.

site_title: Tokyo Olympics open to a sea of empty seats
summary: The 32nd Summer Olympics opened in Tokyo with a largely empty stadium, hosting fewer than 1,000 dignitaries and guests due to the ongoing pandemic. The ceremony featured a mix of traditional Japanese culture and modern performances, including a rendition of "Imagine" and appearances by Angélique Kidjo, John Legend, and Keith Urban. Despite efforts to project a message of peace and global harmony, the event was met with protests outside the stadium and criticism of the organizers' handling of the pandemic and scandals. The Games will proceed with over 11,000 athletes from 205 countries competing in 33 sports over the next two weeks.

site_title: Japan's hikers return to Mount Fuji
summary: Japan's iconic Mount Fuji reopened to hikers after a year due to the coronavirus pandemic. Over 100 people gathered at the summit, eager to catch the sunrise above the clouds. Climbers praised the mountain's majesty and spiritual significance, with some using the challenge as a personal growth experience. However, the climb comes with risks, and the mountain is only accessible from early July to September. Despite the dangers, many hikers are flocking back to the mountain, which is a symbol of Japan and a popular attraction for athletes during the Tokyo Olympics.

site_title: Almost 50% more BTO projects launched in mature estates in 2020 than 2017: HDB
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has launched 13 Build-To-Order (BTO) projects in mature estates, a 50% increase from 2017, with an average application rate of 6.7 times. The demand for BTO flats in mature estates has risen due to marriage and family formation, changing lifestyles, and social aspirations. Flats in mature estates attracted higher interest rates, with some projects drawing almost 50 applicants per unit. HDB plans to build more BTO flats in prime areas and maintain a steady supply, with about 17,000 units to be launched this year.

images.alt_text: In a May launch, Telok Blangah Beacon attracted almost 50 applicants for each of its 70 four-room flats, despite its high starting price and a waiting time of more than five years for the project to be completed.

site_title: PropertyGuru agrees to go public through US$1.78b deal with Peter Thiel SPAC
summary: Singapore's online real estate firm PropertyGuru agreed to go public through a merger with Bridgetown 2 Holdings, backed by billionaires Richard Li and Peter Thiel, for US$1.78 billion. The combined entity will have a market value of US$1.78 billion, with a PIPE investment of US$132 million from investors including Baillie Gifford and REA Group. PropertyGuru has benefited from a pandemic-induced real estate boom in Singapore and expanded to Southeast Asia, making it the largest real estate marketplace in the region.

site_title: Nasa selects SpaceX for mission to Jupiter moon Europa
summary: NASA has selected SpaceX to launch the Europa Clipper mission to Jupiter's icy moon Europa in October 2024. The $178 million contract will use a Falcon Heavy rocket, replacing the Space Launch System (SLS) due to delays and cost overruns. The mission will make 40-50 close passes to determine if Europa could harbor life, using cameras, spectrometers, and radar to study its surface and atmosphere. This is a significant win for SpaceX, marking its entry into deeper solar system missions.

site_title: Spain banking on Apple to invest in AI and video production
summary: Spain's Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez expects Apple to increase investments in the country, particularly in artificial intelligence and television production. Sanchez met with Apple CEO Tim Cook, saying Apple will be a key player in developing Spain's audiovisual hub. Spain aims to create jobs in green energy and technology with EU aid, and the government plans to inject 1.6 billion euros into the audiovisual sector by 2025. This move comes as Netflix opens its first European production hub in Madrid, and companies like Volkswagen and IBM also plan to invest in Spain.

images.alt_text: Spain's Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez said he's expecting Apple Inc to ramp up investments in his country after meeting with chief executive officer Tim Cook at the company's headquarters on Friday.

site_title: Interactive mobile game to encourage empathy and dismantle stereotypes
summary: A new interactive mobile game, To Be You, launched in Singapore to encourage empathy and dismantle stereotypes. The game features two characters, Nadia and Amandeep, from different ethnic and religious backgrounds, who face unique challenges and pressures. Through their stories, the game aims to promote understanding and acceptance. Debuting on Racial Harmony Day, the game's release is part of efforts to foster inclusivity and unity in the country.

site_title: Gold heads for first weekly fall in five on US dollar strength
summary: Gold prices are expected to decline for the first time in five weeks due to the strengthening US dollar, making bullion more expensive for holders of other currencies. The US dollar index hovered below a 31/2 month peak, leading to a second straight weekly rise. Despite lower US bond yields, gold remains range-bound, with inflation expected to support prices in the near term. The European Central Bank pledged to keep interest rates at record lows, offering some respite to gold prices.

site_title: Company acquisitions in focus as directors reduce transactions
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) gained 0.6% over four trading sessions from July 16 to 22, while the FTSE China A50 Index, Hang Seng Index, and FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI averaged a 0.6% decline. Institutions were net sellers of S$11 million, with Singapore Airlines, UOB, and DBS recording the highest net institutional outflow. The Hour Glass conducted share buybacks, buying back 2.219 million shares at an average price of S$1.43 per share. Companies like Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, Prime US Reit, and ComfortDelGro Corporation made significant acquisitions, while Fu Yu Corporation acquired Avantgarde Enterprise for US$4.5 million.

images.alt_text: The manager of Prime, KBS US Prime Property Management, has announced the completion of the acquisitions of One Town Center in Boca Raton Florida (above) and Sorrento Towers in San Diego's Technology Hub, California.

site_title: Judge grants US FTC more time to file amended complaint against Facebook
summary: A US judge granted the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) an extension until August 19 to file an amended complaint in its antitrust lawsuit against Facebook Inc. The initial deadline was July 29, but the FTC requested a three-week extension. The FTC's new complaint will address concerns about Facebook's monopoly power in the social networking market. The agency had previously voted 3-2 to file the lawsuit, with the current chair, Lina Khan, having taken office after the initial vote.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: UG Healthcare Corporation resumed 60% of its workforce capacity in Seremban, Malaysia, following the end of an enhanced movement control order. Far East Group plans to diversify into farming, storage, and distribution of fresh produce through a 20% stake in Australia-based Comfresh Group Holdings. TeleChoice International expanded its product range to include health tech wearables and lifestyle products.

site_title: Jam City ends SPAC deal that would have made US$1.2b firm
summary: Mobile entertainment company Jam City has terminated its planned merger with special purpose acquisition company DPCM Capital, valued at $1.2 billion, due to current market conditions. The deal, which would have included the acquisition of Montreal-based game publisher Ludia, was called off after Jam City's CEO, Chris DeWolfe, stated the company had proven its ability to grow and acquire new companies in-house. Jam City will continue to explore merger targets and has a multiyear game development agreement with Walt Disney Co.

site_title: Pentagon says report on US-approved DJI drones 'inaccurate'
summary: The Pentagon stated that a report claiming US-approved DJI drones were "no malicious code or intent" and "recommended for use" by government entities was inaccurate and uncoordinated. The Defense Department is reviewing the unauthorized release of the report.

images.alt_text: The Pentagon said on Friday that drones produced by Chinese manufacturer Da Jiang Innovations (DJI) pose a potential threat to national security and that a media report that they were approved for purchase by the US government was inaccurate.

site_title: SingPost to begin trial of electric motorcycles
summary: SingPost, a Singaporean mail and logistics company, is set to begin using electric motorcycles for mail delivery. The company will receive two Iona Rap electric tricycles, each with a cargo capacity of up to 50kg, and capable of covering up to 120km on a single charge. The move aims to reduce the company's environmental impact and is part of its goal to cut greenhouse gas emissions by 35% by 2030. The trial is seen as a step towards exploring alternative fuel options and potentially integrating more electric vehicles into its fleet.

site_title: Gold dips as yields perk up, dollar strengthens
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $1,802.78 per ounce, heading for a weekly dip, as a stronger dollar, firmer yields, and rising equity markets eroded its appeal. Fears over the Delta variant have eased, prompting investors to move out of the safe-haven asset. A stronger dollar index and firmer Treasury yields weighed on gold, while technical traders are taking over due to the lack of fundamentals. Market focus now turns to the US Federal Reserve meeting next week.

site_title: Workspace sees some signs of recovery in demand in London
summary: Workspace, a UK office space provider, reported a 1.1% increase in London occupancy to 82.7% in Q2, despite rents still being under pressure. The company saw a 2.4% decline in average rent per square foot and reported its first annual loss in 12 years. However, average monthly enquiries from potential customers nearly doubled to 947, indicating improving demand. Industry analysts believe strong signs of London businesses returning to work, despite uncertainty from the Delta variant.

site_title: Green shift stokes demand for high-grade iron ore
summary: A global commodity boom, driven by supply crunch, China's steel appetite, and an infrastructure-led economic recovery, is fueling demand for high-grade iron ore, also known as "green" iron ore. The Singapore Exchange's commodities futures market has seen a surge in trading, with nearly 80,000 lots traded in high-grade iron ore swaps last month. Experts predict the iron ore market will continue to rise, driven by robust infrastructure spending and decarbonisation efforts, with prices reaching a record high of above US$230 a tonne in May.

site_title: US celebrity chefs to pay US$600,000 settlement over sexual harassment
summary: US celebrity chefs Mario Batali and Joseph Bastianich agreed to pay $600,000 to 20 former employees who were subjected to a hostile work environment due to sexual harassment allegations. The allegations, which included unwanted advances and explicit comments, were found to be true in a four-year investigation. The settlement requires Batali and Bastianich to revise training materials, submit biannual reports, and certify compliance with the agreement. The allegations against Batali, who had previously apologized and taken a sidelines role, are the latest in a series of accusations against him.

site_title: Europe: Auto rally, corporate earnings push shares to record highs
summary: European stocks reached record highs on Friday, with the Stoxx 600 index rising 1.1% to 461.75. The rally was driven by optimism over earnings season and the European Central Bank's pledge of continued monetary support. Automakers were the top gainers, up 2.5%. This marks the biggest weekly gain since early May, with the index also up 1.5% for the week.

site_title: Outlook remains challenging for retail space even as rental decline slows
summary: Singapore's retail rental decline slowed to 0.5% in Q2, compared to a 4.4% drop in Q1. Despite this, the outlook remains challenging due to secondary Covid flare-ups. The retail vacancy rate in the central region increased to 10.4% from 10.2% in Q1. However, the future supply of retail space is manageable, and demand for prime spaces may ease downward pressure on rents. The islandwide retail vacancy rate remained at 8.5%.

site_title: Businesses welcome fresh relief measures, but fear 'stopgap' help will come too late
summary: Singapore has announced S$1.1 billion of support for struggling businesses, including wage subsidies under the enhanced Jobs Support Scheme. However, experts warn that this relief may be insufficient, as businesses fear further restrictions could be implemented. The government's measures are seen as a "stopgap" to alleviate the impact of the pandemic, leaving concerns over the long-term viability of businesses. The government's support aims to stabilize the economy, but the extent of its effectiveness remains uncertain.

site_title: US: Dow ends above 35,000 for first time as stocks hit records
summary: US stocks reached record highs, with the Dow closing above 35,000 for the first time. The Dow Jones Industrial Average surged 0.7% to 35,061.55, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also finished at records, rising 1% each. This follows positive earnings reports earlier in the week. The strong performance is expected to continue next week with more blowout earnings anticipated.

site_title: How nations are learning to 'let it go' and live with Covid
summary: Nations are gradually easing COVID-19 restrictions as more transmissible variants emerge, with countries like Singapore, England, and Germany adopting a "soft suppression" approach by focusing on severe illness rather than infections. Officials acknowledge that rolling lockdowns and restrictions are necessary for recovery, and scientists warn that premature exit strategies may put unvaccinated people at risk. As the pandemic continues, countries are learning to "live with the virus" and prioritize severe illness over infections, with the long-term effects of COVID-19 still unknown.

site_title: What we'll discover when this NFT art project is over
summary: English artist Damien Hirst's latest project, The Currency, combines physical and digital art forms, featuring 10,000 unique hand-painted sheets and corresponding NFTs. Collectors can choose to own either the physical or digital version, with the other being destroyed. The project challenges traditional notions of money and art, highlighting the social and cultural aspects of value and ownership. By creating a fungible currency with unique markings, Hirst questions whether traditional economics' concept of fungibility holds true. The project aims to show how value is assigned by cultural communities, rather than solely by economic factors.

site_title: Electric air taxi startup Joby to add LinkedIn co-founder, Google exec to boar
summary: Electric air taxi startup Joby Aero Inc has added LinkedIn co-founder Reid Hoffman and executives from Google and Toyota to its board ahead of a planned US$6.6 billion reverse merger with special purpose acquisition company Reinvent Technology Partners. The combined company, Joby Aviation, is expected to go public in the second quarter and operate electric aircraft as part of an air taxi service starting in 2024. The deal is led by Hoffman and also includes Google General Counsel Halimah DeLaine Prado and Toyota Motor Corp board member James Kuffner.

site_title: Fireworks light up Tokyo skyline as Olympics finally begin
summary: The Tokyo Olympics officially began with a simple ceremony, marking the first time the Games have taken place without spectators due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. A moment of silence was held to honor those lost to the virus, and athletes paraded into the stadium wearing face masks. The ceremony featured a video recap of Japan's path to the Games and the challenges the world has faced since the selection of Tokyo as host in 2013. The Olympics will run until August 8, with around 11,000 athletes from 204 national Olympic committees participating.

images.alt_text: Singapore's flagbearers are badminton player Loh Kean Yew and table tennis player Yu Mengyu. The stadium was almost empty due to Covid curbs.

site_title: iFast reports 55% jump in Q2 net profit, raises interim dividend
summary: iFast Corporation reported a 55% increase in Q2 net profit to S$7 million, driven by higher revenue and increased assets under administration (AUA). Revenue rose 31.7% to S$50.8 million, and AUA reached a record S$17.54 billion, up 57.3% year-over-year. The company declared an interim dividend of 1.10 cents per share, a 46.7% increase over the previous year. iFast expects its business to show healthy growth in 2021 and plans to increase its dividend payout.

site_title: S$1.1b package to aid workers, businesses hit by tighter Covid-19 measures
summary: Singapore has introduced a S$1.1 billion support package to aid workers and businesses affected by the country's return to Phase 2 (Heightened Alert). The package includes enhanced Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) for affected sectors, rental relief for tenants, and targeted support for taxi and private hire car drivers. The measures aim to help businesses and workers "tide through this heightened alert period." The support package will be funded by reallocations from underutilisation of funds due to Covid-19 and fiscal resources set aside earlier.

site_title: The relentless pursuit of better investment options (Part II)
summary: A Singapore-based wealth advisory firm, Providend, has successfully onboarded institutional share classes of iShares index funds for its clients. The funds are significantly cheaper than their ETF counterparts, with costs ranging from 50% to less than a third of the ETF prices. The onboarded funds also offer tax advantages under the Undertakings for the Collective Investment in Transferable Securities (UCITS) regulation. This marks a significant milestone for Providend, which has been pursuing low-cost and better-performing investment options for its clients, having previously courted Vanguard funds but was unsuccessful.

site_title: Sales of electric cars charge ahead in Europe
summary: Electric vehicles have significantly boosted their market share in Europe, with battery electric vehicles more than doubling their share of new car sales in the second quarter. Sales of all-electric vehicles increased to 7.5% of new car sales, while sales of battery electric vehicles tripled to 210,298 cars. The European Commission's plans to ban new petrol and diesel vehicle sales by 2035 are expected to drive this trend, with many automakers shifting to all-electric vehicles. Hybrid sales also rose, with plug-in hybrids increasing by 255.8% and conventional hybrids by 300%.

site_title: Singapore office rents continue to rise in Q2
summary: Office rents in Singapore continued to rise in Q2, despite a contraction in net office demand and rising vacancies, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority. The median rental for Category 1 office buildings increased 1.1% quarter-over-quarter, while Category 2 office space saw a 1% decline. Analysts attribute the rise to a "flight to quality" by smaller occupiers seeking better locations and quality. The office vacancy rate in Downtown Core climbed to 12.8% and is expected to strengthen on the back of global economic recovery and Singapore's reputation as a safe office location.

site_title: Nightlife body proposes 'three-ring approach' to take industry out of rough water
summary: The Singapore Nightlife Business Association (SNBA) has proposed a "three-ring approach" to address the industry's challenges amid the pandemic. The first ring aims to eliminate unlawful KTV operators and impose stricter penalties, while the second ring provides support to establishments that have pivoted to the F&B sector. The third ring focuses on rebuilding and revitalizing the industry, including pilots for live entertainment and longer hours, with plans to develop a framework for nightlife operators and reinforce surveillance measures.

site_title: Bank of Singapore's Lim Li Li stays on top of her game with Pilates
summary: Bank of Singapore's Lim Li Li credits Pilates for improving her back pain, building core strength, and enhancing her golf and cycling techniques. After incorporating Pilates into her routine 10 years ago, she now practices three to four times a week and has seen significant benefits, including improved balance, muscle control, and overall well-being. As a busy executive, Lim Li Li finds Pilates helps her stay energized and focused, making her better equipped to manage her demanding job.

site_title: Sinopharm's Covid-19 shot offers weaker protection among elderly
summary: A Hungarian study found Sinopharm's Covid-19 vaccine offered weaker protection among the elderly. The study of 450 participants showed 90% of those under 50 had measurable antibody levels, but the protection reduced with age. At 60, about 25% of participants had no antibody response, and at 80, about 50% had no response. The study's results have not been peer-reviewed and were published on medRxiv.

site_title: Protest breaks out at prison in Myanmar's biggest city
summary: A protest erupted at Myanmar's Insein Prison in Yangon, the country's commercial capital, against a worsening Covid-19 outbreak at the jail, where opponents of the military takeover are held. The protest, supported by some prison staff, began with chants against the ruling junta and resulted in a negotiation that accepted the prisoners' demands. Diplomats called for a peaceful resolution, while the military had confiscated staff weapons and claimed the situation had been brought under control.

site_title: F&B groups petition government for greater support and to collaborate on decisions
summary: Food and beverage groups in Singapore are petitioning the government for greater support, including mandated rental relief, to aid businesses struggling during the COVID-19 pandemic. The groups, which represent over 500 restaurants, urge the government to extend Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) measures to foreign workers and to consider a 75% subsidy for businesses that have weathered three phases of no-dine-in rules. They also request easing of rules to allow fully-vaccinated individuals to dine in and a collaborative approach to future decisions.

images.alt_text: A number of groups representing food and beverage establishments, some with members on the brink of closure, are calling on the government to provide additional relief in the form of support for foreigners employed in the industry, and a seat at the table in future decision-making that impacts the beleaguered industry.

site_title: New York hotels see busiest week since pandemic hit: Mayor de Blasio
summary: New York City has seen a significant increase in hotel room bookings, with over 481,000 room nights sold last week, a 17,000 increase from the previous week. This marks the busiest week since the pandemic hit, with demand rising 22% for visits to the Statue of Liberty. Despite this, the city's hotel industry remains depressed, with nearly 100 hotels closed for tourism and occupancy rates at 63% for open hotels. Experts predict a gradual increase in demand but warn of a potential downturn after Labor Day.

site_title: Oil edges up in weekly rebound on forecasts for tight supplies
summary: Oil prices edged up on Friday, rebounding from a steep slide, as supply is expected to remain tight throughout the year. Brent crude rose 31 cents to $74.10 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude gained 16 cents to $72.07 a barrel. The price increase follows concerns over the impact of the Covid-19 Delta variant on crude demand. Oil prices had fallen earlier in the week due to worries about the economy and the variant's impact.

site_title: HDB resale prices rise 3% in Q2, transactions fall amid Covid-19 curbs
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore rose 3% in Q2, marking the fifth consecutive quarter of growth. Despite a 6.8% decline in resale transactions, the market remains strong, with demand outstripping supply. Analysts expect prices to rise further, with construction delays and limited supply contributing to the trend. The number of transactions is still higher than pre-pandemic levels, with over 14,000 resale flats transacted in the first half of the year.

site_title: US lawmakers urge IOC to delay or move China's 2022 Winter Olympics
summary: US lawmakers, including Democrats and Republicans, urged the International Olympic Committee to delay or relocate the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics unless China addresses human rights concerns, particularly the alleged genocide against Uyghurs and other Muslim minority groups. The lawmakers, commissioners on the Congressional-Executive Commission on China, expressed concern over the IOC's lack of action to pressure the Chinese government to change its behavior. They called for the Olympics to be held in a country that does not commit genocide and crimes against humanity.

site_title: Still a Stinger missile
summary: The Kia Stinger GT has undergone a mid-life update with a new exterior design and upgraded infotainment system, featuring a 10.25-inch touchscreen and Android Auto/Apple CarPlay. The car remains a grand tourer with a comfortable and spacious interior, and its 3.3-litre V6 engine produces 365hp, allowing it to reach a top speed of 270km/h. The GT model offers a smooth and cultured driving experience, with features such as a blind spot monitor and camera system, and a Sport mode that adjusts the driver's seat for a more immersive experience. Despite its powerful capabilities, the Stinger GT is considered a bargain compared to German rivals.

site_title: Bitcoin hovers around US$32,000 after boost from big names
summary: Bitcoin hovered around US$32,000 after a 6.5% rebound fueled by comments from Elon Musk, Jack Dorsey, and Cathie Wood. The comments provided comfort to the markets, but the long-term direction remains uncertain. Despite a decline in value since mid-May, Bitcoin has found support at key levels, including its 55-week moving average. Analysts differ on the token's potential, with some predicting a fall to US$15,000 and others seeing a sustainable break above US$32,000.

site_title: SGX to leverage tech, synergies across FX portfolios with MaxxTrader acquisition
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has acquired MaxxTrader, a single-source and direct-to-market foreign exchange (FX) trading platform, for US$125 million. The acquisition will broaden SGX's customer base to over 200 institutional clients and allow the bourse operator to leverage MaxxTrader's technology to set up an "end-to-end" FX electronic communications network. The combined FX franchise's average daily volume will exceed US$75 billion, cementing FX as a core pillar of growth for SGX. The acquisition is expected to be accretive to adjusted earnings per share from the first year.

site_title: China to clamp down on for-profit tutoring
summary: China is cracking down on its private tutoring industry, turning it largely into a not-for-profit sector, and restricting foreign investment. The policy change, announced by the State Council, bars institutions offering school curriculum tutoring from raising capital and investing in listed companies. Foreign investors are also barred from investing in curriculum-based tutoring businesses through mergers and acquisitions. The move is expected to decimate the $120 billion private tutoring industry, with shares of major tutoring firms plummeting.

site_title: I'm tired of being cynical. I'm watching the Olympics
summary: The author reflects on their past admiration for Olympic athletes, who embodied human achievement and triumph, despite the Games' controversies. This year's Tokyo Olympics, marred by corporate greed, climate decay, racial inequity, and pandemic risks, has led to criticism and cynicism. However, the author argues that the athletes themselves remain inspiring, and watching them overcome adversity can be a source of collective inspiration, particularly in a time of global uncertainty. By focusing on the athletes, rather than the institution, the author suggests that it's possible to still enjoy and appreciate the Olympics in good faith.

site_title: Singapore Week of Innovation and Technology activities to be spread over a year
summary: Singapore's Week of Innovation and Technology (SWITCH) will now span a year, offering monthly opportunities for businesses, innovators, and investors to participate in deal-making, networking, and innovation globally. The event, organized by Enterprise Singapore, aims to help businesses build networks and uncover innovation opportunities worldwide. This year's event will be a hybrid mix of virtual and physical events, with a focus on sustainability and climate change. The government encourages local SMEs and startups to participate in innovation challenges to capture new opportunities and respond to future challenges.

site_title: Far East Group proposes diversification into fresh produce business
summary: Far East Group, a CATALIST-listed company, plans to diversify its core business into the fresh produce industry through a 20% stake in Comfresh Group Holdings, an Australia-based firm. The company will fund the A$7.3 million (S$7.32 million) subscription through internal resources. The move aims to broaden revenue streams and reduce reliance on its core refrigeration and air-conditioning business. The proposed subscription will be subject to shareholder approval at an extraordinary general meeting. This diversification follows similar moves by other SGX-listed companies in the fresh produce or grocery segments.

site_title: GM recalls Chevrolet Bolt EVs again following battery fires
summary: General Motors is recalling its 2017-2019 Chevrolet Bolt EVs for the second time due to battery fires. The recall is caused by the simultaneous presence of two rare manufacturing defects in the battery cell, prompting the company to replace battery modules. The issue is a concern as the company transitions to its new Ultium battery, which is more advanced than those in old Bolt models. This is the second recall in less than a year, highlighting ongoing challenges in the auto industry's shift to electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: General Motors is recalling its 2017-2019 model year Chevrolet Bolt battery-powered cars for the second time in less than a year, after two vehicles that had been repaired in a previous recall caught fire.

site_title: KPMG's banking audits not up to scratch, says UK watchdog
summary: The UK's Financial Reporting Council (FRC) has found that KPMG's audits of banks needed improvements for the third consecutive year, with nearly one-third of audits still requiring improvement. The FRC closely monitors the accounting firm, which has agreed to additional improvement activities. Other accountants, BDO and Mazars, also face improvement measures. The findings pile pressure on the government to propose legislation to address corporate governance and audit market issues, following the collapse of retailers BHS and Carillion.

images.alt_text: KPMG's audits of banks needed improvements for the third year running and the accounting firm will be closely monitored, Britain's auditing watchdog said on Friday in its annual check of leading accountants.

site_title: US business activity cools further in July
summary: US business activity cooled in July, with the manufacturing and services sectors growing at a moderate pace, according to IHS Markit's flash US Composite PMI Output Index. The index fell to a four-month low of 59.7, below economists' expectations. Supply constraints and labour shortages are driving inflation, but signs suggest inflation may be peaking. The economy remains supported by strong demand and a labour market recovery, but the Delta variant could lead to consumer caution. Growth estimates for the second quarter are converging around a 9.0% annualized rate.

site_title: From Toa Payoh to Orlando, Singapore wrestler lives WWE dream
summary: Sean Tan, a 25-year-old Singaporean wrestler, has achieved his dream of becoming a WWE professional wrestler. Tan, who trained with Singapore Pro Wrestling (SPW) before joining WWE in 2019, impressed WWE officials with his in-ring abilities and was offered a contract. He relocated to Orlando, Florida, in April 2022 to pursue his WWE career, but the COVID-19 pandemic initially delayed his move. Tan's short-term goal is to make his WWE debut, while his long-term goal is to compete at a pay-per-view event and win a WWE Championship.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 1.45% on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index closing at 27,321.98, due to concerns over China's crackdown on the tech sector. The Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.68% and the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 1.43%. Investors struggled to maintain the previous day's rally, weighing on tech firms.

site_title: Sizing up Audi's new A3
summary: Audi's new A3 Sportback receives a muscular makeover and features a new engine. The car's impact on the motoring world is significant, as it influenced the design of the BMW 1 Series and Mercedes A-Class. Audi's decision to create the A3 Sedan, which competes with Japanese saloons, has led to a shift in consumer behavior, with many opting to upgrade to a smaller Audi rather than a larger model from the same manufacturer. The updated A3 Sportback is expected to continue Audi's success in the market.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's government has announced a $1.1 billion Covid-19 support package to aid workers and businesses affected by tightened measures. Private home prices rose 0.8% in Q2, and office rent increased 1.3% in the central region. Consumer prices rose for the sixth straight month, with inflation forecasted to be 1-2%. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has acquired MaxxTrader, expanding its customer base to over 200 institutional clients. The Straits Times Index closed flat on Friday amidst virus jitters.

site_title: Explaining the rise and fall of WeWork
summary: The Cult of We: WeWork, Adam Neumann, and the Great Startup Delusion explores the rise and fall of WeWork, a company that marketed itself as a tech enterprise despite renting office space to freelancers and entrepreneurs. Co-founder Adam Neumann's ego and greed led to his downfall, transforming what was once a promising startup into a symbol of the "Great Startup Delusion." The book delves into the events that led to WeWork's public collapse in 2019 and its current state, offering a cautionary tale of the dangers of unchecked ambition and the consequences of prioritizing ego over business sense.

site_title: Singapore shares end week mostly unchanged amid virus jitters
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index closed flat on Friday, ending the week mostly unchanged, amid concerns over rising coronavirus cases and tighter restrictions. Consumer prices rose 2.4% for the sixth consecutive month, slightly short of expectations. Despite this, analysts like Jeffrey Halley remain optimistic about Singapore's vaccination program, which could enable the city-state to outperform its peers in Q4. The top gainers included J36 and AIY, while conglomerates like V03 and C31 were among the biggest losers.

site_title: MCT reports 22.9% increase in NPI amid higher revenue
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) reported a 22.9% increase in net property income (NPI) to S$96.9 million for Q1 FY21/22, driven by lower rental rebates and compensation from a pre-terminated lease. Gross revenue rose 23.7% year-on-year to S$124.1 million. The trust's recovery momentum was dampened by Covid-19 measures, but it has rolled out rental assistance. MCT's properties, except for Mapletree Business City, recorded higher year-on-year contributions to NPI, with VivoCity seeing a significant improvement.

site_title: Eurozone businesses boomed in July but confidence weakened
summary: Eurozone businesses expanded at their fastest monthly pace in over two decades in July, driven by the loosening of COVID-19 restrictions and pent-up demand. The IHS Markit's Flash Composite Purchasing Managers' Index rose to 60.6, its highest reading since 2000, ahead of the 50-mark separating growth from contraction. However, business confidence weakened due to concerns over the spread of the Delta variant and the risk of another wave of infections, with the composite future output index slumping to 67.8.

site_title: MAS expected to stand pat on Singdollar policy in October despite raising headline inflation forecast
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is expected to maintain its neutral Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate (S$NEER) setting in October despite a raised headline inflation forecast of 1-2% for the year. Core inflation, a key price gauge, remains unchanged at 0-1%. Analysts attribute the unchanged forecast to subdued private consumption due to stricter Covid-19 restrictions and the ongoing uncertainty over the virus's virulence.

site_title: More rental relief for eligible SMEs, non-profit organisations in commercial properties
summary: Singapore's government has introduced additional rental relief measures for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and non-profit organizations in commercial properties. The relief is part of a S$1.1 billion support package to cushion the impact of re-tightened Covid-19 measures. Eligible tenants will receive an additional four weeks of rental waiver in government-owned properties and two weeks in privately-owned properties. The measure aims to ensure fair burden sharing between the government, landlords, and tenants.

site_title: Athletes parade in empty stadium as Tokyo Games open
summary: The Tokyo Olympics opened with a simplified ceremony, featuring athletes from around the world parading into the empty stadium, wearing masks and mostly represented by both male and female flagbearers. The event marked a global coming together, with an audience of hundreds of millions tuning in, despite the COVID-19 pandemic and strict social distancing rules. The ceremony included fireworks, traditional Japanese elements, and nods to equality and justice, while also acknowledging the challenges the world has faced since the Games' selection in 2013.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index falling 4.18 points to 1,523.44. Volume reached 5.416 billion lots worth RM3.207 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 559 to 443.

site_title: 130 new locally transmitted Covid-19 cases including 78 linked to Jurong Fishery Port
summary: Singapore reported 130 new locally transmitted COVID-19 cases on July 23, including 78 linked to the Jurong Fishery Port cluster, bringing the total to 638. Six new cases were linked to the KTV cluster, and 29 were unlinked. Two seniors over 70 years old with no vaccination status were among the unlinked cases. Three imported cases were also reported, with two developing symptoms during stay-home notice or isolation. The total number of cases in Singapore now stands at 63,924.

site_title: SIA Engineering records 35.5% increase in net profit for Q1
summary: SIA Engineering Company reported a 35.5% increase in net profit for its first quarter, reaching S$14.5 million, driven by higher revenue and government support grants. Revenue rose to S$125.3 million, up from S$118.5 million in the prior year. Despite a slower pace of recovery due to COVID-19 restrictions, the company's flight activities are increasing, with a 97% year-on-year increase at its Singapore base. The group expects a sustained recovery to be uncertain, with no immediate increase in flight frequencies expected.

site_title: Iswaran to oversee more aspects of tourism portfolio; travel by year-end still a possibility
summary: Transport Minister S Iswaran will oversee more aspects of Singapore's tourism portfolio to align regulations and policies between the tourism and aviation sectors. Overseas travel by the end of this year may still be possible as more countries open their borders and vaccination rates increase. Plans include raising confidence in hosting large-scale events and marketing Singapore as a MICE destination to rebuild interest. The Singapore Tourism Board is also working on safe travel requirements, including "safe itineraries" for group travellers, to ensure visitor safety while keeping the industry resilient.

site_title: Myanmar to use Chinese vaccines to fight Covid-19 in border area
summary: China is delivering 2 million Covid-19 vaccine shots to Myanmar to combat a growing outbreak in the border area, which has also seen a spike in cases in southern China's Yunnan province. Myanmar reported 6,701 new cases and 319 deaths, both record highs, amid concerns of a far higher toll. The outbreak has also linked to new cases in China's Yunnan province.

site_title: Tokyo Olympics cases jump as Games start, with athletes infected
summary: Tokyo Olympics organisers reported a record 19 new daily coronavirus infections linked to the Games, including three athletes, bringing the total to 110. The infections, mostly among athletes and staff, have raised concerns about the event triggering more infections and introducing variants. Despite vaccination rates in Japan being lower than other developed countries, the Olympics are proceeding without spectators. The surge in cases has prompted a fourth state of emergency in Tokyo, with the city reporting 1,979 new infections on Thursday.

site_title: Brokers' Take: CGS-CIMB, Jefferies, OCBC optimistic about Suntec Reit's office portfolio
summary: Brokerages CGS-CIMB, Jefferies, and OCBC have maintained a "buy" rating on Suntec Reit, citing optimism about its resilient office portfolio, driven by high occupancy rates and demand from tech and asset managers. However, the retail portfolio is seen as less rosy due to re-imposed Covid-19 restrictions and higher expiring rents in 2022. Analysts expect rental reversions in the retail segment to be between negative 15 to 20% for the full financial year.

site_title: Singapore inflation forecast raised to 1-2% as consumer prices climb again in June
summary: Singapore's inflation forecast has been raised to 1-2% for 2021, with headline inflation remaining stable at 2.4% in June. Consumer prices rose for the sixth straight month, driven by higher transport and housing costs. Core inflation, excluding transport and accommodation costs, fell to 0.6% in June, below forecasts. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry attributed the forecast increase to uncertainty in the economic outlook and rising external inflation.

site_title: Andrew Lloyd Webber opens Drury Lane theatre after US$80m revamp
summary: Andrew Lloyd Webber re-opens Theatre Royal Drury Lane in London after a two-year, $80-million restoration project. The historic theatre, known as "The Lane," boasts a revamped auditorium, swanky staircases, and an all-day dining area. The venue, which dates back to the 17th century, will now be open all day, not just for performances. The restoration aimed to honor the building's history and was completed with the help of his wife Madeleine. The theatre officially reopened with a ceremony led by Prince Charles and Camilla last month, with "Frozen The Musical" set to open in late August.

site_title: Crypto crackdown: Malaysian police steamroll Bitcoin machines
summary: Malaysian police seized over 1,000 Bitcoin-mining machines worth an estimated RM5.3 million (S$1.7 million) and crushed them using a steamroller in a crackdown on energy theft. Eight people were arrested for allegedly stealing US$2 million worth of electricity to power the devices. The arrests follow regular reports of police seizing crypto-mining rigs in the South-east Asian nation. The process of Bitcoin mining requires vast amounts of energy and processing power, but can be lucrative, with each Bitcoin currently worth more than US$32,000.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares tick up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on Friday, extending the previous day's rally, as Wall Street edged towards a new record. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.06% to 27,740.95, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up. The gains were attributed to healthy earnings results and traders' optimism despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher on earnings optimism
summary: South Korean stocks closed higher on Friday, building on the previous session's gains, driven by earnings optimism and positive cues from Wall Street. The Kospi index rose 0.13% to 3,254.42, with internet giants Naver and Kakao jumping 2.73% and 1.36%, respectively. However, chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix slid 0.50% and 0.84%. Foreigners were net sellers, and the won weakened, falling 0.08% to 1,150.8 per dollar.

site_title: SkillsFuture to roll out training courses with Johnson Controls, Ngee Ann Poly
summary: SKILLSFUTURE Singapore (SSG) is partnering Johnson Controls and Ngee Ann Polytechnic to roll out two new courses under the SGUnited Jobs and Skills Package. The first course, "SGUnited Mid-Career Pathways Programme - Company Training for Digital Transformation in the Built Environment," will equip mid-career jobseekers with digital and smart facilities management skills. The second course, "Global Tech Talent Programme," will focus on digitalisation and internationalisation, providing skills for roles such as software engineer and full-stack developer. Both courses are subsidised and offer employment facilitation, with registrations set to open in the third quarter of this year.

site_title: Philippines approves GMO 'golden rice' for commercial production
summary: The Philippines has become the world's first country to approve genetically modified "golden rice" for commercial production. Enriched with the vitamin A-precursor beta-carotene, the rice aims to combat childhood blindness and save lives in developing countries. After a two-decade development process, the rice is expected to be grown by farmers across the country, with "limited quantities" of seed to be distributed to selected provinces next year. The approval paves the way for the rice to be declared safe as ordinary rice, and its development is seen as a significant step in addressing vitamin A deficiency, which affects up to 500,000 cases of childhood blindness annually.

site_title: Eyeing IPO, Geely's Volvo Cars swings to profit in H1
summary: Volvo Cars, owned by Geely Holding, reported a profit of 13.24 billion crowns (S$2.07 billion) in the first half of the year, reversing a loss of 989 million crowns in the same period last year. The company attributed the improvement to a strong market recovery from the pandemic and growing demand for electric cars. Volvo Cars' sales rose 41% to 380,757 cars and its second-half outlook remains unchanged, with flat sales and revenue growth year-on-year. The Swedish automaker is considering an initial public offering (IPO) later this year.

site_title: Australia's Lorna Jane activewear fined A$5m for misleading Covid-19 claims
summary: Australia's Lorna Jane activewear has been fined A$5 million for making misleading Covid-19 claims about its garments. The company claimed its LJ Shield Activewear range "eliminated", "stopped the spread" and "protected wearers" against the coronavirus, but a judge labelled the claims "exploitative, predatory and potentially dangerous". The fine was imposed by an Australian court after the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) sued the company last year. The misleading claims were made on in-store signs, the website, social media, emails, and media releases.

site_title: Three charged with false trading of former mainboard-listed Raffles United
summary: Three former executives of Raffles United Holdings, a former mainboard-listed company, have been charged with false trading under the Securities and Futures Act. The executives allegedly inflated the share price between 2016 and 2018 through trades, including cross trades with each other. They face up to 7 years imprisonment and fines of up to SGD 250,000 if convicted. The charges follow an investigation by the Commercial Affairs Department in 2018.

site_title: Australia: Shares end at record high on healthcare, tech boost
summary: Australian shares closed at a record high, with the S&P/ASX 200 index settling 0.1% higher at 7,394.4. Gains in healthcare stocks (1.3% rise) and tech stocks (nearly 1% gain) outweighed losses in financial and energy firms. The index had fallen as much as 0.2% earlier in the session but recovered for a fourth positive finish in five sessions, marking a 0.6% weekly gain. New Zealand's NZX 50 index also rose 0.5% for its second positive session in three.

images.alt_text: Australian shares closed at a record high after a choppy afternoon trade on Friday, as gains in healthcare and tech stocks slightly outweighed losses in financial and energy firms.

site_title: Flexing a 4-day week to work the right way
summary: A journalist experimented with a 4-day workweek for 8 weeks, taking Fridays off, to boost productivity and work-life balance. Despite initial challenges, they found that setting clear expectations and boundaries helped maintain focus and reduce stress. Data from a large Asian IT company also showed that employees were less productive at home, with a 20% decrease in productivity and more time spent on meetings. The journalist's experience and the study's findings suggest that flexibility in scheduling can be beneficial for employees, allowing them to recharge and be more productive on lighter days.

site_title: Twitter beats revenue targets with ad improvements, shares jump 5%
summary: Twitter reported higher-than-expected revenue growth, driven by ad targeting improvements, and shares rose 5% to $73. The platform has introduced new products, including audio-only chat rooms and newsletter publishing, to boost revenue. Twitter aims to double annual revenue by 2023.

site_title: Europe: Upbeat earnings put stocks on track for weekly gains
summary: European stocks rose 0.4% on Friday, tracking gains from the previous week, driven by upbeat earnings and the European Central Bank's monetary support pledge. Automakers, such as Valeo and Dassault Aviation, were top gainers, while early sector activity readings are expected to show a slight decline from June's strong numbers.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 0.4 per cent by 7.19am GMT to trade at over one-week high.

site_title: Magna's US$3.8b Veoneer buy to drive car safety business
summary: Magna International agreed to buy Swedish auto parts maker Veoneer for approximately $3.8 billion in cash to bolster its driver assistance technology for autonomous vehicles. Veoneer's advanced driver assistance systems will help Magna compete with market leaders Aptiv, Bosch, and Continental. The acquisition is expected to save Magna around $100 million annually by 2024, expand its customer base, and provide access to new regions. The deal will also enable Magna to become a fourth leading player in the industry.

site_title: Brokers' take: Phillip initiates 'buy' on Koda amid furniture demand boom
summary: Phillip Securities has initiated a "buy" call on furniture maker Koda, expecting its net profit to almost double in FY2021 due to increased demand for home furniture. Analyst Vivian Ye set a target price of S$1.32, representing a 50% potential upside. Koda's shares rose 10.6% to 88.5 Singapore cents, trading at seven times expected earnings.

site_title: Malaysia apologises for 'human error' over empty Covid jab
summary: Malaysia has apologized for a "human error" in its national COVID-19 vaccination rollout, where one person was injected with an empty syringe and two others received extra doses due to confusion. The error occurred in the northern state of Kedah, and disciplinary action will be taken against the nurse. The government has also taken steps to prevent similar errors, including allowing recipients to record their vaccination process. Despite 13 police reports lodged on the matter, most have been found to be false or inconclusive, and the country continues to push to fully vaccinate all adults by October.

images.alt_text: Malaysia has confirmed one case of an individual being injected with an empty syringe in its national vaccination rollout, categorising it as a human error.

site_title: Taxis and tuk-tuks come to a standstill after Thai virus surge
summary: Thailand's tourism-dependent economy is suffering its worst crash since the 1997 Asian financial crisis due to a surge in COVID-19 cases. Taxis and tuk-tuks have come to a standstill, with over 100,000 people in the transport sector unemployed. The government has approved $920 million in funding for affected businesses, but critics say more needs to be done. The pandemic has forced residents to stay home, with a night-time curfew and ban on gatherings in place. The industry's decline is also attributed to the highly contagious Delta variant sweeping through the country.

site_title: HDB resale prices rise 3% in Q2, transactions fall amid Covid-19 curbs
summary: Resale prices for Housing Board flats in Singapore rose 3% in Q2, the fifth consecutive quarter, despite a decrease in transactions due to tightened Covid-19 measures. Property analysts predict further price increases as demand outstrips supply, partly due to delays in new flat completions.

images.alt_text: HDB resale volume shrank 6.8 per cent over the previous quarter, amid phase two (heightened alert) measures, when households were allowed to receive only two unique visitors each day.

site_title: SGX to leverage tech, synergies across FX portfolios with acquisition of MaxxTrader
summary: SGX to acquire MaxxTrader, a single-source and direct-to-market FX trading platform, expanding its customer base to over 200 institutional clients and increasing its average daily volume to over US$75 billion. The acquisition will allow SGX to leverage MaxxTrader's technology to set up an "end-to-end" FX electronic communications network, cementing foreign exchange as a core pillar of growth for the bourse operator.

images.alt_text: The acquisition of single-source and direct-to-market FX trading platform MaxxTrader will further cement foreign exchange as a core pillar of growth for SGX under its multi-asset strategy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.85 points, or 0.06%, to 1,526.77. The market saw 295.04 million lots traded worth RM166.95 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 238 to 172.

site_title: Ant-backed Zomato soars in India market debut to US$12b valuation
summary: Zomato, a food delivery firm backed by China's Ant Group, made its stock market debut in India, valuing the company at approximately US$12 billion. The company's shares soared 82.8% in its first trading day, exceeding the IPO price of 76 rupees. Zomato operates in 525 Indian cities, partnering with 390,000 restaurants and offering home delivery, dining-in reservations, and restaurant reviews. Despite a narrow profit, the company's exponential growth is expected to continue, positioning it as a competitor to SoftBank-backed Swiggy and Amazon's food delivery service.

site_title: Philippines to bar travel from Malaysia, Thailand to curb Delta variant's spread
summary: The Philippines has announced a travel ban from Malaysia and Thailand to curb the spread of the highly transmissible Delta Covid-19 variant. The ban, which takes effect on July 25 and runs to July 31, is the country's latest measure to prevent the spread of the virus. This ban joins a previous restriction on travelers from eight countries, including Indonesia and India. The move aims to protect the country's population from the highly contagious variant.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts raise targets for ARA Logos after Australia portfolio acquisition
summary: Analysts at RHB, DBS, and CGS-CIMB have raised their target prices for ARA Logos Logistics Trust, citing strong demand for logistics assets and the trust's growing portfolio. The trust reported a 10.6% increase in distribution per unit and a 15.2% rise in revenue, driven by its Australian portfolio acquisition. Analysts predict a potential rise in units to S$1, and believe the trust's improved valuation will make it easier to acquire yield-accretive properties.

site_title: Asia: Markets struggle to match Wall Street gains as rally fades
summary: Asia's markets struggled to match Wall Street's gains, closing in the red despite healthy corporate earnings and optimism over economic recovery. The Delta variant cast a shadow on trading floors, with some governments reimposing lockdowns or containment measures. Analysts remain hopeful that the latest stumble will give way to gains as more vaccines are administered. The European Central Bank pledged to maintain ultra-loose monetary policies until March 2022, boosting European markets.

site_title: Israel in cold war over Ben & Jerry's ice cream ban
summary: Ben & Jerry's has announced it will no longer sell its ice cream in the Israeli-occupied Palestinian territories, citing the occupied West Bank and East Jerusalem as the reason. Israeli Prime Minister Naftali Bennett has vowed to fight the decision, threatening to use "all tools at its disposal." The move has sparked a political storm, with many Israelis supporting local ice cream makers and calling for a boycott of Ben & Jerry's. The Israeli government has long opposed the BDS movement, which advocates for boycotts of Israel over its treatment of Palestinians.

site_title: Taiwan to ease Covid-19 restrictions as cases drop
summary: Taiwan is set to ease Covid-19 restrictions starting next week, with the government citing rapidly falling case numbers. The restrictions, which include gathering limits and restaurant take-out service, were implemented in mid-May and have been partially eased this month. The current level 3 alert is due to end on July 26, with some restrictions remaining in place. The move comes as Taiwan's case numbers continue to decline, giving authorities confidence to further lower the alert level.

site_title: Villagers flee fresh floods in central China as typhoon approaches
summary: Flooding in central China's Henan province has left at least 33 dead and millions affected as a typhoon approaches. Villagers were evacuated on makeshift bridges as rivers burst their banks, inundating farmland and cutting off towns. Firefighters continue to pump muddy water from tunnels, including a subway where a dozen people drowned. Over 28,000 people are being evacuated, with authorities warning of a major weather event as Typhoon In Fa is expected to make landfall. The floods are seen as a test of China's preparedness for freak weather events, which experts say are happening with increased frequency and intensity due to climate change.

site_title: Gold steady as lower bond yields negate pressure from firm dollar
summary: Gold prices steadied at $1,806.08 per ounce, as lower US bond yields countered a stronger dollar's pressure. Spot gold hit a one-week low of $1,791.16 on Thursday. Weak economic data, including a rise in US unemployment claims, also weighed on gold. Despite a stronger dollar, lower interest rates made gold more attractive, with the European Central Bank pledging to keep interest rates low to boost sluggish inflation.

site_title: Europe: Dovish ECB, upbeat earnings support stocks
summary: European stocks rose for a third session, driven by the European Central Bank's pledge to keep interest rates at record lows, and strong corporate earnings. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.6%, with travel and leisure stocks leading sectoral gains. Earnings reports from EQT and ABB also boosted the market, while Unilever's warning on commodity costs weighed on the sector. The ECB's decision and earnings optimism supported the recovery trade, despite concerns about inflation and a resurgence in virus cases.

site_title: New Zealand suspends quarantine-free travel with Australia
summary: New Zealand has suspended its quarantine-free travel arrangement with Australia for at least eight weeks due to Australia's outbreak of the highly infectious Delta virus variant. This decision, made by Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern, aims to keep New Zealanders safe. The "travel bubble" had already been paused for travelers from New South Wales, Victoria, and South Australia.

site_title: S$1.1b Covid-19 support package to aid workers, businesses hit by tighter measures
summary: Singapore has launched a S$1.1 billion support package to aid workers and businesses affected by Phase 2 (Heightened Alert) measures. The Job Support Scheme will be enhanced to 60% for sectors where activities will be suspended, and 40% for other significantly affected sectors. The package also includes rental relief, a cash assistance fund for hawkers and market stallholders, and additional support for food delivery and driver relief. The measures will run from July 22 to Aug 18, with some support continuing until Sept 30.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed for holiday on Friday
summary: Japan's financial markets are closed on Friday for a public holiday. Meanwhile, Singapore's stocks have seen a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the STI rising 0.4% on Thursday. US stocks, including the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, have also reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views. Additionally, eSIM platform Airalo has raised $220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past $1 billion.

site_title: Controversial Alzheimer's drug has already yielded US$2m in sales
summary: Biogen's Alzheimer's drug Aduhelm has generated $2 million in sales in its first few weeks of availability, despite being priced at $56,000 annually. Fewer than 100 patients have been treated, with a "big chunk" of revenue coming from stockpiled inventory. The drug's release has been slower than anticipated due to complexities in administering the monthly intravenous infusion. Medicare plans to review coverage of the drug, which has sparked scrutiny over its effectiveness and price. The drug's approval has also raised questions about the close collaboration between Biogen and the FDA.

site_title: Airport echoes with sobs and farewells in Hong Kong exodus
summary: Hong Kong's airport is witnessing a mass exodus of residents, with around 1,500 leaving daily via London flights, as they flee the city's increasingly authoritarian rule under China's tightening grip. Many are taking advantage of Britain's offer to settle with British National Overseas (BNO) passports and their relatives. The departures are driven by concerns over education, social atmosphere, and human rights, with some fearing brainwashing and others seeking freedom. The UK expects 300,000 Hong Kongers to move there over the next three years, estimated to bring a net benefit of up to £2.9 billion.

site_title: Uber buys trucking software firm for US$2.25b
summary: Uber has acquired Texas-based Transplace for $2.25 billion to strengthen its freight unit. The combined entity will create a comprehensive transportation and logistics network. Transplace's logistics management software will be integrated with Uber Freight, enhancing the platform's capabilities. The acquisition aims to bolster Uber's presence in the industry and provide a competitive advantage.

site_title: Singapore Q2 private home prices up 0.8%, easing from 3.3% growth in prior quarter
summary: Singapore's private home prices rose 0.8% in Q2, easing from a 3.3% growth in the prior quarter. The return of tightened restrictions may hit new home sales, but analysts expect 10,000+ units sold this year. Overall home price growth is forecasted to be 5-9% for 2021. Landed property prices declined 0.3%, while non-landed home prices rose 1.1%. Rents of private homes climbed 2.9% in Q2, with vacancy rates dipping to 6.3%. The resale market saw a 63% increase in transactions, driven by delayed new launches and construction disruptions.

site_title: Intel sales forecast implies rocky second half of 2021 amid supply constraints
summary: Intel forecasted annual sales of $73.5 billion, beating Wall Street expectations, but its guidance implied a weak fourth quarter due to supply chain constraints. The company's shares fell 2.8% after-hours trading. Intel has been better able to weather supply chain woes than some rivals and is expanding its "foundry" business, making chips for others. Despite this, the forecast suggests a rocky end to 2021.

site_title: EU appeals 250m euro Amazon court ruling
summary: The European Commission has appealed a court ruling that annulled an order requiring Luxembourg to recoup 250 million euros in back taxes from Amazon. The EU claims the General Court made errors in its judgment, despite finding no selective advantage was given to Amazon. The case now goes to the European Court of Justice, a setback for EU competition supremo Margrethe Vestager, who previously accused Luxembourg of giving Amazon illegal state aid.

site_title: Singapore retail property rents, prices continue to slide in Q2
summary: Singapore retail property rents and prices continued to decline in the second quarter, with the Urban Redevelopment Authority's rental index falling 0.5% and price index easing 2.8% quarter-over-quarter. The amount of occupied retail space increased by 14,000 sq m, while the stock of retail space grew by 18,000 sq m, resulting in an unchanged islandwide vacancy rate of 8.5% at end-Q2 2021.

site_title: Australia's Star Entertainment withdraws A$9b bid for Crown Resorts
summary: Star Entertainment Group has withdrawn its A$9 billion proposed takeover of Crown Resorts due to concerns that Crown may lose its Melbourne casino licence, which could impact the deal's value. The decision comes after an inquiry found Crown's Melbourne casino should be stripped of its licence due to insufficient efforts to reform its culture and stamp out money laundering. This is the second inquiry into Crown's Perth and Sydney casinos, with findings expected later this year.

site_title: Spacing Pfizer Covid-19 shots boosts antibody levels after initial drop: study
summary: A British study found that spacing Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine doses leads to higher overall antibody levels, with a longer gap between doses resulting in better protection against the Delta variant. However, there's a sharp drop in antibody levels after the first dose. The study's findings may inform vaccination strategies against the Delta variant, which reduces vaccine effectiveness after a single dose.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS positive on Sabana Reit's newly completed NTP+, ups TP to 49 S cents
summary: DBS has upgraded its target price for Sabana Reit to S$0.49, citing the completion of retail mall NTP+ as a growth driver, with increased growth estimates of 18.4% and 5.3% for FY2021 and FY2022, respectively. The research team expects NTP+ to add around S$3.5 million to the Reit's revenue and boost occupancies and rental reversions. DBS also notes potential upside from asset enhancement initiatives and the removal of Shari'ah compliance requirements.

site_title: The importance of being Agile
summary: The Agile method has revolutionized software development over the past 20 years, shifting from the traditional Waterfall approach to an adaptive model of incremental development cycles. By starting with a product goal without detailed specifications, Agile allows for regular product increments through short cycles of planning, coding, testing, and integration. This approach fosters close collaboration and interaction between parties, enabling businesses to deliver quality software in shorter timeframes, such as 18 weeks, compared to 18 months with traditional methodologies.

site_title: JPMorgan to double advisers as Wall Street vies for wealthy
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co plans to double its advisers in its traditional broker business to 1,000, aiming to expand its wealth management unit amid intense competition for rich clients. The bank will hire over 500 advisers and try to knit the unit closer to retail branches. This move comes as banks compete aggressively to serve America's multi-millionaires and billionaires, with Citigroup expanding its wealth management offerings and Deutsche Bank adding private bankers. The effort will be led by Phil Sieg, a former Bank of America executive.

site_title: Half of Europeans vaccinated as Germany warns on rising virus cases
summary: More than half of European adults are fully vaccinated, with 200 million Europeans receiving the jab, according to the EU. However, cases are rising in several countries, including Germany, where Chancellor Angela Merkel warned of exponential growth and potential reintroduction of measures. The Delta variant is driving the increase, with the European Central Bank keeping its stimulus in place to prevent economic uncertainty. The WHO has called for an audit of the Chinese lab at the origin of the virus, sparking a response from Beijing.

site_title: Australia's drug regulator approves Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine for 12 to 15-year-olds
summary: Australia's Therapeutic Goods Administration has approved Pfizer's Covid-19 vaccine for use with 12 to 15-year-olds. This decision follows similar clearances in the US, EU, and Britain. The approval is part of Australia's efforts to combat the Delta variant outbreak in three states. The vaccine's safety and efficacy have been thoroughly assessed, paving the way for its administration to this age group.

site_title: URA office rent index for central region up 1.3% q-o-q in Q2; islandwide vacancy rises to 12.6%
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority's office rent index for Singapore's central region rose 1.3% in Q2 2021, while the price index increased 0.9%. The islandwide vacancy rate climbed to 12.6%, up from 11.9% in Q1. The amount of occupied office space shrank by 23,000 sq m, while the stock of office space grew by 34,000 sq m, contributing to the vacancy rate increase. The total supply of office space in the pipeline decreased to 697,000 sq m, lower than the previous quarter.

images.alt_text: The Urban Redevelopment Authority's rental index for office space in Singapore's central region rose 1.3 per cent in the second quarter of this year over the previous quarter.

site_title: Oil up US$1.50/barrel as demand recovery seen tightening supply
summary: Oil prices rose about $1.50 a barrel on Thursday, extending gains on expectations of tighter supplies through 2021 as economies recover from the coronavirus crisis. Brent crude settled at $73.79 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate at $71.91 a barrel. Despite Opec+ agreeing to boost oil supply by 400,000 barrels per day, demand is expected to outstrip supply in the second half of the year, with Morgan Stanley forecasting Brent prices in the mid to high-$70s per barrel for the remainder of 2021.

site_title: Brookfield weighs purchase of Germany's Alstria Office
summary: Brookfield Asset Management is exploring a potential takeover of Alstria Office Reit-AG, a German real estate firm, as it bets on workers returning to city centers. The Canadian investment firm already holds 8.35% of the company, valued at approximately 3.3 billion euros. A takeover would be the largest take-private transaction in Germany this year. Brookfield's move follows other real estate titans' bets on workers returning to business hubs after pandemic concerns wane.

site_title: Hamptons home prices surge to a record as pickings get slimmer
summary: Hamptons home prices reached a record high of $1.405 million in the second quarter, a 30% increase from last year, according to a report by Miller Samuel Inc. and Douglas Elliman Real Estate. The median price is the highest since 2005, with 21% of sales exceeding the asking price. Available listings plummeted 43% to 1,081 homes, and it would take 4.8 months to clear the inventory at the current sales pace, the fastest in data going back to 2006. The surge in demand is attributed to post-Covid life and the appeal of suburban living.

site_title: SGX to buy FX trading platform MaxxTrader for US$125m
summary: SGX to acquire FX trading platform MaxxTrader for US$125 million. The acquisition aims to build an integrated FX ecosystem and marketplace, facilitating global access to over-the-counter trading and on-exchange currency derivatives. MaxxTrader has an average daily volume of over US$17 billion and a strong sell-side client base. The acquisition is expected to be accretive to adjusted earnings per share for year one and is expected to be completed by December 2021.

site_title: Two Chinese 'agents' charged in US for targeting Beijing opponents
summary: The US Justice Department indicted two alleged Chinese agents, part of the "Fox Hunt" operation targeting Beijing's opponents in the US. Nine defendants are now charged with acting as unregistered agents of China. This follows the October arrest of five individuals accused of threatening, harassing, and intimidating a Chinese target living in the US. The indictment marks the latest move by the US government to crack down on China's alleged espionage activities in the country.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SGX, ESR-Reit, FCT, SATS, Trendlines Group
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean stocks saw significant developments on Friday. ESR-Reit reported a 14.3% rise in distribution per unit to 1.554 Singapore cents for the half year ended June 30, 2021. SGX acquired MaxxTrader for US$125 million, while Frasers Centrepoint Trust maintained stable retail portfolio occupancy at 96.4%. SATS reported a net profit of S$6.4 million for the first fiscal quarter, thanks to government reliefs. Trendlines Group dropped its plan for a dual primary listing due to unfavorable market conditions. The Singapore stock market remained positive, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Trendlines shelves plans to dual-list on Tel Aviv bourse
summary: Trendlines Group, an Israel-based company, has dropped its plan for a dual primary listing and securities offer on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange (TASE) due to unfavorable economic and capital market conditions. The decision was made following a further assessment of factors affecting the company's growth and long-term shareholder value. Trendlines will continue to explore opportunities to enhance shareholder value, but will not proceed with the proposed listing at this time.

site_title: ESR-Reit H1 DPU up 14% to 1.554 Singapore cents
summary: ESR-Reit reported a 14.3% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.554 Singapore cents for the half-year ended June 30, 2021. Gross revenue rose 5.4% to S$119.8 million, driven by lower property expenses and no Covid-19 rental rebates. Net property income grew 8.4% to S$87 million, and total income available for distribution increased 18.7% to S$56.8 million.
