site_title: KTV and Jurong Fishery Port Covid-19 clusters linked: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Ong Ye Kung announced that two active Covid-19 clusters, at KTVs and the Jurong Fishery Port, are linked. The clusters differ genetically from the Delta variant but are closer to Indonesian cases. As of July 18, there were 173 KTV cases and 42 Jurong Fishery Port cases. The government expects more reported cases and will take decisive actions to suppress the cases. Studies are ongoing to establish the relationship between the clusters.

site_title: Temasek-backed SenseTime launches AI innovation hub in Singapore
summary: SenseTime, a Temasek-backed AI company, has launched its international AI innovation hub in Singapore. The hub, located at Frasers Tower, focuses on segments including augmented and mixed reality, education, healthcare, and customer engagement. The company, which has over 100 employees in Singapore, plans to expand its team regionally, aiming to triple its headcount to 300 within three years. This move marks a significant expansion for SenseTime, which has established itself as a major player in the AI industry.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: How to turn your passion project or side hustle into an ESG business (Ep 99)
summary: A recent episode of BT Money Hacks podcast, hosted by Chris Lim, discusses turning a side hustle into an ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) business. The episode features Helga Angelina, founder of Burgreens and Green Rebel, who shares her experience. The conversation focuses on the disruption caused by the Covid-19 pandemic and how to monetize side hustles while incorporating ESG principles. The episode aims to provide useful financial tips for listeners, but advises that any investment decisions should be made after consulting a financial adviser.

site_title: Sustainable finance booms in H1 2021: Refinitiv data
summary: The sustainable finance market experienced record levels in the first half of 2021, with equity capital markets activity for sustainable companies reaching US$23.2 billion, a 300% increase from 2020. Debt capital markets saw sustainable finance bonds totaling US$551.6 billion, a 76% year-over-year increase, and green bond issuance reached US$259.3 billion, nearly triple the amount in the previous year. M&A activity involving sustainable companies also reached a record high of US$84.3 billion, with China accounting for 26% of total sustainable deal-making activity.

site_title: Gold edges up on Delta virus threat, lower US bond yields
summary: Gold prices edged higher, lifting to US$1,812.83 per ounce, as US Treasury yields retreated and concerns about the Delta virus threat dampened global economic recovery. Despite a modest gain, gold's appeal was limited by a stronger US dollar. Benchmark 10-year Treasury yields hit a near two-week low, reducing the opportunity cost of holding non-interest bearing gold. Inflows into gold-backed ETFs remained steady, leaving room for a potential price rise.

site_title: Hot stock: CapitaLand shares rise 1.8% on updates to restructuring plans
summary: CapitaLand shares rose 1.8% on Monday after the company's management provided updates on its restructuring plan. The new unit, CapitaLand Investment (CLI), aims to achieve S$100 billion in funds under management by 2024 and grow its lodging business to 160,000 units by 2023. An independent financial adviser has deemed the plan "fair and reasonable," boosting investor confidence. The restructuring plan, which includes a listing of CLI, is expected to take place on or around September 17.

site_title: US firms in Hong Kong seek assurances on freedoms, AmCham says
summary: US companies in Hong Kong are seeking assurances from China that the business environment will not be eroded, particularly regarding internet access and information flow. The US State Department has issued a warning about growing risks in Hong Kong due to the national security law, which has raised concerns about data privacy and access to information. American Chamber of Commerce in Hong Kong president Tara Joseph says the advisory serves as a wake-up call, but many firms are already aware of the changes and are positioning themselves to deal with the increased risks.

site_title: Malaysia's CTOS Digital rises as high as 60% on market debut
summary: Malaysia's CTOS Digital made its market debut, rising 60% to an all-time high. The credit reporting company's RM1.2 billion IPO was fully subscribed, with 23 institutional investors participating. The retail portion was oversubscribed 27.6 times. Group CEO Dennis Martin announced plans to expand product offerings and explore acquisitions in Malaysia and Southeast Asia.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end 1% lower, pulled down by technology heavyweights
summary: South Korean shares ended 1% lower on Monday, pulled down by technology heavyweights, due to growing inflationary pressures and concerns over COVID-19 cases. The Kospi index closed at 3,244.04, its lowest close since July 9. Technology giants Samsung Electronics, SK Hynix, and internet giant Naver fell 1%, 2.06%, and 0.89%, respectively. The decline marked a second consecutive day of losses for the Kospi.

site_title: PM Johnson pleads for caution as 'Freedom Day' arrives in England
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson lifted most Covid-19 lockdown restrictions in England on "Freedom Day," urging the public to remain cautious despite surging infections. 87% of adults have received at least one vaccine dose, and daily deaths are just a fraction of the peak. However, a new variant could emerge, and case numbers could grow severely, posing economic risks. Johnson called for caution, emphasizing the importance of completing the vaccine program and noting that the virus is still present.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment to bank on multiple engines for growth
summary: CapitaLand Investment aims to achieve S$100 billion in funds under management by 2024 and grow its lodging business to 160,000 units under management by 2023. The company plans to meet these targets through multiple engines, including acquisition right of first refusal, organic growth, and strategic acquisitions. CapitaLand's restructuring aims to create a new, listed unit for its fund-management and lodging-management businesses, with a pro forma net asset value of S$15.1 billion. Analysts expect the company to trade closer to its initially stated net asset value of S$2.82, with upside potential due to its full-stack investment and operating capabilities.

site_title: Online eyewear retailer Lenskart raises US$220m from investors including Temasek
summary: Lenskart, an Indian online eyewear retailer, raised US$220 million from investors including Temasek Holdings and Falcon Edge Capital. The company plans to use the capital to expand online sales and add brick-and-mortar stores in India and internationally. With a valuation of US$2.5 billion, Lenskart aims to become the largest eyewear seller in India and a leader in South-east Asia and the Middle East, with a projected market opportunity of over US$15 billion by 2025.

site_title: Australia extends Covid-19 lockdown in Victoria state
summary: Australia's Victoria state will extend its Covid-19 lockdown beyond Tuesday, despite a slight drop in new infections, due to ongoing community cases. Premier Daniel Andrews said lockdown rules won't be lifted until cases decrease, aiming to avoid repeated lockdowns. The decision comes as the country battles the highly infectious Delta variant in its two biggest cities.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, Qian Hu, Interra
summary: CapitaLand's proposed split of its investment and property arms received endorsement from Evercore Asia, valuing the deal as "fair and reasonable." Qian Hu Corporation returned to profitability in H1 2021 with a net profit of S$856,500. Interra Resources reached an agreement with Myanmar's national oil and gas company to resume operations at two fields.

site_title: Barrier Reef outlook poor despite coral 'recovery': scientists
summary: The Great Barrier Reef's outlook remains "very poor" despite a recent coral recovery, according to Australian government scientists. The reef's hard coral cover has increased at 69 of 81 locations surveyed, but climate change and other factors continue to pose significant threats. A UNESCO ruling on the reef's world heritage status is expected, with Australia facing the possibility of being downgraded due to inaction on climate change. The reef's economic impact, estimated at $4.8 billion annually, is also at risk.

site_title: France bans crushing and gassing of male chicks from 2022
summary: France will ban the killing of male chicks by crushing or gassing from 2022, joining Germany as the first countries to outlaw the practice. Breeders must now use machines to detect chick sex before hatching, expected to cost 1 euro cent per box of six eggs. France will also grant subsidies and prohibit the castration of live piglets from 2022, aiming to improve animal welfare.

site_title: Europe: Stocks sink at open on renewed virus fears
summary: European stocks plummeted at the open on Monday, mirroring global losses, amid concerns over the lifting of COVID-19 curbs in England and the spread of the Delta variant. The FTSE 100 index dropped 1.2% to 6,926.70 points, while the DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices fell 1.1% and 1.3% respectively. Investors remain cautious despite the lifting of restrictions in England, with soaring infection rates and the Delta variant sparking fears of a resurgence.

images.alt_text: European stocks opened sharply lower on Monday, mirroring losses elsewhere, as investors eyed the lifting of most Covid curbs in England and fretted over the spreading Delta variant.

site_title: Brokers' take: RHB upgrades Dairy Farm to 'buy', citing attractive valuation for recovery
summary: RHB analysts have upgraded Dairy Farm International Holdings to a "buy" call, citing an attractive valuation for recovery. The analysts predict 10% earnings growth in FY2021 and growth in restaurants, convenience stores, and home furnishings, driven by relaxed lockdown restrictions. However, the health and beauty segment is expected to face challenges. The company's efforts to source sustainable products, reduce plastic waste, and support staff are also praised. The target price remains unchanged at US$4.78, representing a 16.9% upside on Monday's closing price of US$4.09.

site_title: Japan's Suga, South Korea's Moon to hold first summit meeting on Friday
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga and South Korean President Moon Jae-in will hold their first in-person summit on Friday, coinciding with the start of the Tokyo Olympics. The meeting comes amid strained diplomatic relations between the two countries, including issues such as compensation for forced labor during Japan's colonial rule and a recent diplomatic incident. The summit's outcome remains uncertain, with South Korea's office stating that a visit and meeting have not been finalized. The leaders are expected to discuss these and other issues affecting bilateral relations.

site_title: Singapore still first in tech innovation hub global ranking: KPMG survey
summary: Singapore has retained its top spot as the leading technology innovation hub globally, according to KPMG's survey for the second consecutive year. The city-state's strong technology and innovation ecosystems, combined with its vibrant lifestyle and research-intensive universities, make it an attractive destination for young professionals and skilled talent. The survey also highlights the growing potential of the Asia-Pacific region, with six of the top 10 cities ranking in the Asia-Pacific. The pandemic has not dampened the allure of urban city living, and openness to virtual workforces may create a viable competitor to Silicon Valley.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on shortened week
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index dropping 1.34% and the Topix index losing 0.95%. The shortened week, ahead of the Olympics, may have contributed to the decline. Investors are focusing on major events next week.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Monday; STI down 1.1%
summary: Singapore shares fell 1.1% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 34.07 points to 3,118.23. The decline was attributed to a resurgence of Covid-19 infections in the Republic, leading investors to turn cautious. Losers outnumbered gainers 139 to 49, with 71.45 million securities worth S$65.5 million changing hands.

site_title: China will continue to release metals reserves in batches: state planner
summary: China will continue to release metals reserves, including copper, aluminium, and zinc, in batches to cool metal price rallies. The National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) sold 20,000 tonnes of copper, 50,000 tonnes of aluminium, and 30,000 tonnes of zinc in batches, achieving a 3-9% price reduction. This move aims to lower raw material costs for Chinese manufacturers and reinforce supervision of the futures and spot market to crack down on irregularities.

site_title: Singaporeans expect inflation to remain flat on uneven global outlook: poll
summary: Singaporeans expect inflation to remain flat for the year, with 55% of respondents believing Covid-19 will have a significant impact on inflation rates. The survey, conducted by DBS and SMU, polled 500 individuals and found that 63% expect no change in inflation, while 21% expect a slight decrease. The results are based on a cross-section of Singaporean households and reflect the country's uneven global outlook.

site_title: Oil falls US$1 after Opec+ agreement on boosting supply
summary: Oil prices fell US$1 a barrel after the Opec+ group agreed to boost output, sparking concerns about a crude surplus amid rising Covid-19 infections. Brent crude dropped 1.5% to US$72.51, while US oil fell 1.4% to US$70.80. The decision comes after oil prices reached their highest in 2-1/2 years in June, driven by the global economy's recovery from the pandemic. The Opec+ agreement aims to cool prices by increasing supply from August.

site_title: Australian PM Morrison's approval rating slumps on slow vaccine roll-out
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison's approval rating has dropped to 51% due to a slow national COVID-19 vaccine rollout, the lowest level in over a year. The vaccine rollout has left the country exposed to a deadly new wave of the coronavirus pandemic. Morrison's Liberal-National Party coalition government trails the opposition Labor Party 47-53 in a two-party preferred basis, with a potential election defeat looming. The country has recorded just over 31,900 cases and 914 deaths, with 13% of the adult population fully vaccinated.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.79 points or 0.12% to 1,520.69. Trading volume reached 118.57 million lots worth RM69.8 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 159 to 112, despite overall market sentiment.

site_title: Evergrande shares, bonds slump after unit's bank deposit frozen
summary: China Evergrande Group's shares and dollar bonds plummeted after a court ordered the freezing of a 132 million yuan bank deposit held by its onshore division, raising concerns over the company's ability to repay debts. Evergrande's shares fell nearly 7% in Hong Kong trading, while its dollar bond due 2025 dropped 2.3 US cents on the dollar. The move deepens concerns over the financial health of China's most indebted developer, with some analysts predicting a crisis and potential difficulties in raising funding in the future.

site_title: Flush with unicorns, India's tech moment arrives
summary: India's tech industry experienced a significant boost as record fundraising and initial public offerings (IPOs) drew global attention. Zomato Ltd became the nation's first unicorn to list on the stock market, raising $1.3 billion, while Paytm's parent filed for a $2.2 billion IPO and Flipkart raised $3.6 billion at a record valuation of $38 billion. This surge in funding is attributed to improved internet infrastructure and a growing appetite for tech stocks globally, with investors now focusing on India as a potential alternative to China.

site_title: Singapore prepares to swap its oil hub status for greener future
summary: Singapore is transitioning from its role as a major oil refining hub to a green energy center, driven by declining demand for fossil fuels and growing interest in renewable energy. The government has released the Singapore Green Plan 2030, aiming to become a leading regional hub for carbon trading, green finance, and consulting services. Royal Dutch Shell's decision to slash capacity by half at its largest refinery marks a turning point in Singapore's reliance on fossil fuels. The city-state is exploring opportunities in hydrogen and liquefied natural gas, and is developing grant programs to support green and sustainability loans.

site_title: Zoom to buy cloud software provider Five9 in US$15b deal
summary: Zoom Video Communications has agreed to acquire cloud software provider Five9 in an all-stock transaction valued at approximately US$14.7 billion. The deal, expected to close in the first half of 2022, will make Five9 an operating unit of Zoom. Five9's CEO Rowan Trollope will become a president of Zoom and stay on as chief of the unit. The deal represents a price of US$200.28 per Five9 share, with Five9 stockholders receiving 0.5533 shares of Zoom Class A common stock for each share of Five9.

site_title: Singapore dollar's haven appeal rises in region ravaged by Covid
summary: The Singapore dollar is poised to outperform its South-east Asian peers due to its higher vaccination rate and rising core inflation, potentially leading to earlier policy tightening. Singapore has over 45% of its population fully vaccinated, compared to 3% in the Philippines, 5% in Thailand, 6% in Indonesia, and 13% in Malaysia. This may spur the Monetary Authority of Singapore to signal a more hawkish stance, benefiting the Singapore dollar, which is expected to approach 1.31 against the US dollar by end-2021.

site_title: UK supermarkets may shift supply chains to EU, call for N Ireland solution
summary: UK supermarket groups, including Tesco, Sainsbury's, and Asda, may shift supply chains to the EU unless the future of Britain-Northern Ireland trade is addressed urgently. The current post-Brexit protocol requires controls on goods from mainland Britain to Northern Ireland, which could lead to increased costs and complexity for retailers. The CEOs of the groups have called for talks with the UK government and the EU to find solutions, such as a veterinary agreement or a facilitated movement scheme, to avoid significant disruption to supply and costs for Northern Ireland consumers.

site_title: UK shopper numbers to jump a fifth after Covid rules lifted: Springboard
summary: The UK is expected to see a significant increase in shopper numbers after the lifting of Covid-19 restrictions on July 19. Market researcher Springboard forecasts a 19.7% rise in footfall in the week to July 24, with 32.2% and 39.5% increases on Fridays and Saturdays, respectively. High streets are expected to see a 25% rise, while shopping centres and retail parks are forecast to see 18% and 10% increases, respectively. Despite this, footfall is still expected to be 20.1% below pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: New fund gears up to manage private debt portfolio of Singapore SMEs
summary: A new fund is set to manage a private debt portfolio of Singaporean small and medium enterprises (SMEs), offering investors exposure to loans to these businesses. This move is part of the growing private credit asset class in Asia. The fund's launch aims to capitalize on the increasing demand for alternative investment options in the region.

site_title: Yellen expresses doubts on results of Trump's China trade deal
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen expressed doubts about the effectiveness of the 2020 trade deal between the US and China, citing that tariffs imposed on China may have hurt American consumers. Yellen questioned the "thoughtfulness" of the deal and stated that it did not adequately address the fundamental problems with China. The Biden administration must now decide whether to keep, scrap, or replace the agreement.

images.alt_text: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen expressed doubts about last year's trade deal with China, the first clear statement from the Biden administration detailing its thinking about the future of the agreement between the world's two largest economies.

site_title: Flash floods hit Bavaria as European death toll climbs
summary: Flash floods hit Bavaria, southern Germany, killing at least one person and raising the European death toll to 183. This is the latest in a series of devastating floods in Europe, with Germany's death toll now at 156, its worst natural disaster in nearly six decades. The Berchtesgadener Land district in Bavaria was hit by record rainfall, exacerbating the flooding crisis.

site_title: Fully-vaccinated Hong Kongers top 2m aided by giveaways
summary: Hong Kong has reached 2 million fully vaccinated residents, doubling in seven weeks, thanks to giveaways and incentives. The city has administered over 2.8 million doses, with 2.01 million receiving two shots. Vaccination rates have been slower than Singapore, but officials predict reaching a 70% vaccination rate by the end of September. Initially, mistrust of the government led to slower uptake, but private sector incentives and a surge in sign-ups have helped boost vaccination numbers.

images.alt_text: The number of Hong Kong residents that are fully vaccinated against Covid-19 topped two million on Sunday, doubling in just seven weeks as giveaways helped stoke initially slow demand.

site_title: Indonesian soup kitchen brings food to Covid-19 patients stuck at home
summary: Volunteers in Jakarta, Indonesia, are delivering meals to Covid-19 patients stuck at home due to hospital overcrowding. Four volunteers, including 26-year-old driver Badie Uzzaman, deliver packages three times a day to up to 70 homes, providing nutritious food to boost their immune systems. The non-profit charity Dompet Dhuafa set up the kitchen to help those with no beds available, with hospital occupancy rates at 90%. Daily infections have reached 57,000, and the death toll has doubled to about 1,000 per day, highlighting the need for support during the surge.

images.alt_text: As coronavirus surges in the Indonesian capital, volunteers like Badie Uzzaman are pitching in to help, delivering food to people who have tested positive but are forced to quarantine at home as hospitals run short of beds.

site_title: Healthcare workers in England may be able to skip self-isolation orders
summary: The UK government announced an exemption for fully-vaccinated healthcare workers in England to continue working even if they're exposed to Covid-19, to ease staff shortages. The exemption applies to staff whose absence would cause a significant risk of harm, and requires daily testing. The move aims to support the healthcare system during a surge in Covid-19 cases, which is also causing increased workload.

images.alt_text: Frontline health and social care workers in England may be able to carry on working even if they are exposed to someone with Covid-19, the government said on Monday as minister seek to ease pressure on the health service caused by rising infections.

site_title: Co-working spaces are back, and options abound
summary: Co-working spaces are experiencing a resurgence, with various options available. The Wing, a feminist-aligned co-working space and social club, has seen a return of regular members after the pandemic. This trend is also reflected in WeWork's recent move to fill more space at 21 Collyer Quay, Suntec City, following its bankruptcy. The increased demand for co-working spaces is likely driven by the need for professionals to return to communal work environments after prolonged periods of remote work. This shift is expected to continue as the industry adapts to changing work habits.

site_title: London restaurants boost menu prices as costs of staff, ingredients mount
summary: London restaurants are increasing menu prices due to rising costs of staff and ingredients, with some restaurants raising prices by as much as 8% in busier locations. The hospitality industry faces ongoing challenges, including staff shortages and rising wages, which may lead to concerns about inflation at the Bank of England. The industry also struggles with logistics costs, including a shortage of truck drivers, and Brexit-related price increases for imports.

site_title: China's luxury retirement homes draw millions from investors
summary: China is experiencing a surge in luxury retirement homes, drawing millions of investors. The country's aging population, with 260 million residents aged 60 and above, is driving demand for elder-care facilities. Companies like Lendlease Corp and Citic Capital are investing heavily in these developments, despite concerns about affordability. The government is also strengthening the senior-care sector with policies to expand basic and affordable services. However, the market is still in its early stages, with only around 3% of Chinese seniors willing or able to afford luxury elder-care services, and occupancy rates currently hovering at 37-48%.

site_title: UK house prices rise again amid record monthly sales: Rightmove
summary: UK house prices rose 0.7% between mid-June and early July, the largest monthly increase since 2007, according to Rightmove. This rise pushed average asking prices to a record high for the fourth month in a row. The increase was attributed to a shortage of properties on the market and a surge in sales before a tax break deadline on June 30. Asking prices have risen 6.7% over the past six months, with the imbalance between supply and demand expected to support the market.

site_title: Fund managers ride out pandemic by sticking with old playbooks
summary: US fund managers have stuck to traditional investment strategies despite the pandemic, favoring stable growth stocks over cheap ones and avoiding economically sensitive shares. This stance is similar to their approach pre-pandemic, with almost three-quarters of their portfolio holdings remaining unchanged. Some experts warn that the prolonged economic recovery and potential for inflation could lead to a shift in investment strategies, but for now, fund managers are cautious, with median turnover at a decade low.

site_title: China signals end to US$2t US stock listing juggernaut
summary: China's decision to require approval from a newly empowered cybersecurity regulator for companies seeking to list overseas marks a significant shift in the country's approach to the US stock market. The move, triggered by Didi Global's contentious New York listing, is expected to halt the "juggernaut" of Chinese tech firms listed in the US, worth over $2 trillion. The clampdown is set to send shockwaves through markets, with US-traded Chinese stocks plummeting 30% from their recent high, and Wall Street firms bracing for lucrative underwriting fees to dry up.

site_title: Landslides kill at least 30 in Mumbai after heavy rains
summary: At least 30 people died in Mumbai after heavy rains triggered landslides and house collapses in three suburbs. Rescuers used hand-digging to search for survivors, and authorities warned of further downpours that could lead to more people being trapped. The incident highlights the danger posed by heavy rainfall in the area, with some residents potentially being forced to relocate.

site_title: Opec+ agrees to gradual oil supply boost from August
summary: Opec+ has agreed to gradually add 400,000 barrels of oil per day to the market from August, ending a two-week spat between Saudi Arabia and the UAE. The deal, reached after a compromise, will boost output by 400,000 barrels daily each month until all halted output is revived. The agreement also adjusts baselines for UAE and other countries, easing a supply squeeze and reducing inflationary oil price risks. The deal resolves longstanding grievances and maintains Opec+ unity.

site_title: Looking beyond the index
summary: The FTSE EPRA Nareit Global Real Estate Index Series does not include S-Reits and property trusts, despite being a widely followed global benchmark. The index has an estimated US$340 billion of assets under management. Meanwhile, S-Reit IPOs have seen activity, with NTT DC Reit's US$773 million offering being the largest in over a decade. Other notable developments include Soilbuild Construction securing S$178.6 million in new contracts and GuocoLand securing a S$619.3 million green loan for its River Valley Green development.

site_title: Flush with unicorns, India's tech moment arrives
summary: India's tech industry is experiencing a surge in funding, with record-breaking fundraising and IPOs, as investors seek opportunities in the country's vast and under-penetrated market. The successful listing of loss-making startups has led to a re-rating of existing companies, and many expect India to become a major player in the global tech market. With a population expected to overtake China's this decade, investors are optimistic about the country's growth potential, despite concerns about a tightening regulatory regime and potential market bubbles.

site_title: China puts controlling stake in revamped Anbang on sale
summary: China's state investors plan to sell a combined 98.78% stake in Dajia Insurance Group, the revamped entity of Anbang Insurance Group, for 33.6 billion yuan (S$7 billion) through an auction. China Insurance Security Fund Co aims to auction 98.23% of its stake for 33.38 billion yuan. The sale is part of the government's efforts to restructure the embattled insurance group, which has faced financial difficulties in the past.

site_title: FAANGM doing well despite tax, anti-trust moves
summary: The FAANGM group of tech giants, including Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Netflix, Google, and Microsoft, continue to perform well despite tax and anti-trust moves by governments worldwide. Their share prices have fallen slightly below recent peaks but remain high due to optimistic growth expectations. Market participants are shrugging off regulatory actions, and the companies' directors are working to limit tax increases. However, the ongoing battles against anti-trust and regulation may chip away at profits, with fines and lobbying expenses already rising.

site_title: The movies are back in cinemas. But what are movies now?
summary: The resurgence of movie theaters has brought back a sense of excitement and communal experience, despite the pandemic's impact on traditional cinema. Releases like F9, A Quiet Place Part II, and Black Widow have done well at the box office, feeding hopes of a return to pre-Covid normalcy. However, critics argue that the shift to streaming has made movies less special and more specialized, with global blockbusters catering to mass audiences rather than providing thought-provoking content. The lines between film, television, and the internet are becoming increasingly blurred, with companies like Disney and Warner Bros exploring both theatrical and streaming releases to maximize profits.

site_title: Shanghai city to regulate data from smart vehicle testing
summary: Shanghai city has issued draft regulations to safeguard data generated during smart vehicle testing, requiring entities to properly handle data acquisition, processing, and transmission. The regulations also prohibit data transmission overseas unless approved by authorities. This move comes as China revamps its policy towards privacy and data security, with the country drafting a Personal Information Protection Law and implementing its Data Security Law. The regulations aim to protect data confidentiality and prevent illegal trading and disclosure of relevant data. The move is part of China's efforts to better govern data storage and personal data privacy.

site_title: Cash unwanted by large US banks piling up at Federal Reserve reverse repo facility
summary: US banks are using the Federal Reserve's overnight reverse repurchase agreement (RRP) facility to shed unwanted deposits, with volumes reaching an all-time high of $992 billion in June. The facility, which yields 0.05%, serves as an investment option for banks to mop up excess cash, with Bank of America strategist Mark Cabana predicting $1.5 trillion in demand by the end of October. This shift is driven by banks' reluctance to absorb reserve and deposit growth, with JPMorgan Chase's CFO acknowledging the RRP's role in managing deposit growth and supplementary leverage.

site_title: Bond distribution in Asia finally marches a digital path
summary: Singapore's fixed income distribution business is finally embracing digitalization, with a growing number of digital bond issuances transforming the traditional market. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has completed its maiden digital bond issuance and Marketnode, a joint venture between SGX and Temasek, has seen over $2 billion in digital bond notional completed. Digital bond issuances can automate processes, reduce costs, and increase transparency, with benefits including faster settlement times and lower liquidity risk. However, more regular supply of borrowers and regulatory clarity are needed for the market to truly take off, with DBS and HSBC launching digital platforms to encourage issuances of smaller-sized bonds.

site_title: Wall Street's China dreams jolted by Biden's warning on Hong Kong
summary: US President Joe Biden has warned Wall Street to reconsider their presence in Hong Kong due to China's tightening grip on the territory's legal and financial systems. This warning may prompt a re-evaluation of strategic plans for banks seeking to expand in China's second-largest economy. Despite the warning, major banks such as Citigroup and Morgan Stanley remain committed to their operations in Hong Kong, citing the city's valuable market and growth opportunities. China has also announced plans to exempt companies going public in Hong Kong from cybersecurity regulations, potentially giving the city an advantage over other financial hubs.

images.alt_text: Citigroup earlier this year said that it will hire as many as 1,700 people for its operations in Hong Kong as part of a plan to capture more business in China's Greater Bay Area.

site_title: India's HDFC Bank misses profit estimate as bad loans rise on virus wave
summary: HDFC Bank, India's largest private-sector lender, reported a smaller-than-expected profit in the June quarter due to a rise in bad loans and the impact of the recent coronavirus surge. The bank's net income fell to 77.3 billion rupees, lagging analyst estimates. Gross bad loan ratio widened to 1.47%, and provisions were set aside at 48.3 billion rupees. The bank attributed the decline to disruptions in loan originations, card usage, and collection efforts following the pandemic.

site_title: Record steel prices inject life into long-suffering industry
summary: Steel prices have surged worldwide, breaking records as industrial demand increases and plants struggle to meet supply. China and Russia are limiting exports to support domestic industries. The boom is attributed to roaring demand and a lack of supply, with steel plants lying dormant during the pandemic. This has led to a positive outlook for the steel industry, with some managers expressing optimism about the first half of 2021.

site_title: Saving too much for rainy day can dampen retirement
summary: Singaporeans may be saving too much for a rainy day, potentially delaying their retirement. With an estimated annual inflation rate of 2.5%, S$50,000 saved in banks over 20 years would only keep pace with inflation, not grow. Experts advise a diversified mix of financial solutions, including conservative and liquid fixed income instruments, to avoid holding too much cash. In fact, holding S$50,000 for 20 years could result in a nominal value of S$81,930, lagging inflation by 35%. Investors should consider investing a portion of their savings to meet long-term financial goals, starting with building emergency funds and then investing via a regular unit trust or robo-advisory platform.

site_title: Protesters denounce Thai PM for pandemic handling
summary: Protesters in Bangkok, Thailand, defied Covid-19 restrictions to demand Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha's resignation and call for a budget cut to the monarchy and army to combat the pandemic. The protesters, who wore gas masks and hard hats, also demanded the introduction of mRNA vaccines. The protests come as Thailand faces its worst-ever Covid-19 wave and a severe economic impact due to restrictions. The protesters' demands include Prayut's resignation, a reduction in military and monarchy funding, and the use of available funds to combat the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Protesters marching from Bangkok's Democracy Monument to Government House on Sunday. They were led by a frontline group wearing gas masks and hard hats, and were joined by motorbike drivers who hoisted mock body bags on their vehicles.

site_title: When Europe's planned carbon rules will hit oil guzzling industries
summary: The European Union plans to implement sweeping proposals to curb greenhouse emissions, which are expected to significantly impact the continent's oil demand. Key measures include phasing out free permits for airlines by 2026, increasing sustainable aviation fuel blends to 63% by 2050, and implementing an international offsetting system for flights. The EU also aims to include shipping in its Emissions Trading System by 2023 and boost the uptake of sustainable fuels. Additionally, the EU plans to establish a new emissions-trading programme for heating and road transport fuels, with a target of reducing CO2 emissions from cars to 55% by the end of the decade.

site_title: Younger workers seek space in London suburbs
summary: London's young workers are moving to the suburbs due to the city's affordability squeeze and the pandemic's lasting impact on the hospitality industry. Data from SpareRoom shows higher prices in outer boroughs and a decline in central neighbourhoods during Q2, with 3/4 of its users being between 18-34 years old. The shift underscores London's difficulty in recovering from pandemic restrictions and its lag in generating jobs compared to other UK regions.

site_title: Saudi Arabia allows businesses to open during prayers in key reform
summary: Saudi Arabia has officially allowed businesses to remain open during the five daily Muslim prayers, a significant reform aimed at reducing the kingdom's dependence on oil and promoting economic growth. The decision, part of a broader effort to modernize the country, was made despite concerns from some that it may trigger a backlash from conservative groups. The move is seen as a trial loosening of restrictions on businesses, with some stores already staying open during prayer times, and is expected to boost the economy by tens of billions of riyals annually.

site_title: Philippine central bank lukewarm on new relief package
summary: The Philippine central bank chief, Governor Benjamin Diokno, stated that an additional pandemic relief package would not improve the country's credit ratings prospects, following Fitch Ratings' downgrade to negative from stable. The decision to implement further stimulus is outside the central bank's mandate, Diokno said, amid the country's prolonged COVID-19 outbreak.

site_title: DBS Private Bank sees wave of interest in ESG among clients
summary: DBS Private Bank has seen a surge in interest in environmental, social, and governance (ESG) investments among its clients, with assets under management (AUM) in its ESG funds more than tripling to 260% as of May 2021. The bank's wealth management AUM rose 18% year-on-year, significantly higher than pre-COVID levels. DBS aims to have over 50% of its private banking AUM in sustainable investments by 2023, driven by the pandemic's accelerated ESG agenda and Asia's wealth transition to younger generations focused on investing in "something they can be proud of".

site_title: Time for fresh view of Singapore-China trade corridor opportunities
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to expand 6.3% in 2021, driven by its successful management of the COVID-19 pandemic and government initiatives such as the Green Plan 2030. The country is well-positioned to capitalize on opportunities arising from its longstanding partnership with China, including in sustainability, digital transformation, and e-commerce. The Singapore-China trade corridor offers numerous opportunities for businesses to tap into new growth areas, with both countries embarking on committed sustainability journeys and ambitious targets to reach net-zero carbon emissions.

site_title: SMEs adapt their giving-back activities as businesses scale back
summary: Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore are adapting their corporate social responsibility (CSR) activities as the pandemic disrupts their operations and reduces income. Many are scaling back or redefining their giving-back initiatives due to logistical challenges and reduced resources. However, experts suggest that SMEs can still make a positive impact by focusing on strategic partnerships, leveraging core competencies, and measuring the impact of their CSR activities. By doing so, businesses can strengthen bonds with the community, build brand loyalty, and ultimately benefit in the long term.

site_title: Crush at market seafood stalls, businesses scramble for supplies as Jurong Fishery Port shuts for 2 weeks
summary: Singapore's main distribution centre for fresh fish, Jurong Fishery Port, has been shut for 2 weeks, prompting businesses to scramble for alternative seafood supplies. Consumers have responded with a rush to seafood markets, leading to long lines and some stalls selling out early. Suppliers are limiting new orders, further exacerbating the shortage. The closure is expected to impact the seafood industry, with businesses and consumers bracing for potential shortages.

site_title: Shades of Keppel's big 2020 O&M losses in Sembmarine's dour loss guidance for 2021
summary: Sembmarine's larger-than-expected H1 2021 loss of around $583 million has raised concerns about the company's ability to consolidate its operations, following a similar loss by Keppel's O&M division in 2020. The loss may provide justification for the shabby treatment minority investors experienced during Sembmarine's fundraising efforts. The company's larger-than-expected loss may prompt a review of its operations, particularly in the face of structural changes in the O&M sector and the disruption caused by Covid-19. A potential merger between Keppel O&M and Sembmarine remains a possibility, with Keppel holding an upper hand in negotiations.

site_title: France's Soitec bets 275m euros on Singapore to tap consumer tech surge
summary: Soitec, a French chipmaker, is investing 275 million euros in its Singapore factory to produce 300mm silicon-on-insulator (SOI) substrates, aiming to triple its revenue to $2 billion by 2026. The facility will increase production capacity by fivefold, producing up to 1 million SOI wafers per year. The investment is part of Soitec's global plan to achieve its revenue target, and the company expects all growth from its 300mm substrates to come from Singapore over the next two years. The move is seen as a strategic move to tap into the consumer tech surge and capitalize on the growing demand for semiconductors.

site_title: Santander to buy broker Amherst in US fixed income push
summary: Santander's US unit has agreed to buy Amherst Pierpont Securities in a $600 million deal, expanding its presence in fixed income trading. The acquisition gives Santander a greater presence in the US market, following Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria's sale of its US business last year. Amherst Pierpont, which serves over 1,300 institutional clients, will be a primary dealer of US Treasuries. The deal is part of Santander's push into the US fixed income market, which has seen a surge in trading over the past year.

site_title: PropNex executive director doubles down as stock rallies
summary: Singapore stocks rallied over the past five trading sessions, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 1.0% and the FTSE China A50 Index, Hang Seng Index, and FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI averaging a 1.8% gain. Share buybacks were also seen, with The Hour Glass buying back 1.968 million shares at an average price of S$1.46 per share. Meanwhile, PropNex executive director Kelvin Fong increased his deemed interest in the company to 8.58% after acquiring 300,000 shares. Other notable transactions include Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings selling 300,000 shares at a return of 42%, and Second Chance Properties founder Mohamed Salleh Marican acquiring 458,000 shares.

site_title: Singapore bank shares chalk up strong gains in H1, but more rotations ahead
summary: Singapore's three major banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, saw a 19% total return in the first half of 2021, in line with global peers. Despite strong gains, the sector is expected to experience more volatile trading in the second half as investors rotate in and out of the sector. The banks' price-to-book ratios are still below pre-pandemic levels, but their net institutional and proprietary inflows reached S$1.39 billion in Q1 2021. As the economy normalizes, recurring rotations are anticipated, driven by differing expectations on monetary policy and economic outlook.

site_title: British PM Johnson tries to skirt self-isolation through Covid-19 testing programme
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson agreed to self-isolate after being exposed to Covid-19, reversing his earlier decision not to isolate after being contacted by the UK's test and trace programme. Johnson's office initially stated he and Chancellor Rishi Sunak would take part in a daily testing programme instead, sparking a backlash from the Labour Party and public. The U-turn comes as the UK is set to lift remaining virus curbs on Monday.

site_title: US dollar ends week strong on upbeat US retail sales data
summary: The US dollar ended the week strong, logging its largest weekly gain in a month, after upbeat retail sales data boosted expectations of accelerated economic growth in the second quarter. The dollar index rose 0.11% to 92.675, up 0.6% for the week, despite Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's reassurance that rising inflation is transitory. Strong US data and shifting interest rate expectations have lifted the dollar, making investors nervous about shorting it. This trend is also seen in other currencies, with the New Zealand dollar rising and sterling falling against the dollar.

site_title: Electric car lithium demand powers mining revival in UK
summary: A British company, Cornish Lithium, is experiencing a mining revival due to the increasing demand for lithium, a key component in electric car batteries. Founded by former investment banker Jeremy Wrathall, the company in Cornwall, southwest England, is capitalizing on the growing electric vehicle market. The company's operations are likely to benefit from the recent hosting of the G-7 summit in Cornwall.

images.alt_text: Cornish Lithium carrying out exploratory drilling at a former mine in Cornwall. British demand for lithium is set to reach 75,000 tonnes by 2035, five years ahead of a UK ban on the sale of high- polluting diesel and petrol vehicles.

site_title: Jurong Fishery Port closure: Singapore has activated other supply routes, says Grace Fu
summary: Singapore has activated alternative supply routes after a Covid-19 cluster broke out at Jurong Fishery Port, with the port expected to reopen on July 31. The government has asked major wholesalers to increase their offtake and supermarkets to stock up on seafood. Local fish farms have seen increased sales, with some doubling their production to meet demand. The move aims to minimize disruption to seafood supplies, with frozen and chilled seafood stocks available to substitute for wet markets.

site_title: 88 new locally transmitted cases; Lawrence Wong urges unvaccinated seniors to stay home
summary: Singapore reported 92 new COVID-19 cases on Sunday, including 88 locally transmitted cases, with 25 linked to a KTV cluster and 42 linked to the Jurong Fishery Port cluster. Lawrence Wong urged unvaccinated seniors to stay home to minimize the risk of infection. Stallholders selling fresh fish and seafood at affected markets were told to obtain a negative PCR test result before reopening. The nation has switched to alternative supply routes, with major supermarkets increasing seafood stocks to substitute for wet markets.

images.alt_text: There were 88 new locally transmitted coronavirus cases confirmed at noon on Sunday, including 23 cases linked to the growing cluster involving KTV outlets and nightclubs.

site_title: Biden to host Iraq's prime minister at White House on July 26
summary: US President Joe Biden will host Iraqi Prime Minister Mustafa al-Kadhimi at the White House on July 26, to strengthen bilateral cooperation and advance shared interests in energy and health. The visit aims to enhance security cooperation, including efforts to defeat the Islamic State militant group. The meeting does not appear to address Iran's influence in Iraq, which has been a point of tension. This visit highlights the strategic partnership between the two countries under the 2008 agreement governing US troop withdrawal from Iraq.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden will host Iraqi Prime Minister Mustafa al-Kadhimi at the White House on July 26, the White House said on Friday.

site_title: Fresh fish, seafood stallholders need negative PCR test result before reopening
summary: Singapore's National Environment Agency (NEA) has temporarily closed all fresh fish and seafood stalls at markets managed by the agency or appointed operators due to Covid-19 clusters linked to the Jurong Fishery Port, where 56 cases have been reported. The NEA urges stallholders to undergo negative PCR tests before reopening. Major supermarket chains like FairPrice and Dairy Farm confirm that fresh fish and seafood remain available at their stores, with suppliers making alternative arrangements to maintain supplies.

site_title: Signs point to fading bullish momentum for AUDUSD
summary: A bullish trend for AUDUSD is fading, with signs pointing to a trend reversal to the downside. A bearish head and shoulders pattern, a struggling Relative Strength Index (RSI), and a narrowing gap between the 50 and 200-day Simply Moving Average (SMA) lines support the bearish outlook. However, a falling wedge pattern and bullish divergence in the RSI indicate a short-term rebound, with potential targets at S1: 0.7375 and S2: 0.7280.

site_title: Saudi sovereign fund buys into McLaren as part of £550m equity raise
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) and global investment firm Ares Management invested £400 million in McLaren Group as part of a £550 million equity raise. Existing shareholders also contributed £150 million. The investment will support McLaren's sustainable growth plans, with Automotive being its core profit driver. The company's revenues rose 145% in the first quarter of this year. This investment comes after PIF was involved in a proposed takeover of Newcastle United football side last year, which ultimately collapsed.

site_title: 88 new locally transmitted Covid-19 cases, including 37 linked to Jurong Fishery Port, 23 linked to KTV cluster
summary: Singapore reported 88 new locally transmitted Covid-19 cases, including 37 linked to Jurong Fishery Port and 23 linked to the KTV cluster, bringing the total number of KTV cluster cases to 172.

site_title: China vows to curb commodities speculation to ensure price stability
summary: China vows to curb commodities speculation to ensure price stability. The Ministry of Industry and Information Technology plans to crack down on hoarding and speculation of bulk commodities, guiding upstream and downstream players to stabilize production and prices. Authorities have been warning against speculative trading, auctioning off base metals reserves, and launching probes into prices and reserves of key commodities. China aims to boost its coal storage capacity to 600 million tonnes and has expanded its 5G base stations to 961,000. The move aims to tame price volatility and prevent price increases from being passed on to consumers.

site_title: Nomura joins Wall Street rivals in boosting pay for juniors
summary: Nomura Holdings is boosting the salaries of its entry-level bankers to US$100,000, joining Wall Street rivals such as Bank of America, Barclays, and JPMorgan Chase & Co. in an effort to retain junior talent amid the work-from-home grind and 100-hour workweeks. The move aims to ease the burden on younger bankers and improve their physical and mental health. This follows a presentation by Goldman Sachs analysts highlighting the challenges faced by junior bankers.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for July 16, 2021, reveals a week of declining tanker and dry bulk market values. The Capesize market experienced a $2,430 drop to $28,572, while the Panamax market declined across all regions. The Supramax market saw limited fresh enquiry and lengthening tonnage lists. The Handysize market moved up 18 points to a new yearly high, despite sparse activity in East and East Coast South America. VLCC rates remained stable in the Middle East, while Suezmax rates gained 2.5 points in the Nigeria/UK Continent market. Aframax rates softened in the Mediterranean, while the clean market lacked direction.

site_title: TSMC founder says breaking up chip supply chain will be costly
summary: TSMC founder Morris Chang warned that efforts to build domestic chip supply chains globally could lead to increased costs and still fail to achieve self-sufficiency. He stated that the complex technology and globalized supply chain have boosted semiconductor development, but turning back the clock would slow down technology development and increase costs. Despite billions of dollars spent, governments may still struggle to build a self-sufficient supply chain, with TSMC continuing to expand its overseas projects. Chang advocated for maintaining a free-trade system for private sector demand.

site_title: Delta Covid variant now dominant strain worldwide, US deaths surge
summary: The Delta Covid-19 variant has become the dominant global strain, with US cases increasing 70% and deaths rising 26% over the previous week. The surge is largely among unvaccinated individuals, particularly in areas with low vaccination rates. The seven-day-average of daily cases has more than doubled to over 26,000, with the US CDC reporting a 26% increase in deaths.

site_title: CapitaLand's restructuring plan is 'fair and reasonable': IFA
summary: CapitaLand's restructuring plan has been deemed "fair and reasonable" by independent financial adviser Evercore Asia. The plan involves splitting the company into a privately-held development arm and a new, listed unit for investment management platforms and lodging. The proposed entity, CapitaLand Investment Ltd (CLI), would become the largest real estate investment manager on the Singapore bourse, with pro forma real estate assets under management of S$115 billion. Shareholders will vote on the plan next month, with the deal expected to be completed around mid-September 2021.

site_title: Olympics: Nigerian delegate is first hospitalised with Covid-19
summary: A Nigerian Olympic delegate became the first visitor to the Tokyo Games hospitalized with Covid-19, a week before the event starts. The individual, in their 60s with pre-existing conditions, was hospitalized due to age and mild symptoms. Organizers have promised a "safe and secure" Games, despite increasing Covid-19 infections among athletes and staff. Tokyo is under a state of emergency, and spectators are limited due to concerns about the virus.

site_title: Thailand bans public gatherings as coronavirus cases and deaths hit daily records
summary: Thailand has imposed a nationwide ban on public gatherings due to record-breaking coronavirus cases and deaths. The ban carries a maximum penalty of two years in jail or a fine of up to $1,655. Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha announced the measure as the country battles its worst outbreak yet, fueled by Alpha and Delta variants. The ban follows partial lockdowns in Bangkok and nine provinces, with high-risk areas facing tougher restrictions, including curfews and closures of non-essential businesses.

site_title: Amazon-backed EV maker Rivian delays output, citing supply-chain woes
summary: Rivian Automotive, an electric vehicle maker backed by Amazon, has delayed production of its debut vehicle, the R1T pickup, by two months to September due to supply-chain bottlenecks, including a chip shortage. The company also pushed back the timeline for its second planned model, an electric sports-utility vehicle, to the fall. Rivian cited the pandemic's impact on facility construction, equipment installation, and component supply, particularly semiconductors, as the reason for the delays.

site_title: Moon 'wobble', climate change seen as driving coastal flooding in 2030s
summary: US coastlines will face increasing flooding in the mid-2030s due to a combination of rising sea levels caused by climate change and a lunar cycle's effect on tides. The "wobble" in the moon's orbit, identified in the 18th century, will amplify the tides, resulting in higher high tides and lower low tides. This will coincide with the expected sea level rise, leading to serious coastal flooding from 2030 to 2040, pushing previous estimates forward by about 70 years.

site_title: 12 more markets and food centres linked to Covid-19 cases: MOH
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Health (MOH) has linked 12 more markets and food centres to COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 13. Most cases are fishmongers infected through contact with stallholders at Jurong Fishery Port. Six KTV lounges have also been added to the list of transmission hotspots, with 148 cases reported in the KTV cluster and 19 in the fishery cluster. The MOH is investigating cases at Chong Boon Market and Food Centre and has closed it until August 1 for deep cleaning and quarantine.

images.alt_text: Mr Ramasamy Venkatesan (right) from Gayatri Restaurant with a fishmonger preparing fish heads from a regular supplier at Jurong Fishery Port.

site_title: Two new clusters emerge; Jurong Fishery Port, Hong Lim Market, Jalan Besar eatery closed
summary: Two new COVID-19 clusters have been identified in Singapore, resulting in the closure of Jurong Fishery Port, Hong Lim Market and Food Centre, and Khoi Grill and Hotpot. Seven cases are linked to each cluster, prompting the Ministry of Health to take measures to contain the spread of the virus. The closures are part of the government's efforts to prevent further transmission and protect public health.

site_title: Europe: Basic material, luxury stocks drive shares to a third day of losses
summary: European stocks fell for a third consecutive day, down 0.3% on Friday, as mining majors like Rio Tinto, BHP, and Glencore were hit by a decline in iron ore shipments. Luxury stocks, however, saw gains, but concerns about sustainability overshadowed these results. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index took weekly losses to 0.6%.

site_title: Intel eyes GlobalFoundries in US$30b deal: WSJ
summary: Intel is in talks to buy GlobalFoundries Inc for approximately $30 billion, according to the Wall Street Journal. GlobalFoundries, which operates five wafer fabs in Singapore and employs 4,800 staff, has significant investments in the country. The deal could help Intel ramp up chip production amid a global semiconductor shortage, and would be a significant move for the US-based company to expand its manufacturing capacity.

site_title: Jokowi urges 'sense of crisis' as Indonesia becomes Covid-19 hotspot
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo has urged his ministers to adopt a "sense of crisis" amid the country's surge in COVID-19 cases, overtaking Brazil as the world's worst hotspot. The president called off a paid vaccination plan and restricted travel overseas for state officials, citing public backlash over a plan to sell vaccines to individuals. All vaccines remain free, but employers will cover the cost of doses for private vaccination programs. The decision comes as the healthcare system is overwhelmed, with 75.6% of Indonesians still approving of the president's handling of the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo urged for a "sense of crisis" among his ministers as the country overtakes Brazil in daily coronavirus cases to become the worst in the world.

site_title: Sydney tightens lockdown as Australia's Covid-19 cases rise
summary: Sydney, Australia, has tightened its lockdown as new COVID-19 cases rise, with 111 reported in the past 24 hours. The city, home to 5 million people, has been under lockdown since June 26 and is set to end on July 30. Authorities have banned non-essential retail, banned people from leaving their neighborhoods for work, and threatened fines for employers who force staff to attend the office. The state has recorded 913 national COVID-19 deaths and 1,000 positive cases, with 29 infectious individuals still active in the community.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends down as Delta variant drives fears
summary: US stocks ended lower on Friday, weighed down by declines in technology heavyweights like Amazon, Apple, and Nvidia, amid concerns over the highly contagious Delta variant of the coronavirus. US coronavirus cases rose 70% over the previous week, with deaths up 26%, prompting worries about a potential market impact. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.86%, while the S&P 500 lost 0.75% and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.8%.

site_title: US sanctions Chinese officials over Hong Kong democracy crackdown
summary: The US imposed sanctions on seven Chinese officials over Beijing's crackdown on democracy in Hong Kong, targeting those from the Hong Kong liaison office. The sanctions, announced by the US Treasury Department, follow criticism of China's erosion of rule of law in the former British colony. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken said Chinese officials had "systematically undermined" Hong Kong's democratic institutions, prompting the US to take action. The move is part of a series of sanctions imposed on Chinese officials, including Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam and senior police officers, for curtailing political freedoms in the territory.

images.alt_text: The United States imposed sanctions on Friday on seven Chinese officials over Beijing's crackdown on democracy in Hong Kong, Washington's latest effort to hold China accountable for what it calls an erosion of rule of law in the former British colony.

site_title: Dance lessons at US$15,000 a pop mark ballroom's Covid comeback
summary: Hong Kong's ballroom and Latin-American dance studios are experiencing a resurgence after the COVID-19 pandemic, with wealthy enthusiasts seeking social activities and improving fitness. Private dance lessons can cost up to $15,000, and top celebrities often hire world champion instructors for private sessions. Despite initial concerns, enrollments and competitions have increased globally, with Arthur Murray International seeing a 65% rise in enrollments and 40% increase in competition sign-ups. The industry's recovery has been slower in Hong Kong due to the city's cautious approach to social activities.

site_title: Europe reels from worst floods in years as death toll nears 130
summary: Devastating floods have torn through Europe, particularly in western Germany, killing at least 128 people and leaving thousands without electricity. The floods, dubbed the "flood of death," have submerged entire villages, destroyed homes and businesses, and triggered a landslide in a neighboring town. The death toll is expected to rise as emergency services continue to search affected areas. Climate change is being cited as a contributing factor, with warmer atmospheres holding more water increasing the risk and intensity of flooding from extreme rainfall.

site_title: Moderna surges as S&P 500 inclusion boosts vaccine maker
summary: Moderna's stock surged 10% to a record high after S&P Dow Jones Indices announced it will be added to the S&P 500 Index on July 21, replacing Alexion Pharmaceuticals. The vaccine maker's market valuation surpassed $100 billion, making it an elite biotech firm. Analysts expect Moderna to boost its 2021 revenue guidance and raise its share price target to $250. The company's inclusion in the S&P 500 is seen as a significant milestone, with some comparing it to Tesla's addition to the index in 2020.

site_title: Olympics: First Covid case found at athletes' village, stoking fears ahead of Games
summary: Tokyo Olympics organisers reported a Covid-19 case at the athletes' village, the first such case at a site where competitors will be staying. The visitor, from an unspecified country, tested positive during a routine test on Friday. The 2020 Games, postponed due to the pandemic, is being held with limited spectators and strict quarantine rules. This new development raises concerns over the safety and security of the Games, contradicting earlier promises of a "safe and secure" event.

site_title: Poland's Tusk says conflicts with EU could eventually end the bloc
summary: Former European Council President Donald Tusk warns that Poland's conflicts with the EU could lead to the bloc's demise. Tusk says if more countries damage the EU, it may result in the organization's end. Despite this, Tusk notes that the process is likely to take years. The EU is currently at odds with Poland over democratic standards, including the independence of the judiciary and press freedoms. A ruling by Poland's Constitutional Tribunal has deepened the standoff, with the European Commission taking legal action against the country over LGBT rights.

site_title: Lending platform Blend Labs rises in debut after top-end IPO
summary: Blend Labs, a lending platform, rose 16% in its debut after raising $360 million in an initial public offering priced at the top of its marketed range. The company's shares opened at $20 and closed at $20.90, giving it a market value of $4.6 billion. Co-founder Nima Ghamsari retains control of the company through ownership of Class B shares. The company's lending platform is used by 31 top US financial firms, processing an average of $5 billion in transactions per day.

site_title: Gaming for a living: Are NFT games a fair gig or low-wage exploitation?
summary: Players of blockchain games like Axie Infinity can earn tokens equivalent to nearly $800 per month by spending about two hours a day. Proponents praise the games for helping those from emerging economies pay bills and put food on the table, but critics raise concerns about the volatility and lack of regulation in the non-fungible token (NFT) space. Some players band together to offer "scholarships" to new players, who can keep 70% of their earnings. However, critics warn that the games may exploit desperate labor and lack accountability, with some gamers reporting scams and harassment.

site_title: WHO eyes China lab audits next in Covid origin probe
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has proposed the second stage of its investigation into the origins of Covid-19, which includes further studies in China and lab audits. WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus suggested five priorities, including audits of Chinese laboratories and research institutions, studies on geographic areas with early Sars CoV-2 circulation, and more research on animal markets in Wuhan. The investigation aims to determine how the virus first emerged, with the WHO emphasizing the need for transparency and scientific inquiry, and rejecting the idea that a lab leak is "extremely unlikely".

site_title: First case of monkeypox detected in Texas resident
summary: A rare case of human monkeypox was detected in Texas, the first in the state, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). The case involves a US resident who recently traveled from Nigeria to the US and is currently hospitalized in Dallas. The Dallas County Judge downplayed the threat, stating that the case is not alarming and does not pose a risk to the general public. The individual's travel history and current hospitalization are being monitored.

site_title: Does a negative treadmill test mean that there is no heart disease?
summary: A negative treadmill test does not necessarily mean there is no heart disease, particularly for individuals under 40. The American College of Cardiology and American Heart Association guidelines, which apply to those 40-79 years old, are not suitable for younger individuals. A 32-year-old man with a family history of coronary artery disease and high LDL cholesterol may still be at risk, even with a negative test result. Clinical judgment is essential in assessing cardiovascular risk for younger individuals.

site_title: Thailand tycoon's property unit bets big on reopening
summary: Thailand's Asset World plans to invest 100 billion baht (S$4.1 billion) over five years to develop new shopping malls, hotels, and office buildings, betting on pent-up demand post-pandemic. The company's CEO, Wallapa Traisorat, cited a "slightly more than 10 per cent" occupancy rate in hotels due to travel restrictions, but noted bookings at one hotel in Phuket have reached 40 per cent of capacity after foreign tourist arrivals resumed. Thailand aims to reopen its borders to international tourists in October, aiming to revive its tourism industry, which contributed 20% to GDP before the pandemic.

site_title: Ethereum co-founder says safety concern has him quitting crypto
summary: Ethereum co-founder Anthony Di Iorio is quitting the cryptocurrency world due to personal safety concerns. He plans to sell his company Decentral Inc and refocus on philanthropy and other ventures. Di Iorio, 48, has had a security team since 2017 and expects to sever ties with other startups he is involved with. He cited the high risk profile of the crypto space and believes he would be safer tackling larger problems. Di Iorio, who co-founded Ethereum in 2013, will sell Decentral for "hundreds of millions" and does not plan to fund any more blockchain projects.

site_title: Why even seasoned investors can get burnt
summary: Experienced investors, including seasoned professionals, can fall prey to biases that lead to costly investment decisions. Two such biases are the herd mentality and illusory superiority bias. The herd mentality refers to following popular trends, while illusory superiority bias involves overconfidence in one's own decision-making. Both biases can result in impulsive and incorrect investment decisions. To avoid these biases, investors should adopt a first-principles approach, basing decisions on data and findings, and staying objective and independent. By doing so, they can make smarter, more informed investment decisions and avoid joining the herd.

site_title: The height of fashion
summary: The Land Rover Defender 90 is a rugged and imposing vehicle that defies its low-slung design, offering a unique driving experience. Despite its width and height, the Defender 90 is actually shorter than a Toyota Corolla Altis, and its slow and vague steering makes it less suitable for sports driving. However, its high ground clearance and powerful engine make it well-suited for off-road adventures, and its spacious interior provides ample room for passengers and cargo. The Defender 90 is a practical choice for those seeking a fun and capable vehicle that can handle both on-road and off-road terrain.

site_title: Oil falls for the week on supply concerns, rising Covid cases
summary: Oil prices fell for the week, ending lower due to growing supply concerns and rising Covid-19 cases that could lead to lockdown restrictions and depressed demand. Brent futures rose 0.2% to $73.59 a barrel, while US WTI crude rose 0.2% to $71.81 a barrel. The decline marks the third week of a decline since April 2020. Despite the rise in oil prices over the past few months, the US oil rig count increased by two rigs, and US crude production rose to 11.4 million barrels per day.

site_title: US sees surprise retail sales increase in June
summary: US retail sales rose 0.6% in June to $621.3 billion, beating forecasts for a decline, as pandemic restrictions ease. Sales jumped at department stores, electronics, and gas stations, but declined at motor vehicle dealers. Core retail sales excluding gas stations and auto sales rose 1.1%. The increase reflects shifts in consumer preferences during the summer months, but it's unclear how Americans will spend their accumulated $2.3 trillion in pandemic savings.

site_title: Biden says Facebook, others 'killing people' by carrying Covid misinformation
summary: US President Joe Biden criticized Facebook and other social media platforms for allowing misinformation about coronavirus vaccines to spread, saying they "are killing people." The administration has been urging the company to do more to police harmful content. Despite Facebook's claims of providing reliable information and helping to save lives, researchers and lawmakers have long accused the company of failing to address the issue. The Delta variant has led to a surge in deaths among unvaccinated Americans, with cases and deaths up 70% and 26% respectively over the previous week.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden on Friday said social media platforms like Facebook "are killing people" for allowing misinformation about coronavirus vaccines to be posted on its platform, as the administration continued criticizing the company.

site_title: Dovish Fed plays down taper talk and Gold finds its mojo
summary: Gold prices reached a month high above $1,820 an ounce after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell reassured investors about the Fed's plan to tighten policy, soothing fears and reducing US bond yields. Central bankers worldwide are concerned about the resurgence of the coronavirus, while China's economic recovery slowdown and the European Central Bank's potential new guidance on monetary stimulus also support gold prices. The technical analysis indicates a bullish trend, with key support levels at $1,760 and a major 200-day trend now considered a support level.

site_title: Dine-in group size cut, pivoted nightspots suspended amid 'major setback' due to KTV cluster
summary: Singapore has scaled back dining-in at food and beverage establishments due to a growing cluster of KTV lounge infections. From July 19 to Aug 8, groups of up to two people will be allowed, with fully vaccinated individuals allowed to join groups of five at establishments with SafeEntry systems. The measures, a "major setback" in the country's recovery, aim to target the cluster, which has 120 cases. The authorities will also suspend nightlife establishments for two weeks, requiring them to demonstrate safe management measures before resuming operations.

site_title: Bukalapak ups IPO to US$1.5b, set to be largest Indonesian issue
summary: Indonesian e-commerce firm Bukalapak has increased its initial public offering (IPO) size to $1.5 billion, the largest local issue in the country. The IPO was initially set to raise $300 million, but was later increased to $800 million and then to $1.13 billion. The listing comes as Indonesia's e-commerce market has been boosted by the pandemic, and Bukalapak is expected to debut on the market on August 6. The IPO is likely to be priced at the top end of its range, with order books already multiple times covered.

site_title: US consumer sentiment drops in early July on inflation fears
summary: US consumer sentiment plummeted to its lowest level in five months in early July, dropping to 80.8 from 85.5 in June, according to a University of Michigan survey. Inflation fears, fueled by supply constraints and rising prices, significantly impacted confidence in the economic recovery. The survey's gauge of current economic conditions fell to 84.5, its measure of consumer expectations slid to 78.4, and one-year inflation expectations rose to 4.8%. Economists attribute the decline to inflation's added pressure on living standards, particularly for lower and middle-income households.

images.alt_text: US consumer sentiment fell sharply and unexpectedly in early July to the lowest level in five months as inflation worries dented confidence in the economic recovery, a survey showed on Friday.

site_title: Bitcoin's growing pains
summary: Bitcoin's growing pains are evident in the volatility of stablecoins, which are pegged to real currencies to offer stability. The Iron Titanium token's 500% gain and subsequent 100% loss in one day highlights the risks. Decentralized Finance (DeFi) attempts to address volatility by offering interest-bearing loans and insurance, but leverage introduced by DeFi has increased the system's instability. Tether, a major stablecoin, has raised questions due to its lack of audit and potential Ponzi scheme concerns. El Salvador's adoption of bitcoin as legal tender has increased the risk of volatility, and experts warn that the country's US$150 million reserve may be insufficient to mitigate the effects.

site_title: Binance ditches 'stock tokens' as global crackdown widens
summary: Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange by spot trading volumes, has stopped selling "stock tokens" linked to shares, effective immediately. The move comes after Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission warned that offering stock tokens to the public without authorization could be an offense. This decision follows similar announcements from Italian regulators and comes amid global scrutiny over lax consumer protection and money laundering concerns. Binance will cease support for stock tokens in October, and users holding them can sell or hold them until then.

site_title: Wage, rental support to be extended for F&B and sectors affected by tightened measures
summary: Singapore's multi-ministry task force on Covid-19 has announced tightened measures, including reduced group sizes at food-and-beverage outlets and gyms, starting July 19. Affected sectors will receive 10% wage support under the enhanced Jobs Support Scheme until August 8. Targeted support for self-employed hawkers includes rental waivers and subsidies for table-cleaning services. These measures aim to slow the spread of Covid-19 in the country.

site_title: China may exempt Hong Kong IPOs from cybersecurity reviews
summary: China is considering exempting Hong Kong IPOs from cybersecurity reviews, a move that could make it easier for companies to list in the Asian financial hub instead of the US. The exemption would allow companies to comply with local laws without undergoing a formal review, which is required for companies headed to other countries like the US.
