The move aims to tighten oversight of companies like Didi Global and ByteDance that control valuable user data, and could benefit international banks and Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing.

site_title: Ford recalling 775,000 SUVs for steering issue linked to six injuries
summary: Ford Motor is recalling approximately 775,000 2013-2017 Ford Explorer SUVs globally due to a steering issue linked to six reported injuries in North America. The recall affects 676,152 vehicles in North America, 59,935 in China, and 38,600 elsewhere, with US vehicles in high-rust states. The issue is expected to be resolved by the end of 2021.

site_title: US: Stocks edge higher as retail sales top estimates
summary: US stocks rose early Friday as retail sales beat expectations, sparking a positive conclusion to a choppy week. Retail sales rose 0.6% to $621.3 billion, exceeding forecasts for a decline. The stronger-than-expected data lifted stocks, reversing losses from earlier in the week. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Vaccination checks pose operational challenges for F&B, gym operators
summary: Singapore will introduce differentiated treatment for vaccinated customers at eateries and gyms, allowing groups of up to five to dine in without restrictions. However, non-vaccinated individuals are limited to groups of two. Businesses are concerned about potential logistical challenges in implementing the new rules, which may require additional manpower and operational effort. The changes come amid a growing cluster of 120 cases linked to KTV lounges, leading to a setback in the country's economic reopening.

images.alt_text: Sean Tan, president and co-founder of Singapore Fitness Alliance, says every new round of tightening measures puts a dent in the confidence of gym goers.

site_title: China launches trading in biggest carbon market
summary: China has launched its national carbon market, the world's biggest emissions exchange hub, with trading beginning at 48 yuan (S$10) a tonne. The initial scope covers 2,200 power companies and has been criticized for generous pollution allowances. Analysts predict modest prices that won't immediately induce drastic changes, but will allow companies to adapt to the market. Authorities aim to extend the system to other industries, with a goal of peaking carbon emissions by 2030 and reaching carbon neutrality by 2060.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Qian Hu Corporation, a mainboard-listed fish service provider, returned to profitability in the first half of 2021 with a net profit of S$856,500, up from a loss of S$525,237 in the same period last year. Revenue rose 19.5% to S$39.7 million, driven by a 29.5% increase in fish exports. Qian Hu plans to expand its domestic distribution network to mitigate supply chain risks.

site_title: ecoWise shareholders to convene extraordinary general meeting after company flip-flopped on earlier decision to do so
summary: Three ecoWise Holdings shareholders plan to convene an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) after the company initially decided against holding one. The shareholders, Tan Swee Boon, Tan Jin Beng Winston, and Sunny Ong Keng Hua, had sent a requisition in May requesting the removal of director Cao Shixuan and the appointment of three new directors. The shareholders will proceed with convening the EGM, despite the company's reversal of its earlier decision, which resulted in a lost month for preparation.

site_title: Economists upgrade Singapore trade outlook on H1 export outperformance
summary: Economists have upgraded Singapore's trade outlook for 2021 due to better-than-expected export performance in the first half, with non-oil domestic exports jumping 15.9% year on year in June. Despite Covid-19 outbreaks in key markets, external demand is expected to remain strong over the next six months. This upgrade follows a recent study suggesting Singapore has the opportunity to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging. The upgrade is a positive sign for the country's economy, which has been impacted by the pandemic.

site_title: Property heir urges Hong Kong to improve land policy
summary: Hong Kong property heir Adam Kwok criticized the local government's land policies, calling for an overhaul to address the city's housing shortage. Kwok, an executive director at Sun Hung Kai Properties, suggested developing buffer zones along wetlands and green belt areas to prevent encroachment. He also urged the government to allow private housing projects to proceed despite incomplete infrastructure. Kwok praised the government's efforts, but emphasized the need for improved procedures and policies to solve the issues. Hong Kong's housing crisis has led to record-breaking home prices and a shortage of new residential units.

site_title: UK's Sunak might delay budget until 2022 due to Covid
summary: British finance minister Rishi Sunak is considering delaying the UK's annual budget plan until 2022 to assess the economic impact of ending state support for businesses amid the Covid-19 response. The government wage-subsidy programme is set to expire at the end of September, and data on its impact may not be available until the end of 2021. A three-year spending strategy is also planned for the autumn. A government spokesman said there is no need to make a decision on the budget's timing, citing the need for further assessment.

site_title: Apec leaders look to boost virus coordination
summary: Global leaders, including US President Joe Biden and China's Xi Jinping, held a virtual Apec meeting to discuss strategies for emerging from the Covid-19 pandemic. The meeting aimed to speed vaccine distribution and ease travel restrictions through vaccine passports or quarantine bubbles. New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern emphasized that the pandemic "has a while to run," highlighting concerns about its ongoing impact. The leaders also discussed economic cooperation and the need for coordinated efforts to address the pandemic's effects on the global economy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.66 points to 1,522.48 on Friday, driven by a higher volume of 4.488 billion lots worth RM2.939 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 518 to 406.

site_title: UK's office workers set to stay home as reopening falls flat
summary: The UK's office workers are unlikely to return to their desks as planned due to rising Covid-19 cases. Despite the government's guidance to end work-from-home restrictions on July 19, many companies, including major banks, are maintaining flexible work arrangements and occupancy limits. Only a few hundred staff members are expected to return to the office, with some companies redesigning their offices as collaborative spaces. The lack of clear guidance on masks and occupancy levels has led to caution among employees, and businesses are waiting for the end of the summer before reassessing their return-to-office plans.

images.alt_text: With little guidance from the government on masks or occupancy levels, most companies looking to boost in-person attendance are now waiting for the end of the summer.

site_title: Why are there more successful older golfers today?
summary: A group of professional golfers, including Phil Mickelson, Stewart Cink, and Lee Westwood, are defying age and expectation to contend and win tournaments and majors. These middle-age mavericks have learned to stay fit and play smarter, making better decisions on the course. Key factors contributing to their success include a better fitness regimen, strategic play, and a focus on recovery and downtime. Experts attribute their longevity in golf to maintaining leg strength, walking instead of riding, and fueling their bodies with the right foods.

images.alt_text: England's Lee Westwood (left) and Stewart Cink, along with PGA Championship winner Phil Mickelson are among a group of professional golfers who are defying age and expectation to contend and win tournaments and majors.

England's Lee Westwood and Stewart Cink, along with PGA Championship winner Phil Mickelson (above) are among a group of professional golfers who are defying age and expectation to contend and win tournaments and majors.

site_title: Top China fund manager says EV stocks offer shelter from crackdown
summary: Top China fund manager Xiong Lin recommends holding electric vehicle (EV) stocks as a shelter from the regulatory crackdown on technology companies, citing policy support for the industry and its strategic growth potential. EV-related stocks have soared in valuations, with some trading at over 100 times their three-year average. Despite high valuations, Lin expects the sector to remain robust in the next three to five years, driven by China's goal of EVs accounting for 20% of vehicles sold by 2025 and its ambition to reach carbon neutrality by 2060.

images.alt_text: Zeekr 001, a model from Geely's new premium electric vehicle (EV) brand Zeekr. Deemed an area of strategic growth, Beijing's goal is for EVs to account for 20 per cent of vehicles sold in 2025.

site_title: Eiffel Tower reopens after eight-month Covid closure
summary: The Eiffel Tower in Paris reopened on July 16, 2021, after an eight-month closure due to the Covid-19 pandemic, its longest shutdown since World War II. Visitors were required to wear masks and follow social distancing measures, with each elevator car carrying half the normal capacity. From July 21, visitors must show a French government "health pass" to demonstrate vaccination or a recent negative test. The reopening was met with cheers and applause from visitors, who expressed excitement and relief at finally being able to experience the iconic landmark.

site_title: Malaysia to allow commercial sale of Covid-19 vaccines
summary: Malaysia is set to allow the commercial sale of Covid-19 vaccines manufactured by Sinopharm and Sinovac, amid a surge in cases. The Sinopharm vaccine, approved for emergency use, will be available for private purchase. About 39% of the adult population has received at least one dose of a Covid-19 vaccine. This move aims to boost inoculation rates, which have been one of the fastest in the region.

site_title: STI caps choppy week with 0.39% gain
summary: Singapore shares closed higher on Friday, ending a two-day losing streak, with the Straits Times Index rising 12.32 points or 0.39% to 3,152.30. Strong trade data, including a 15.9% jump in non-oil domestic exports, lifted sentiments, while caution prevailed due to rising Covid-19 infections. The STI gained 20.9 points or 0.7% week-on-week, bringing its year-to-date gain to nearly 11%.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks finish lower for third straight session
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower for a third consecutive session, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.98% to 28,003.08 and the Topix index losing 0.38% to 1,932.19. Investors' caution was driven by surging virus cases in Tokyo one week before the Olympic Games begin.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks closed lower for a third consecutive session on Friday with investors cautious as virus cases surge in Tokyo one week before the Olympic Games begin.

site_title: Hong Kong watchdog says Binance not licensed to sell stock tokens
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) stated that Binance, a major cryptocurrency exchange, is not licensed to sell "stock tokens" in the city. The SFC considers these tokens as securities, which require authorization to sell to the public. Binance announced it would stop selling the products following warnings from regulators in other countries, including the US, Italy, Thailand, Japan, and Germany. The SFC vowed to take enforcement action against unlicensed platform operators, emphasizing its commitment to upholding securities laws.

site_title: Nightlife outfits suspended for two weeks from July 16 to 30
summary: Singapore has suspended all nightlife establishments for two weeks from July 16 to 30 due to a Covid-19 cluster linked to KTV joints and nightclubs. Over 400 businesses will be affected, with staff required to undergo testing and adhere to safe management measures before reopening. Individuals who visited these establishments are advised to undergo compulsory testing and self-isolate for 14 days. The suspension aims to curb the spread of the virus and prevent further transmission.

site_title: F&B, retail outlets brace for tightened Covid-19 measures amid KTV cluster spread
summary: Singapore's food and beverage and retail industries are bracing for tightened Covid-19 measures amid the growing KTV cluster, which has grown to 88 cases. The multi-ministry task force is deliberating on the type of measures to take, with Finance Minister Lawrence Wong expected to provide an update soon. Businesses are worried that the recent relaxation of measures will be reversed, with some owners hoping for targeted restrictions on KTV segments and others expecting more general measures. The tightened measures are expected to impact the livelihoods of many F&B and nightlife operators, with the retail industry also anticipating a blow to confidence.

site_title: BT podcast: GovTech's Li Hongyi on balancing best of big tech and digital government
summary: Singapore's approach to digital government is discussed by Li Hongyi, director of open government products at GovTech Singapore. The conversation focuses on balancing modern tech practices to help governments and citizens. Li highlights the country's success in implementing the Covid-19 vaccine appointment system and the "HelpGov" initiative, showcasing Singapore's approach to leveraging technology to improve governance and citizen services. The episode emphasizes the importance of finding a balance between adopting best practices from big tech and implementing digital solutions tailored to government needs.

site_title: Bitcoin miners navigate extreme world of crypto power-hunting
summary: Bitcoin miners in China, who were recently banned due to concerns over illicit coal mining and financial risks, are scrambling to relocate their millions of computers. A gathering of hundreds of miners in a luxury hotel in western China heard presentations from Bitmain Technologies, the world's largest mining equipment maker, on alternative locations such as Texas and Kazakhstan. The attendees discussed a dismal outlook for their local industry, highlighting the challenges of decentralization and independence in the crypto sector. The miners must now navigate the extreme world of crypto power-hunting to ensure their operations remain viable.

images.alt_text: A Bitcoin mining rig is usually made up of thousands of computers, specially built to run the complex calculations that maintain the cryptocurrency's network.
A Bitcoin mining operation needs power supply, substations and transformers - devices that filter the high powered volts in the power grid to be gentle enough that they will not fry the computers.

site_title: The future of space is bigger than Jeff Bezos, Richard Branson, or Elon Musk
summary: Private space companies, including those led by billionaires like Jeff Bezos, Richard Branson, and Elon Musk, are transforming the orbital economy with unprecedented speed. Decades of false starts have given way to commercialization, with dozens of private companies launching satellites and space tourism ventures. The industry's growth is driven by easier access to public markets, attracting billions of dollars from investors. Recent discoveries, such as Decker Eveleth's satellite imagery analysis, demonstrate the potential for private eyes to uncover critical information. While concerns about frivolity and scientific uselessness persist, technological advances like satellite Internet services and crop health monitoring highlight the value of pure science and the democratizing effects of private space enterprises.

site_title: BOJ cuts growth forecast, unveils outline of climate scheme
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) lowered its growth forecast for the current fiscal year to 3.8% from 4.0%, citing a moderate recovery. However, it revised up its forecast for the next fiscal year to 2.7%. The central bank also unveiled a climate scheme to boost funding for climate change activities, offering zero-interest loans to banks that extend green and sustainability-linked loans. The scheme will run from this fiscal year to fiscal 2030 and aims to address long-term structural issues beyond the pandemic.

site_title: China finances Apec fund for Covid-19
summary: China has financed the setup of a fund under the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) group to combat COVID-19 and support economic recovery. President Xi Jinping also expressed support for waiving intellectual property rights for COVID-19 vaccines and cooperation on vaccine supply chains. He emphasized the need for an open, fair, and unbiased digital commerce environment and called for the establishment of a high-level Asia-Pacific free trade zone.

site_title: A born-again runner: Sports Hub CEO Lionel Yeo
summary: Lionel Yeo, CEO of Singapore Sports Hub, shares his journey to better health and fitness in his 40s. After receiving a doctor's advice to build strength and muscle mass, he became a born-again runner, chalking up 60km a month. He credits his wife, Janice, for motivating him to work with a personal trainer and try guided meditation and plant-based meals. His health screenings show improved cholesterol, blood pressure, and bone density scores, demonstrating the benefits of his lifestyle changes.

images.alt_text: Lionel Yeo on a trail run at Bukit Timah.
With his family at 100PLUS Promenade, a popular place for runners and exercise groups.
Practising bodyweight and kettlebell workouts, "homework" given to him by his personal trainer.
On his Saturday morning run where he joins a group that meets at 6am to run about 10km at an easy, social pace.

site_title: Hot stock: Singapore Myanmar Investco up 24% after news of crypto cloud mining MOU
summary: Shares of Singapore Myanmar Investco rose 24% on Friday after the company signed a non-binding MOU with China-based The9 to launch a cryptocurrency cloud mining business. The company will develop a platform for Bitcoin, Filecoin, and Chia cryptocurrencies and plans to launch it in the fourth quarter of 2021. Singapore Myanmar Investco also entered into a cooperation agreement with Hang Zhou Suan Li Technology to purchase crypto mining machines and receive technical support.

site_title: Europe: Stocks advance at open
summary: European stock markets opened higher on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.5% to 7,045.47 points. The eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 also increased, with gains of 0.2% and 0.4% respectively. Investors appeared to shrug off concerns over resurgent coronavirus cases and Asian losses.

site_title: Dine-in group size reduced to 2 from July 19; cap of 5 remains for those fully vaccinated
summary: Singapore to reduce dine-in group size to 2 from July 19, with a cap of 5 for fully vaccinated individuals, amid a surge in community cases linked to a KTV cluster. The measures will last until August 8 and allow fully vaccinated individuals to dine-in in groups of 5 at participating establishments that check vaccination status. Children under 12 can dine with household members in groups of 5, while unvaccinated individuals with negative test results or recovered from Covid-19 can also join groups of 5.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end lower on virus worries, tech sell-off
summary: South Korean stocks ended lower on Friday, falling 0.28% to 3,276.91, amid virus worries and a decline in tech stocks. The Kospi rose 1.83% for the week, its sharpest gain since mid-April. Tech giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix fell 0.99% and 1.62%, respectively, while foreigners sold US$79.72 million worth of shares.

site_title: Australian officials race to stem Covid-19 outbreak
summary: Australia is racing to stem a Covid-19 outbreak fueled by the highly contagious Delta variant. A five-day snap lockdown in Victoria has been imposed, affecting 40% of the population, while neighboring New South Wales is expected to see a surge in cases. Total cases since mid-June have reached nearly 1,000, with Victoria reporting six new cases on Friday. Officials are tracking two chains of transmission and have tightened restrictions in South Australia. The Delta variant has raised concerns of a major fresh wave, despite Australia's relatively low case numbers and strict lockdown measures.

images.alt_text: Australia's Victoria reported a steady increase in locally acquired Covid-19 cases on Friday, the first day of a five-day snap lockdown across the state, while infections are expected to surge in neighbouring New South Wales.

site_title: China dispatches officials to inspect Didi's data security
summary: China has dispatched officials to inspect Didi Global's data security amid a probe into the ride-hailing giant. The Cyberspace Administration of China ordered app stores to remove Didi's services within China days after its initial public offering in the US. The probe, involving multiple government agencies, follows renewed scrutiny of China's tech giants over data and foreign IPOs. Didi's shares have dropped nearly 12% since its debut, and the company has warned of adverse impacts on its business. The investigation is part of tightened oversight over data and foreign listings.

site_title: Yellen 'not certain' Amazon would pay under global tax agreement
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen expressed uncertainty about whether Amazon will be required to pay taxes under a proposed global minimum corporate tax deal. The deal, which aims to end multinational companies shopping for low-tax countries, would tax companies with profit margins exceeding 10% regardless of where they're based. However, Amazon's 6.3% profit margin last year falls short of the threshold, making it unclear if the company will be subject to taxes under the agreement.

site_title: Australia: Shares end the week higher
summary: Australian shares rose to log their best week in six, driven by gains in the healthcare sector and mining giant BHP Group. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended the week 0.17% higher, despite lockdowns in major cities. BHP Group hit a record high as iron ore futures increased, and the healthcare sector rose 0.7% due to a stronger US dollar. New Zealand's benchmark index was flat, while its consumer price index beat expectations, leading to speculation of potential policy tightening.

site_title: China growth forecasts raised as consumer spending strengthens
summary: China's economic growth forecasts have been raised due to stronger-than-expected consumer spending and investment in June. Several economists, including Standard Chartered, JPMorgan, and ING Bank, upgraded their growth projections for the rest of the year. The country's economy steadied in the second quarter, with consumer spending and investment picking up, and industries like restaurants and hotels continuing to expand at a solid pace. This data shift has reduced pressure on policymakers, with the central bank moving away from a policy tightening bias.

site_title: 53 new locally transmitted Covid-19 cases including 32 linked to KTV cluster
summary: Singapore reported 53 new local Covid-19 cases, including 32 linked to the KTV cluster, as of July 16. 24 cases were linked to previous cases and 20 were detected through surveillance. There are currently nine unlinked cases.

site_title: Singapore's higher-end work passes: a short history
summary: Singapore's higher-end work passes have undergone significant changes over the years. The minimum salary for the S Pass, which allows mid-skilled foreign employees to work in Singapore, was raised from S$1,800 to S$4,500 over several increments. The Employment Pass (EP), which is available to more experienced applicants, has also seen multiple salary increases, with the current minimum salary being S$4,500 for new applicants and S$9,000 for more experienced applicants. The Personalised Employment Pass, a higher-tier pass, has a minimum salary of S$18,000 for new applicants and S$12,000 for existing EP holders.

site_title: Economists upgrade Singapore's trade outlook on hopes of strong export demand
summary: Economists have upgraded Singapore's trade outlook for 2021 due to strong export demand in the first half. Non-oil domestic exports (NODX) jumped 15.9% year-over-year in June, and growth is expected to stay strong for the next six months despite Covid-19 outbreaks in key markets. Analysts have raised forecasts for NODX growth, with some predicting it could be the best year since 2018. The strong export performance is driven by growth in electronics and petrochemicals, with exports to mainland China, Taiwan, and the European Union rising year-over-year.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore has implemented new measures to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. Starting July 19, dine-in groups are limited to 2 people, while fully-vaccinated patrons can still dine-in in groups of 5 at participating F&B outlets. Nightlife businesses are suspended for two weeks from July 16-30. The government has also announced wage and rental support for affected sectors, with extended support from July 26 to August 8. Economists have upgraded Singapore's trade outlook due to strong export demand.

images.alt_text: For three weeks from Monday July 19, dining-in at food and beverage (F&B) establishments will be scaled back to groups of no more than two people.

site_title: 1,300 lift and escalator technicians to benefit from enhanced progressive wage model
summary: The Singapore government has accepted recommendations to increase wages and implement annual bonuses for 1,300 lift and escalator technicians, with basic monthly wages set to rise from S$1,850 in 2022 to over S$3,000 by 2029. The Lift Progressive Wage Model will also include escalator maintenance workers from 2022, and adoption will become mandatory from July 2022. The wage increases aim to narrow the income gaps with the average worker and recognize the industry's importance.

site_title: South Korean PM says further gathering limits may be needed as Covid-19 cases rise
summary: South Korean Prime Minister Kim Boo Kyum announced that further gathering limits may be needed due to the rising number of Covid-19 cases, which have reached 1,536 new cases. The Delta variant is fuelling the new wave of infections. The government has already imposed a semi-lockdown in the greater Seoul area, and Kim urged local governments to standardize gathering limits to less than four people in the non-metropolitan area. Total infections stand at 175,046 cases and 2,051 deaths, with the number of confirmed cases continuing to spiral.

site_title: Qian Hu back in black in H1 with net profit of S$856,500
summary: Qian Hu Corporation, a mainboard-listed integrated fish service provider, reported a net profit of S$856,500 in the first half of the year, reversing a loss of S$525,237 in the same period last year. Revenue rose 19.5% to S$39.7 million, driven by a sustained recovery in its ornamental fish and aquaculture business. Sales of aquarium and pet accessories have reached pre-pandemic levels, according to the company. Earnings per share were 0.75 Singapore cent, compared to a loss of 0.46 cent in the previous year.

site_title: Brokers' take: PhillipCapital initiates HRnetGroup with 'buy', S$1 target price
summary: PhillipCapital initiated a "buy" call on HRnetGroup, projecting an expected turnaround in the hiring landscape, particularly in permanent recruitment and flexible staffing. The firm cited the company's asset-light business model, strong income-generating business, and high returns on equity. A target price of S$1 is set, representing a 30% upside from its last closing share price of S$0.77. PhillipCapital praises HRnetGroup's cash-rich status, low capital expenditure, and expansion opportunities in North Asia, particularly China.

site_title: Pakistan moves to bring cryptocurrency boom out of the dark
summary: Pakistan is taking steps to regulate its booming cryptocurrency industry, following criticism from the global money laundering watchdog. The government has set up a committee to study cryptocurrency regulation, with observers from the Financial Action Task Force (FATF) and experts from the country's intelligence agencies. The move comes as institutions have treated cryptocurrency traders with suspicion, and advocates have been arrested on charges of money laundering. Pakistan's crypto boom shows no signs of slowing, with thousands of traders and investors eager to learn about mining and trading cryptocurrencies.

site_title: Australian leaders under pressure to contain Covid-19 outbreak
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison and state premiers face pressure to contain a growing Covid-19 outbreak fueled by the Delta variant. The outbreak, centered in Sydney, has led to 103 new cases, with 2 deaths and 75 hospitalizations. Critics blame the government's slow vaccine rollout, lax quarantine measures, and flipflopping guidance for widespread vaccine hesitancy. The situation has prompted calls for stricter lockdowns and tighter restrictions, with economists forecasting a significant economic hit, estimated at A$1 billion per week.

site_title: Bank of Japan cuts this year's growth forecast, unveils outline of climate scheme
summary: The Bank of Japan cut its fiscal year growth forecast to 3.8% for the current year and 2.7% for the following year, down from 4.0% and 2.4% previously. The central bank maintained its monetary policy stance, keeping short-term interest rates at -0.1% and 10-year bond yields at 0%. The BOJ unveiled a new climate scheme, offering zero-interest funds for financial institutions to boost loans and investments in combating climate change.

site_title: Property heir urges Hong Kong to improve land policy
summary: Hong Kong property heir Adam Kwok criticized the local government's land policies, suggesting an overhaul to address the city's housing shortage. Kwok, an executive director at Sun Hung Kai Properties, urged the government to explore buffer zones along wetlands and green belt areas, and to speed up infrastructure construction. He praised Chief Executive Carrie Lam's proposals but emphasized the need for a dedicated team and policies to solve the issues. Hong Kong's housing market continues to face pressure, with home prices expected to break records and demand outpacing supply.

site_title: The AI advantage for Asia's SMEs
summary: Small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in Asia need better access to advanced AI technologies to compete with larger enterprises in the evolving digital landscape. The pandemic has accelerated online adoption, with 40 million new internet users in Southeast Asia alone in 2020, intensifying competition. To stay ahead, SMEs must harness AI to improve customer experiences and business processes. As AI veteran and board member of iKala, the author emphasizes the need for SMEs to adapt to the digital landscape, citing the exponential growth of online platforms and the changing consumer behavior.

site_title: China plans to exempt Hong Kong IPOs from cybersecurity reviews
summary: China plans to exempt Hong Kong IPOs from cybersecurity reviews, removing a hurdle for companies seeking to list in the Asian financial hub. Under the new framework, companies will still need approval from the China Securities Regulatory Commission, but vetting will focus on compliance with local laws. This move is aimed at reducing regulatory hurdles for businesses and helping Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing, which has seen its stock surge in recent years. The exemption is seen as a bid to retain Chinese companies from listing in the US, where regulators have expressed concerns over data security risks.

site_title: Rescuers draining flooded tunnel in search for trapped Chinese workers
summary: Rescuers in southern China are battling to reach 14 construction workers trapped in a flooded tunnel under a reservoir. The workers were trapped in an underground section after a highway construction site collapsed in the early hours of Thursday morning. Water began flooding in before everyone could evacuate, and they are now 1,160m away from the tunnel's entrance. Rescue efforts have been hampered by the large influx of water, with five mobile pump trucks hauling out 15,400 cubic meters of water per hour. The construction is part of a new highway project connecting Hong Kong, Macau, and Zhuhai.

site_title: Asia: Shares slip as investors look past upbeat tech earnings
summary: Asian shares declined on Friday as investors took profits from Taiwanese chip giant TSMC's record profits, despite a more dovish US rates outlook. TSMC's 4% fall weighed on other tech firms, while bond yields remained near multi-month lows. The US dollar rose for its best weekly gain in about a month, and gold hit a one-month high. Oil prices stayed under pressure due to a compromise deal between OPEC producers and a weak US fuel demand.

images.alt_text: TSMC's fall weighed on many other semiconductor related shares in the region, with South Korea's Kospi down 0.6 per cent and Japan's Nikkei losing 1.1 per cent.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 7.49 points, or 0.49%, to 1,513.33. The market saw 255 losers compared to 153 gainers. The lower opening came despite positive news from Singapore and Europe, where mining and healthcare stocks rose, and US stocks edged to fresh records.

site_title: At least 67 dead in Germany, Belgium as storms ravage Europe
summary: Heavy rains and floods in western Europe have killed at least 67 people, with 59 in Germany and eight in Belgium, as rising waters caused several houses to collapse. Rescue efforts were hindered by the severe weather, with residents seeking refuge on rooftops. The floods also affected neighboring countries, including Luxembourg, the Netherlands, and Belgium, where evacuations were ordered. This is one of the worst weather disasters in Germany since World War II.

site_title: Singapore exports up 15.9% in June on year-ago low base, with boost from semicon, petrochem demand
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rose 15.9% in June, beating the median forecast, driven by strong demand for semiconductors and petrochemicals. Electronics NODX increased by 25.5%, while non-electronics NODX expanded by 13.2%. This marks the seventh consecutive month of growth, as the country benefits from a low base.

site_title: FLCT's S$150m 2.18% sustainability notes due 2028 three times subscribed
summary: Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) has priced S$150 million of its 2.18% sustainability notes due 2028, three times subscribed to a final order book of S$450 million. The seven-year fixed-rate notes are rated BBB+ by S&P and will be used to finance or refinance eligible sustainability projects. This is the first-ever sustainability note priced in the Singapore dollar bond market. Net proceeds will be allocated to support FLCT's sustainability initiatives, with institutional investors and banks contributing to the deal.

site_title: WhatsApp tests breaking free from smartphones
summary: WhatsApp is testing a feature allowing users to break free from smartphones and use the messaging service on multiple non-phone devices, such as computers, without needing a smartphone app. This new capability enables users to use WhatsApp on up to four devices simultaneously, even if their phone battery is dead. The feature aims to remove hurdles in the current system, which requires a smartphone to perform every operation, and maintains the same level of security and privacy through end-to-end encryption. The new capability will be expanded as it is refined, with assurances that WhatsApp's security measures will still work.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge lower as lockdowns weigh
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% on Friday as lockdowns in Victoria and Sydney weighed on investor sentiment. The S&P/ASX 200 index was set to post a weekly gain of over 0.5%. Miners, including Rio Tinto and BHP Group, declined due to increased labor and input costs. Healthcare stocks, however, rose, led by CSL, as the US dollar advanced.

site_title: Oil prices sink again, as investors look out for more supply
summary: Oil prices dropped by more than $1 a barrel on Thursday, settling at $73.47 for Brent crude and $71.65 for US West Texas Intermediate, due to expectations of increased supply after a potential deal between Opec producers and the United Arab Emirates. A compromise agreement is still pending, and investors are concerned about the impact of the deal on the tight oil market. Despite a drawdown in US crude stockpiles, prices fell due to rising fuel inventories and concerns about supply. Analysts expect supplies to remain tight in the coming months.

site_title: One in two Covid-19 hospital cases develop complications: study
summary: A new study of over 70,000 hospital patients in the UK found that one in two Covid-19 hospital cases develop complications, with common issues including kidney and lung problems, neurological, and cardiovascular conditions. The study also found that nearly one-third of patients experienced difficulties caring for themselves after discharge. Researchers warn that the true impact of Covid-19 extends beyond death, particularly in younger people, and call for longer-term monitoring and specialized follow-up care for survivors.

site_title: F&B demand in Singapore's CBD picks up after dine-in group size upped to five
summary: Singapore's CBD restaurants see a revival in demand after the government relaxed dine-in group size limits to five. Several Chinese restaurants have reported a 25-55% increase in bookings since July 12, with groups of four or five customers returning. However, operators note that corporate bookings remain weak due to work-from-home and other restrictions. Despite this, businesses are optimistic about recovery, with efforts to improve delivery and takeaway services, and some restaurants gearing up for the Mid-Autumn Festival.

images.alt_text: F&B establishments in the CBD say corporate crowds have begun to trickle back in.

site_title: China launches long-awaited carbon trading scheme
summary: China launched its long-awaited emissions trading system, a key tool to drive down climate change-causing greenhouse gases and achieve carbon neutrality by 2060. The scheme sets pollution caps for big-power businesses, allowing firms to buy the right to pollute from others with a lower carbon footprint. Initially covering 2,225 power producers, accounting for about a seventh of global carbon emissions, the market is expected to be about a third the size of Europe's market. Analysts say it is not a quick climate fix and could take years before China changes course.

site_title: Top US general feared Trump 'Reichstag' power seizure: book
summary: US Joint Chiefs Chairman Mark Milley feared a "Reichstag moment" where then-President Donald Trump would suspend the constitution to retain power, similar to Adolf Hitler's 1933 takeover. Milley expressed concerns Trump's refusal to accept defeat in the 2020 election and his calls for a march on Washington and January 6 rally. He schemed with other officials to resign to signal opposition to a potential coup. Milley warned that Trump's actions could not succeed without military and intelligence backing.

site_title: Europe: Bourses sink on growth worries, disappointing earnings
summary: Europe's stocks fell 1.2% on Thursday, snapping a four-day rally, due to disappointing earnings and concerns over growth. The Stoxx 600 index dropped 1% as oil majors Royal Dutch Shell and BP fell 2% amid falling crude prices. Economically sensitive stocks like banks and automakers also declined. Analysts attribute the downturn to rising Covid-19 cases and inflationary pressures, with the ECB and BoE expected to consider monetary policy tightening. UK-based cybersecurity firm Avast surged 18% after merger talks.

site_title: Singapore stocks little changed at Friday's open; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.1% or 1.44 points to 3,138.54 at 9:01am, with 59 gainers outnumbering 52 losers. The most actively traded securities were Sembcorp Marine, KTL Global EB7, and Singapore Myanmar Investco. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC fell 0.03%, 0.04%, and 0.3% respectively. This follows a similar trend on Wall Street, where major indices ended mostly lower due to profit-taking and concerns ahead of earnings season.

site_title: Brokers' take: RHB says 2021 likely a record year for Reit acquisitions
summary: RHB expects 2021 to be a record year for Reit acquisitions, with S$7 billion in acquisitions year-to-date, exceeding expectations. The research team maintains its "overweight" call on S-Reits, citing industrial Reits for earnings resilience. The valuation gap between small-mid-cap and large-cap Reits has narrowed, with small-mid-cap Reits outperforming by 10% in the year to date. A stronger economic rebound and positive policy shift in Singapore are expected to drive market activity in the second half of 2021, potentially surpassing the S$10 billion record level of acquisitions in 2019 and 2020.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly fall in profit taking after records
summary: US stocks declined on Thursday, falling 0.3% and 0.7% in the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index, respectively, after reaching records earlier in the week. Analysts attributed the drop to profit-taking following strong corporate results and a bullish outlook for the US economy. Federal Reserve Chair Jay Powell's congressional testimony reinforced the central bank's plan to maintain stimulus initiatives. New data showed a decline in US unemployment benefits and a drop in China's GDP growth, but stronger-than-expected retail sales and industrial production data offset the weaker GDP figure.

site_title: WTO chief seeks to wrap up fish talks as developing countries cry foul
summary: World Trade Organization (WTO) Director-General Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala expressed optimism about reaching a deal to curb overfishing by year-end, despite criticism from developing countries, including India, over parts of the draft agreement. The 20-year talks aimed to fix rules on harmful subsidies leading to overfishing. The WTO has not reached a global deal in years, and Okonjo-Iweala's success will be a key test of her credibility. The virtual conference in Geneva marked the first meeting of WTO trade ministers since 2017.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, down 1.12% at 27,961.70, amid expanding virus infections at home just days before the Olympic Games. The Nikkei 225 index fell 317.39 points, while the Topix index lost 12.86 points. Investors are cautious, following a mixed close on Wall Street.

site_title: Stocks to watch: FLCT, PropNex, APAC Realty, AEI, Mercurius, UOL, Sembmarine
summary: Several Singaporean companies saw notable developments on Friday. Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust priced S$150 million of sustainability notes, with the issuance three times subscribed. PropNex and APAC Realty saw significant share price increases, with PropNex rising 5.5% and APAC Realty gaining 7.9%. AEI Corporation surged 19% after afternoon trading, while Mercurius Capital Investment faced a 14.1% decline after responding to SGX queries about its acquisition of a Malaysian supermarket chain. UOL will launch a new condominium project, and Sembcorp Marine was questioned by the Securities Investors Association Singapore regarding its proposed rights issue.

site_title: Uniqlo owner trims profit forecast citing fresh Covid-19 related curbs
summary: Fast Retailing, owner of Uniqlo, trimmed its profit forecast for the fiscal year due to additional government restrictions in Japan and other markets to contain fresh Covid-19 infections. The company now expects operating profit to rise 64% year-over-year to 245 billion yen, down from a previous estimate of 255 billion yen. Japan's fourth coronavirus state of emergency in Tokyo has slowed customer traffic to stores, affecting the company's resilience during the pandemic.

site_title: SoftBank invests US$1.7b in Korea's Yanolja ahead of IPO
summary: SoftBank's Vision Fund II has invested approximately US$1.7 billion in Yanolja Co, a Seoul-based travel app ahead of its initial public offering (IPO). The investment will be used to expand geographically and bring digital technologies to the travel and hospitality industry. Yanolja, founded in 2005, aims to tap into Korea's resurgent tech scene. This investment follows SoftBank's expansion in South Korea, which has led to successful IPOs for companies like Coupang Inc.

site_title: The future of bling
summary: Jewellery sales continue to grow, driven by e-commerce and pent-up demand during the pandemic. Luxury brands such as LVMH and Richemont have seen significant increases in jewellery sales, with online revenues playing a key role. The fine jewellery market is expected to grow at a 3-4% compound annual growth rate between 2019 and 2025, with Asia accounting for 45% of sales. Luxury brands are leveraging technology, including AI and augmented reality, to enhance the online experience and sell their products.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares edge down at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower, with the Hang Seng Index down 0.08% to 27,973.05, amid a mixed US stock market finish and concerns over US President Joe Biden's potential advisory on doing business in the city. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also fell 0.14% each. The decline follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and comes ahead of the expected advisory.

site_title: Swiss franc marches higher against struggling euro
summary: The euro hit a five-month low against the Swiss franc due to growing signs of a slowdown in China and a rise in Covid-19 cases globally. Safe-haven government bond yields declined, weakening the dollar against the franc and yen. The US dollar also lost value after Federal Reserve Chief's dovish comments broke a recent rise in Treasury yields.

site_title: Intel in talks to buy GlobalFoundries for about US$30b: WSJ
summary: Intel Corp is reportedly in talks to buy GlobalFoundries Inc for approximately US$30 billion, according to the Wall Street Journal. The talks do not include GlobalFoundries directly, as the company claims not to be in discussions with Intel. The potential deal could help Intel ramp up chip production, addressing a global semiconductor shortage and supporting its plans to start manufacturing chips for car makers. Intel aims to expand its advanced chip manufacturing capacity in the US, while GlobalFoundries has manufacturing facilities across the US, Europe, and Asia.

site_title: 'Extreme' wildfires and heavy smoke grip western US and Canada
summary: Wildfires in the western US and Canada continue to spread, fueled by extreme heat and dry conditions. The Bootleg Fire in Oregon has grown to 227,000 acres, threatening 2,000 homes, while a new California blaze, the Dixie Fire, has doubled in size and is near the town of Paradise, devastated by the 2018 Camp Fire. The region has seen consecutive heat waves, worsened by global warming, with air quality alerts issued in British Columbia. The US wildfire officials have raised the inter-agency preparedness level to the highest tier, citing the devastating effects of climate change.

images.alt_text: A brutal start to the wildfire season in the western United States and Canada worsened Thursday as a massive Oregon blaze exploded in dry, windy conditions and a new California blaze threatened communities devastated by the 2018 Camp Fire.

site_title: Higher S Pass salary alone won't help local workers: economists
summary: Economists say raising the minimum salary for S Pass holders in Singapore is unlikely to benefit local workers unless more action is taken to boost productivity and address automation concerns. The proposal, while welcomed as a step towards a higher-skilled economy, may not be enough to offset low productivity gains and the shift towards automated labor.

site_title: Now is the time to take a fresh view of the Singapore-China trade corridor opportunities
summary: Singapore's economy is poised for growth, with a rebound in GDP growth in the first quarter and a projected 6.3% expansion for 2021. The country's success in managing the pandemic has positioned it well to reap the benefits of the global recovery. A fresh view of the Singapore-China trade corridor is needed to capitalize on opportunities, including digital transformation, sustainability, and ecommerce. China is forecast to grow 8% this year, and the two countries have a long history of collaboration, with Singapore being a key player in the region's largest ecommerce platforms and smart city development.

images.alt_text: Singapore's trade relationship with China has been one of the most important in the past three decades and as both nations look to accelerate their post-pandemic recoveries, the Singapore-China corridor will drive future growth and prosperity.

site_title: Self-driving car startup Aurora on road to going public
summary: Aurora, a self-driving car startup, is set to go public through a merger with Reinvent Technology Partners Y, valuing it at $13 billion. The deal, expected to be completed by the end of the year, will allow Aurora to trade on the Nasdaq with the ticker symbol AUR. Backed by Amazon, Fiat Chrysler, and Hyundai, Aurora aims to commercialize self-driving technology at scale for the US trucking and passenger transportation markets. The company's co-founder and chief, Chris Urmson, expressed optimism about deploying self-driving vehicles and delivering benefits to the world.

images.alt_text: Self-driving car startup Aurora on Thursday announced it is taking a side road to going public in a transaction valuing it at US$13 billion.

site_title: US to see 'several more months' of high inflation, Yellen says
summary: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen predicts the US will experience "several more months" of high inflation before it retreats to "normal levels" over the medium term. The producer price index rose 7.3% and the consumer price index climbed 5.4% in the 12 months ended in June, fueled by the economy's bounceback from the Covid-19 pandemic. Yellen also expressed concern over housing prices, warning that higher prices could create affordability issues for first-time homebuyers.

site_title: Covid crisis offers silver lining for Indonesia's healthcare sector
summary: Indonesia's healthcare sector faces a crisis amid the COVID-19 pandemic, with the country's GDP growth forecast slashed to 3.7-4.5% and rising cases forcing lockdowns and closures. The government's response has been criticized for being late and ineffective, with hospitals overwhelmed and medical supplies in short supply. However, the crisis may also offer a silver lining, with the need to leverage technology, data analytics, and artificial intelligence to transform the healthcare sector and improve its response to future pandemics.

site_title: Beyond Meat bites bullet, opens online store in China
summary: Beyond Meat has launched an online store on JD.com's e-commerce platform in China, aiming to boost sales in the country's largest meat market. The move comes as consumer interest in meat alternatives is low in China. The online store will initially be available in four major cities, with plans to expand to 300 cities nationwide. Beyond Meat's products will be delivered within 48 hours of orders being placed, with prices starting at 210 yuan for a half-kg twin pack of plant-based beef.

site_title: Blackstone to buy US$7.3b of AIG housing, insurance assets
summary: American International Group (AIG) agreed to sell a 9.9% stake in its life and retirement business to Blackstone Group Inc for $2.2 billion in cash, and affordable-housing assets for $5.1 billion. The deal builds on Blackstone's expansion into insurance to generate steady capital and reduce reliance on private equity fundraising. The asset-management relationship is expected to grow to $92.5 billion in six years, with Blackstone's president and COO Jon Gray joining the AIG board.

site_title: OGSE firms must embrace low-carbon future to stay competitive: Petronas
summary: Malaysia's oil and gas industry is facing a tough period, with the Covid-19 pandemic accelerating the energy transition and a supply glut eroding profit margins. Petronas senior executive Hazli Sham Kassim says the industry must adapt to a low-carbon future to stay competitive, with the state-owned energy firm aiming to achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2050. Only 32 of the 2,800 active OGSE companies in Malaysia have adopted sustainability reporting, highlighting the need for increased ESG awareness.

site_title: The value of control rooms for modern issues
summary: Control rooms play a crucial role in modern operations, enabling swift decision-making by gathering and analyzing data from various sources. As the volume of data increases, control room operators must prioritize speed and accuracy to stay competitive. Control rooms also facilitate public safety by providing real-time information, allowing decision-makers to break down barriers and enhance collaboration capabilities. Effective control room solutions can support the development of smart cities and digital operations, ultimately driving success in various industries.

site_title: Soho House entering a club of its own: The stock market
summary: Membership Collective Group (MCG), the parent company of Soho House, has begun trading on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) at a valuation of approximately $2.8 billion. The company raised $420 million from its initial public offering (IPO) and plans to expand its global presence, opening 3-5 new clubs annually. MCG aims to pay down debt and turn a profit by the end of 2022, with a focus on diversifying its offerings and expanding beyond its traditional high-end market.

site_title: A love for the classics
summary: Joel Chin, a creative director, has curated a Mid-Century Modern home filled with iconic furniture pieces, including an Eames Lounge Chair and Ottoman, Barcelona chairs, and an Egg Chair. Chin, a self-proclaimed design aficionado, values the importance of original design and refuses to compromise on quality, opting for licensed manufacturers like Herman Miller and Knoll. His home showcases a mix of classic and contemporary pieces, highlighting the evolution of design over time, and serves as a testament to the enduring power of good design.

site_title: Toyota's tech arm plans major hiring push in self-driving race
summary: Toyota's tech arm, Woven Planet Holdings, plans a major hiring and acquisition push to lead the company in the self-driving car market. CEO James Kuffner aims to double or quadruple the company's size in the next couple of years. This move comes as carmakers globally compete to develop smart cars that will one day drive themselves. The hiring spree is part of Toyota's efforts to blur the lines between technology and cars.

site_title: When living off gaming may not be a fair gig
summary: A new income stream is emerging in the digital economy, where gaming platforms are selling access to users in Southeast Asia, allowing games to trade in digital assets for fiat money. This "player-based economy" in blockchain games raises questions about its sustainability and whether it capitalizes on "desperate labor". The concept is being explored in a Business Times Weekend article.

site_title: How far do a CEO's powers reach?
summary: A recent tussle at ecoWise Holdings, a Singapore-based company, has highlighted the power dynamics between a CEO and the board. The dispute has shed light on the rights and responsibilities of both parties, with implications for corporate governance. The outcome is still uncertain, leaving investors and stakeholders waiting for clarity on the company's future direction.

site_title: China growth slows to 7.9% in second quarter
summary: China's economy slowed to 7.9% growth in the second quarter, down from 18.3% in the first quarter, due to manufacturing slowing and consumer demand not picking up as quickly as expected. The National Bureau of Statistics attributed the decline to external uncertainties and uneven domestic recovery. Despite this, China is still on track to meet its growth target of over 6% for the year. Surging raw material costs and supply shortages are weighing on manufacturers, but household consumption is expected to be supported by rising vaccination and corporate investment.

site_title: Two bungalows in Cluny Road in early stage of being sold for S$91m
summary: Two adjacent old freehold bungalows on Cluny Road in Singapore's Good Class Bungalow (GCB) Area have been sold for S$91 million, with options to purchase granted at about S$3,000 per square foot. The properties, owned by lawyer Laurence Wee and Ronald Ooi of Kim Eng Securities, are ripe for redevelopment and are being bought by a family of Indonesian Chinese origin. This sale follows a record-breaking S$30 million deal for an old bungalow on Second Avenue, which reflects a record S$2,045 per square foot price for GCB redevelopment land.

images.alt_text: Options for both bungalows in Cluny Road (above) are said to have long exercise periods till early next year.
Options for both bungalows in Cluny Road (above) are said to have long exercise periods till early next year.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall as expected
summary: US jobless claims fell 26,000 to 360,000 in the week ended July 10, as expected. Despite a record 9.2 million job openings, worker shortages continue to frustrate businesses trying to hire amid strong demand for goods and services. The early termination of federal unemployment benefits, which started on June 12, has not led to a surge in job searches, with economists expecting job gains to remain strong in coming months.

site_title: Cooking with the stars
summary: Thai celebrity couple Aimee Morakot and James Jirayuth Sangtaweep have designed a luxurious kitchen in their Bangkok home, featuring Sub-Zero and Wolf appliances, inspired by the action movie Mr & Mrs Smith. The professional layout was designed by Thai celebrity chef Ian Kittichai, who is a culinary ambassador for the brand. The kitchen is equipped with high-end appliances, including a side-by-side refrigerator, dual fuel range, and outdoor BBQ grill, which the couple uses for cooking and entertaining guests. Their kitchen showcases the quality and craftsmanship of Sub-Zero and Wolf, with both Aimee and James having their favorite uses for the appliances.

site_title: Property agents' share of pie shrinks as their ranks swell further
summary: The number of property agents in Singapore increased to 30,399 in 2021, despite a decline in sales transactions. Agents are diversifying their income streams, including rental properties and gig-economy work, to mitigate industry attrition. Robust property prices attracted individuals to join the agency business, with the industry growing to pre-2013 levels. Agents' productivity varies, with rental transactions yielding more deals on average, while sales transactions decreased. Competition is expected to intensify, with fewer new launches and completions, potentially leading to a decline in private home sales and rental transactions.

site_title: China should provide raw data on Covid origins: WHO chief
summary: The head of the World Health Organization (WHO), Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, urged China to provide raw data on the origins of Covid-19, citing the lack of transparency as a hindrance to investigations. A WHO-led team found the virus likely transmitted from bats to humans through another animal, but China has disputed this theory, calling it "absurd." The WHO is proposing a second phase of study, and international leaders, including German Health Minister Jens Spahn, are urging China to cooperate and provide more information.

site_title: UOB Asset Management sees quadrupling in SMEs investing online
summary: UOB Asset Management (UOBAM) has seen a 330% increase in SME users on its digital investment portal, UOBAM Invest, over the last 18 months, with total assets under management (AUM) surpassing S$1 billion. The growth reflects increasing demand from corporate investors for round-the-clock access to digital solutions, allowing for flexibility and personalized portfolios. The bank attributes the success to its user-friendly and secure digital platform, which has seen over 60% of users new to the banking group.

images.alt_text: In addition to offering the UOBAM Invest digital investment portal for corporate investors, UOBAM also has a mobile robo-advisory app dedicated to individual investors located in Singapore and Thailand.

"We have been enhancing our digital capabilities across various channels, products and services group-wide to offer our best-in-class solutions to more customers, including offering them the ease and convenience of self-serve online investing." - Wee Ee Cheong, deputy chairman and CEO, UOB.

site_title: Yellen, Powell to discuss financial risks of sizzling housing market
summary: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell will discuss the US housing market's financial risks at a meeting on Friday. The aim is to prevent a crisis similar to the 2008 property-price bubble that led to top banks' insolvency and a deep recession. The closed-door session focuses on ensuring the US financial system is resilient to potential risks. Yellen and Powell will assess the market's stability and consider measures to mitigate any potential threats.

site_title: Sydney Airport rejects A$22b buyout proposal amid deal frenzy
summary: Sydney Airport Holdings rejected a proposed A$22.26 billion buyout offer from a group of infrastructure funds, citing that the proposal undervalued the airport and did not deliver long-term value. The airport's board, which includes top-20 investor Argo Investments, will only consider a deal that recognizes the airport's value. The rejection comes as record-low interest rates have fueled a frenzy of Australian deals, with other assets such as Telstra Corp and Qube Holdings recently being acquired.

images.alt_text: Sydney Airport (above) is Australia's only listed airport operator. A deal would bring its ownership in line with the country's other major airports, owned by consortia of investors, primarily pension funds.

site_title: Malaysia to stop using Sinovac vaccine after supply ends: health minister
summary: Malaysia will stop using Sinovac's Covid-19 vaccine after its supplies end, citing concerns over efficacy, and will instead use the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine. The country has secured enough Pfizer doses to cover 70% of its population and has already distributed about half of the 16 million Sinovac doses. The Pfizer vaccine will be used for those who have yet to be vaccinated, and the government is also considering adding the Sinopharm vaccine to its approved list.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: mm2 Asia, a Singapore-listed entertainment group, responds to a Singapore Exchange (SGX) query stating there's no need to suspend trading of its shares due to concerns over its ability to continue as a going concern. The company had announced its auditor's report noting a material uncertainty that may cast significant doubt on its ability to continue. However, mm2 Asia believes it is able to demonstrate to SGX and shareholders it can continue operating.

site_title: Covid vaccine makers take aim at bottlenecks to speed up production
summary: Covid-19 vaccine manufacturers are launching an initiative to overcome production bottlenecks by linking with suppliers of vital materials, including filters, lipids, and vials. The platform, led by the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations, aims to accelerate the production of tens of millions of doses for global distribution through Covax. Manufacturers see addressing component shortages as a way to address inequitable access to vaccines, particularly in lower-income countries, and will focus on eliminating trade barriers and patent protection proposals. The platform will serve as a marketplace for confidentially matching buyers and sellers of essential supplies.

site_title: TSMC posts record quarterly sales
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) reported a record quarterly sales of $13.29 billion, a 28% increase from the same period last year. The company forecasts revenue for the current quarter to jump by at least a fifth, driven by a surge in global demand for semiconductors. TSMC's business has been boosted by the pandemic-led chip shortage, but the company expects overall semiconductor capacity tightness to extend into next year.

site_title: 'Carry is king' in credit market trapped in summer stalemate
summary: Global credit markets remain subdued, with investors focusing on bond coupons for profits. Analysts at JPMorgan Chase & Co and BNP Paribas SA describe the situation as "Carry is king," highlighting the return from simply holding a bond. The statement reflects the lackluster market environment, where investors are seeking stable returns rather than growth opportunities.

site_title: Diamonds, nickel - and S$1.46b of failed promises
summary: Singapore businessman Ng Yu Zhi, 34, is suspected of running a multi-million dollar investment fraud scheme that duped nearly 1,000 investors into parting with S$1.46 billion. Ng, who ran Envy Asset Management and Envy Global Trading, promised investors an average quarterly return of 15% and allegedly forged documents to convince them of the existence of nickel trades. Investors included prominent figures such as Temasek International general counsel Pek Siok Lan and former Law Society president Thio Shen Yi. Ng's companies were not audited, and authorities have confiscated over S$100 million in bank accounts and properties linked to him. Ng's bail has been raised to S$4 million, and he faces multiple counts of cheating and fraud.

site_title: China's shaking skyscraper 'safe to use' after minor repairs
summary: China's 300-meter SEG Plaza skyscraper, which shook violently in May, has been deemed "safe to use" after minor repairs, according to engineering experts. The building's wobble was caused by wind-related "vortex-induced vibration" and the ageing mast, not an earthquake. Officials plan to remove the mast to solve the issue of perceptible vibrations. Demolition and damage repairs will be carried out "in the near future." The building's main structure is considered safe under normal use conditions, allowing it to reopen.

site_title: 12 million to stay home in Australia as Delta strain surges worldwide
summary: Australia is imposing a 'hard and fast' lockdown on Melbourne and Sydney due to the surge of the Delta Covid-19 variant, with 12 million people expected to stay home. The highly infectious strain is spreading globally, from Asia to Africa, and countries are struggling to combat it. The lockdown follows Australia's successful 'Covid zero' strategy, which has now been breached. The Delta variant is being hampered by new strains, and the global battle against the disease is becoming increasingly challenging.

site_title: Wall Street has surrendered to the US$500b ETF rush
summary: US money managers have joined the surge in exchange-traded funds (ETFs), fueling a record-breaking influx of capital. In seven months, ETFs have attracted $483 billion, surpassing the 2020 full-year record of $497 billion. This trend is driven by investors seeking low-cost and diversified investment options. The stampede is expected to continue, potentially breaking the record in weeks or days. The surge in ETFs is part of a broader market trend, with other news outlets reporting on related topics such as China's slowing GDP growth and the impact of US tariffs.

site_title: Second BOE official says time to slow stimulus may be near
summary: The Bank of England's (BOE) Deputy Governor Michael Saunders has signaled that the time to slow stimulus may be near due to an unexpectedly sharp rise in inflation. Saunders stated that continuing bond purchases later this year could risk entrenching higher inflation expectations. The BOE has been buying £150 billion of government bonds to support the economy, but Saunders' comments suggest a possible reining in of this stimulus. This could lead to higher interest rates and a stronger pound, potentially slowing economic growth.

site_title: Manhattan's apartment rebound means sweet deals are fading fast
summary: Manhattan's apartment market is experiencing a rebound, with landlords raising rents and dialing back concessions. The share of deals with incentives fell to 38% in June, down from 60% in October. Average free rent has dropped to 1.9 months, the lowest since August. The pace of the rebound is faster in pricier neighborhoods, with some apartments getting snatched up quickly, leaving buyers with limited options. As the city's reopening lures back exiles, recent graduates and young professionals are competing for units, making it a busy market.

site_title: PropNex share price spike triggers SGX query; APAC Realty up 7.9%
summary: Shares of PropNex and APAC Realty surged 5.53% and 7.9% respectively, despite a decline in new private home sales in June. The sudden spike in shares has triggered a query from the Singapore Exchange (SGX). This follows a 9.8 times oversubscription of NTT DC Reit's public offer earlier this week.

site_title: US: Stocks edge lower, extending choppy trend
summary: US stocks declined early Thursday, extending a period of choppiness as investors weigh better employment data and the latest Federal Reserve commentary. New unemployment benefit applications fell to 360,000, the lowest level since the Covid-19 pandemic start. Despite this, Federal Reserve Chair Jay Powell acknowledged inflation had topped expectations, indicating the US economy still needs significant support to fully recover. The improving jobs picture and mixed Fed views led to a decline in stocks.

site_title: Emerging markets need an inclusive approach to net-zero
summary: Emerging markets face a significant challenge in achieving net-zero emissions due to the current approach of doubling weight of clean energy solution providers while reducing allocations to sectors with high emissions. This approach disproportionately burdens emerging markets, and doubling weight of emerging market stocks increases emissions by 10%, while sovereign bond indices increase emissions per GDP by 22%. To address this, net-zero targets should reward both improvement and end-states, and be calculated in a way that does not drive capital away from sectors and regions that need to transition.

site_title: Two CEOs, no drama - Ground rules for co-leadership
summary: A global consumer goods company's co-leadership model failed due to conflicts, stalled initiatives, and lack of direction, resulting in executive departures. Despite initial success, the arrangement proved unworkable. Experts point to rare instances of successful co-leaderships, such as in the health sector, but note that other industries, like professional services and family firms, often thrive with a single leader. To avoid similar pitfalls, companies should establish clear ground rules for co-leadership, prioritize effective communication, and define roles and responsibilities to ensure a cohesive and productive leadership structure.

site_title: Blue Origin says will fly 18-year-old to space on July 20
summary: Blue Origin announced that 18-year-old Oliver Daemen will fly to space on July 20 aboard the company's maiden crewed spaceflight on New Shepard. Daemen, who holds a private pilot's license, will become the youngest astronaut to travel to space. He will join founder Jeff Bezos, Mark Bezos, and 82-year-old Wally Funk on the historic flight, marking the beginning of commercial operations for New Shepard.

site_title: China home price growth slows for first time since Nov
summary: China's new home price growth slowed for the first time since November last year, with a 0.5% month-on-month increase in June, down from 0.6% in May. This marks the first slowdown since December 2020. The slowdown is attributed to government measures to cool the housing market, including tightening credit conditions and existing curbs. New home prices rose 4.7% compared to the previous year, down from a 4.9% increase in May. The data also showed a weaker real-estate investment pace in June, the weakest this year.

site_title: From Savoie, white wines that refresh like mountain air
summary: The article highlights the unique qualities of Savoie, a small region in eastern France known for its refreshing white wines. The region's indigenous grapes, such as altesse and jacquere, produce crisp and flavorful wines that evoke the region's mountainous landscape. Ten Savoie whites were recommended, including those from producers like Nicolas Gonin, Domaine Giachino, and Lambert de Seyssel, which showcase the region's diversity and quality. These wines are characterized by their freshness, minerality, and ability to age well, making them a great addition to any wine collection.

site_title: WHO experts warn of 'strong likelihood' of new concerning variants
summary: The World Health Organization's emergency committee warns of a "strong likelihood" of new concerning variants of Covid-19 emerging and spreading globally, potentially making the pandemic harder to control. Four variants, including the rapidly-spreading Delta variant, currently dominate the pandemic picture. The committee notes that the pandemic is "nowhere near finished" and that "worse could lie ahead." The emergence of new and possibly more deadly variants poses a significant threat to global efforts to control the pandemic.

site_title: Opec sees world oil demand reaching pre-pandemic level in 2022
summary: OPEC forecasts world oil demand to reach pre-pandemic levels in 2022, driven by growth in the US, China, and India. Demand is expected to rise 3.4% to 99.86 million barrels per day, averaging over 100 million per day in the second half of 2022. The report also predicts a 2.1 million bpd rise in supply from OPEC's rivals in 2022, which may limit growth in demand for Opec crude.

site_title: Europe: Oil majors drag shares lower, Siemens Energy tumbles
summary: European stocks fell for a second consecutive session, with the Stoxx 600 index slipping 0.4% due to lower crude prices and a downbeat margin outlook from Siemens Energy. Oil majors Royal Dutch Shell and BP dropped 3% as crude prices fell on expectations of more supplies. Siemens Energy's wind power division, Siemens Gamesa, also fell 16% after higher-than-expected costs.

site_title: A personal journey at modern Korean NAE:UM
summary: Louis Han's maiden restaurant, NAE:UM, offers a soul-searching dining experience over culinary finesse. The restaurant is located at 161 Telok Ayer Street in Singapore and is open for dinner only from Tuesdays to Saturdays from 6pm to 10:30pm.

images.alt_text: Cold buckwheat noodles with strips of sweet pear and briny uni.
Bingsu of mixed fruit granita with bits of watermelon, a grainy mascarpone snow and makgeoli ice cream that all melt together into luscious slush.
The restaurant itself is easy on the eyes with wall-to-wall blond wood and muted colours.

site_title: Fed's Powell rapped on inflation, regulations in Senate hearing
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell faced sharp questions from the Senate Banking Committee about inflation and banking regulation, amid his possible renomination to the top Fed post. Republicans questioned the Fed's ability to anchor inflation at 2% and criticized its bond purchases, while Democrats argued the central bank had weakened bank regulations. Powell defended the Fed's actions, saying inflation is "unique in history" and capital requirements are "about right." The hearing is a key step in his possible renomination, with the Senate Banking Committee set to be the first stop.

site_title: EH-Reit stapled securityholders unlikely to see compensation from sales proceeds: trustee
summary: DBS Trustee has stated that sales proceeds from the sale of Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) properties are unlikely to reach minority investors, with US$478.6 million in net proceeds from 14 properties not expected to satisfy all unsecured creditors. The sale proceeds are primarily used to settle secured claims, leaving stapled securityholders without a recovery. DBS Trustee clarified it is not a creditor to EHT and is not directly involved in the due diligence process for the IPO. The trustee attributed EHT's post-IPO issues to delinquencies by previous master lessees.

site_title: Malaysia new Covid cases top 13,000 as Delta outbreak grows
summary: Malaysia reported a record 13,215 new COVID-19 cases on July 15, with the majority in Selangor. The country has administered over 400,000 vaccine shots in three days, fully inoculating 12.3% of the population. To combat the Delta outbreak, the government will offer walk-in vaccinations in Selangor for those aged 60 and above.

site_title: Google expands India cloud infrastructure
summary: Google has expanded its cloud infrastructure in India, establishing a second cluster of data centers in and around New Delhi to meet increasing customer demands. The new infrastructure aims to provide disaster recovery solutions and low latency for state-run enterprises in the region. This move follows Google's significant investment in India, including a $4.5 billion stake in Jio Platforms last year. The expansion is part of Google's bet on India's growing startup economy and its digitization efforts.

site_title: Malaysia's Sime Darby Plantation scraps rights panel after resignations
summary: Malaysia's palm oil giant Sime Darby Plantation has dissolved its human rights commission after two of its experts resigned, citing concerns over lack of transparency and delays. The commission was established to review a labor practice assessment and address a US import ban over forced labor accusations. The company's sustainability committee will now take on the commission's role, with one of the resigning experts continuing to work with the company to improve foreign worker recruitment processes. The move comes after the US imposed a ban on imports from the firm in March.

site_title: Offer price raised, closing date extended for Dutech voluntary unconditional cash offer
summary: Dutech Holdings' voluntary unconditional cash offer has raised its offer price to S$0.435 per share, up from the original S$0.40, and extended the closing date to Aug 2. This represents a 74% premium over the last transacted share price and a 73.3% premium over the volume weighted average price. As of July 15, about 281.8 million shares, or 79% of the total, have been accepted, with 208.7 million shares held by concert parties. The revised offer price and extended closing date apply to all accepted shareholders.

site_title: Beyond Meat opens JD.com store amid China consumer caution on meat substitutes
summary: Beyond Meat has launched an online store on JD.com's ecommerce platform in China, aiming to boost sales in the country's largest meat market.
