A digital euro would be an electronic version of euro coins and banknotes, potentially allowing eurozone citizens to have accounts directly with the ECB.

site_title: Ant-backed Zomato's IPO 35 times subscribed by anchor funds: sources
summary: Zomato, an Indian food delivery startup backed by Ant Group, has received 35 times more bids from anchor investors than intended for its initial public offering (IPO). The startup received 1.5 trillion rupees (S$27.26 billion) in bids, exceeding its 42 billion rupee offer. The IPO, valued at US$1.3 billion, is one of the most popular Indian IPOs among institutional investors, signaling confidence in the market debut of the country's first real consumer internet offering.

site_title: Yongnam gives notice of three years of losses; auditor notes material uncertainty over ability to continue as going concern
summary: Yongnam Holdings, a steel fabricator, has reported three consecutive years of losses, as per its regulatory filing. Its independent auditor, Ernst & Young, has noted material uncertainty over the company's ability to continue as a going concern due to significant work stoppages caused by the Covid-19 pandemic, as well as dependence on cash flow and lender support. The company's market capitalization has fallen to S$43.3 million, below the threshold of S$40 million required to avoid being placed on the Singapore Exchange's watch-list.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed 7.24 points lower on Wednesday, finishing at 1512.32. Volume was 4.379 billion lots worth RM2.997 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 542 to 411. This marks the third consecutive day of losses for the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index.

site_title: Malaysia may ease curbs in more states as vaccination ramps up
summary: Malaysia is considering easing curbs in more states by early August as vaccination rates increase. The country administered a record 420,000 vaccine shots in two days, exceeding its goal of 10% population coverage by July. Eight states have already moved into the second phase of the national recovery plan, which involves opening more economic sectors. The accelerated vaccine rollout has allowed the government to ease curbs despite a record 11,000 new cases.

site_title: Fortress Minerals Q1 net profit more than triples to US$7.2m on record revenue
summary: Fortress Minerals reported record revenue of US$17.3 million for Q1, nearly two-and-a-half times the year-ago period, with net profit more than tripling to US$7.2 million. Strong iron ore prices and increased sales volume attributed to resilient demand from regional steel mill customers drove the results. The company's mining and production operations have gradually returned to normalcy since reopening in July. Fortress Minerals aims to ramp up production in its Bukit Besi mine and start production at Mengapur by the end of 2022.

site_title: Twitter sees jump in government demands to remove content of journalists, news outlets
summary: Twitter reported a 26% increase in government demands to remove content from journalists and news outlets in the second half of 2020, with 361 requests globally. Verified accounts of 199 journalists and news outlets were affected. India was the single largest source of information requests, surpassing the US. Twitter complied with 29% of the 38,500 legal demands to take down content, and 30% of the 14,500 information requests were produced in response. The platform saw a 9% decline in content removal demands.

site_title: Citigroup trounces profit estimates as economic recovery spurs reserve release
summary: Citigroup reported a second-quarter profit of $6.19 billion, exceeding market estimates of $1.96 per share, as the economic recovery fueled by vaccine rollouts and stimulus packages drove banking profits. The bank released $2.4 billion in loan loss reserves, offsetting a 12% decline in revenue and a 3% drop in loans. Citigroup's investment bank fared better, with revenues rising slightly, but expenses jumped 7% due to spending on risk and control systems. CEO Jane Fraser attributed the strong results to the global recovery and consumer and corporate confidence.

site_title: IReit Global's preferential offering closes 151.2% subscribed
summary: IReit Global's preferential offering closed with 151.2% subscriptions, exceeding the target. Approximately 201.1 million units were issued at 59.5 Singapore cents per unit, raising S$119.7 million in gross proceeds. This, combined with a S$7 million placement, brings the total gross proceeds to S$126.7 million.

site_title: STI falls 0.4%, snaps three days of gains on back of US inflation jitters
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.43% to 3,153.15, snapping a three-day winning streak, amid US inflation jitters. The index was affected by the US central bank tightening monetary policy expectations. Other Asian markets also declined, with Japan down 0.4%, Hong Kong and Malaysia down 0.6% and 0.5% respectively. The Singapore economy expanded 14.3% year-on-year in Q2, but contracted sequentially due to COVID-19 measures.

site_title: BlackRock profit beats estimates as assets soar to record US$9.49t
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, reported a quarterly profit of US$1.55 billion, beating estimates of US$9.46 per share. The company's assets under management surged to a record US$9.49 trillion, driven by record levels of global dealmaking and net inflows of US$81 billion. Revenue rose 32% to US$4.82 billion, fueled by higher performance fees and technology services growth. The US economy showed signs of recovery, with large government stimulus and vaccination programs contributing to the surge.

site_title: Tokyo reports most daily Covid-19 cases in six months as Olympics loom
summary: Tokyo reported 1,149 new Covid-19 cases, the highest daily tally in six months, amid a growing fifth wave of infections driven by more infectious variants and a low vaccination rate. The city government has declared a renewed state of emergency, and no fans will be allowed at Olympics events in affected areas. Experts warn that hospital beds in the capital region may be maxed out by August, with only 31% of Japan's population vaccinated. The Delta variant now accounts for over 30% of cases in Tokyo.

site_title: US producer prices surge more than expected in June
summary: US producer prices surged 1% in June, exceeding expectations, with a 7.3% year-on-year rise, the largest since November 2010. Higher commodity prices and labor costs are driving inflation, which has been fueled by the economy's recovery from the pandemic. The Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell is set to present his view on the latest inflation data, with most economists believing inflation has peaked or is close to doing so.

site_title: On the Singapore market: Shophouses, Holland Village house, Geylang en bloc
summary: Several properties in Singapore have been put up for sale, including a trio of conservation shophouses in Raffles Place, a detached house in Holland Village, a residential development in Upper Serangoon, and the Baode Building en bloc sale in Geylang. The properties offer a mix of commercial and residential uses, with prices ranging from S$10 million to S$28 million. The sales will close by August 18, with the majority of tenders set to close in the second half of the month.

site_title: Singapore to invest S$50m to develop digital trust capabilities
summary: Singapore is investing S$50 million over five years to develop its digital trust capabilities. Minister for Communications and Information Josephine Teo announced the investment, which will focus on addressing industry needs and unlocking opportunities enabled by emerging digital trust technologies. The initiative aims to provide businesses and consumers with greater assurance and confidence as they digitalize, with research institutions and industry partners driving research and translation in trust technologies.

site_title: Fed's Powell stays focused on jobs recovery, says inflation to ease
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell emphasized the need for continued job gains, stating that US monetary policy will offer "powerful support" to the economy until the recovery is complete. Powell noted that a recent jump in inflation is temporary and that any potential pullback on economic support is still far off. Despite recent job gains, millions of lower-wage workers remain on the sidelines, and Powell highlighted the need for continued job growth to address this issue.

images.alt_text: US monetary policy will offer "powerful support" to the economy "until the recovery is complete", Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said on Wednesday in remarks that portrayed a recent jump in inflation as temporary and focused on the need for continued job gains.

site_title: Japan panel calls for 3% hike in average minimum wage
summary: A Japanese panel has recommended a 3% hike in the national average minimum wage to approximately $8.50 per hour, a 28 yen increase to 930 yen, for the upcoming fiscal year. This follows calls from Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga to raise the minimum wage to 1,000 yen. The move aims to boost household consumption as the COVID-19 pandemic's economic impact fades.

site_title: EU proposes effective ban on new fossil-fuel car sales from 2035
summary: The European Union has proposed a ban on the sale of new petrol and diesel cars by 2035, aiming to accelerate the switch to zero-emission electric vehicles. The proposal includes a 55% cut in CO2 emissions from cars by 2030 and a 100% cut by 2035, making it impossible to sell new fossil-fuel-powered vehicles. The EU also plans to require public charging points along major roads by 2025 to boost EV sales, which is expected to create 16.3 million charging stations by 2050. The proposals must be negotiated and approved by EU member states and the European Parliament.

site_title: Q2's GDP rebound hints at upgrade to official growth outlook in August, say economists
summary: Singapore's GDP rebounded 14.3% year-over-year in Q2, driven by a low base from the previous year, but sequential growth contracted 2% due to tighter Covid-19 measures. Economists predict an upgrade to the official growth outlook, with some forecasting a 6-8% growth rate for the full year, driven by a strong manufacturing sector and rapid vaccine rollout. However, economists caution that the recovery may be subject to "variant risks" and potential disruptions, and the Monetary Authority of Singapore may keep monetary policy under review.

site_title: ESG fever: Share of sustainable fund trading soaring in 2021
summary: Investors have poured billions into exchange-traded funds (ETFs) focused on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues, with monthly turnover tripling to nearly €3 billion in the first half of 2021. ESG assets now account for 16% of total ETF trading turnover on Deutsche Boerse's Xetra platform, up from 6% last year. Total assets under management for ESG ETFs have swelled to nearly $1.7 trillion, driven by European Union legislation and demand for mega-cap technology stocks.

site_title: Malaysian Cabinet backs PM amid coalition infighting
summary: Malaysian Cabinet ministers have unanimously pledged their support for Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin amid a coalition infighting crisis. The United Malays National Organisation (Umno) withdrew its support for Muhyiddin, calling for his resignation, but Umno ministers in government vowed to continue giving their full support to his leadership. The decision comes ahead of a five-day special Parliament meeting scheduled for July 26, where Muhyiddin's slim two-seat parliamentary majority will be determined.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index slipping 0.63% due to investor anticipation of Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell's testimony to Congress for clues on US policy direction following inflation surge. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell, with losses of 1.07% and 0.88% respectively.

site_title: Pan Ocean Co signs long-term time charter contract with Shell worth around US$319m
summary: Pan Ocean Co has signed a long-term time charter contract with Shell worth approximately US$319 million. The seven-year contract, with two extension options, will commence in October and last up to 13 years. The deal was announced after the company requested a trading halt, which was lifted shortly after. As a result, Pan Ocean's shares were flat at S$8.15.

site_title: eBay sells US$2.25b Adevinta stake to secure classified ads tie-up
summary: eBay agrees to sell a 10.2% stake in Adevinta to private equity firm Permira for $2.25 billion, clearing the way for a tie-up between the two companies. The deal follows a regulatory hurdle in Austria, where eBay was required to reduce its stake in Adevinta to 33%. eBay will sell 125 million shares, with Permira having a 30-day option to buy an additional 10 million shares, reducing eBay's stake to 33%. The transaction is expected to close in the fourth quarter of this year.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore reported 56 new Covid-19 cases, with 41 linked to a growing KTV cluster. The economy rebounded 14.3% in Q2, surpassing the pre-pandemic level, and Singapore is investing S$50m to develop digital trust capabilities. New private home sales dipped in June, but demand remains buoyant. The STI fell 0.4% after US inflation data sparked concerns of a sooner US interest rate hike.

site_title: Gold firms as investors seek taper cues from Powell's testimony
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,812.80 per ounce, boosted by robust US inflation numbers and seen as an inflation hedge. Investors await Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's testimony for potential tapering cues, limiting gains. Market participants are cautiously optimistic about Powell's comments, with some firms expecting early tapering. Despite this, gold remains an attractive option for investors seeking to hedge against inflation.

images.alt_text: Gold prices rose on Wednesday after robust US inflation numbers lifted the metal's appeal as an inflation hedge, although gains were kept in check ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's testimony as early tapering bets rise.

site_title: Apple's potential 'buy now, pay later' plan sends sector shares tumbling
summary: Apple is reportedly working on a "buy now, pay later" service, partnering with Goldman Sachs to offer interest-free instalments for Apple Pay users. This move sent shares of Afterpay, Zip, and Affirm Holdings sharply lower, with Afterpay's stock sliding over 10% in trading. The new service would rival existing BNPL services in the US, a growing market where competition is intense. Analysts believe the new competition could take time to play out, but pure-play BNPL firms face a major test against a company like Apple.

site_title: Big Four still dominate UK blue chip audits as fees rise
summary: The Big Four accounting firms (KPMG, EY, PwC, Deloitte) dominated UK blue chip audits, auditing all FTSE 100 companies in a roughly even four-way split. They collected higher fees, with average audit fees rising by 7.7%. Smaller auditors increased their share in the FTSE 250 segment. Despite tough economic conditions, the industry reviews proposed a shake-up, including a new regulator and market share caps on the Big Four. However, the government has yet to implement the recommendations.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit, IHH Healthcare extend lease agreements for 20 years, with S$150m capex injection
summary: Parkway Life Reit and IHH Healthcare Berhad have extended their lease agreements for 20 years, with Parkway Life Reit injecting up to S$150 million in renewal capital expenditure. The agreement includes the right of first refusal for Mount Elizabeth Novena Hospital. The three hospitals, which account for 60.2% of Parkway Life Reit's portfolio, have existing 15-year leases set to expire on Aug 22, 2022. The new agreements will continue to generate significant revenue for Parkway Life Reit.

images.alt_text: Gleneagles Hospital, one of the three hospitals for which Parkway Life Reit and IHH Healthcare are extending the master lease agreement.

site_title: Myanmar anti-coup activists protest as US seeks regional action
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken urged Southeast Asian nations to take joint action to help end violence, restore a democratic transition, and release those "unjustly detained" in Myanmar. Protests in Yangon, led by women, marked the city's 21st Century Queen Panhtwar's Strike, with around 100 opponents marching through the city center. The US has imposed sanctions on the junta, but the military has shown little sign of following through on a peace plan. Myanmar's security forces have killed over 900 people and detained thousands since the coup.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end lower on record virus cases, US inflation data
summary: South Korean stocks closed down 0.20% on Wednesday, as record high daily Covid-19 cases and a significant jump in US inflation data led to bets of earlier-than-expected monetary policy tightening. The Kospi index fell 6.57 points to 3,264.81. The US consumer price index rose 0.9% in June, the largest gain since 2008, while South Korea reported a record 1,615 new Covid-19 cases.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks slip ahead of Powell testimony
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.38% as investors awaited US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's address to Congress for clues on policy direction. The Nikkei 225 index dropped to 28,608.49, while the Topix index fell 0.23%. Asian markets were soft, with Shanghai and Hong Kong also down. Investors took a wait-and-see stance ahead of Powell's testimony, which pressured the Tokyo market.

site_title: Final death toll in China hotel collapse put at 17
summary: A budget hotel in Suzhou, China, collapsed, killing 17 people, with nine confirmed dead and six rescued. The hotel, which opened in 2018, had 54 guest rooms. An investigation into the cause of the disaster is underway, with an unspecified number of people linked to the hotel detained. The collapse is the latest in a series of building disasters in China, often attributed to lax construction standards or corruption.

site_title: 56 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, 42 from KTV cluster; no change to Covid-19 measures for now
summary: Singapore reported 56 new Covid-19 cases, with 42 linked to the KTV lounge cluster. Health Minister Ong Ye Kung stated that the multi-ministry taskforce decided to keep current Covid-19 measures unchanged, citing the high vaccination rate. The decision was made despite the growing cluster, with more cases expected to surface. Ong urged the public to exercise restraint and caution in socializing, but ruled out reversing the current relaxation of measures.

images.alt_text: Empress KTV at Tanglin Shopping Centre. The KTV lounges involved had been allowed to operate as food and beverage outlets, not to provide hostess services.

site_title: Plant-based chicken meat company in Singapore secures funds to enter US
summary: Next Gen Foods, a Singapore-based plant-based chicken meat company, has secured US$20 million in funding from investors including GGV Capital and Yeo Hiap Seng to enter the US market. The company's valuation has increased to almost US$180 million, and plans to use the funds to enter the US retail market within the next 12 months. The funding round, which brought the total to US$30 million, is part of the company's goal to become the world's number-one plant-based chicken maker.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.17 points, or 0.01%, to 1,519.39. Volume was 484.33 million lots worth RM181.24 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 167 to 162.

site_title: SGX RegCo orders Kitchen Culture to expand scope of internal control review
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has ordered Kitchen Culture to expand its internal control review, commissioned by Baker Tilly Consultancy, to investigate breaches of Catalist rules and internal control weaknesses. The review, initially focused on cash management, now also includes circumstances surrounding the termination of CEO Lim Wee Li, who was dismissed on July 7 for "gross default or grave misconduct". The regulator has asked the audit and risk committee to report concurrently to Kitchen Culture's board, SGX RegCo, and the company's continuing sponsor SAC Capital.

site_title: Europe: Travel drags stocks lower, inflation woes mount
summary: European stocks declined 0.2% due to concerns over inflation and the spread of the Delta variant. Travel stocks fell 1% with Tui's shares dropping 4.2%. The UK's FTSE 100 slid 0.4% due to a stronger pound after inflation data showed it jumped above the Bank of England's target. Meanwhile, Tele2 rose 3.7% after reporting a 8% increase in quarterly earnings, while Hugo Boss forecast a 30-35% revenue growth.

site_title: Education platform founded by Nas Daily creator bags US$11m in Series A funding
summary: Nas Academy, an online education platform founded by Nuseir Yassin, creator of Nas Daily, has secured US$11 million in Series A funding led by Lightspeed Venture Partners. The platform allows content creators to create and market courses to students, and has seen revenue generated by well-known creators such as Smile Squad and MingWeiRocks. Since its inception in 2020, Nas Academy has hosted 250 cohorts of full courses covering topics like storytelling and social media presence, and aims to make it easy for creators to monetize their skills.

site_title: Thailand considering regulating its AstraZeneca vaccine exports
summary: Thailand is considering regulating the export of locally manufactured AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccines to ensure sufficient supplies for domestic use amid its worst coronavirus outbreak yet. The health ministry will discuss with AstraZeneca to secure local production before issuing regulations, following delays in delivery to countries such as the Philippines and Malaysia. Thailand has recorded nearly 363,000 Covid-19 cases and 2,934 fatalities, with the majority of cases occurring since early April.

site_title: Property investment market continuing improvement in Q2: Knight Frank
summary: The Singapore property investment market continued to improve in Q2, with a 127.3% increase in investment deals to S$5 billion, driven by developers, retail, and institutional investors. Land site sales reached S$1.45 billion, with several GLS sites receiving multiple bids. The residential sector saw strong demand for landed and non-landed homes, while commercial and industrial segments also performed well. Knight Frank expects demand for land sites to remain robust and investment activity to increase in the second half of the year, potentially reaching S$30 billion in deals.

site_title: Australia: Shares up on miners, energy boost; Afterpay slumps
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to 7,362 points, driven by gains in miners and energy stocks, while Afterpay slumped. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed relatively flat on Tuesday. Investors await New Zealand's monetary policy review later in the day, with expectations of unchanged policy.

site_title: US budget deficit narrows in June as pandemic payments drop: government
summary: The US budget deficit narrowed in June to $174 billion, a 80% decrease from the previous year, as pandemic payments dropped. This marks a decline of 18% for the first nine months of the fiscal year, with government receipts and outlays hitting records for the October 2020 to June 2021 period. Business taxes recovered, despite another expensive stimulus package.

site_title: Singapore's new private home sales dip in June, but demand stays buoyant: analysts
summary: Singapore's private home sales dropped 2.2% in June to 871 units, largely due to the absence of new launches amid heightened restrictions. Despite this, analysts remain optimistic about market demand, citing positive economic recovery, Singapore's safe-haven status, and domestic buyers "playing catch-up" due to travel restrictions. Analysts expect sales to pick up in the coming months as new projects are slated for launch.

site_title: Acromec unit enters JV with Tako Ventures to launch co-working lab spaces
summary: Acromec, a specialist engineering services provider, has entered into a joint venture (JV) with Tako Ventures to launch co-working laboratory spaces for startups in the medical technology, biotechnology, and health technology sectors. The JV, called Life Science Incubator, will provide flexible co-working laboratory spaces for research and development, with the first premises set to be located at the German Centre. Acromec will hold a 30% stake in the JV, with Tako Ventures holding the remaining 70%.

site_title: US Democrats agree on US$3.5t budget target
summary: US Senate Democrats have agreed on a $3.5 trillion budget package, aligning with President Joe Biden's plans for climate initiatives, health insurance, and human infrastructure programs. The proposal, which has faced opposition from Republicans, aims to direct federal funds to various projects over the coming decade. After a meeting with Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer, all 11 Democrats on the Senate Budget Committee announced their decision on the budget number, paving the way for the package's potential implementation.

site_title: Singapore stocks slip at open following Wall Street retreat; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks opened weaker on Wednesday, following a retreat on Wall Street, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.2% or 5.89 points to 3,160.92. The decline was attributed to investor concerns over the impact of rising US inflation on monetary policy. Losers outnumbered gainers 80 to 63, with 84.9 million securities changing hands.

site_title: More than 270,000 locals hired under Jobs Growth Incentive scheme in first six months
summary: Singapore's Jobs Growth Incentive (JGI) scheme has supported the hiring of over 270,000 workers in its first six months, including 130,000 locals hired from September to November 2020. The scheme offers up to 12 months of salary co-payment for new local hires and up to 18 months for mature workers. Most hires were made in growth areas such as wholesale trade, professional services, and food services. The government has set aside S$1 billion for the scheme, with another S$5.2 billion added in the February Budget.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Wednesday, following declines on Wall Street due to US data showing a surprise jump in inflation. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.27% to 27,888.01, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 0.51% and 0.39%, respectively. The market concerns are linked to investor worries over Federal Reserve policy amid the inflation rise.

site_title: France fines Google 500m euros in news copyright row
summary: France's competition watchdog fined Google 500 million euros for failing to negotiate "in good faith" with media companies over EU copyright rules. This is the largest fine ever imposed by the agency for a company's failure to adhere to a ruling. Google must now offer media publishers a renumeration for using their copyrighted content or face additional damages of up to 900,000 euros a day. The decision aims to "reflect the gravity" of Google's shortcomings and ensure compliance with EU copyright rules.

images.alt_text: France's competition watchdog on Tuesday slapped Google with a 500-million-euro (S$803.7 million) fine for failing to negotiate "in good faith" with media companies over the use of their content under EU copyright rules.

site_title: New Zealand central bank holds rates but reduces stimulus
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) held its official cash rate (OCR) at 0.25% on July 14, 2021, as expected by economists. The central bank also halted additional asset purchases under its Large Scale Asset Purchase (LSAP) programme by July 23. Funding for its Lending Programme operation remained unchanged. This decision aims to balance the economy and manage inflation, despite the uncertainty surrounding the global economic outlook.

site_title: Sembcorp, PUB open one of world's largest floating solar farms on Tengeh Reservoir
summary: Singapore has officially opened the Sembcorp Tengeh Floating Solar Farm, one of the world's largest inland floating solar photovoltaic farms, spanning 45 hectares with 122,000 solar panels. The 60 megawatt-peak solar farm will power Singapore's five local water treatment plants, offsetting about 7% of PUB's annual energy needs and reducing carbon emissions by 32 kilotonnes annually. The project marks a significant milestone in Singapore's goal to quadruple solar energy deployment by 2025 and is a showcase for the country's commitment to environmental sustainability and renewable energy.

site_title: Hot stock: mm2 Asia down 11.11% after auditor notes material uncertainty
summary: mm2 Asia's shares plummet 11.11% after its independent auditor noted a material uncertainty regarding the group's ability to continue as a going concern due to a net loss of $99.5 million and liabilities exceeding assets. The auditor's unmodified audit opinion remains unchanged despite drawing attention to the group's current financial struggles. The company is on the road to recovery, with segmental businesses generating 73% of total revenue in the second half of 2021. mm2 Asia plans to seek funding through an initial public offering and refinancing of existing borrowings.

site_title: Robo adviser Syfe gets US$30m in Series B funding led by Peter Thiel's Valar Ventures
summary: SYFE, a digital wealth management platform, has raised US$30 million in a Series B round led by Peter Thiel's Valar Ventures, valuing the company at US$210.6 million. This funding round, nine months after the previous one, brings the total amount of money raised to US$52.6 million. The investment is attributed to rising interest in digital investment tools amid a low interest rate environment, supporting Syfe's growth and expansion in the digital wealth management space.

site_title: Asia: Markets fall on US inflation concerns
summary: Asian markets fell on Wednesday due to concerns over US inflation, with the consumer price index (CPI) surging 5.4% in the 12 months ended in June, the highest rate since August 2008. The US stock market also retreated from records, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh highs. Investors are worried about the Federal Reserve's policy direction, which may lead to tighter monetary conditions. Asian markets, including Singapore, were lower as a result, with the STI down 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower extending US falls
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, following US falls, as investors weighed the impact of a US inflation jump on monetary policy. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.74% to 28,506.60, and the Topix index slipped 0.54% to 1,957.01. This decline extends the US market's earlier losses.

site_title: Short-term uncertainty in Ho Chi Minh City's commercial sector but longer-term outlook still bright: CBRE
summary: The office market in Ho Chi Minh City remains uncertain due to the new Covid-19 wave, but the residential condominium market is doing well. Vacancy rates for Grade A and Grade B office buildings decreased, with 12.2% and 9.1% respectively, while rental rates decreased 6.4% and 1% year-over-year. The retail market saw a decrease in vacancy rates, with CBD areas remaining low due to limited supply. Despite short-term uncertainty, the medium-term outlook is positive, with new supply and green credentials adding value to landlords' portfolios.

site_title: China's yuan eases as investors grow cautious after basket index hits five-year high
summary: China's yuan eased against the dollar on Wednesday, hitting a 5-year high, after investors became cautious. The yuan's trade-weighted basket index rose to 98.45, prompting concerns about China's exports. The People's Bank of China maintained a neutral monetary policy stance, despite previous moves to cut reserve requirements. The yuan opened at 6.4731 per dollar, 63 pips weaker than the previous close, and was changing hands at 6.4748. Investors are watching the Federal Reserve's policy decisions for clues on the timing of a tapering of stimulus and higher interest rates.

site_title: Australian consumer sentiment holds up as Sydney locks down
summary: Australian consumer sentiment rebounded in July, rising 1.5% after relief from coronavirus lockdowns offset the latest shutdown in Sydney. The Westpac-Melbourne Institute index recouped some of June's 5.2% drop, leaving it up 23.8% from last July. The improvement in sentiment was seen as a temporary reprieve, but the ongoing lockdown in Sydney may impact consumer spending in the coming months.

site_title: Ezion to sell subsidiary and tug vessels for US$83.7m
summary: Ezion Holdings is selling its subsidiary Teras Sunrise and two tug vessels to ZhongXie Industrial for US$83.7 million, resulting in a US$13.1 million gain. The sale of tug vessels Teras Darius and Teras Eden will incur an estimated collective loss of US$117,500. The proceeds will be used to repay secured bank loans and partially repay debt to DBS. This sale is part of Ezion's ongoing restructuring, aiming to stop incurring operating costs and liabilities, and reduce outstanding liabilities.

site_title: Sydney braces for extended lockdown as Covid-19 spreads
summary: Australian authorities are expected to extend a three-week lockdown in Sydney amid a spreading Covid-19 outbreak. The lockdown, which started on June 26, has seen 800 total infections and two deaths reported. The highly contagious Delta variant has spread to previously unaffected areas, with cases detected in regional areas and Victoria state. State Premier Gladys Berejiklian is scheduled to address the issue, with restrictions only set to be lifted when the number of community cases is near zero.

site_title: Catalist-listed M Development to delist from SGX on July 16
summary: M Development, a Catalist-listed IT solutions provider, will delist from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on July 16. The company's shareholders approved its plan to go private through a members' voluntary liquidation at an extraordinary general meeting on March 23. This decision comes after the company received a delisting notice from SGX on October 16, 2020. M Development must provide a fair and reasonable exit offer to shareholders within a month of the notice, but the company chose to proceed with the delisting plan. The company will cease trading on SGX at 9am on July 16.

site_title: Cruise ship returns to Singapore over suspected Covid-19 case
summary: A 40-year-old passenger on the Dream Cruises ship World Dream tested positive for Covid-19 after initially testing negative on board, forcing the ship to turn back to Singapore. The passenger, who had received two vaccine doses, was isolated and taken to a hospital for further testing. Three close contacts were also isolated after testing negative, but further contact tracing is ongoing. The ship's crew and remaining passengers remain on board, awaiting results, and the ship will undergo full cleaning and sanitization. A subsequent cruise has been cancelled, and passengers can choose to transfer to other dates or receive a refund.

images.alt_text: Dream Cruises ship World Dream was forced to turn back to Singapore after a Covid-19 case was found on board.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, CNMC Goldmine, mm2 Asia
summary: OCBC announced it will offer higher loan quanta to mutual funds with AAA or AA MSCI ESG ratings, a first in Asia. CNMC Goldmine Holdings' subsidiary gained approval to resume mining operations at its Sokor gold mine in Malaysia. Shares of OCBC rose 1.3% and CNMC closed 5% higher.

site_title: Biden taps ex-Pentagon official for key China tech position
summary: President Joe Biden nominated Alan Estevez, a former Pentagon official, to be the US Commerce Department's undersecretary for industry and security. Estevez, who has a 36-year career with the Department of Defense, will oversee export controls to limit Chinese companies in telecommunications infrastructure on national security concerns. This move comes amid escalating US-China tech tensions, following the Trump administration's restrictions on Huawei Technologies. Estevez's nomination may help him win confirmation in the US Senate, where China hawks have been critical of other Biden nominees.

site_title: Britain to ban all new diesel and petrol heavy goods vehicles from 2040
summary: Britain to ban the sale of new petrol and diesel heavy goods vehicles from 2040, as part of a plan to achieve net zero emissions from all forms of transport by 2030. The ban will apply to smaller diesel trucks from 2035 and larger ones weighing over 26 tonnes from 2040. The government also aims to create a net zero rail network by 2050 and ensure net zero domestic aviation emissions by 2040.

site_title: Hong Kong says no personal data shared in vaccine deal with Fosun
summary: Hong Kong's government has clarified that its agreement with Fosun Pharmaceutical Group, a Chinese sales agent for BioNTech Covid-19 vaccines, does not include clauses allowing Fosun or third parties to collect personal data of vaccinated individuals. Hong Kong has emphasized its strong emphasis on personal data privacy and has strict guidelines for the collection and use of personal information in its vaccination program. The clarification comes after Reuters reported that Fosun had sent a template to Taiwanese tech firms seeking access to medical records.

site_title: SGX adds three new forward freight agreements and futures contracts for LNG vessels
summary: SGX has launched three new forward freight agreements and futures contracts for liquefied natural gas (LNG) vessels, referencing the Baltic Exchange's independent freight price assessments for three routes. The contracts, launched on July 12, provide risk management tools for LNG-powered carriers with a relatively lower carbon footprint. Global LNG trade reached an all-time high of 356.1 million tonnes in 2020, with Asia accounting for over 70% of imports. The launch marks a milestone for SGX's FFA business and is seen as a vote of confidence in the Baltic Exchange's LNG freight assessments.

site_title: Shell, Cosan JV Raizen targets 70b reais valuation in IPO: sources
summary: Raizen, a joint venture between Royal Dutch Shell and Cosan SA, is targeting a valuation of around 70 billion reais (S$18.3 billion) in its initial public offering. The company, which owns petrol stations and produces sugar and ethanol, has cut its initial estimate of raising 12 billion reais, now planning to raise around 6 billion reais (US$1.2 billion). The IPO syndicate has received close to the full book of the offering, with 12 investment banks participating in the process, and the issue size and share price range may be announced in a new prospectus soon.

images.alt_text: Brazil's Raizen, a joint venture between Royal Dutch Shell PLC and Brazilian energy company Cosan SA, is targeting a valuation of around 70 billion reais (S$18.3 billion) in its initial public offering, four people with knowledge of the matter said on Tuesday.

site_title: Nasa, European Space Agency join forces on climate change
summary: NASA and the European Space Agency (ESA) have formed a strategic partnership to combat climate change, aiming to lead a global response through Earth science observations, research, and applications. The partnership, formalized on July 13, 2021, will utilize data from Earth-observing satellites to monitor the Earth's environment and track changes threatening millions of lives. The move is seen as crucial in tackling the global issue of climate change, with the COP26 conference in November providing an opportunity to integrate space into the solution.

site_title: Sydney extends lockdown by two weeks amid Delta outbreak
summary: Sydney, Australia has extended its lockdown by two weeks due to a rise in new Covid-19 cases caused by the highly contagious Delta variant. The state of New South Wales reported 97 new cases, up from 89 the previous day. The lockdown, initially set to end on July 16, will now run until July 30. Premier Gladys Berejiklian announced the extension during a televised news conference, stating that current restrictions will remain in place for at least two weeks.

images.alt_text: Australian authorities on Wednesday said they would extend a lockdown of the country's most populous city, Sydney, by two weeks after reporting a rise in new Covid-19 cases as it battles an outbreak of the highly contagious Delta variant.

site_title: Oil rises nearly 2% as investors size up tight market
summary: Oil prices rose nearly 2% on Tuesday as investors anticipate tighter supply due to disagreements among major producers. The International Energy Agency expects record-low storage drawdowns in the third quarter, citing reduced US, European, and Japanese stock levels. Despite Opec+ plans to boost supply, discussions broke off without an agreement. Brent crude rose to $76.49 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude rose to $75.25 a barrel, with the market expected to remain volatile until differences are resolved.

site_title: Japan's factory mood in July hits highest since late 2018: Reuters Tankan
summary: Japan's manufacturers have reported a business confidence of over two-and-a-half years high in July, according to the Reuters Tankan poll. The country's export-driven recovery remains intact due to solid global demand. However, service-sector sentiment has turned pessimistic due to the ongoing coronavirus crisis. Despite this, the global economy is showing signs of recovery from the pandemic.

site_title: ECB to launch digital euro project
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to launch a digital euro project, a multi-year initiative to create a digital equivalent of the euro currency. The digital euro will be a digital wallet that eurozone citizens can hold at the ECB, with holders having a claim against the bank. The ECB aims to complement, not replace, physical cash, and the digital euro will be intrinsically safer than private sector counterparts. The project's design is expected to take two years to finalize, with implementation and launch to follow in the next three years.

site_title: British companies accelerate hiring as economy unlocks
summary: UK firms accelerated hiring in June, with 7% increase from May, reaching 16% above June 2019 levels. Demand was strongest in sectors with in-person contact, including wellness, healthcare, and retail. Construction hiring also surged. This marks an "encouraging milestone" in the nation's recovery journey, according to LinkedIn senior economist Mariano Mamertino.

site_title: Singapore Q2 GDP contracts from Q1 and pre-pandemic level; up 14% from last year's low base
summary: Singapore's Q2 GDP contracted 2% seasonally-adjusted, reversing the 3.1% gain in the previous quarter. Despite this, the economy rebounded 14.3% year-on-year due to a low base from the "circuit breaker" period in Q2 last year. The GDP fell 13.3% in Q2 last year and was 0.9% below its pre-pandemic level when compared to the same period in 2019. The country's economic performance suggests that the worst of the headwinds may be behind it.

site_title: EU set to call time on combustion engine within two decades
summary: The European Union plans to propose measures that could phase out petrol and diesel car sales by 2040, accelerating a switch to electric propulsion. The proposal aims to reduce emissions and align with EU's climate goals. Carmakers have already invested in electrification, but are seeking clarity on public charging infrastructure and hybrid vehicle phase-out timelines. The EU's move is expected to influence carmakers' decisions on electrification and could lead to significant changes in the automotive industry.

site_title: US to seek global rules on AI misuse, Blinken says
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken announced plans to seek global rules on preventing the misuse of artificial intelligence. Blinken warned that authoritarian states, particularly China, are using new technologies to curb dissent and exert control. He reiterated US concerns over Russia's involvement in hacking, stating that countries harboring cyber criminals have a responsibility to take action. The US will deploy diplomatic and security measures to establish shared understanding and prevent proliferation of AI misuse. Blinken also ordered recommendations to strengthen the State Department's focus on technology diplomacy.

site_title: Next frontier of sustainable investing: Measuring impact
summary: Experts discuss the next frontier of sustainable investing, measuring impact. Capitalism has created wealth, but faces challenges of climate change and inequality. ESG (Environmental, Social and Governance) analysis is key to delivering economic prosperity and protecting the environment. Materiality in ESG factors can enhance returns, but data quality is a concern. Engagement, not divestment, is preferred, and investors should align portfolios with global challenges. Carbon offsets can mitigate climate change, but quality and auditing are crucial. The panel recommends technical skills and a broad understanding of ESG metrics for success in impact investing.

site_title: Ransomware gang goes offline, prompting questions
summary: A Russian-based ransomware gang, REvil, went offline after a massive attack crippling hundreds of companies worldwide, sparking speculation about a potential government-led action. The attack prompted a $70 million ransom demand and affected businesses globally. US President Joe Biden warned Russian President Vladimir Putin about harboring cybercriminals, and analysts suggest that the REvil gang may have suffered a planned takedown of their infrastructure, possibly by law enforcement or the operators themselves. The exact reason for the gang's disappearance remains unclear.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Koda, a Vietnamese furniture manufacturer, has temporarily closed its factories in Long An province due to a local government directive to limit Covid-19 contagion risks. The closure will allow firms to make arrangements for work to resume.

site_title: Biden to warn US firms of risks of operating in Hong Kong: sources
summary: The US government will warn companies operating in Hong Kong of increasing risks due to the Chinese government's ability to access data stored by foreign companies. This warning comes after a previously issued warning on Xinjiang was updated. The risks include data breaches and potential espionage. The move is aimed at protecting US firms' sensitive information.

site_title: JPMorgan's profit more than doubles despite trading slump
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co reported a 155% jump in profit, driven by the release of $3 billion from pandemic-related loan reserves and a surge in dealmaking. Despite a trading slump due to calmer financial markets, the bank's fortunes reflect the health of the US economy. The bank's trading business took a hit, but overall profit more than doubled.

site_title: US sees biggest annual inflation jump since 2008
summary: The US saw its largest annual inflation surge in over a decade, reaching 5.4% in June, the highest rate since 2008. Rising prices for used cars, gasoline, hotels, and airline fares, driven by pent-up demand and supply chain bottlenecks, challenge the White House's narrative that inflation will fade. The Federal Reserve's pledge to continue stimulus may be under pressure, and inflation hawks may push for a reduction in the massive bond-buying program.

site_title: Covid-19 surging in Africa with more than 6 million cases: AFP tally
summary: Covid-19 cases are surging in Africa with a record average of 41,400 new cases per day, a 13% increase over last week. Over 6 million cases have been officially counted in Africa's 54 nations and territories since December 2019. The Delta variant is highly present in countries like South Africa, Tunisia, and Libya, which are experiencing rapid growth in new cases. The unequal distribution of vaccines across the continent has exacerbated the situation, with only about 4 doses administered per 100 inhabitants, compared to nearly 72 in Europe.

images.alt_text: Coronavirus is surging in Africa with a record average number of new cases according to an AFP tally based on official sources on Tuesday at 1815 GMT.

site_title: Starwood Capital makes rival bid for industrial property Reit
summary: Monmouth Real Estate Investment Corp received an unsolicited takeover bid from Starwood Capital Group for US$18.70 a share, surpassing its original deal with Equity Commonwealth to be acquired by Sam Zell's firm for US$18.10 a share plus a dividend. Starwood Capital Group is a rival bidder and was part of the original strategic review process. Monmouth's board is evaluating the new proposal, which amounts to a purchase price of US$19.51 a share after a US$62 million reduction due to a termination fee.

site_title: Bank of England scraps curbs on bank dividends as pandemic crisis fades
summary: The Bank of England has lifted its pandemic curbs on bank dividends for HSBC, Barclays, and other top lenders, effective immediately. Governor Andrew Bailey cited the rapid vaccination rollout and improving economic outlook as the reason for the change. The central bank had initially imposed restrictions in March 2020, and eased them last December. The move is seen as a positive signal for the banking sector, with shares rising by 1-2% for affected lenders. Risks to the recovery remain, however, and the bank emphasized the need for continued support from the financial system.

site_title: Thailand defends Covid vaccine 'mix-and-match' after WHO warning
summary: Thailand defends its "mix-and-match" Covid-19 vaccine strategy after the World Health Organization's top scientist warned it's a "dangerous trend" not backed by evidence. The country is battling a surge in infections fueled by the Delta variant, with cases and deaths rising. Thai authorities plan to combine a Sinovac jab with an AstraZeneca booster to achieve a faster "booster" effect, citing the need to contain the outbreak. The WHO's warning comes as Thailand's healthcare system is stretched thin, with nearly 900 medical staff infected with Covid-19.

site_title: France fines Google 500m euros in news copyright row
summary: France's competition regulator fined Google 500 million euros for failing to negotiate "in good faith" with media companies over the use of their copyrighted content under EU copyright rules. The regulator ordered Google to present media publishers with a remuneration offer for current use of copyrighted content, or risk additional damages of up to 900,000 euros a day. Google was "very disappointed" by the decision, but the regulator's chief said it was "the biggest ever fine" imposed for a company's failure to adhere to a ruling.

site_title: Why European equities will do well in next 6 to 12 months
summary: European equities are expected to outperform in the next 6-12 months, driven by the ongoing economic recovery and monetary policy support. Despite elevated valuations, investors can enhance returns by tilting their equity allocation towards reopening regions and value-oriented sectors. This strategy was successful in the past recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic, and the author believes it will continue to work. Meanwhile, emerging markets and Asia are still recovering from the Delta variant, but are expected to gain ground in the long term.

images.alt_text: To enhance returns without raising risk, one strategy would be to identify which regions or countries are likely to open next and assign a greater investment allocation within a diversified portfolio to the corresponding equity market. This strategy generated a strong outperformance of China and the US equities earlier in the recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: China technology stock pain shown in widening gap with US giants
summary: China's megacap technology stocks, Baidu, Alibaba, and Tencent, have seen a 2% decline in the past 12 months, with an equal-weighted basket of their shares. In contrast, US peers have risen 40%. This marks the widest gap between Chinese and US tech stocks in at least five years, as Beijing tightens its regulatory grip on the industry.

site_title: World's biggest green energy hub proposed for W Australia
summary: A massive green energy hub, the Western Green Energy Hub, has been proposed for Western Australia, covering 15,000 sq km and generating up to 50 gigawatts of wind and solar power. The project, costing up to A$100 billion, aims to produce 3.5 million tons of green hydrogen or 20 million tons of green ammonia annually. Environmental approvals and finding buyers are major challenges, with most hydrogen likely to be exported, potentially becoming costly compared to local production.

site_title: Europe: Shares hover near all-time highs; Nokia surges
summary: European stocks hovered near all-time highs on Tuesday, with the Stoxx 600 index ending flat despite hotter-than-expected US inflation and concerns about an overheating economy. Banks, autos, and oil sectors declined, but technology shares and defensive stocks countered losses. US consumer prices rose by 13-year high, fueling fears of an elevated inflation rate. European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde stated the bank would not repeat its past mistake of tightening policy too early, while yields on European bonds hit three-month lows ahead of the ECB's meeting.

site_title: Think different: 10 unconventional lessons from owning Apple shares for 10 years
summary: A long-time Apple shareholder shares 10 unconventional lessons learned from owning Apple shares for over 10 years, including the importance of being adaptable, not relying on conventional wisdom, and focusing on long-term business growth. The investor highlights the company's remarkable turnaround under Steve Jobs' leadership and its ability to surprise with innovative products and services. Key takeaways include the potential for trillion-dollar internet-scale companies, the value of services over products, and the importance of adapting to changing business landscapes.

site_title: US dollar awaits inflation data, oil lifts petrocurrencies
summary: The US dollar remained relatively stable ahead of US inflation data, with a fractionally firmer rate against the euro at $1.1856. Petrocurrencies, such as oil, lifted Norway's crown, Canada's dollar, and the Russian rouble. China's yuan rose to a near one-week high after strong trade data eased concerns about a slowdown in the country's economy. Economists expect the June CPI data to show a 0.5% rise, which could impact interest rates and the dollar.

site_title: US: Wall Street falls from records after data show inflation spike
summary: US stock indices fell on Tuesday after data showed inflation spiked 5.4% in June, the highest rate since 2008. The Labor Department report overshadowed big bank earnings announcements. Despite top Federal Reserve officials' assurances that price increases will be temporary, persistently high inflation may lead policymakers to reconsider massive stimulus policies. This could impact the markets, which have grown accustomed to such policies since the COVID-19 pandemic began.

site_title: Swatch CEO sees good prospects as shops reopen, travel resumes
summary: Swatch Group CEO Nick Hayek expects the company to return to pre-pandemic revenue levels in 2021 as pandemic restrictions ease. The watchmaker's shops are opening more than closing in the second half, with growth at its own stores recovering quickly after reopening. Demand for luxury goods is outpacing production capacity, particularly for brands like Omega and Blancpain. The company swung to a profit in the first half, beating analysts' estimates, with revenue in local currencies expected to be higher in the second half compared to the year-earlier period.

site_title: Lalamove weighs moving IPO venue from US to Hong Kong
summary: Lalamove, a Chinese on-demand logistics firm, is considering moving its planned $1 billion US IPO to Hong Kong due to uncertainty created by Chinese regulators' proposed new rules. The company filed confidentially for a US IPO last month but is weighing a venue switch amid concerns. This move comes as Chinese regulators crack down on firms chasing overseas listings.

site_title: Singapore's new trade-data platform aims to be game changer in digitalisation
summary: Singapore has launched a new trade-data platform aimed at improving transparency in the supply chain, enabling logistics coordination, and digitizing documents. The platform, developed in partnership with the private sector, aims to overcome previous digitalization efforts' failures due to lack of trust, cost concerns, and insufficient volume. It offers a neutral and open framework, providing a common data infrastructure for industry stakeholders. The platform promises to improve efficiency and savings, potentially changing the game in digitalization efforts in the industry.

site_title: US June consumer prices up by the most in 13 years amid supply constraints
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.9% in June, the largest gain in 13 years, driven by supply constraints and rebounding travel costs. This surpasses the 0.6% increase in May. The Labor Department reported the data on Tuesday. The economic recovery momentum continued, contributing to the price hike.

site_title: Mercurius ends 10.3% lower after rising as much as 8.2% on hefty turnover
summary: Mercurius Capital Investment shares fell 10.3% after rising 8.2% in early trade, closing at 8.7 cents. The stock reached a high of 10.5 cents before dropping to its intraday low. The decline came after a significant surge in turnover.

site_title: Megacap tech rebound reignites concern over 'extreme' valuations
summary: US technology stocks have surged, with the S&P 500 information technology index up 16% this year, raising concerns over "extreme" valuations. The sector's price-to-sales ratio has reached 7.4, similar to the dot-com bubble in 2000. Morgan Stanley sees "unprecedented headwinds" for the tech sector, including rising costs, competition, and regulations. Despite this, mega-cap tech companies like Apple and Microsoft have outperformed the S&P 500, with combined market capitalization adding over $1 trillion since June.

site_title: Development aid should be practical and feasible
summary: Rich countries should redefine development aid to focus on investments in state capacity, targeting weak governments rather than direct aid delivery to the population. This approach prioritizes the development of local governance capacity, enabling recipient governments to deliver services effectively. By providing tools and training to government workers, aid can help create conditions for sustained development over the long term. This approach shifts the focus away from lofty political objectives and instead emphasizes practical and feasible solutions, such as biometric markers and local elections, to reduce corruption and improve service delivery.

site_title: Shell sees opportunity as carbon capture market evolves
summary: Royal Dutch Shell sees an opportunity in the evolving carbon capture market, with the company aiming to scale up carbon capture and storage technology (CCS) as a service. CCS can capture emissions from various industries, including steel and cement, and Shell is currently linked to several major CCS projects. The company plans to develop a "carbon handling network" that can offer carbon services to heavy emitters, and its head of CCS Syrie Crouch believes the technology has the potential to aid the blue hydrogen industry and aid in reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

site_title: Creating a dynamic and resilient board through board evaluation
summary: Corporate boards in South-east Asia are shifting focus from traditional governance to environmental, social, and governance (ESG) imperatives due to the Covid-19 pandemic. A dynamic and resilient board is essential to deliver returns in a complex environment. While internal board evaluations can provide early detection, external advisers can offer objective assessments. A dynamic board requires self-scrutiny, collaborative work, and a learning culture. Effective board evaluation involves focusing on areas of improvement, encouraging candid feedback, and incorporating external stakeholder views. By doing so, boards can unlock new value and provide true oversight.

site_title: Will carbon capture take shipping to zero carbon?
summary: Carbon capture technology, which removes CO2 and other pollutants from shipping emissions, is being revisited as a viable solution to make shipping zero-carbon. Initially developed a decade ago, the technology was deemed impractical at sea and projects on land were faltering. However, recent advancements and the growing urgency to address climate change may lead to its widespread adoption, potentially transforming the shipping industry.

site_title: Four-bedroom unit at Shun Tak's Les Maisons Nassim scooped up for S$39 million
summary: A 6,577 sq ft four-bedroom unit at Shun Tak Holdings' luxury Les Maisons Nassim in Singapore's Nassim Road was sold for S$39 million (S$5,930 psf) in early May. The unit, marketed by SRI, is the first transaction for the project. Developer Shun Tak said "a few units" have been reserved, pending finalisation of sales documentation. The sale price is above the record price achieved by SC Global's The Marq in 2011 but below other recent luxury transactions in the area.

images.alt_text: Les Maisons Nassim sits on a 66,453 sq ft site which was formerly a landed property that Shun Tak purchased in 2018 for S$218 million.

site_title: Thai chemical company PTTGC rules out raising capital to fund 4 billion euro Allnex purchase
summary: Thai chemical company PTT Global Chemical (PTTGC) has ruled out raising capital to fund its 4 billion euro acquisition of German coating resins maker Allnex, citing sufficient cash reserves and loan options. The deal will be funded by cash and loans, with a total of over 155 billion baht available. The acquisition is expected to conclude by the end of the year pending regulatory approval and will not impact the company's dividend payment ability.

site_title: CNMC subsidiary gets go-ahead to resume gold mining in Kelantan
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings subsidiary CMNM Mining Group Sdn Bhd has received approval to resume gold mining operations at its Sokor gold mine in Kelantan, Malaysia, following the easing of Covid-19 restrictions in the state. Kelantan has transitioned into Phase 2 of Malaysia's National Recovery Plan, allowing the company to resume mining. This decision comes after the Malaysian federal government relaxed restrictions in five states, including Kelantan, from July 5.

site_title: PepsiCo raises profit forecast as soda demand jumps, plans price increases
summary: PepsiCo raised its full-year earnings forecast due to surging demand for its sodas from pandemic-weary consumers. The company plans to increase prices of its products, citing higher raw-material costs and rising advertising and marketing expenses. Net revenue rose 20.5% to $19.22 billion in the second quarter, exceeding expectations. PepsiCo expects fiscal 2021 core earnings per share to increase 11%, and will expand an automation program with expected pre-tax charges of $3.15 billion. The company's shares rose 2.5% to hit a record high.

site_title: Olympics organisers face uninsured loss from spectator ban
summary: Tokyo Olympics organisers are unlikely to receive a significant insurance payout due to lost ticket sales from the spectator ban. The ban, enforced due to the resurgent coronavirus, resulted in ticket revenues of about $815 million dwindling to close to zero. The Tokyo organising committee had taken out an event cancellation policy totaling $500-800 million, with much of the limit likely already used up for postponement costs. Reinsurers, such as Munich Re and Swiss Re, may face significant claims, estimated at $300-400 million, mainly from lost hospitality and ticket sales.

site_title: Black Widow gives a taste of how theatres and streaming can coexist
summary: The movie Black Widow, released on Disney+, simultaneously opened in theaters, collecting approximately $80 million in the US and Canada, and $78 million overseas, with 17 million people attending the film in theaters. This demonstrates that theatrical distribution and streaming can coexist, generating significant revenue for studios, with Disney clearing $98 million from ticket sales and $60 million from Disney+ orders. The success highlights the importance of theatrical distribution for big-budget films, despite the rise of streaming, and suggests that studios must consider both platforms to make money.

site_title: Vaccine passports need blockchain technology to work
summary: Vaccine passports require blockchain technology to function effectively, but poor understanding by decision-makers is stalling their adoption. The current patchwork of Covid passports is insecure, prone to misinformation, and may exacerbate existing inequalities. A globally recognized standard is needed to facilitate international travel and restore economies. Blockchain technology can provide immutability, transparency, and traceability, but its decentralized nature is underutilized. Asian countries, such as Singapore and South Korea, are leading the charge in integrating blockchain into travel verification systems, paving the way for global adoption.

site_title: New Boeing production problem found in undelivered 787 Dreamliners: FAA
summary: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has found a new manufacturing quality issue in undelivered Boeing 787 Dreamliners, located near the nose on certain planes. Boeing has committed to fixing the issue before resuming deliveries. Although the issue poses no immediate threat to flight safety, the FAA will review data to determine if similar modifications should be made on 787s already in commercial service. This issue follows previous production problems on the 787 and 737 MAX models, which have been plagued by electrical and other issues.

site_title: When Chinese firms are guilty by association
summary: A study found that Chinese firms experience a greater negative impact on their stock market valuations due to misconduct allegations against fellow Chinese firms, even when the accused firms are not directly involved. This phenomenon, known as "guilt by association," is attributed to inductive and deductive generalization, fueled by entrenched negative stereotypes of Chinese firms. The study shows that innocent Chinese firms experienced a 0.272% devaluation, while non-Chinese firms experienced a 0.149% devaluation, and that media coverage with a negative tone towards China further amplified the spillover effects.

site_title: Shipping chaos set to fester with most seafarers unvaccinated
summary: Global shipping chaos is looming due to the slow vaccination rate of seafarers, with over half of the 1.6 million workers unvaccinated. This poses a risk to trade disruptions, maritime worker safety, and global supply chains, particularly as the US and Europe recover from the pandemic slowdown. Ports in developing countries are restricting access to seafarers, exacerbating the issue, and the shipping industry is sounding the alarm on the potential for outbreaks and economic harm.

images.alt_text: Infections on vessels could further harm already strained global supply chains, just as the US and Europe recover. Outbreaks could also shut down ports with massive knock-on consequences for trade.

site_title: Becoming an entrepreneur at a mature age an alluring idea
summary: Over 50-year-olds are reconsidering entrepreneurship, citing digitalization's ease of starting a business, lower start-up costs, and increased access to global markets. While becoming an entrepreneur may not be as financially secure as a salaried job, it offers personal satisfaction, flexibility, and the chance to create value in communities. With Singapore's supportive business environment, many have successfully transitioned to entrepreneurship, and the country's aging population may see a rise in mature entrepreneurs, with some considering starting a business in their 50s or 60s.

site_title: Wellness resorts eye long Covid treatments as new moneymaker
summary: Wellness resorts are capitalizing on the growing demand for long Covid treatments, offering various therapies and programs to alleviate persistent symptoms. Despite a lack of consensus among physicians, medical spas and resorts are providing locally inspired or high-tech modalities, such as hyperbaric chambers and pranayama breathing exercises. The treatment programs, which can range from $3,000 to $3,500, often include a combination of medical treatments, healthy food, and exercise programs. With an estimated 23 million people worldwide potentially experiencing long Covid, the wellness resorts aim to provide a holistic approach to recovery.

site_title: New York City condo buyers less keen on becoming landlords
summary: New York City condo buyers are less interested in renting out their units for income, with only 2.7% of 2020 purchases listed for rent within six months, down from 11% in 2017. The pandemic led to a surge in apartment vacancies, causing landlords to discount rents and offer incentives. However, the number of empty units remains high, and some investors are stepping back into the rental market as Covid infections decline and employers plan a return to the office.

site_title: Yellen sees US companies pushing to back global tax deal
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said companies are likely to support a global overhaul of corporate taxation, which was endorsed by the G-20 nations over the weekend. The deal, which includes a minimum tax rate of at least 15%, aims to prevent companies from relocating to low-tax havens and share profit taxes imposed on the largest international companies. Yellen expressed hope that Republicans would come on board, despite challenges to ratification, and that the deal could be finalized in October at the G-20 summit in Rome.

site_title: Digital economy agreements herald new era of global connectivity
summary: The digital economy has emerged as a resilient sector despite the pandemic, driving growth and enterprise transformation. Governments worldwide are strengthening connectivity and trade infrastructure through Digital Economy Agreements (DEAs), which establish digital trade rules and collaboration. The US is discussing a new digital trade agreement with Indo-Pacific economies, including Singapore, Canada, and Japan, to establish standards for the digital economy. Singapore has also signed a DEA with Thailand and is negotiating with the UK and South Korea. DEAs aim to facilitate seamless digital trade, trusted data flows, and trust in digital systems, benefiting companies and individuals alike.

site_title: EU approves investment plans of 12 members, including Italy, France, Spain in boost to recovery
summary: The European Union has approved investment plans from 12 member states, including Italy, France, and Spain, totaling 800 billion euros, to boost the economic recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic. The plans aim to boost public investment to 3.5% of the bloc's GDP next year, the highest in over a decade. Disbursements of up to 13% of the funds will be made in coming weeks, with further disbursements conditional on national recovery plans. The EU estimates 4.8% growth this year and 4.5% in 2022, with the funds helping to fuel the economic rebound.

site_title: Tech-driven credit management solutions are key for businesses in post-Covid world, says new report
summary: A new report by Experian highlights the need for businesses to adopt tech-driven credit management solutions in the post-Covid world. With a complex dual economy emerging, where some consumers have higher incomes while others have declined, businesses must adapt to changing credit landscapes. The report found that 63% of Asia-Pacific businesses are concerned about customers' credit worthiness, and 27% of consumers use Buy Now Pay Later methods to make purchases. To succeed, businesses must rethink their analytic models, address consumers' growing digital needs, and provide increased payment flexibility.

site_title: Invest in multiple assets to manage climate issues: Pictet
summary: Pictet Wealth Management is advocating an asset-allocation strategy that moves away from the classic 60/40 portfolio to endowment-style investing, incorporating real assets like real estate and commodities to manage climate issues. The group expects real returns from cash to remain negative due to inflation and low interest rates, while private equity is expected to deliver highly attractive returns. Asia's economic importance is expected to rise, with China's annual GDP growth projected to be 4.2% by 2031. Governments and central banks are integrating climate-change issues into their policy-making, presenting opportunities and challenges for investors.

site_title: One year on since GE2020: Thinking afresh for the post-Covid era
summary: One year since the 2020 general election in Singapore, Parliament has focused on remaking the country for a fairer, more just, and compassionate society in a post-Covid world. Despite the pandemic dominating the legislative agenda, key reforms and initiatives have been introduced to address social and economic challenges. The government aims to create a more equitable society, building on the importance of democratic principles and the power of individual voices, as emphasized by former British Prime Minister Winston Churchill. Parliament will continue to shape Singapore's future in the post-Covid era.

site_title: K-Pop billionaire behind BTS doubles wealth on adding Bieber, Grande
summary: Bang Si-hyuk, founder of the K-pop agency behind BTS, has seen his wealth more than double to $3.2 billion after Hybe Co's shares surged 131% since its October IPO in South Korea. His net worth was around $1.5 billion at the IPO. This increase comes after Hybe Co's shares rose significantly, making Bang Si-hyuk one of the richest people in South Korea.

site_title: Nokia plans to raise full-year outlook, citing strong Q2
summary: Nokia plans to raise its full-year outlook due to a stronger-than-expected second quarter, where the company kept costs in check despite demand picking up. The company expects to revise its prior outlook ranges for 2021, with additional details to be released on July 29. Shares rose 4.3% following the statement. CEO Pekka Lundmark announced plans to cut 10,000 jobs and invest in 5G upgrades, citing a good foundation for the full year despite some headwinds in the second half.

site_title: Wealth gains in a pandemic and no easy answers on inequality
summary: Singapore's wealth report by Credit Suisse found that despite the country's worst-ever recession, median wealth per resident adult grew to US$86,720 in 2020, ranking 20th in the world. However, median household income from work fell by 2.5% in nominal terms, highlighting the disconnect between wealth and income. Economists attribute the rise in wealth to asset price growth, interest rate cuts, and sectoral reallocation, but warn that this has exacerbated income inequality, with the well-off benefiting while the low-income struggle to hold on to jobs. The government's fiscal support, such as the Jobs Support Scheme, has helped mitigate the effects, but experts argue that addressing wealth inequality requires a proactive fiscal and tax policy.

images.alt_text: Economic inequality is increasingly recognised as an issue involving not just income and wealth, but opportunity as well, authors Rachel Teo and Wong De Rui wrote in a report by GIC in April.

site_title: Netflix extends deal for animation films with Universal Pictures
summary: Netflix has extended a multi-year deal with Universal Pictures to stream animated film franchises such as Minions and Puss in Boots in the US. The deal includes rights to stream movies like Despicable Me and The Grinch, as well as full-animated and live-action films from four years after their release. This comes as studios like Disney hold back on selling rights to streamers to boost their own platforms, and is seen as a move to keep Netflix's kids subscriber base engaged.

site_title: Japan calls for 'sense of crisis' over China-Taiwan tensions
summary: Japan has expressed concern over China's military expansion, warning that it poses a threat to the US-China balance of power and Japan's security. In its annual white paper, the Japanese Defence Ministry emphasized the importance of stabilizing the Taiwan situation, calling for a "sense of crisis" due to the escalating tensions. This warning comes amid heightened military posturing by Beijing and Washington over Taiwan, highlighting the need for international attention and cooperation to address the growing security concerns.

site_title: Asian businesses step up to ESG reckoning
summary: Asian businesses are stepping up to ESG reckoning, recognizing that ESG obligations extend beyond shareholder interests. Corporates are partnering with stakeholders to drive environmental, social, and governance consciousness. A growing body of evidence shows that ESG practices lead to improved financial performance, better risk management, and increased access to capital. Governments in the region, such as Singapore and China, are also integrating sustainability into their national agendas, providing support for lasting ESG development. As a result, businesses that adopt ESG practices are better positioned to attract talent, reduce tail-risk controversies, and benefit from strategic opportunities.

images.alt_text: Digital trading platform HeveaConnect, which connects various stakeholders along the natural rubber supply chain, is one example of how private-sector players can come together to drive environmental, social and governance (ESG) consciousness.

site_title: US: Stocks open modestly lower on high inflation data
summary: US stocks opened modestly lower on Tuesday due to high inflation data, with the Consumer Price Index (CPI) rising 5.4% seasonally adjusted in June, its biggest gain since 2008. Used car prices surged 10.5% and petrol prices rose 45.1% over the past year. Despite the drop, the market was not severely affected.

site_title: Gold firms after US CPI surge; strong dollar limits gains
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,812.05 per ounce after US consumer prices surged 0.9% in June, the largest gain in 13 years. Despite this, a strong dollar limited gains, with the dollar index jumping 0.4% against rivals. Analysts expect the Federal Reserve to be cautious in responding to inflation, with Fed Chairman Jerome Powell's testimony on Wednesday and Thursday to be closely watched. The Fed's potential tapering of asset purchases is seen as a key factor in gold's price, with inflation concerns weighing on the metal.
