Above: To anyone for whom charging access isn't a problem, the Mercedes EQC 400 is surely a tempting proposition.
Mercedes has also been clever enough to add spark (not literally, of course) to the cabin.

site_title: Sex after 60 and other 'taboos' for women
summary: An online production, "The Festival Of Women N.O.W.", addresses taboo subjects for women, including sex after 60. 15 women aged 59-82 share their experiences, including artist Dana Lam and former MP Faizah Jamal. The production includes a facilitated discussion on sex and intimacy, aiming to spark honest conversations. The event aims to provide a platform for women to discuss often-discussed topics, including their desires, needs, and experiences as they age.

site_title: Manhattan's apartment glut eases as renters race to sign leases
summary: Manhattan's apartment glut has decreased by 38% in June, with 11,853 available units, a significant drop from pre-pandemic levels. Renters are signing leases at a record rate, agreeing to deals with fewer concessions and longer lease terms. The number of new leases tripled to 9,642, bringing down the borough's vacancy rate from 7.6% to 6.7%. Landlords are also pulling back on move-in concessions, with average concessions averaging 1.9 months of rent.

site_title: KKR breaks its own record with US$8b in loans
summary: KKR & Co has broken its own record, committing to $8 billion in commercial-property loans in 2021, more than double its previous full-year record. The surge in demand for financing is driven by the pandemic reopening, low interest rates, and trillions of dollars in stimulus money. KKR's real estate finance unit has closed on $4 billion in commercial-property loans and committed to $4 billion more, surpassing its 2019 annual record of $3.1 billion. This growth is attributed to increased financing options, including the acquisition of Global Atlantic Financial Group and the launch of KKR Real Estate Select Trust.

site_title: 2021 Kia Stonic review: Mild hybrid, mild mannered
summary: The 2021 Kia Stonic review highlights the vehicle's impressive features, including a mild hybrid system, at a relatively affordable price of S$91,999. The system captures energy to store in a 48V lithium-ion pack, reducing fuel consumption and allowing for a more eco-friendly driving experience. While the Stonic's new engine vibrates at idle and its air-conditioning is affected when the engine shuts down, its hybrid system seems to have made it "mild-mannered." Kia's mild hybrid technology may be a gateway to electric drive, with the company aiming to make all combustion cars mild hybrids in the future, as announced by Mercedes-Benz.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keppel Corporation is proposing to divest its data centre facility in Frankfurt, Germany, for 76 million euros (S$121.8 million) to a wholly-owned subsidiary of Iron Mountain. The property, Keppel DC Frankfurt 1, was previously held under a 60-40 joint venture with Alpha DC Fund. This move is part of Keppel's strategy to focus on core businesses and optimize asset utilization. The sale is expected to be completed in the near term, with no further details provided.

site_title: Evergrande's US$32b of IOUs add to liquidity concerns
summary: Evergrande Group, a Chinese property giant, is facing liquidity concerns as it ramps up issuance of short-term IOUs, known as commercial bills, to avoid missing payments. The company has about $32 billion of outstanding commercial bills, with some trading at yields as high as 36%, compared to its dollar bonds yielding around 25%. This reliance on short-term funding casts doubt on its deleveraging campaign, and missed payments could have a broader impact on China's $560 billion commercial bill market, potentially leading to a freeze and supporting the government's desire to rein in moral hazard.

images.alt_text: Evergrande's turn towards short-term funding casts doubt on whether its widely touted deleveraging campaign has actually made its finances more sustainable.

site_title: Ferrari 296 GTB gives more of what Singaporean customers want
summary: Ferrari's 296 GTB, the first road-going model with fewer than eight cylinders, boasts a powerful electric motor producing 830 horsepower. The plug-in hybrid V6 drivetrain accelerates from 0-100km/h in 2.9 seconds and 0-200km/h in 7.3 seconds, outperforming the F8 Tributo. With a fully charged range of 25km, the 296 GTB is set to arrive in Singapore next year with a price tag of S$1.2 million. Ferrari's director, Nicholas Syn, notes that electrification is a way to excite drivers, as the brand is known for pushing boundaries, rather than a customer demand.

site_title: Malaysia's PM to exercise executive powers despite losing Umno's support
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin will continue to exercise executive powers despite losing the support of the United Malays National Organisation (Umno), the country's biggest political party. Attorney-General Idrus Harun stated there are no "clear facts" to show the premier has lost majority support, citing the constitution. Umno withdrew support on Thursday, calling for Muhyiddin's resignation over the country's Covid-19 crisis, but its ministers in government have not said they will quit. A five-day special parliament meeting is scheduled for July 26.

site_title: From one music teacher to another, and another
summary: A musical tribute to Indonesian composer Zubir Said, who wrote Singapore's national anthem, will be staged by Wild Rice in August. The concert, titled "Don't Call Him Mr Mari Kita," will feature three generations of musicians, including Julian Wong, a 33-year-old music director and composer, and his ex-students and collaborators. The show will highlight 16 of Zubir's best songs, including the official Children's Day song, and will be accompanied by projected images and dramaturg Alfian Sa'at. The concert aims to keep alive Zubir's legacy and values, which were passed down through his students, including Wong.

site_title: There's nothing like hearth and office
summary: Employee surveys in Singapore reveal a shift in preference towards flexible hours and remote working, contrary to expectations that Gen Z and young millennials would prefer to return to the office after a year of remote work. However, this younger workforce is now ready to return to the office, according to recent surveys. Meanwhile, the Singapore Management University's new president, Lily Kong, shares her vision for the university, and various business and social initiatives are highlighted, including partnerships to drive financial literacy for women and promote sustainability.

site_title: Tesla unveils much cheaper Model Y in China after months of bad press
summary: Tesla has unveiled a significantly cheaper version of its Model Y sports utility vehicle in China, starting from US$42,600 after government subsidies. The standard-range version, available in Hong Kong, can run 525 kilometers on a single charge and is eligible for a state subsidy. This move comes after months of bad press in China, including negative publicity and concerns about customer service. Tesla's wholesale shipments decreased 0.9% in June, but the company aims to continue its investment in China and accelerate the world's transition to sustainable energy.

site_title: QuickCharge wants to make you an energy baron
summary: QuickCharge aims to turn individuals and businesses into Charging Point Operators, allowing them to sell electricity to EV drivers and make money. The company's Charge and Earn scheme uses AC chargers that can pay for themselves in eight months. Owners set pricing, and drivers pay using contactless devices or a smartphone app. QuickCharge estimates a gross profit of S$3.40 per hour, with a S$50 monthly membership fee for managing the charger through its app. The company plans to launch its service in the third quarter of this year and also targets the private residential market with its affordable AC charger.

site_title: S. Korea unveils 41 trillion won plan to be EV battery giant
summary: South Korea plans to invest 40.6 trillion won (S$41.2 billion) by 2030 to solidify its position as a major global force in the electric vehicle (EV) battery industry, competing with China and Japan. LG Energy Solution, SK Innovation, and Samsung SDI will be key players in the investment, with a focus on research and development and battery production. The government aims to support companies developing next-generation products, including solid-state batteries, and has allocated an 80 billion won fund to help small and medium-sized firms.

site_title: China's powerful Internet regulator flexes muscles with Didi probe
summary: China's Cyberspace Administration (CAC) has launched a probe into ride-hailing giant Didi Global, accusing it of illegally collecting users' personal data. This move follows high-profile investigations and penalties against "platform economy" companies, as Beijing tightens its grip on the tech sector and enforces data security efforts. The CAC's actions are part of China's broader policy of "Internet sovereignty," aiming to keep the country's online ecosystem behind the Great Firewall.

site_title: On track to better well-being
summary: Sparkd, Asia's first brain and fitness hub, offers a series of exercises that challenge both physical and mental capabilities. Founded by Anna Milani, the centre provides a neuro rehabilitation space and programmes for adults, kids, and seniors, backed by scientific evidence. Meanwhile, DexaFit Asia provides science-based health and fitness solutions, including tests for body composition, 3D body scans, and cardio assessments. The Zero 2.5 Air Ioniser, designed in Singapore, generates a million-fold more negative air ions than a live tree, cleaning the air of pollutants and refreshing the mind.

site_title: Upskilling and reskilling for opportunities in the new normal (SkillsFuture Forum 2021)
summary: Employers and employees must adapt to the new normal of the COVID-19 pandemic by upskilling and reskilling for opportunities in the post-pandemic era. Experts emphasize the importance of a culture that encourages experimentation, learning from failure, and continuous growth. Employers should focus on developing transferable skills, providing a safe work environment for learning, and investing in training programs that cater to the changing job market. The current recovery pace is rapid, and companies should not wait to invest in training, as it may lead to missed opportunities and being left behind.

site_title: SPH appoints Yeoh Oon Jin to the board as independent director
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) appoints Yeoh Oon Jin as an independent director, effective July 9. Yeoh, a 60-year-old with 38 years of experience at PwC Singapore, will join the executive and audit committees. His appointment comes as SPH faces unprecedented challenges from media industry disruption and the pandemic. SPH chairman Lee Boon Yang sees Yeoh's knowledge and leadership as a valuable asset to the company's strategic growth and success.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Thursday, down 21.44 points to 1,508.71. Volume was 5.349 billion lots worth RM 3.542 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 1,057 to 147.

site_title: Three new locally transmitted Covid-19 cases; 13 imported
summary: Singapore reported 16 new COVID-19 cases on July 8, with three locally transmitted and 13 imported cases. The locally transmitted cases are unlinked, except for one linked to a previous case. All imported cases were already on stay-home notices or isolated upon arrival. The country's total COVID-19 cases reached 62,668, with 36 deaths from complications and 15 who died of other causes.

site_title: Changi Prison cluster closed, 16 new Covid-19 cases
summary: A cluster at Changi Prison Complex in Singapore has been closed after 28 days with no new Covid-19 cases linked to it. The cluster, which affected 13 inmates, has recovered, and enhanced measures have been implemented to detect and contain Covid-19. The Ministry of Health reported 16 new Covid-19 cases, including 3 locally transmitted and 13 imported, with 22 active clusters of infection.

site_title: Dilemmas for central banks: climate stress tests for the real world
summary: Central banks are increasingly being asked to conduct climate stress tests to assess risks to human society and life. The Network for Greening the Financial System (NGFS) has produced climate scenarios to make stress testing easier for banks and investors. However, critics argue that conventional economic modeling can underestimate climate action benefits and overestimate costs, ignoring existential risks. Central banks must consider externalities impacting human society and take a more holistic approach to risk assessment, rather than just focusing on corporate value. The "hot house world" scenario, where a 3 deg C temperature rise is reached, suggests severe policy measures would be implemented, making it difficult to imagine mild policy reactions.

site_title: G-20 ministers, central bankers to discuss financing vaccinations, maintaining economic recovery
summary: G-20 ministers and central bankers will convene in Venice to discuss financing vaccinations, maintaining economic recovery, and implementing tax reforms. Despite the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, with 184.3 million confirmed cases and 4 million deaths, only 3 billion vaccinations have been administered, with developed nations ahead of emerging countries. The IMF proposes that at least 40% of the population should be vaccinated by the end of 2021 and 60% by mid-2022, with a focus on equitable access to vaccines and therapies.

site_title: Construction industry making progress on digital road
summary: Singapore's construction industry is making progress in digitalizing its processes, with companies like Lum Chang Holdings adopting technologies such as drones, laser scanning, and digital fabrication to improve efficiency and accuracy. Despite this, industry fragmentation, squeezed margins, and a lack of skilled labor remain major hurdles. Experts say that collaborative contracting, common platforms for digital delivery, and the development of new technologies such as cloud-based systems and artificial intelligence are key to accelerating digital adoption. The use of drones, AI, and cloud-based technologies are expected to see faster adoption, with potential benefits including increased productivity and improved health and safety on site.

site_title: Deliveroo hikes forecasts as food delivery demand stays strong
summary: Deliveroo reported an 88% jump in quarterly food orders and raised its annual order value forecasts, predicting a 50-60% growth in gross transaction value (GTV) for 2021. The food-delivery firm attributed the surge to people relying on home deliveries due to coronavirus curbs. Deliveroo also invested in growth opportunities and expects average order values to revert to pre-Covid levels, leading to lower profit margins. The company's GTV came from the UK and Ireland, accounting for nearly half of its total.

site_title: Hong Kong's Next Digital says CEO, CFO resign
summary: Hong Kong Media group Next Digital announced the resignation of its CEO, Cheung Kim-hung, and CFO, Hung Chi Keung, amid investigations under the national security law. The resignations, effective June 30, follow the raid of Apple Daily's newsroom and the freezing of the company's assets. The board will investigate the reason for Cheung's resignation, while Hung Chi Keung cited personal reasons. The company will cease operations from July 1.

site_title: US: Stocks fall amid worries over growth, Delta strain
summary: US stocks fell amid concerns over global growth, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 1.4% at 34,184.56. The 10-year US Treasury bond yield dropped below 1.3%, as inflation fears eased. The Delta variant of the coronavirus and rising cases also contributed to the market's decline. Despite this, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records, driven by the tech sector.

site_title: No 'clear facts' to show Malaysia PM has lost majority: Attorney-General
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin's Cabinet will continue to exercise executive powers as there are no "clear facts" to show he has lost his majority, according to Attorney-General Idrus Harun. The decision comes after Umno, the largest bloc in his coalition, withdrew support, citing tensions with the prime minister amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The move was seen as a bid to ease infighting within the ruling alliance, with Muhyiddin appointing a senior Umno member as deputy prime minister.

site_title: Grab CEO Anthony Tan's family buys GCB in Bin Tong Park for S$40m
summary: Grab co-founder and CEO Anthony Tan's family purchased a Bin Tong Park Good Class Bungalow (GCB) for S$40 million, with Tan's wife Chloe Tong being the buyer. The property, with a bungalow built in the 1990s, is expected to be redeveloped. The sale price works out to S$1,849 per square foot based on the freehold land area of 21,637 sq ft. This purchase follows a trend of rising prices in GCB areas, with 53 deals totaling nearly S$1.5 billion in the first-half of this year.

site_title: China's LinkDoc shelves US$211m US IPO after regulatory crackdown
summary: LinkDoc Technology, a Chinese medical data solutions provider, has shelved its US$211 million initial public offering (IPO) following Beijing's regulatory crackdown on overseas listings. The move comes after Beijing strengthened supervision of Chinese firms listed offshore, triggering a sell-off in US-listed Chinese stocks. LinkDoc had filed for the IPO last month and was due to price its shares after the US market closes. The decision is seen as a result of Beijing's efforts to tighten regulatory oversight on Chinese companies listing abroad.

site_title: Telenor quits Myanmar with US$105m sale to Lebanon's M1 Group
summary: Norwegian telecom firm Telenor has sold its Myanmar business to Lebanese investment firm M1 Group for $105 million, citing difficulties in operating under the military junta and concerns over employee safety. The sale comes as violence and restrictions have driven over 230,000 people from their homes and killed more than 880 people. Telenor's exit is a blow to activists who relied on the company for communications, and its decision has been welcomed by some investors who value human rights.

site_title: SP Group starts vehicle-to-grid technology trial
summary: SP Group, Singapore's national grid operator, has started a trial of vehicle-to-grid (V2G) technology, which enables electric vehicles to supply energy back to the grid. The trial aims to enhance grid reliability and mitigate intermittency problems. SP has raised its investment in V2G technology firm The Mobility House and will provide four V2G charging points for the trial, set to be completed in June 2022. The trial supports Singapore's goal of phasing out internal combustion engine vehicles by 2040 and demonstrates the potential of V2G technology in supporting a wider adoption of electric vehicles.

site_title: All eyes on Phuket sandbox, but questions remain over Asean tourism recovery
summary: Thailand's "Phuket sandbox" for quarantine-free leisure travel has sparked hope for the region's tourism recovery, with industry players eyeing expansion to other parts of the country and neighboring markets. However, the timeline for a return of tourists from China, where outbound travel remains restricted, will be crucial. Success of the Phuket sandbox remains uncertain, and its impact on the broader Asean tourism recovery is still to be seen. The industry is holding its breath for signs of growth and a return to normalcy in the tourism sector.

site_title: US jobless claims unexpectedly rise, overall trend points lower
summary: US jobless claims unexpectedly rose 2,000 to 373,000 for the week ended July 3, despite a trend pointing to a lower rate. Continuing claims dropped 145,000 to 3.339 million. The labor market recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic remains choppy, with record 9.2 million job openings and 9.5 million people officially unemployed in June. A decline in federal unemployment aid is expected to continue, with 14 states ending the $300 weekly cheque by mid-September.

images.alt_text: The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits rose slightly last week but continuing claims dropped, another indication that the labour market recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic continues to be choppy.

site_title: Axington Inc proposes acquisition of Web technology firm that will result in reverse takeover
summary: Axington Inc has signed a non-binding MOU to acquire a 60% stake in Veivo Web Technology for S$405 million. The acquisition, expected to result in a reverse takeover, will see Axington pay at least S$30 million in cash and issue new shares at S$0.19 per share. The deal is subject to definitive agreements to be entered into within a month.

site_title: Suga declares state of Covid-19 emergency in Tokyo
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga declared a state of emergency in Tokyo due to rising coronavirus infections, with restrictions in place until August 22. The measures include banning all spectators from the upcoming Olympics, which will be held under the state of emergency. Medical experts had recommended the move to curb a potential surge in infections. The decision marks the latest blow to the troubled Olympics, which have been plagued by setbacks and budget overruns.

site_title: EU fines Volkswagen, BMW US$1b for emissions cartel
summary: The European Commission fined Volkswagen and BMW US$1 billion for colluding to curb the use of emissions cleaning technology. This case sets a precedent by extending European competition law to technical-level talks between industry players. The talks, held a decade ago, centered on design standards for AdBlue, an additive used to cleanse nitrogen oxide from diesel-powered cars. The fine is separate from the 'Dieselgate' scandal, which involved software designed to cheat on vehicle emissions tests.

site_title: Singapore and regional markets extend losses; STI down 1.08%
summary: Singapore's benchmark STI fell 1.08% to 3,107.59, extending regional market losses. Asian stocks declined, with the Nikkei 225 Index and Hang Seng Index down 0.88% and 2.89%, respectively. The sole gainer, J36, rose 0.63%. Analysts predict a potential earnings per share (EPS) downgrade due to the ongoing COVID-19 resurgence and potential loan moratoriums.

site_title: Olympics bans spectators after Tokyo declares Covid-19 emergency
summary: The Tokyo Olympics have been forced to ban spectators due to a COVID-19 state of emergency declared in the capital. Organisers had initially planned to hold the games with limited spectators, but the decision was made to hold the event without spectators. Tokyo 2020 President Seiko Hashimoto expressed regret over the limited format, citing the spread of coronavirus infections. The decision marks a sharp turnabout from just weeks earlier, and fans who purchased tickets will not be able to attend the games.

site_title: ECB adds its clout to climate change battle
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has announced plans to incorporate climate change into its core policy decisions, a move seen as a significant step in addressing the issue. The ECB, led by President Christine Lagarde, will assess climate change-related metrics in its corporate bond purchases and disclose financial information. The bank aims to be more forward-leaning on climate change than the US Federal Reserve. The move comes ahead of the EU's launch of a carbon-cutting package next week, aiming to reduce net emissions by 55% by 2030 and limit global warming to 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels.

site_title: Thai authorities consider tighter curbs as Covid-19 deaths climb
summary: Thailand's health ministry has proposed new travel curbs and tighter restrictions to contain rising Covid-19 cases, including closing non-essential venues and areas that attract crowds, in high-risk areas like Bangkok. The proposed 14-day restrictions will cover the Bangkok metropolitan area and "buffer zones." The proposal comes after a record 75 daily deaths from Covid-19 and 7,058 new cases, bringing the total to 308,230. Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha will consider the new restrictions in a meeting on Friday.

site_title: Singapore-based SPAC files to go public via Nasdaq in US$100m IPO
summary: Singapore-based special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) Fat Projects Acquisition Corp has filed for a US$100 million initial public offering (IPO) on the Nasdaq. The company, sponsored by Fat Projects SPAC, aims to acquire technology-led companies in supply chain, logistics, and finance. If a suitable deal is not found, investors can redeem their capital. The IPO listing consists of 10,000,000 units at US$10 per unit, with a focus on companies in South-east Asia driven by the rapidly growing middle class and evolving consumption needs.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is working with banks and payment players to establish clear liability for consumers and financial firms in e-payment scams. HDB resale prices rose in June, with 19 million-dollar flats sold. Singapore Airlines is in a dominant position in the region, having raised US$16 billion since the pandemic. Ocean Tankers sold its lubricant assets to Hinduja Group for US$36 million. In Malaysia, Umno withdrew support for Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin, calling for his resignation due to the government's handling of the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Singapore's shophouse transaction value up 29.9% in H1 2021
summary: Singapore's shophouse transaction value increased 29.9% to S$836.1 million in H1 2021, up from H2 2020. This was driven by a pick-up in activity from Q4 2020. The half-year saw 118 sales, up from 90 in H2 2020, with total transaction values of S$365.4 million and S$470.7 million in the first and second quarters, respectively.

site_title: Kitchen Culture board dismisses CEO over 'grave misconduct' affecting the company's business
summary: Kitchen Culture Holdings has terminated CEO Lim Wee Li's employment with immediate effect due to "grave misconduct" affecting the company's business. The board cited Lim's actions as a "gross default" and appointed interim CEO Lincoln Teo to ensure the group's operations continue smoothly. Lim's resignation as a director and his termination from all subsidiaries will follow according to his employment contract. The company halted trading in its shares on Wednesday pending an announcement.

site_title: Novena Global Healthcare's Terence Loh declared bankrupt
summary: Terence Loh, 43, was declared bankrupt by the High Court after Maybank Singapore secured an order to recoup S$3 million in outstanding debt. This comes six months after his estranged cousin Nelson Loh was also declared bankrupt. Terence Loh had total outstanding debts of S$70 million, primarily due to personal guarantees for loans extended to Novena Global Healthcare, the flagship firm he founded. The bankruptcy marks a significant blow to Loh's efforts to distance himself from his cousin and salvage the businesses, including Novu Fasthetics, which operates aesthetics clinics.

site_title: Indonesia, Thailand consider booster shots amid doubts over Sinovac vaccine
summary: Indonesia and Thailand are considering offering booster shots to medical workers who received Sinovac's Covid-19 vaccine amid concerns over its effectiveness against new variants. The move comes as the countries face a record surge in cases and deaths, with low vaccination rates and rising infections among healthcare workers. Experts say a booster shot could increase immunity, but may undermine public trust in the vaccine. The decision is part of China's "vaccine diplomacy" efforts, but critics argue that the lack of efficacy data for Sinovac against the Delta variant is a concern.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend losses for the seventh day
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower for the seventh consecutive day, with the Hang Seng Index falling 2.89% to 27,153.13. The decline is attributed to the ongoing crackdown on tech firms by Beijing. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell, with declines of 0.79% and 0.48%, respectively. The losses are part of a broader market downturn in Asia, where traders are bracing for US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: MAS and French central bank complete wholesale cross-border payment and settlement experiment using CBDC
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and French central bank Banque de France have successfully completed a wholesale cross-border payment and settlement experiment using central bank digital currency (CBDC). The experiment, supported by JPMorgan's Onyx blockchain platform, simulated cross-border transactions between Singapore and France, demonstrating the potential for 24/7, real-time cross-border payments. The design of the multi-CBDC network enables scalability and cost efficiency, offering "great potential" for simplifying integration and reducing costs.

site_title: US will not immediately lift travel restrictions: White House official
summary: The Biden administration will not immediately lift international travel restrictions, despite growing pressure from US business groups and lawmakers. Interagency working groups with the EU, UK, Canada, and Mexico are exploring ways to lift restrictions, but further discussions are needed before any next steps are announced. The White House official emphasized that lifting travel restrictions with any country is not imminent.

site_title: Vietnam imposes stricter curbs to stem Ho Chi Minh City Covid outbreak
summary: Vietnam's Ho Chi Minh City will be placed under stricter COVID-19 restrictions for 15 days, starting July 9, to stem a new wave of infections. Residents are required to stay home except for essential needs, and motorbike taxis will be banned for two weeks. The measures follow a call from Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh for tighter rules to stop the virus's spread, with Ho Chi Minh City reporting 8,151 local infections. The city's COVID-19 total is now 23,071, making it Vietnam's worst-hit region.

site_title: OCBC rolls out sustainability training for staff as part of S$30m skills drive
summary: OCBC has launched a sustainability training program for its 30,000 employees, investing S$30 million over three years. The training is part of the OCBC Future Smart Programme and aims to create more subject experts in sustainability areas. The bank has already created over 50 sustainability-related jobs in the past two years, and the training program will further enhance its sustainability push.

site_title: Law firm representing interests of Wu and Woods in EHT cases says it is owed US$258,000
summary: Lawyers representing Howard Wu and Taylor Woods, co-founders of Eagle Hospitality Trust's sponsor Urban Commons, have applied to withdraw as counsel in EHT-related bankruptcy cases. The law firm, Potter Anderson & Corroon, claims to be owed US$258,633.47, excluding an "evergreen retainer" of US$250,000. Total unfunded obligations now stand at at least US$508,633.47.

site_title: Tan Chong expects to swing into profit of HK$60m for H1 from HK$46 million loss
summary: Tan Chong International, an auto dealer, expects to report a HK$60 million after-tax profit for the half-year ended June, swinging from a HK$46 million loss in the same period last year. The company attributed the improvement to the disposal of a surplus property in Singapore, which generated substantial gains. However, it also flagged a possible unaudited unrealised loss of HK$398 million on its investments due to share price changes.

site_title: ERA to provide Redbrick customers with proprietary tools under MOU
summary: ERA Realty has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Redbrick, an independent mortgage-advisory firm, to provide Redbrick's customers with ERA's proprietary tools, RealtyWatch and iERA Robo Advisor. Under the agreement, Redbrick customers will have access to up-to-date property information and personalized financial advice, while ERA customers will receive real-time interest rate information and mortgage advice from Redbrick. The collaboration aims to enhance customers' financial prudence and provide unbiased, customized real-estate financing advice.

site_title: Auditor issues disclaimer on finances of Loh cousins' Axington
summary: Axington, a cash company facing the risk of delisting, received a disclaimer of opinion from its independent auditor Foo Kon Tan LLP on its financial statements for 2020 due to issues with receivables, cash, and other expenses. The company's board attributed the issues to significant changes in its board composition and management personnel. Axington is seeking legal advice to resolve outstanding matters, including unexplained receipts and an outstanding balance from a placement share issuance. The company must acquire a new business within a year to avoid delisting.

site_title: Southeast Asian Games in Vietnam postponed over virus
summary: The Southeast Asian Games, originally scheduled for November 2021 in Vietnam, have been postponed due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The games will likely be held in 2022, with Vietnam proposing to host them in April or May next year. The decision was made due to the ongoing virus clusters in Vietnam, including in provinces where games events were planned, resulting in nearly 23,500 infections and 105 deaths. The postponement affects 11 locations, including Hanoi, where the games were initially set to take place.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks post sharpest drop in nearly two months
summary: South Korea's Kospi index dropped 0.99% on Thursday, its largest decline in nearly two months, amid record daily Covid-19 cases in the capital Seoul. The benchmark index fell 32.66 points to 3,252.68, with tech giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix leading the decline. Foreign investors sold US$420.10 million worth of shares, contributing to the market's downturn. The decline was attributed to the government's consideration of a semi-lockdown in Seoul, prompting concerns about the country's economic recovery.

site_title: Singapore's MiRXES raises US$77m to treble valuation as biotech craze catches on
summary: Singapore-based cancer diagnostics startup MiRXES has raised US$77 million in a Series C round, valuing the company at over US$500 million. The funding, led by CR-CP Life Science Fund, will support the commercialization of its early cancer detection test kits globally. MiRXES plans to use the funds to tap into investor appetite fueled by the pandemic and to prepare for a potential public listing. The company aims to double its global talent pool to 400 staff over the next two years, focusing on research and development, and data science.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares fall as Tokyo plans state of emergency ahead of Olympics
summary: Japanese shares fell 0.88% to 28,118.03, their lowest close in two weeks, due to concerns over a state of emergency in Tokyo ahead of the Olympics. The city will be placed under heightened restrictions, including closing restaurants that serve alcohol, in an effort to contain a resurgence of Covid-19 infections. Olympic organisers plan to ban all spectators from the Games, scheduled for July 23 to Aug. 8. The economic slowdown is causing investors to be hesitant to buy Japanese stocks, with some predicting the Olympics may be a negative factor for the market.

site_title: HDB resale prices rise in June with 19 million-dollar flats sold
summary: HDB resale prices rose 0.9% in June, marking the 12th consecutive month of gains, with a total of 2,311 resale flats sold, a 17.5% increase from May. The 19 flats sold for over $1 million, with the most expensive unit selling for $1.27 million, and 106 such transactions in the first half of the year, mostly in mature estates. Analysts expect prices to continue rising, driven by demand and construction delays on BTO flats.

site_title: Companies that support staff through SkillsFuture see rise in labour productivity
summary: Singapore companies that support staff training through the SkillsFuture programme saw a rise in revenue, with a 0.7% increase in revenue per year for up to three years after training, and a 2.2% increase in labour productivity per year for two years. Minister of State Gan Siow Huang stated that investing in workforce training leads to positive business outcomes, describing it as a "win-win proposition" for companies.

site_title: Singapore's HiLife Interactive bags S$8m in Series A funding from Shanghai 2345
summary: Singapore-based HiLife Interactive secured S$8 million in Series A funding from Shanghai 2345 Network Holding Group. The funds will be used to expand its presence in South-east Asia and break into the Australasian and European markets by the end of this year. HiLife will leverage Shanghai 2345's technological expertise to offer its smart solutions to commercial, hospitality, healthcare, and educational institutions.

site_title: MAS taskforce to make clear the liability held by consumers, financial firms in e-payment scams
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has set up a taskforce to clarify liability for consumers and financial firms in e-payment scams. Minister of State Desmond Tan aims for "fair, clear and consistent approaches" to protect consumers. The taskforce will work with banks and payment players to improve security measures, including One-Time Password verification processes. This move comes as the Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) enhances OTP verification using digital tokens. The goal is to better safeguard consumers against scams and fraudulent transactions.

site_title: ECB agrees on new inflation goal of 2%
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) agreed to raise its inflation goal to 2% and allow for some flexibility to overshoot it, marking a significant change from its previous target of "below, but close to 2%". This decision aims to guide the central bank's actions as the economy recovers from the pandemic and could justify sustaining ultra-loose monetary policy. The revised strategy is a result of the ECB's first strategy review in almost 20 years.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slide at open
summary: European stock markets slid at the start of trading on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 1.0% to 7,078.02 points, and the eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also losing 1.0% each. The decline follows concerns over strong inflation, as the Federal Reserve reported a higher-than-expected jump in US inflation, potentially leading to reduced emergency stimulus packages and earlier interest rate hikes.

site_title: Ransomware cases in Singapore rose 154% in 2020
summary: Singapore's cybersecurity agency reported a 154% increase in ransomware cases in 2020, with 89 cases affecting mostly small and medium enterprises in sectors like manufacturing, retail, and healthcare. The number of reported cases is expected to exceed last year's, and the agency has sounded the alarm on the growing threat. Ransomware has evolved into a "massive and systemic threat" with targeted attacks on large businesses and essential service providers. The agency is directing Critical Information Infrastructure sectors to enhance their cybersecurity posture and conducting an incident management exercise to refresh agencies' procedures.

site_title: Temasek-backed online education firm UpGrad earmarks US$250m for acquisitions
summary: UpGrad, an online education firm backed by Temasek, plans to allocate $250 million for acquisitions to accelerate global expansion. The company will target digital learning providers and immersive short-form learning startups in Indonesia, Vietnam, and Africa. Two acquisitions are expected to be announced within 60 days. With a valuation nearing $4 billion, UpGrad aims to create an integrated, connected model in higher education across multiple geographies, targeting over 1 billion knowledge workers and 250 million higher education enrollees.

site_title: Climate change is top emerging risk for banks in Asia-Pacific: survey
summary: Climate change has become the top emerging risk for banks in the Asia-Pacific region, with 100% of chief risk officers viewing it as a top risk over the next 12 months. This surpasses the global result of 91%. Climate change is also seen as a top long-term risk, with 90% of bank CROs in the Asia-Pacific viewing it as such. Despite efforts to assess and manage climate risk, banks in the region are still "maturing" in their ability to do so.

site_title: CDL down as much as 4.2% on Chongqing Sincere's potential restructuring
summary: CDL shares plummeted 4.2% as Chongqing Sincere Yuanchuang Industrial, a significant shareholder, faces potential restructuring. A Beijing-based creditor filed a bankruptcy petition, triggering a formal process that could lead to restructuring, liquidation, or settlement. CDL has ring-fenced its financial exposure, but analysts expect a "knee-jerk negative reaction" due to significant underperformance. Despite this, Citi maintains a target price of S$11.02, citing undemanding valuations.

site_title: Macquarie consortium weighs rival bid for Sydney Airport: sources
summary: A consortium led by Macquarie Group is exploring a rival bid for Sydney Airport, potentially challenging IFM Investors' A$22.3 billion offer. Macquarie may partner with local pension funds and use its own capital for the deal. The move could be a bold bet on global travel recovery after the pandemic. If successful, it would be the largest airport acquisition in Australia and one of the world's biggest. Deliberations are at an early stage, with no certainty Macquarie will proceed with a formal offer.

site_title: Hin Leong's Ocean Tankers close US$36m sale of lube assets to India's Hinduja unit
summary: Ocean Tankers, a Singapore-based vessel operator, has sold its lubricant blending plant and storage facilities in Tuas to Gulf Oil International, a unit of Indian conglomerate Hinduja Group, for US$36 million. The deal, led by Ocean Tankers' judicial managers, aims to fulfill the company's survival as a going concern. Gulf Oil sees the acquisition as a strategic opportunity to invest in the marine segment and grow its market share in marine lubricants and services. The sale marks a significant step for Ocean Tankers, which was placed under judicial management last year due to severe debt strain.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower as virus fears linger
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on Thursday as investors expressed concerns over possible anti-infection measures in Japan. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.08% to 28,342.99, while the Topix index declined 0.02% to 1,937.23. Strong US stocks provided limited support, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 8.53 points or 0.6% to 1,521.62. Losers outnumbered gainers 331 to 48. Volume reached 174.5 million lots worth RM56.4 million.

site_title: Keppel divests data centre in Frankfurt for 76m euros
summary: Keppel Corp is divesting its data centre facility in Frankfurt, Germany to a wholly-owned subsidiary of Iron Mountain for 76 million euros (S$121.6 million). The divestment is expected to be completed in Q3 2021 and is not expected to impact Keppel's net tangible assets per share or earnings per share for the current financial year. The book value of the property as of Dec 31, 2020 is 63 million euros.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open down
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.28% at the start of trade on Thursday, amid concerns over a potential crackdown on tech firms by Beijing. The Hang Seng Index dropped 79.56 points to 27,881.06. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 3.38 points to 3557.20, while the Shenzhen Composite Index on China's second exchange increased 0.34% or 8.59 points to 2456.18.

site_title: Asia: Virus woes and tech crackdown hammer stocks; bonds rally
summary: Asian stocks fell to a six-week low on Thursday due to a broad risk-averse mood, with tech shares in Hong Kong and rising virus cases adding to pressure. The Hang Seng index dropped 1.9% and the MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan fell 1% to its lowest since late May. A dovish turn from Chinese policymakers sparked a rally in sovereign Chinese debt, while US yields fell to a 10-month low. The US dollar retained bid amid concerns over higher interest rates, and oil prices declined for a third day.

site_title: Singapore stocks open slightly higher on Thursday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened 0.1% higher on Thursday, tracking gains on Wall Street. The STI rose 1.72 points to 3,143.32, with 62.1 million securities worth S$51.5 million changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 90 to 58. Banking stocks were mixed, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite ended higher in the US. European stocks rose, and Tokyo shares opened lower due to concerns over Japan's anti-infection measures.

site_title: GIC-backed Bukalapak increases IPO target to over US$1b on strong demand: sources
summary: Indonesian e-commerce firm Bukalapak is targeting a US$1 billion IPO, 25% more than initially planned, due to strong investor demand for the country's first tech unicorn listing. Backed by Singapore's GIC and Microsoft, the company is set to be the largest local listing in 13 years and the largest ever by a startup in Southeast Asia, indicating investors' keen interest in technology sector offerings in the region.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB raises target price of GKE Corp to S$0.21
summary: CGS-CIMB has maintained a "buy" rating on GKE Corp, raising its target price to S$0.21. Analysts Ong Khang Chuen and Kenneth Tan forecast a 140% increase in core net profit to S$11.3 million due to high ready-mix concrete volumes and pricing in China, as well as robust warehousing performance in Singapore. The analysts attribute this growth to the company's increased capacity and strong demand for construction materials, particularly at its Wuzhou RMC plant.

site_title: Gold steady above US$1,800 as lower yields counter stronger dollar
summary: Gold prices held steady above $1,800 due to lower US Treasury yields, which countered a stronger dollar. Benchmark US 10-year Treasury yields dropped to their lowest since February, reducing the opportunity cost of holding non-interest bearing gold. However, a stronger dollar made gold more expensive for other currency holders. The Federal Reserve may taper its asset purchases as soon as this year, according to minutes from its last meeting. Gold prices were little changed, with spot gold steady at $1,803.01 per ounce.

site_title: AirAsia eyes US listing of digital business this year
summary: AirAsia Group is exploring a potential US listing of its digital business, either AirAsia Digital or the AirAsia SuperApp, as early as this year. CEO Tony Fernandes mentioned receiving interest from special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) and plans to adapt its financial reporting to US methods. This move comes as the airline doubles down on its digital strategy amid the ongoing pandemic. The acquisition of Gojek's businesses in Thailand for $50 million through the AirAsia SuperApp was also announced.

site_title: Amid Delta scare, EU forecasts higher growth in eurozone
summary: The European Commission forecasts a 4.8% expansion in the eurozone economy this year, higher than the 4.3% initially estimated in May, driven by the reopening of national economies and boosted tourism. The eurozone is expected to grow by 4.5% next year, with higher inflation anticipated this year due to the Delta variant. The Commission urges a further vaccination campaign to contain the spread of the variant, despite expressing optimism about Europe's ability to control it without new restrictions.

site_title: Sydney sees worst day of 2021 as Delta Covid-19 outbreak spreads
summary: Australia's New South Wales state reported its biggest daily rise in locally acquired Covid-19 cases for 2021, with 38 new cases, amid a growing cluster of the highly infectious Delta variant in Sydney. The state is in its third week of a lockdown, with NSW Premier Gladys Berejiklian urging residents to limit family visits and urging those with flu symptoms to get tested for Covid-19. Only around 10% of the country has been fully vaccinated, and the lockdown is expected to last until July 16.

site_title: Covid-19 infections in England have quadrupled since June
summary: Covid-19 infections in England have quadrupled since early June, according to a large prevalence study. The Delta coronavirus variant is fueling the new wave, with cases estimated to double every six days. Despite this, Prime Minister Boris Johnson plans to fully re-open the economy on July 19, citing the need for life to return to normal despite potential increases in deaths.

site_title: Citigroup creates tech, media and telco role for South-east Asia dealmaking
summary: Citigroup has hired Varun Matta, former head of mergers and acquisitions at CIMB, as the head of technology, media and telecommunications investment banking for the Asean region. Matta will lead a push in dealmaking in countries such as Indonesia, Malaysia, and Singapore. This move comes after Citigroup advised on significant deals in the region, including the $18 billion merger of Tokopedia and GoJek in Indonesia. Matta will report to Jim Perry and Ho-Yin Lee, co-heads of TMT for Asia Pacific, and David Biller, head of Asean banking, capital markets and advisory.

site_title: Heartland malls in areas with less retail space per capita may recover more quickly
summary: Singapore's suburban malls are expected to recover unevenly due to varying tenant mixes, shopping experiences, and catchment sizes. Areas with limited retail space per capita, such as emerging regional centers and fringe precincts, are likely to fare better, with higher revenue and occupancies. Conversely, established regional centers and areas with more retail space per capita will require retailers to focus on tenant mixes and marketing to boost footfall. The recovery of suburban malls will also depend on the presence of significant working populations and established housing estates.

site_title: BT Explains: A look at payment fraud, which hits Singapore firms more than in region
summary: Singapore firms experienced significant losses due to payment fraud, with 9 in 10 losing revenue in 2020. Synthetic identity fraud (58%) and account takeover fraud (60%) were the most common types, surpassing the regional average. The Asia-Pacific region as a whole reported a 84% loss in revenue due to payment fraud. This highlights the rising sophistication of fraud methods, with Singapore's numbers slightly higher than the regional average. The findings are based on a survey by Worldpay from FIS.

site_title: Umno withdraws support for Muhyiddin; calls on PM to resign
summary: Malaysia's largest party, Umno, withdrew support for Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin, citing his failure to manage the Covid-19 pandemic effectively. Umno President Ahmad Zahid Hamidi called on Muhyiddin to resign and a new prime minister to be appointed for a limited term, focusing on pandemic management and elections to be held after herd immunity is achieved. The move comes amid tensions between Umno and the ruling coalition, with Muhyiddin's tenure plagued by infighting and criticism over his handling of the pandemic.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq post record closing highs after Fed minutes
summary: US stocks closed at record highs on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching new highs, following minutes from the Federal Reserve meeting that indicated officials may not be ready to tighten policy yet. The minutes showed Fed officials felt substantial progress on the economic recovery had not been met, but were poised to act if inflation or other risks materialized. Treasury yields edged lower, and stocks mostly edged higher, with both growth and value stocks gaining.

site_title: Hot stock: Metal Component sees heavy trading, up 14% after share issue gets nod
summary: Metal Component Engineering (MCE) saw a 14.3% surge in its share price after receiving the Singapore Exchange's in-principle approval to issue shares in relation to its proposed acquisition of Gainhealth, a healthcare business. 29.7 million shares were traded, making it the second most traded security after the market opened on Thursday. The share price rose to 6.4 Singapore cents, with no married deals recorded in early trade.

site_title: First Reit skips call on S$60m perpetual; distribution rate reset at 4.9817%
summary: First Reit Investment Trust (Reit) announced it won't redeem its S$60 million perpetual securities on its first call date, instead resetting the distribution rate to 4.9817% per annum. The decision aims to diversify funding sources and optimize the Reit's capital structure. The move comes amid uncertain economic conditions and favorable market conditions for future issuance. The Reit's shares rose 1.89% on the news.

site_title: London fintech funding soars in first half of the year
summary: London fintech companies raised $5.3 billion in funding from venture capital investors in the first half of 2021, exceeding $2.1 billion in the same period in 2020. This marks the largest six-month funding haul for London fintech startups, demonstrating the city's resilience as a hub for digital financial services post-Brexit. Globally, fintech companies raised $54.1 billion between January and June, with London accounting for over a third of Europe's funding, ranking second behind San Francisco.

site_title: UK house prices fall ahead of cuts to tax perks
summary: UK house prices fell 0.5% in June, the first decline since January, ahead of tax breaks expiring. Prices rose 8.8% annually, but remain £21,000 higher than last year. The decline is attributed to the end of the Covid-19 emergency tax break for buyers, which expired at the end of June. Despite this, Halifax predicts demand for bigger homes will continue, supporting prices. London prices rose 2.9% annually, while other regions saw faster growth.

site_title: Novo Tellus Capital mulls joining Singapore SPAC race: sources
summary: Singapore-based private equity firm Novo Tellus Capital Partners is considering setting up a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) to list in the city-state, amid a surge in listings globally. The firm has had preliminary discussions with banks and is awaiting official exchange guidelines before making a final decision. This move could benefit Singapore's exchange, which has seen just three IPOs this year, raising US$242 million in total. Novo Tellus would join Vertex Holdings, a unit of Temasek Holdings, in seeking to be among the first to launch a blank-cheque company in Singapore.

site_title: Trump sues Facebook, Twitter, Google over social media bans
summary: Former US President Donald Trump sued Facebook, Twitter, Google, and their CEOs, seeking to restore his social media accounts and punitive damages. Trump filed three class-action lawsuits in Florida, claiming the tech giants are violating his First Amendment rights. The lawsuits aim to prevent future users from being banned or flagged by the companies. Trump's legal team, led by John P Coale, is seeking court orders to reinstate Trump's accounts and protect users' rights.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise as commodity stocks rebound, techs jump
summary: European stocks rose 0.8% on Wednesday, rebounding from a three-day losing streak, as commodity-linked stocks recovered and technology shares gained 1%. The Stoxx 600 index, led by SAP's 3.5% surge, posted its best session in seven weeks. Mining stocks also rebounded, while the travel and leisure sector fell 1.5%. Analysts expect strong earnings growth in the second quarter, with profits projected to jump 108.6% year-over-year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDL, Keppel, Singtel, Hongkong Land, CapitaLand, First Reit
summary: Keppel sold its German data centre facility for $121.6 million, while Singtel's technology services arm, NCS, unveiled a new brand identity and was recast as a pan-Asian B2B digital services provider. Hongkong Land's green bond offering was three times subscribed, and CapitaLand launched a second logistics private fund in India worth $400 million. First Reit will not redeem its perpetual securities on its first call date, with a reset distribution rate of 4.9817% per annum.

site_title: South Korea reports highest ever daily rise in Covid-19 cases
summary: South Korea reported its highest daily rise in Covid-19 cases with 1,275 new infections, surpassing the peak of its third wave in December. The government considers tightening social distancing restrictions due to the rapid spread of the Delta variant among unvaccinated people in their 20s and 30s. Only 10% of the population of 52 million has been fully vaccinated, with 30% receiving at least one shot. The country's total Covid-19 infections stand at 164,028, with 2,034 deaths. Authorities are worried about the growing number of highly contagious Delta variant cases.

site_title: Oil falls in volatile trade as investors seek Opec clarity
summary: Oil prices fell more than $1 a barrel on Wednesday as investors awaited clarity from Opec+ talks, which broke down between Saudi Arabia and the UAE. Brent crude settled at $73.43 a barrel, down 1.5%, and US West Texas Intermediate fell to $72.20 a barrel, shedding 1.6%. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and its allies maintained nearly 6 million barrels of output cuts, but the breakdown may lead producers to increase supply.

site_title: Chip crisis deepens with Daimler, Jaguar warnings on sales
summary: Daimler and Jaguar Land Rover have warned of further sales declines due to the global semiconductor shortage, which began last year amid pandemic lockdowns. The shortage is expected to slash $110 billion in car industry sales, with deliveries curtailed by a lack of chips. Other carmakers, including Nissan and Hyundai, have also warned of shrinking inventory and squeezing sales this summer. The crisis has forced manufacturers to overhaul their supply chains, with Jaguar Land Rover now expecting a 50% decline in second-quarter deliveries. The shortage persists despite efforts to address the issue.

site_title: Malaysia's PM names new deputy as Parliament set to reconvene
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin has appointed Defence Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob as his deputy, ahead of Parliament's scheduled reconvening later this month. Foreign Minister Hishamuddin Hussein has also been promoted to senior minister, taking over Ismail's security portfolio. The moves are seen as an attempt to win over a major coalition partner.

site_title: Japan considers ban on all Olympic spectators
summary: Japan is considering banning all spectators from the upcoming Olympic Games due to public concern about the risk of fueling new surges of COVID-19 infections. Medical experts have deemed having no spectators as the least risky option. The move would come just over two weeks before the Games are set to begin.

site_title: How Singapore can lead the world in building better buildings
summary: Singapore's construction industry can lead the world in building better buildings by adopting effective project management, embracing technology, and investing in power skills. The industry faces challenges such as poor project performance, inconsistent processes, and a lack of consistency in project management skills. Effective project management can help reduce waste, improve productivity, and enhance safety. The use of technologies like Building Information Modelling (BIM) and Artificial Intelligence can also boost efficiency and productivity. Additionally, investing in power skills such as leadership, communication, and collaboration can help professionals adapt to the changing industry landscape and drive innovation.

site_title: Nike shares lose out to Chinese sneaker rivals after Xinjiang cotton boycott
summary: Nike shares have lost out to Chinese sneaker rivals as global firms face sales decline due to tensions over human-rights issues in Xinjiang. A surge in patriotic buying in China has boosted local sneaker makers, with one company seeing a 250% increase in value since March. This has led to a Bloomberg gauge of Hong Kong-listed apparel and retail stocks reaching its highest level since 2015, surpassing global peers like Nike.

site_title: Evergrande's US$32b pile of IOUs adds to liquidity concerns
summary: China Evergrande Group has ramped up issuance of short-term IOUs, known as commercial bills, despite touting a deleveraging campaign to reduce its debt. The company's main onshore subsidiary has approximately $32 billion of commercial bills outstanding, with some trading at implied yields as high as 36%. This growth in short-term funding raises concerns about Evergrande's liquidity and potential for missed payments, which could impact its suppliers and the broader Chinese commercial bill market.

site_title: Listing of payments firm Wise boosts UK tech hub ambitions
summary: Wise, a fintech company that revolutionized money transfers, is going public through a direct listing on the London Stock Exchange, eschewing a traditional IPO. Existing shareholders are selling at least 2.4% of their stake, and Wise's market capitalization could reach £7.46 billion. This deal could signal the UK's ability to attract fast-growing companies, with London's listings surpassing continental competitors in the first half of 2021, raising a cumulative $14 billion.

site_title: Differentiated measures for fully vaccinated persons to kick in soon
summary: Singapore is set to introduce differentiated safe management measures for fully vaccinated individuals, including larger social gathering group sizes, increased dine-in capacities, and resumption of wedding receptions and work gatherings, starting from next week. The measures are contingent on reaching 50% of the population being fully vaccinated, expected around July 26. This milestone will also see increased group sizes for cinemas, congregational worship, and live performances to up to 500 persons.

site_title: Firms with US$5t in cash set to splurge: Janus
summary: Companies with over US$5 trillion in cash reserves are expected to start spending, unleashing a surge in capital expenditures and shareholder payouts, according to a report by Janus Henderson Investors. This comes after firms added US$1.1 trillion to their "war chests" in 2020, nearly doubling the previous five-year total. The increased spending is likely to boost economic growth, but also raises concerns about inflation and market volatility.

site_title: IMF chief urges G-20 to prevent 'devastating' blow to poorest
summary: IMF chief Kristalina Georgieva urged the G-20 to prevent a "devastating" blow to the poorest countries by taking urgent steps to help them withstand the pandemic and economic damage. She warned of a "deepening divergence" between rich and poor, calling for increased vaccine access and funding to repair fortunes. The IMF estimated that low-income countries need $200 billion over five years to fight the pandemic and $250 billion for economic reforms. Georgieva proposed a $50 billion joint effort to expand vaccine access, which she said would save hundreds of thousands of lives.

site_title: Euro 2020: England survive Denmark scare to reach first major final in 55 years
summary: England reached the first major tournament final in 55 years after coming from behind to beat Denmark 2-1 in the Euro 2020 semi-final. Denmark's Mikkel Damsgaard scored a stunning free-kick, but England equalized with a Simon Kjaer own goal and won the penalty shootout after controversy over a disputed penalty call. England will now face Italy in the final on Sunday, with captain Harry Kane saying it's one of the proudest moments of his life.

images.alt_text: England will play in their first major tournament final for 55 years after coming from behind to beat Denmark 2-1 after extra time in front of a delirious 65,000 crowd at Wembley in Wednesday's Euro 2020 semi-final.

site_title: Pentagon hits reset on Trump's US$10b cloud deal
summary: The US Pentagon cancelled a $10 billion cloud-computing project, known as Jedi, which was awarded to Microsoft in 2019 under the Trump administration. The contract was challenged by Amazon, which alleged improper pressure from Trump, and is now expected to be rebid to multiple cloud providers, including Amazon and possibly others. The Biden administration has said it will parcel out the project to multiple companies, aligning with private-sector practices. The Pentagon hopes to award new cloud contracts by April 2022, with both Microsoft and Amazon expected to secure contracts.

site_title: Political stability in Laos holds the key to economic prosperity
summary: Laos held a nationwide election in February, with the ruling Lao People's Revolutionary Party (LPRP) securing 158 seats. Despite media criticism, the election was seen as contributing to the country's drive for economic prosperity. With a relatively stable political situation, Laos is becoming an attractive investment destination, with major international companies exploring opportunities in the agricultural, tourism, and minerals sectors. The country's infrastructure development, including the China-Laos Railway, is also expected to boost its appeal as a trade and investment hub.

site_title: UK housing boom may derail post-Brexit trade dreams
summary: The UK housing market is experiencing a boom, with house prices rising at the fastest annual rate since 2004. This surge in housing prices could threaten post-Brexit export-powered growth, as it may crowd out manufacturing, which accounts for 10% of the overall economic output. Experts warn that a booming housing market can attract foreign investment, boosting the domestic currency and making exports expensive, potentially harming the manufacturing sector. Policymakers must resist the temptation to stimulate the housing market again, as it may undercut efforts to boost more productive sectors.

site_title: Binance hasn't got everything right, says CEO
summary: Binance CEO Changpeng "CZ" Zhao acknowledges the company's mistakes, attributing them to rapid growth. The exchange has faced a series of regulatory issues, including a UK crackdown, warnings from Japan and Thailand, and a probe by the US Justice Department. Zhao outlined steps to address these issues, including expanding compliance and localising operations to comply with local regulations. Despite these efforts, Binance remains at the "tipping point" with the broader cryptocurrency industry.

site_title: Covid-19 resurgence, slow vaccination roll-outs, external risks diminish Asia's recovery prospects
summary: Asia's economic recovery is being weighed down by an uneven pace of economic growth, with stocks underperforming globally. The S&P 500 has surged 15.64% year-to-date, while the MSCI World Index is up 13.11%. In contrast, Asian stocks have struggled, with concerns over a resurgence of COVID-19 and slow vaccination roll-outs. External risks, such as trade tensions and global economic uncertainty, also pose a threat to the region's recovery prospects.

site_title: S Korea considers reimposing curbs as Covid-19 cases surge
summary: South Korea reported its second-highest daily new Covid-19 cases on July 7, with 1,212 cases, mostly in Seoul. Movement restrictions in the capital and surrounding regions were extended for at least another week. The government is considering reimposing strict social distancing measures if the situation doesn't improve. Only 10% of the population has been fully vaccinated, and officials are urging younger, unvaccinated individuals to get tested preemptively.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Kim Boo-kyum says a fourth wave of the virus is spreading fast, especially among unvaccinated people in their 20s and 30s, while a growing number of contagious Delta variant cases have raised new worries.

site_title: Reviving Kodak moments as technology fatigue hits
summary: Millennials are rediscovering the joys of analogue photography as technology fatigue sets in. Digital editor Samantha Francis is among those who have turned to SLR film, finding nostalgia appeal in the process. This revival is seen as a welcome change, with many documenting their photos on social media. Meanwhile, a musical tribute to Indonesian composer Zubir Said is set to take place, reflecting on his iconic national anthem and music career. The trend is also seen in the rise of new restaurants, including Tapas 24, which is making its debut in Singapore.

site_title: E-commerce boom to double India warehouse deals, says Knight Frank
summary: India's e-commerce boom is expected to more than double the size of warehouse deals over the next five years, with annual transactions growing to 76.2 million square feet by March 2026. This follows a drop in the past year due to the pandemic. E-commerce companies are betting on growth in tier two and three locations, which are becoming preferred warehousing hubs. The demand for Grade A compliant, multistorey warehouses is expected to spike, with e-commerce accounting for 165% more space in Indian warehouses over the next five years.

site_title: Shell to boost shareholder returns after sharp rise in oil prices
summary: Royal Dutch Shell will boost shareholder returns via share buybacks or dividends earlier than expected, increasing distribution to 20-30% of cash flow from operations starting in the second quarter. The move comes after the company reduced debt due to a sharp rise in oil and gas prices, exceeding its previous target of net debt below $65 billion. Shell's shares rose 2.2% following the announcement, with analysts praising the company's strong operational and financial delivery.

site_title: Singtel's tech-services unit recast as pan-Asian B2B digital services provider
summary: Singtel's technology services arm, NCS, has been rebranded as a pan-Asian business-to-business digital services provider. The unit will focus on two key business segments: "Gov+" for governments and smart cities, and "Telco+" for helping telcos improve efficiency and develop 5G solutions. NCS aims to hire up to 2,000 tech talents and expand into markets such as mainland China, Hong Kong, and North Asia. The company's new strategy aims to capitalize on the digitalization trend driven by the pandemic and 5G, and is expected to play a key role in Singtel's growth.

site_title: FTSE says to add Didi in indices on July 8
summary: FTSE Russell plans to add Didi Global to its global equity indices on July 8, pending no trading halt in shares. However, if a halt occurs during US market hours on July 7, the addition will be delayed. This comes as Didi faces turmoil due to a Chinese regulator crackdown, causing its shares to slump in US trading.

site_title: Will Bitcoin become a transaction currency?
summary: Bitcoin's volatility and limited merchant acceptance make it unsuitable as a transaction currency. However, stablecoins, which associate cryptocurrencies with stable assets, may offer a solution to the volatility problem. Governments like the US are now exploring the use of blockchain technologies and stablecoins, and central bank digital currencies are gaining prominence. Stablecoins have the potential to facilitate international payments and provide infrastructure support for decentralized finance, but their adoption depends on regulatory and supervisory frameworks.

site_title: Sale of rare Leonardo drawing triggers legal battle in France
summary: A rare Leonardo da Vinci drawing of Saint Sebastian is at the center of a French court battle. The drawing, valued at 8-12 million euros, was discovered in a box in 2016 and attributed to the artist. France's culture ministry claims the piece is a national treasure and wants to acquire it for the Louvre, but the owner, Jean B, refuses, citing a 10 million-euro offer from the state. Jean B has applied for an export permit to sell the drawing to a foreign buyer, and a court hearing is underway to determine the drawing's fate.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Cheung Woh Technologies' voluntary unconditional cash offer for its shares has closed with 97.1% of valid acceptances, exceeding the required 90% threshold. As a result, the Singapore Exchange has suspended trading of its shares from 9am on Wednesday. The offer closed at 5:30pm on Tuesday, marking a successful completion of the transaction.

site_title: How to use Europe's excess savings
summary: Europe's households are accumulating vast savings during the pandemic, totaling 450 billion euros in 2020, with an additional 200 billion euros expected in 2021. However, these savings are largely held by high-income households, which may channel only about one-third of their savings into consumption, providing a moderate economic boost. To maximize the benefits, policymakers should encourage households to invest their excess savings in long-term, sustainable projects, such as European long-term investment funds, which could support Europe's green and digital transformation and yield a double dividend for savers and the economy.

site_title: India's Dilip Kumar, who embodied melancholy on screen, dies at 98
summary: Dilip Kumar, a renowned Indian actor known for his roles as a tragic hero in Bollywood films, died at 98. Born in 1922 in Peshawar, Pakistan, Kumar began his acting career in the 1940s and rose to stardom with his breakthrough role in 1949's "Andaz." He is remembered for his iconic portrayal of a doomed lover in "Devdas," earning him the nickname "tragedy king." Kumar's legacy has been hailed by Prime Minister Narendra Modi and actor Amitabh Bachchan, who praised his unparalleled brilliance and enduring impact on Indian cinema.

site_title: AirAsia to buy Gojek's Thai business for US$50m in shares
summary: AirAsia Group agreed to buy Gojek's Thai business in a stock swap worth US$50 million, giving Gojek a 4.76% stake in AirAsia SuperApp. The deal values the Thai business at around US$1 billion, more than AirAsia's current market value. AirAsia aims to turbo-charge its ambitions in the Thai market, while Gojek will focus on increasing investment in Vietnam and Singapore. The acquisition comes as AirAsia seeks to raise more capital amid the pandemic-induced slump in global travel.

site_title: Haitian president assassinated in 'barbaric act': PM
summary: Haitian President Jovenel Moise was assassinated in his private residence, with his wife injured. Interim Prime Minister Claude Joseph described the act as "inhuman and barbaric." The attack occurred amid rising violence in Port-au-Prince, driven by poverty and political instability. Moise faced opposition protests and accusations of seeking a dictatorship, and had ruled by decree since legislative elections failed to materialize. The incident has raised fears of widespread disorder in the impoverished Caribbean nation, already facing a growing humanitarian crisis and shortages of food.

site_title: China tech rout deepens as Beijing targets data restrictions, US listings
summary: China's State Council has announced plans to revise rules for overseas listings and increase regulatory oversight of companies trading in offshore markets, aiming to slow the pace of Chinese listings in the US and reduce lucrative fees. This move is expected to impact Chinese technology firms, potentially slowing their pace of listings and reducing fees on Wall Street. Increased regulation may also lead to economic decoupling between China and the US, with the risk of national security concerns.

site_title: New Covid-19 cluster in Singapore with 4 cases
summary: A new Covid-19 cluster was declared in Singapore with four cases linked to case 64599. The cases are part of the city-state's total of 62,652 cases, with 12 new cases reported, bringing the active clusters to 23. The number of new cases in the community has decreased from 68 to 24, and the number of unlinked cases has decreased from nine to seven.

images.alt_text: Overall, the number of new cases in the community has decreased from 68 in the week before to 24 in the past week.

site_title: Euro near three-month lows; dollar awaits Fed minutes
summary: The euro traded near a three-month low against the US dollar after German data raised doubts about the strength of the economic recovery, while the US dollar awaits the minutes from the last Federal Reserve policy meeting. The euro fell to US$1.1820, and investor sentiment in Germany, the euro zone's biggest economy, fell sharply in July. Oil prices plunged, affecting risk-sensitive currencies, with the Australian dollar trading 0.3% higher.

site_title: Singapore office market abuzz with investment sale activity
summary: Investment sale activity in Singapore's office market is expected to recover, driven by rising rents in the second half of the year and a recovery in the market. Deals are underway for One George Street and Twenty Anson, with prices ranging from S$1.25 billion to S$1.29 billion and S$630 million, respectively. Other properties, such as Lazada One and PIL Building, are also expected to be put on the market, with potential prices in the S$3,000 psf range. This follows a decline in transactions in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: One George Street (above) could fetch between S$1.25 billion and S$1.29 billion, or S$2,800-S$2,900 per square foot on its net lettable area (NLA), say observers. The guide price for Twenty Anson, is understood to be S$630 million or S$3,050 psf on NLA of about 206,200 sq ft. It was bought by AEW in 2018 for S$516 million or S$2,503 psf.

The guide price for Twenty Anson (above), is understood to be S$630 million or S$3,050 psf on NLA of about 206,200 sq ft. It was bought by AEW in 2018 for S$516 million or S$2,503 psf.

site_title: UK productivity rises as lockdowns shut bars and restaurants
summary: The UK's productivity rose unexpectedly in the first quarter, despite lockdowns and restrictions, with output per hour increasing 0.9% from a year earlier. This contrasted with the closure of bars and restaurants, but was driven by highly educated staff in professions such as law firms and IT companies. The Office for National Statistics noted a positive allocation effect, with activities shifting from less productive to more productive industries. However, the overall economy still lags behind pre-pandemic levels, with hourly output 25% lower than expected.

site_title: Nintendo unveils US$350 Switch with display that still lags rivals
summary: Nintendo has unveiled a new Switch console with a larger 17.8cm OLED screen and doubled onboard storage to 64GB, priced at US$350. The upgrade lacks a 4K graphics display, disappointing fans and investors. Analysts predict the new console will stimulate holiday sales but may not surpass the rumored Switch Pro device.
