Singapore's statutory corporate tax rate is 17%, but many big companies use tax incentives to pay an effective rate in the single digits. A global tax reform could impact Singapore's ability to remain a top hub for MNCs.

site_title: Alleged S$1b nickel fraudster said to spend S$2m a month on private jets, nightclubs, alcohol, luxury cars
summary: A Singapore court has tightened bail conditions for Ng Yu Zhi, a businessman accused of involvement in a $1.5 billion nickel trading scheme. Ng's bail was increased to $4 million, and authorities found plans to help him flee the country. Ng, 34, faces 31 charges and has a monthly personal expenditure of $2 million, including luxury items and gifts. An investigation estimated net outflows of $475 million from Ng's companies, compared to $841.5 million in inflows from investors.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.73 points to 1,531.63. The index saw 6.755 billion lots traded worth RM 3.654 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 580 to 417.

site_title: Maybank KE identifies potential ESG winners in economic transition
summary: Maybank KE's Singapore ESG Compendium identifies potential ESG winners in various sectors amid the country's economic transition. Companies such as DBS, Venture Corporation, and ComfortDelGro are favored for their strategic advantages in addressing environmental, social, and governance challenges. Analysts highlight companies like DBS for its sustainable finance goals, Venture Corporation for its employee reskilling, and ComfortDelGro for its environmental goals. These companies have outperformed their peers in the market, with some seeing significant growth in 2020 and 2021.

site_title: Nextdoor to go public in US$4.3b merger with Khosla-backed SPAC
summary: Nextdoor, a social network for neighbors, will go public through a US$4.3 billion merger with Khosla-backed SPAC Khosla Ventures Acquisition Co II. The deal includes a private investment of US$270 million and will generate proceeds of about US$686 million for the combined company. Nextdoor plans to use the funds for hiring and expansion into new territories. The merger is expected to close in the fourth quarter this year, with the merged entity listed under the ticker symbol "KIND".

site_title: Working with right partners is key to business survival amid persisting pandemic
summary: Singapore's businesses have been severely tested by the pandemic, with many shutting down or adapting to a "new optimal" capacity. To survive, businesses must evolve and operate with technology and adaptive thinking. Rethinking business practices, core metrics, and outsourcing non-core functions can lead to cost savings and increased efficiency. Leveraging technology platforms, such as cloud-based solutions and automation tools, can help manage electricity expenditures and achieve sustainability goals. Working with the right partners, including those with expertise in renewable energy, can also help businesses future-proof their operations and thrive in a post-pandemic landscape.

site_title: With an eye on elections, Japan's ruling party considers cash payouts in stimulus plan
summary: Japan's ruling party is considering a one-off cash payout of 100,000 yen (S$1.21 million) to low-income citizens to ease social disparity caused by the pandemic. The proposal, made by policy chief Hakubun Shimomura, would be included in an economic package ahead of the general election later this year. Finance Minister Taro Aso has opposed uniform cash payouts, citing concerns about debt, but Economy Minister Yasutoshi Nishimura left the possibility of an extra spending plan open.

site_title: Share of EP holders from India nearly doubled since 2005 due to global tech talent trends
summary: The share of Employment Pass holders from India has nearly doubled since 2005, from about one-seventh to one-quarter, due to global tech talent trends, not favorable treatment under the India-Singapore Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement. This information was shared by Manpower Minister Tan See Leng in a parliamentary statement, aiming to address misconceptions about the foreign workforce.

site_title: Vaccination to determine pace and extent of Singapore's post-pandemic transition: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore's post-pandemic transition will be determined by vaccination rates, with milestones such as fully vaccinating two-thirds of the population serving as guidelines. Minister for Health Ong Ye Kung emphasized the importance of psychological readiness for policy changes, ensuring public confidence in shifting from pandemic to endemic status. Changes will be implemented progressively, with a focus on vaccination as a key factor in determining the pace and extent of the transition.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares suffer fresh losses by close
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended lower on Tuesday, extending losses into a fifth day, as traders grow concerned about China's crackdown on tech giants. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.25% to 28,072.86, while the Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.11% to 3,530.26. The losses come amid broader market trends, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and trade talks between the US and EU in focus.

site_title: Australian F1 Grand Prix and MotoGP to be called off
summary: The Australian Formula One Grand Prix and MotoGP are set to be cancelled for a second consecutive year due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. The events, originally planned for October and November, have been cancelled due to Australia's strict quarantine requirements for overseas arrivals. An official announcement is expected later Tuesday from the Australian Grand Prix Corporation.

site_title: STI up 1.6% on Tuesday, clocks strongest daily gain since May
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.58% on Tuesday, its strongest daily gain since May 18, driven by investor optimism. Finance Minister Lawrence Wong's announcement of additional Covid-19 support measures is expected to cost S$1.2 billion, but analysts see it as a targeted support measure. Domestic reopening names like C52 and J69U are expected to lead the market, while travel and leisure stocks are expected to lag due to border reopening uncertainty. The STI has been treated to an end-of-quarter rebalance and robust economic reports, contributing to its strong performance.

site_title: Plane with 29 people on board goes missing in Russia's far east: TASS
summary: A Russian AN-26 airplane with 29 people on board has gone missing in Kamchatka peninsula in Russia's far east, according to TASS news agency. The plane lost contact with air traffic control while attempting to land. Authorities are investigating the cause of the disappearance.

site_title: Chip crisis deepens with Daimler, Jaguar warning of lost sales
summary: Daimler and Jaguar Land Rover warned of lost sales due to the global semiconductor shortage, which is threatening to slash US$110 billion in car industry sales. The shortage, caused by high demand for personal devices during pandemic lockdowns, has persisted through 2021 and is expected to continue into next year. Other automakers, including Nissan Motor, Hyundai Motor, and Volkswagen, have also warned of shrinking inventory and squeezed sales. The chip shortage is impacting car deliveries, with Jaguar Land Rover flagging a 50% drop in second-quarter deliveries.

site_title: Australia: Tech stocks drag shares lower, despite energy boost
summary: Australian shares closed 0.7% lower on Tuesday, weighed down by tech stocks and a decision by the Reserve Bank of Australia to pare its bond buying program. The energy sector, however, received a boost from rising oil prices, with the energy sub-index rallying 1.6%. Tech stocks fell 1.8%, led by Appen and Megaport, while the big four banks also declined. The decision by Opec+ to call off oil output talks raised concerns about supply tightening.

site_title: Didi plunges below IPO price as China crackdown brings US pain
summary: Didi Global, a Chinese ride-hailing giant, plummeted 25% in its first trading day after listing on the New York Stock Exchange, falling to $11.58. The company's platform was ordered to be removed from Chinese app stores by the Cyberspace Administration of China, citing security risks. This move may impact Didi's revenue in China, and some analysts suggest that the company may have known of the crackdown in advance, raising concerns about its governance.

images.alt_text: Didi Global shares slumped as much as 25 per cent in U pre-market trade on Tuesday, ahead of its first session since Chinese regulators ordered the company's app be taken down days after its US$4.4 billion listing on the New York Stock Exchange.

site_title: Hong Kong to shorten IPO settlement cycle by next year
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange plans to shorten the IPO settlement cycle from five days to two days by the fourth quarter next year, aligning with other financial hubs. The change, facilitated by a digital platform called Fini, aims to drive market efficiency and reduce liquidity risks. The move is expected to cut income for brokerages but will likely increase market efficiency, reinforcing Hong Kong's position as the world's premier IPO market.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks hit record closing high on tech boost
summary: South Korean stocks reached a record closing high on Tuesday, driven by technology stocks ahead of Samsung Electronics' preliminary earnings. The Kospi index rose 0.36% to 3,305.21, following a 0.35% gain on Monday. The won strengthened, and the benchmark bond yield also rose.

site_title: Europe: Shares muted after three days of gains
summary: European stocks fell 0.1% on Tuesday, following three days of gains, due to gloomy trading in Asia and a drop in German industrial orders, which posted their sharpest slump in May since 2020. Automakers led the decline. The Stoxx 600 index was hurt by weaker demand from countries outside the euro zone.

site_title: Thai exports seen rising more than 7% y-o-y in Q3: shippers
summary: Thailand's exports are expected to rise more than 7% in the third quarter and 6% in the final quarter of the year, driven by higher global demand and a weaker baht. The country's shippers' council attributes the growth to vaccinations for factory workers, which could lead to a 10% export increase this year. However, the Federation of Thai Industries' sentiment index has dropped for the third straight month due to concerns over the country's coronavirus outbreak and sluggish domestic demand. The government is urged to tackle worker shortages in labor-intensive industries.

site_title: Israel, South Korea agree to Covid-19 vaccine swap
summary: Israel and South Korea have agreed to exchange expiring COVID-19 vaccine doses. Israel will deliver around 700,000 doses of Pfizer-BioNTech's vaccine to South Korea by the end of the month, while South Korea will return the same number to Israel in September and October. The deal aims to help South Korea accelerate its vaccination plans and achieve herd immunity earlier than its current target of November.

site_title: CECA and other FTAs do not give foreigners 'free rein to come to live and work in Singapore': Ong Ye Kung
summary: Health Minister Ong Ye Kung defended Singapore's free trade agreements (FTAs) against criticism, stating that they do not give foreigners "free rein" to live and work in Singapore. Ong clarified that FTAs, including the India-Singapore Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA), require foreign professionals to meet Singapore's qualifying work pass criteria. He also acknowledged that competition between foreign and local professionals exists, but emphasized that FTAs are part of the solution, rather than the cause of challenges faced by local professionals.

site_title: ST Telemedia unit launches hyperscale 40MW data centre in Loyang
summary: ST Telemedia Global Data Centres (STT GDC) launched its hyperscale data centre, STT Loyang, in Loyang, Singapore, with a 40MW IT load capacity. The six-storey facility, spanning over 27,000 sq m, is STT GDC's largest in Singapore. To mitigate construction delays due to the pandemic, the data centre's electrical, mechanical, and building elements were prefabricated off-site. This brings the total number of STT GDC data centres in Singapore to eight.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 2.29 points higher, or 0.15%, at 1,534.65, with 426.58 million lots traded worth RM220.91 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 265 to 123.

site_title: Indian e-commerce industry set to grow by 141% through 2025: GlobalData
summary: The Indian e-commerce industry is expected to grow by 141% from 2020 to 2025, reaching $111.4 billion, according to GlobalData. Despite concerns about Covid-19 and inflation, the industry's long-term outlook is optimistic due to rising income, favorable demographics, and foreign investment. Retailers are advised to look to peers in China, Singapore, and South Korea for recovery strategies, and some have resorted to salary cuts and layoffs. However, the industry's growth is expected to be driven by rising income and favorable demographics.

site_title: We can't think only about Covid, British health minister says
summary: British Health Minister Sajid Javid emphasized the need to move beyond COVID-19 concerns and address other pressing health issues, economic problems, and education challenges. The UK has seen a significant vaccine rollout, with 86% of adults receiving a first dose and 64% receiving two doses. Prime Minister Boris Johnson plans to end social and economic restrictions in two weeks, betting on the vaccination program to prevent a new wave of COVID-19. The UK has suffered the seventh highest global death toll from COVID-19, and the health minister's comments come as the country faces a second month of economic contraction.

site_title: Hong Kong will assess Singapore's Covid strategy before reviving travel bubble
summary: Hong Kong will assess Singapore's new Covid-19 strategy to revive a quarantine-free travel corridor. Singapore plans to loosen restrictions and achieve two-thirds of its population fully vaccinated by August 9. The city-state's stance has shifted towards learning to live with the virus, rather than eliminating it. Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam expressed a need to understand the new strategy's impact on travel arrangements. The two cities aim to revive the travel bubble, which was initially planned for last November but has not yet materialized.

site_title: China's Suning shares jump after restructuring eases debt concerns
summary: China's Suning.com shares jumped 10% on Tuesday after the company announced a restructuring plan that will see a state-backed fund become a major shareholder. The 8.8 billion yuan deal, which will leave Suning.com without a controlling shareholder, addresses concerns over cash flow. Chairman Zhang Jindong and other major shareholders will sell a combined 17% stake to the fund, which also includes Alibaba Group and Xiaomi as investors. The deal aims to ease liquidity concerns and provide a new path forward for the loss-making online retailer.

site_title: Rural India sinks deeper into debt as Covid-19 wipes out work
summary: A report from Reuters found that rural India is struggling with debt and poverty, exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic. Households in Uttar Pradesh state have seen their incomes plummet by 75% and nearly two-thirds have taken on debt. The lack of jobs and rising debt is affecting private consumption and investments, hindering economic recovery. Economists warn that this will prolong the recovery process and have a significant impact on the country's GDP growth, which has already fallen by 7.3% in the previous year.

site_title: Lower-wage workers' faster-than-median wage growth not to be taken for granted: Zaqy Mohamad
summary: Singapore's lower-wage workers have experienced faster-than-median wage growth, but this progress should not be taken for granted, according to Senior Minister of State for Manpower Zaqy Mohamad. In comparison to OECD countries, workers at the 20th percentile in Singapore have seen robust real income growth, while those in the UK saw no real wage growth and those in Japan and US saw cumulative real wage growth of 3% and 6% respectively over a 10-year period. New recommendations for the Progressive Wage Model will be announced, with plans to expand to more sectors and benefit up to 218,000 workers.

site_title: Hot stock: Rex up 5% on drone technology investment
summary: Rex International's shares rose 5% on Tuesday after the company announced a US$4 million investment in commercial drone company Xer Technologies. The investment includes a US$1 million stake and a commitment to inject up to US$3 million, subject to certain milestones. The move aims to diversify Rex International's business and align with its approved mandate for sustainable energy solutions.

site_title: Black box retrieved from crashed Philippines Air Force plane
summary: Philippine authorities have retrieved a black box from a crashed Air Force plane on Jolo island, killing over 50 people. The pilot, experienced in flying the C-130 aircraft, was among the fatalities. The incident occurred on the weekend, and the cause of the crash remains unknown. The retrieval of the black box is an important step in investigating the incident, but further details have not been released.

images.alt_text: Philippine authorities have retrieved a black box from an Air Force plane that crashed at the weekend, killing more than 50 people, Military Chief Cirilito Sobejana told Reuters on Tuesday.

site_title: Hong Kong leader dismisses Big Tech privacy law fears
summary: Hong Kong's leader Carrie Lam dismissed concerns from major tech companies, including Google and Facebook, that they may quit the financial hub if a new privacy law is passed. The law aims to target "doxxing," publishing private details online to harass others. Tech companies warned that the broad legislation could lead to sanctions and prosecution of employees. Lam likened the law to a national security law and suggested that the city's privacy commission would meet with industry representatives to address concerns. The government plans to fast-track the legislation despite tech industry worries.

site_title: Reserve Bank of Australia tapers QE but affirms lower-for-longer rates
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) held the cash rate at 0.1% and tapered its quantitative easing program, buying government bonds at a weekly pace of A$4 billion, to support the economy as it transitions from recovery to expansion. The decision reaffirms the RBA's dovish stance until 2024, citing ongoing virus outbreaks and uncertainty. Analysts expect a "flexible" setting, with most economists predicting no interest rate hike until mid-2023.

site_title: 'Superman' director Richard Donner dies at 91
summary: Richard Donner, director of the first "Superman" movie and other blockbusters, died at 91. Donner's credits include "The Goonies," "The Omen," "Lethal Weapon," and "16 Blocks." He also directed episodes of iconic TV shows and produced hits like "X-Men" and "Free Willy." No cause of death was revealed. Donner's assistant confirmed his passing, while his wife, Lauren Schuler Donner, declined to comment. Fellow actor Sean Astin remembered Donner's "biggest, boomiest voice."

images.alt_text: Richard Donner, a prolific filmmaker who directed the first "Superman" movie, "The Goonies," and other blockbusters hits, died on Monday at age 91, US media reported.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks flat at start of trade
summary: Hong Kong shares were flat at the start of trade on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index inching down 6.87 points to 28,136.63. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw marginal declines. The focus is on the Federal Reserve's policy meeting minutes, which are expected to provide insight into its monetary policy plans.

site_title: Asia: Oil prices extend gains after Opec+ talks fail, most equities up
summary: Oil prices continue to rise in Asia after Opec+ talks failed, potentially leading to US$100 a barrel, a level not seen since 2014. The breakdown of talks raises concerns about inflation, prompting central banks to reconsider monetary policy. Equity markets remained largely buoyant, with most regional bourses up, except Hong Kong, which extended losses due to fears of a crackdown on the tech sector. Analysts predict increased volatility in the oil market, with possible scenarios including a no-deal outcome or countries slashing prices to fight for market share.

site_title: Deutsche Bank launches indices to track 21 emerging market currencies
summary: Deutsche Bank has launched four non-tradable foreign exchange indexes to track 21 emerging market currencies, reflecting growing global investment in developing markets. The indices, which track spot and carry performance, serve as barometers for EM investors. The move indicates increased relevance of emerging markets in the global economy, with these currencies seeing increased global investment inflows and government debt issuance. The new indexes are expected to provide a comprehensive view of emerging market currencies.

site_title: Endemic Covid-19 situation will bring fresh economic opportunities: Gan Kim Yong
summary: Singapore aims to reopen its economy and borders after transitioning to a Covid-19 endemic state, enabling effective vaccination, testing, and treatment regimes to minimize hospitalizations. Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong sees this shift as an opportunity to rebuild competitive strengths and develop new ones, positioning Singapore as a critical node in the digital economy. The government plans to strengthen connectivity through Digital Economy Agreements and support businesses to digitalize, while also focusing on sustainability and emerging as a carbon trading and services hub.

images.alt_text: Singapore seeks to reopen its economy and borders after transitioning to a Covid-19 endemic state, which would gradually return economic activities to normal, said Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong on Tuesday.

site_title: Dior show celebrates fashion up close and personal after pandemic
summary: Christian Dior kicked off Paris Fashion Week with an in-person runway show, marking a return to traditional catwalk shows after the pandemic. The Fall/Winter 2021-2022 haute couture collection featured tweed ensembles, vegetal prints, and embroidered long dresses. Designer Maria Grazia Chiuri emphasized the importance of fabrics being front and centre, citing the tactile nature of the fabrics as a key aspect of the show. The limited crowd, which included celebrities like Jessica Chastain and Cara Delevingne, was the first to witness the show since the pandemic, highlighting the revival of pre-pandemic glamour.

site_title: Japan to ship millions more Covid-19 vaccines to Taiwan, Asian neighbours this week
summary: Japan plans to ship 1.1 million AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine doses to Taiwan on Thursday, followed by shipments to Thailand, the Philippines, and Vietnam. This is part of Japan's bilateral vaccine donation efforts, with the country having previously sent doses to Indonesia and Malaysia. Japan has arranged to buy 120 million doses of the vaccine, with most produced domestically. The shipments are outside of the global COVAX program, as AstraZeneca doses produced in Japan have not yet been approved by the World Health Organization for use in COVAX.

images.alt_text: Japan said on Tuesday it would ship millions more doses of AstraZeneca Plc's Covid-19 vaccine to Asian neighbours this week as a continuation of bilateral donations.

site_title: Nomura halts coverage of dozens of firms as top analysts leave
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc suspended coverage of 29 companies, including Nintendo Co and Rakuten Group Inc, after two top analysts, Junko Yamamura and Yoshitaka Nagao, left the company. The move follows Nomura's efforts to reorganize and consolidate its research capabilities under CEO Kentaro Okuda. The brokerage covers over 1,200 stocks worldwide with 200 research specialists in 10 regions. The suspension affects companies in the leisure and amusement sector, broadcasting and advertising industry, and real estate investment trusts. This decision is part of Nomura's broader growth plans.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.4% to 3,154.73, driven by gains from Serial System. The market saw 77.3 million securities worth S$50.4 million traded, with 92 gainers outnumbering 39 losers. This marks the latest in a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.36% and the Topix index increasing 0.26%. The moves came as investors sought fresh cues ahead of the Olympics, held in Japan in two and a half weeks.

site_title: ecoWise lead ID resigns from other commitments to focus on compliance notice
summary: ECOWISE lead independent director Er Kwong Wah has resigned from CFM Holdings and Chaswood Resources Holdings to focus on a Singapore Exchange compliance notice for a "troubled listed company". The notice requires the companies to appoint new independent directors, commission internal audits, and form a new auditing committee. The resignations will not comply with Catalist rules, which require at least three members on the auditing committee and two non-executive independent directors on the board. The companies will attempt to fill the vacancies within two months.

site_title: Temasek-backed Pine Labs raises US$600m from investors including Fidelity, BlackRock
summary: Pine Labs, a Singapore-based payments platform, has raised US$600 million from investors including Fidelity and BlackRock, valuing the company at US$3 billion. The startup offers in-store and online payment solutions, prepaid, loyalty, and "pay later" programs, and targets a public offering within 18 months. With the growing popularity of payment services in Asia, Pine Labs aims to capitalize on the trend, with banks and merchants paying monthly fees for its software as a service and micro-fees on every transaction.

site_title: Egypt notified that Ethiopia has resumed filling of giant dam
summary: Egypt's irrigation minister confirmed that Ethiopia has resumed filling its Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) for a second year, prompting Cairo's categorical rejection as a threat to regional stability. Ethiopia considers the dam crucial for economic development and power provision, while Egypt is concerned about its Nile water supplies, on which it is almost entirely dependent. The UN Security Council is set to discuss the issue on Thursday.

site_title: Tokyo bourse chief optimistic on extending five-hour trading day
summary: Tokyo Stock Exchange President Hiromi Yamaji expressed optimism about extending the trading day to five hours, a first extension in over a decade. Yamaji stated that the current five-hour trading day is "short" compared to other major world exchanges, and a longer trading day could improve the market's appeal to foreign investors. A working group is exploring the feasibility of the extension, with opinions ranging from the impact on post-market processes to the potential benefits for liquidity.

site_title: Gold hovers near two-week high on softer dollar, Fed minutes awaited
summary: Gold prices hovered near a two-week high on Tuesday, influenced by a weaker dollar, with spot gold steady at $1,792.34 per ounce. The dollar's decline, following a weaker US payrolls report, made gold less expensive for holders of other currencies. Investors await minutes from the US Federal Reserve's June policy meeting for clarity on monetary policy. Meanwhile, other precious metals, such as silver, palladium, and platinum, also saw changes, with palladium and platinum rising.

site_title: Lot in Canadian village for sale with small catch: it's under water
summary: A 7.7-hectare lot in Shrewsbury, Ontario, is for sale for C$99,000, despite being entirely underwater. The lot, located in a protected bay on Lake Erie, has no address but is described as quiet and car-friendly. The real estate agent declined to comment on potential future uses for the property, which is currently underwater.

site_title: New Zealand business outlook rebounds in Q2 fuelling rate hike speculation
summary: New Zealand's business confidence improved sharply in Q2, with a net 7.0% of firms expecting general business conditions to improve. This suggests a robust economic recovery and sparks speculation of a sooner-than-expected rate hike. The New Zealand Institute of Economic Research's quarterly survey found 10% of businesses expected conditions to improve, with capacity utilisation at 94.9%. Labour shortages and supply chain disruptions are leading to rising inflation pressures, which may prompt interest rate increases from the Reserve Bank of New Zealand.

site_title: Chinese regulators suggested Didi delay its US IPO: WSJ
summary: Chinese regulators, including the Cyberspace Administration of China, suggested Didi Global Inc delay its US IPO and review its network security, weeks before the company went public. The regulators found the company had illegally collected personal user data, leading to a suspension of app downloads. Didi ultimately decided to proceed with the IPO, despite facing increasing investor pressure. The investigation raised concerns about the potential for sensitive data to fall into foreign hands.

site_title: Volkswagen sheds Bugatti, maker of over-the-top sports cars
summary: Volkswagen has sold its majority stake in Bugatti, a luxury sports car manufacturer, to a joint venture between Porsche and Croatian company Rimac. Rimac will own 55% of the venture, with Porsche holding 45%. Bugatti's Chiron model, priced at nearly $3 million, will continue to be produced under the new ownership. Mate Rimac, the 33-year-old founder of Rimac, will serve as CEO of the joint venture. Financial terms were not disclosed, marking the end of Volkswagen's control over the iconic brand.

site_title: Suning.com gets US$1.36b bailout from Chinese state fund, Alibaba
summary: Chinese billionaire Zhang Jindong's Suning empire has received a $1.36 billion bailout from a state-backed fund, with investors including Alibaba and other major Chinese companies, marking another step in Beijing's efforts to clean up heavily indebted conglomerates. The deal will see Zhang's stake in Suning.com cut to 17.62%, while Alibaba will become the largest shareholder with a 19.99% stake. The bailout aims to improve corporate governance and support Suning's stable growth, following a series of financial struggles and debt repayments.

images.alt_text: Chinese billionaire Zhang Jindong has received a US$1.36 billion state-backed bailout of the troubled retail arm of his Suning empire, marking another step in Beijing's efforts to clean up its heavily indebted conglomerates.

site_title: Philippine inflation eases to six-month low in June
summary: Philippine inflation dropped to 4.1% in June, its lowest level in six months, easing pressure on the central bank to maintain an accommodative monetary policy. This is below the median forecast of 4.3% and near the central bank's projected range of 3.9-4.7%. Core inflation, excluding food and fuel prices, was 3.0%. Despite this, risks to inflation remain "broadly balanced" due to higher commodity prices and a global recovery, according to BSP Governor Benjamin Diokno. The central bank will review its monetary policy settings on August 12.

site_title: Japan's May household spending growth slows from previous month
summary: Japan's household spending grew 11.6% year-over-year in May, slowing from a 13.0% rise in April, due to a new wave of Covid-19 infections affecting consumer confidence. The month-on-month figures showed a 2.1% contraction, beating forecasts. Despite a surge in overtime pay, analysts fear Japan's economy may fall back into recession in the second quarter, citing a hit to consumer and business confidence. This contrasts with the International Monetary Fund's forecast of a 7.0% US economic growth this year, the fastest pace in a generation.

site_title: French champagne industry group fumes over new Russian law
summary: A new Russian law requires foreign producers of sparkling wine to add "sparkling wine" to the back of their champagne bottles, sparking criticism from the French champagne industry group. The group, which represents French champagne producers, has called for halting exports to Russia and warned that the name "champagne" has legal protection in 120 countries. The move comes after Russian President Vladimir Putin signed the law on Friday, which also allows Russian producers to use the term "shampanskoye" without the "sparkling wine" designation.

site_title: Rex to invest up to US$4m in commercial drone company
summary: REX International has entered into a subscription agreement to invest up to US$4 million in commercial drone company Xer Technologies, with US$1 million for a 40% stake and up to US$3 million conditional on milestones. The investment aims to diversify the group's business, focusing on sustainable energy production and materials. Xer Technologies plans to launch commercially available heavy-duty drones in the fourth quarter of 2021, targeting clients in infrastructure inspection, search-and-rescue, and public safety. The investment is part of the group's efforts to tap the global commercial drone market, valued at US$501.4 billion by 2028.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust terminates sale and purchase agreement with two ARA units
summary: DASIN Retail Trust's trustee-manager has terminated a proposed sale and purchase agreement with two ARA Asset Management subsidiaries. The agreement, made in April, involved the subsidiaries buying a half-stake in the trustee-manager and 5% of the trust's total units. The termination was announced by chairman Zhang Zhencheng and controlling shareholder Aqua Wealth Holdings, citing unspecified reasons. The decision affects the proposed sale and purchase agreement, but no further details on the outcome are provided.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain ahead of central bank meeting
summary: Australian shares rose 0.29% to 7,336.2 points ahead of the Reserve Bank of Australia's meeting, where a record-low cash rate is expected to boost employment and inflation. Energy and mining stocks led the gains, while Japan's Nikkei and S&P 500 E-minis futures also increased.

site_title: England set to lift virus restrictions despite soaring cases
summary: The UK government, led by Prime Minister Boris Johnson, plans to lift most of England's coronavirus restrictions, including face masks and social distancing, on July 19, despite soaring cases of the highly contagious Delta variant. Vaccination rates are high, with 86% of adults having received their first dose and 63% their second. However, scientists are concerned that hospitals and medics could be stretched anew if the variant runs amok or new strains emerge. The decision has been met with both support and criticism from politicians and experts.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Rex, Dasin Retail Trust, Lian Beng, SIA, Nanofilm, Zico
summary: Rex International has entered a subscription agreement to invest up to US$4 million in Xer Technologies, part of its business diversification efforts. CEDU's trustee-manager terminated a sale and purchase agreement, while L03's offer for civil engineering and construction group has turned unconditional. SIA has appointed former PwC Singapore executive Yeoh Oon Jin as independent non-executive director. Nanofilm has appointed Gary Ho Hock Yong as executive director, replacing Lee Liang Huang. Zico has entered into a head of agreement for a proposed joint venture to apply for an Islamic digital bank licence.

site_title: Germany relaxes curbs on travellers from UK and India
summary: Germany's health agency has lifted a ban on most travellers from the UK, India, and three other countries affected by the Delta variant of Covid-19. The reclassification, effective Wednesday, allows non-resident travellers to enter as long as they follow quarantine and testing rules. The change comes after the countries were previously listed as "virus variant countries."

site_title: Opec+ in crisis as spectre of destructive infighting looms again
summary: Opec+ is in crisis as a dispute between Saudi Arabia and the UAE has blocked an oil-supply increase, sending crude prices above $77 a barrel for the first time in over two years. The breakdown in talks has raised concerns about the stability of the global economic recovery amid growing inflationary pressures. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) and its allies had agreed to boost output, but the disagreement over production cuts and personal spats between the two countries has led to the collapse of talks. The immediate consequence is a lack of oil supply increase, which is expected to send prices higher, and the split could potentially have the opposite effect, bringing lower prices in the medium term.

site_title: Oil prices accelerate rise as Opec+ calls off output talks
summary: Oil prices surged, with Brent reaching 2-1/2 year highs at $77.11 a barrel, driven by Opec+ nations' decision to call off talks on output levels. The Opec+ ministers abandoned the talks after clashing over a proposed eight-month extension to output curbs. US oil also rose, with prices up 1.5% at $76.27 a barrel. The move marks a setback for efforts to boost production and ease supply constraints.

site_title: Westpac to sell New Zealand life insurance arm for NZ$400m to Fidelity
summary: Westpac Banking Corp will sell its New Zealand life insurance arm to Fidelity Life for NZ$400 million, simplifying its business amid regulatory scrutiny. The move follows a series of asset offloads by the Australian bank to focus on core banking operations. Westpac CEO Peter King stated that the transaction is the latest step in streamlining its business.

site_title: Solar power is dirt-cheap and about to get even more powerful
summary: The solar industry is shifting its focus from reducing costs to increasing panel power, driven by plateaued savings in equipment manufacturing and rising raw material prices. New technologies, such as perovskite, bi-facial panels, and n-type polysilicon, promise further cost reductions and efficiency gains. These advancements aim to make solar power more competitive with fossil fuels, particularly for around-the-clock carbon-free power, and are expected to deliver more powerful systems, including 700-watt panels and larger wafers, by 2023 and 2028.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: BH Global Corp's cybersecurity unit secured S$4.2 million in orders in the first half of 2021. The subsidiary, Athena Dynamics, expects minimal impact on the group's performance for the current financial year. Dukang Distillers completed its restructuring, acquiring a kiwi fruit business and disposing of its liquor business, with revenue growth since 2017. Nanofilm Technologies appointed Gary Ho Hock Yong as executive director, overseeing commercial strategy and operations.

site_title: Rescuers struggle to locate dozens in landslide-hit Japan town
summary: Rescuers in Japan's Atami town are searching for at least 64 people buried under mud and wreckage after a devastating landslide hit the hot-spring resort on Saturday. Four people have been confirmed dead, and hundreds of rescue workers are working to find survivors. The landslide, caused by intense rain, destroyed 130 homes and other buildings, with many more injured or missing. Authorities are investigating whether a 2007 real estate project may have contributed to the disaster.

site_title: US forces shoot down armed drone over Iraq embassy
summary: US forces shot down an armed drone above their embassy in Baghdad, Iraq, on Monday night, following a rocket attack on a nearby base housing US soldiers. This is the 47th attack on US interests in Iraq this year, with six involving drones that can evade air defenses. The US has offered up to $3 million for information on drone attacks targeting its interests in Iraq. The incident highlights the ongoing threat posed by drones to US military operations in the country.

site_title: Euro 2020: Spain frustrated by 'strange' block on foreign fans at finale
summary: Spain coach Luis Enrique expressed frustration over a possible lack of Spanish fans attending the Euro 2020 semi-final due to strict quarantine rules. Despite a crowd of 60,000 being allowed at Wembley, only 2,500 VIPs were exempted. The Spanish Football Federation launched a social media campaign to encourage English fans to support Spain. Meanwhile, Italy, who have a 32-game unbeaten run, advanced to the last four. Spain's coach Luis Enrique downplayed the issue, saying it's not worth his energy and that the focus should be on the match.

site_title: Europe: Strong business activity lifts shares; London mid-caps at record high
summary: European shares reversed losses and rose 0.3% to near all-time peaks, driven by upbeat eurozone business activity and a 12% surge in Morrisons. The Stoxx 600 extended gains for a third straight session, with banks, material stocks, and travel shares leading gains. London mid-caps hit a record high, and British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is set to outline plans to end social and economic Covid-19 restrictions.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore stocks see a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with NTT DC Reit's public offer receiving 9.8 times oversubscription. Meanwhile, Creative Technology warns of potential revenue and operating loss, and London's Heathrow considers higher fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detains a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. MAS and PBOC to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. US stocks open lower amid Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada.

site_title: F9 reigns at North America box office as Boss Baby 2, Zola start strong
summary: Universal Pictures dominated the US box office over the Fourth of July holiday with F9, Boss Baby 2, and The Forever Purge, generating an estimated $72 million in ticket sales. F9 topped the box office with $24 million, while Boss Baby 2 and The Forever Purge trailed behind with $17.4 million and $12.8 million, respectively. The success marks a boost for the industry, which has seen slower business since the pandemic. The industry analyst predicts that Black Widow's release next week may also break box office records, with estimates suggesting it could earn up to $90 million domestically.

site_title: Japan's plan for digital yen to get clearer in late 2022
summary: Japan is set to gain clarity on its digital yen plan by late 2022, with lawmakers planning to outline key functions, including intermediary entities, by the end of next year. The move could test the Bank of Japan's argument that a digital yen won't crowd out private businesses. If designed to use commercial banks as intermediaries, it could shift business and data away from non-bank retailers and platform providers, potentially reshaping Japan's financial industry.

site_title: Up to 1,500 businesses affected by ransomware attack, US firm's CEO says
summary: A ransomware attack on US software firm Kaseya has affected between 800 and 1,500 businesses worldwide, with the majority being small businesses in Sweden and New Zealand. The hackers have demanded $70 million to restore the affected data, but Kaseya's CEO has refused to comment on negotiations. The attack has paralyzed businesses on all five continents, with some countries, including the US, assessing national risk and providing assistance to victims. The hackers claimed responsibility and indicated a willingness to temper their demands in private conversations with a cybersecurity expert.

site_title: Future of student hostel market in Singapore has no textbook answer
summary: The future of the student hostel market in Singapore is uncertain, with investors facing a lack of clarity on the attraction and profitability of this asset class. Despite over 68,000 foreign students in Singapore, fewer than 20 private properties are approved for use as student hostels, and current licensing rules and planning regulations add to the deterrent. Rental income from co-living spaces and HDB flats can be relatively stronger, and investor demand may not be as robust as in Western markets. The market is also influenced by factors such as lower demand from domestic students and a reliable public transport system.

site_title: Hackers demand US$70m to restore data held in ransomware attack
summary: Hackers suspected to be behind a global ransomware attack, believed to be from the Russia-linked REvil cybercrime gang, have demanded $70 million to restore data held hostage. The attack, which affected hundreds of companies worldwide, including schools, small public-sector bodies, and credit unions, was executed last Friday. The REvil gang has an affiliate structure, making it difficult to determine who is speaking on their behalf, but experts believe the demand came from the gang's core leadership. The White House has offered assistance to victims based on an assessment of national risk, while the hackers' actions are seen as an attempt to make the best of an awkward situation.

site_title: UK politics in flux as Parliamentary recess nears
summary: The UK is experiencing unprecedented political volatility ahead of the parliamentary recess, with the recent by-election result in Batley and Spen seeing Labour hold onto a seat despite being favourites to lose. The Conservatives had been on track to win their second by-election victory this parliament, but Labour's surprise win prevents this. This is part of a broader trend of shifting voter allegiances, with issues like Brexit and immigration becoming equally important as traditional right-left party affiliations. The erosion of the two-party system has led to increased unpredictability in UK politics, with the Liberal Democrats making headway in traditional Conservative seats and the SNP governing in Scotland.

site_title: Settlement agreed to release ship that blocked Suez Canal
summary: The owners and insurers of the Ever Given container ship have agreed to a settlement, allowing the vessel to sail through the Suez Canal on July 7. The Suez Canal Authority had held the ship since it became stuck in March, demanding $916 million in compensation. The settlement contract will be signed on July 6, with the ship's release to be marked by a ceremony. The canal will receive a tug boat as part of the settlement, and the owner will pay no damages, preserving the authority's rights and relationships.

site_title: China widens tech probe beyond Didi to Full Truck Alliance, Kanzhun
summary: China has expanded its crackdown on the technology industry, ordering Didi Global, Full Truck Alliance, and Kanzhun to halt new user registrations and removing their services from app stores. The move, which began after Didi's US$4.4 billion IPO, targets companies' handling of sensitive online data and cybersecurity. Shares of Chinese tech stocks in Hong Kong and SoftBank Group fell, and investors are concerned about the impact on the pipeline of overseas IPOs and potential economic decoupling between China and the US. The government's oversight of Didi's data security is seen as a threat to individual privacy and national security, with some calling for stricter regulations.

site_title: Macron, Merkel hold video talks with China's Xi
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Angela Merkel held video talks with Chinese President Xi Jinping on climate change and human rights, aiming to calibrate positions ahead of global meetings in the autumn. The two European leaders discussed ending the financing of coal-fired power stations. The talks also focused on calibrating positions ahead of the COP26 summit on global warming and the G-20 summit in Rome.

images.alt_text: French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Angela Merkel discussed issues ranging from climate change to human rights in video talks with Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping on Monday, France said.

site_title: Britain proposes tech company listing reforms to catch up with New York
summary: Britain's financial watchdog, the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA), has proposed reforms to make it easier for tech companies to list in London, aiming to strengthen the capital's competitiveness with New York and the EU post-Brexit. The proposed changes would allow dual class share structures for "innovative, often founder-led companies" for the first five years of a listing on the London Stock Exchange's premium segment. This move is intended to attract more tech companies and boost the UK's financial sector.

site_title: Investors may adjust China risk appetite after Didi crackdown
summary: China's crackdown on ride-hailing company Didi has heightened scrutiny of the country's tech sector, potentially prompting investors to reassess their risk appetite. The move follows a series of regulatory actions, including the cancellation of Ant Group's IPO and fines on Alibaba, Tencent, and Baidu. Industry players expect this increased oversight to lead to a higher risk assessment for Chinese tech investments, as regulators continue to strengthen their supervision of the tech sector.

site_title: Greenback dips as rate hike fears subside
summary: The US dollar declined against a basket of major currencies after investor fears about a faster end to monetary stimulus subsided following mixed US labor data. The data showed positive progress, but left room for the Federal Reserve to wait before tapering asset buying or raising interest rates. This eased concerns about a rate hike, contributing to the dollar's decline.

site_title: Asset allocation: mixing and matching investments to meet your goals
summary: Investors should diversify their assets to manage wealth sustainably. Putting all money in a single stock or sector can lead to significant losses due to unforeseen events. A diversified approach allows for risk management and potential long-term gains. Asia is expected to drive and benefit from dollar asset diversification, with retail investors contributing to massive ETF growth in the region.

site_title: Retail sales up 79.7% in May from 'circuit breaker' low base
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 79.7% in May from a low base, exceeding economists' expectations of a 65% rise, but still below pre-Covid levels. May's figures were driven by online sales, which accounted for 13.7% of takings, up from 11.2% in April. However, on a month-on-month basis, most retail industries saw declines due to Phase 2 (Heightened Alert) measures. Experts predict that the low base effects will wear off after June, with potential respite for the retail sector due to vaccination and border reopening.

site_title: Malaysian parliament to sit this month after Covid suspension
summary: Malaysia's parliament will sit for the first time since January 2021, following a nationwide state of emergency declared to combat the Covid-19 outbreak. The 5-day sitting, scheduled for July 26, will focus on recovery plans and changes to Parliament sessions during the pandemic. Analysts downplay the possibility of dramatic events, with some suggesting Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin now believes he commands a parliamentary majority. The emergency is set to end in August.

site_title: Marilyn Monroe, dead for 59 years, is a counterfeiter's best friend
summary: Marilyn Monroe's image remains a lucrative brand 59 years after her death, with counterfeiters continuing to sell goods bearing her name and likeness. Authentic Brands Group, which owns the rights to Monroe's name and image, has won a court order freezing the assets of dozens of virtual storefronts selling counterfeit goods. The company works with marketplaces like Amazon to shut down the sites, but the problem persists due to the sophistication of varied payment methods and the ease of global reach. The estimated value of counterfeit goods is projected to reach $1.9 trillion annually by next year.

site_title: Tokyo bourse chief wants better compliance after Toshiba scandal
summary: The Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE) has urged Toshiba Corp to make prompt and transparent disclosures about its widening governance scandal, including who was responsible. TSE chief Hiromi Yamaji also expressed support for activist investors, who can foster dialogue between shareholders and companies, and plans to tighten criteria for companies to stay on the main board, aiming to improve governance and profitability. This comes as the TSE seeks to attract more Asian companies to list on the exchange, citing its stable environment and attractive fundraising opportunities.

site_title: Chinese developers' woes weighing on Asia's junk bond market
summary: Chinese property developers' financial struggles are affecting the Asian high-yield debt market, with yields for speculative-grade dollar bonds rising 41 basis points in the second quarter. This is driven by a 150 basis-point increase in Chinese notes, amid the government's campaign to cut leverage and uncertainty surrounding major borrowers like China Evergrande Group. The divergence in borrowing costs between high-yield and investment-grade debt is expected to continue until investor sentiment towards the Chinese property industry improves.

site_title: China set to unleash funds abroad as opening of southbound bond link nears
summary: China is set to expand its capital outflows as it nears the launch of a southbound bond link, allowing Chinese investors to purchase offshore bonds. The move aims to balance the influx of foreign capital into the country's markets, which have seen a significant increase in popularity in recent years. China's government bonds have gained popularity due to attractive yields and low correlations to other markets, with global funds nearly tripling their holdings of Chinese sovereign debt to over 10%. The southbound link is expected to integrate Chinese investors into the international financial system in incremental steps, with domestic traders to gain access to different types of foreign-currency bonds.

site_title: Squawking about persistently higher inflation?
summary: Inflation in the US is expected to remain higher in the near-term, but it's unlikely to persistently elevate over time. Research suggests that core inflation, which is responsive to domestic factors, may not pass through into broader price changes. The gap between headline and core inflation has tended to converge in recent years, implying that future inflation is less likely to remain high. A composite measure of inflation expectations, which tracks the Fed's rhetoric and assessment on its longer-run inflation goal, remains well-anchored at 2%, indicating that inflation expectations remain well-anchored.

site_title: S$1.2b in extra Covid-19 support partly funded by reallocation under SINGA
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced that S$1.2 billion in extra Covid-19 support measures for the "Heightened Alert" period will be funded by reallocation of previously budgeted monies under the SINGA. This move does not require drawing on past reserves, alleviating concerns about funding.

site_title: Daimler, Volvo, Traton form US$593m truck-charging venture
summary: Daimler, Volvo, and Traton have formed a US$593 million joint venture to establish a high-performance charging network for battery electric trucks and coaches across Europe by 2027. The venture aims to meet EU regulations and will spend 500 million euros (approximately $799 million) on at least 1,700 charging points powered by green energy. The project is expected to support the transition to sustainable transportation and reduce carbon emissions in the European market.

site_title: Mining's impact on biodiversity - a rising risk?
summary: A growing number of investors are warning that biodiversity losses could surpass climate change as a major global risk. The World Economic Forum estimates that nearly 50% of global GDP is dependent on nature and its services, making it vulnerable to biodiversity loss. Mining operations, in particular, pose a significant threat to fragile environments and ecosystems, leading to increased operational roadblocks, stakeholder resistance, and investor concerns. As companies face scrutiny over their environmental impact, investors are urged to consider the potential risks and consequences of their investments.

site_title: Foodpanda claims top spot in food delivery for Asia-ex China
summary: Foodpanda, a subsidiary of Delivery Hero SE, has become the leading food-delivery app in Asia, excluding China. The company, based in Singapore, attributes its growth to its expansion into new markets and the rise of the food delivery industry due to the pandemic. Foodpanda plans to further expand into grocery delivery and quick-commerce services, citing exciting investment opportunities in countries like Japan and Southeast Asia. The company's head, Jakob Angele, notes that the food delivery industry is still young and full of growth potential.

site_title: As China's CCP turns 100, 'soft power' issues rise to the fore
summary: China's Communist Party (CCP) celebrated its 100th anniversary, but faces challenges, including a growing "soft power" deficit. The CCP's success has led to increased international perception of China as a rising superpower, but also negative views, with a majority of 14 countries surveyed having unfavorable opinions. China's handling of the pandemic, economic growth, and lack of international trust have contributed to this shift. The CCP must address its soft power deficit by engaging in international public diplomacy and fostering trust, or risk its growing influence in the 2020s.

site_title: Silicon Valley's Rocketship.vc unfazed by 'crazy' fintech valuations in South-east Asia
summary: Rocketship.vc, a Silicon Valley-based venture firm, remains bullish on South-east Asian fintech despite high valuations. The company, which made its first South-east Asian bet in February, is particularly interested in digital payments, investment tools, and crypto exchanges. Despite the challenges posed by travel restrictions, Rocketship.vc's partner Madhu Shalini Iyer sees opportunities for value creation in the region and is optimistic about the exit potential of startups. The firm is looking to "lean in and be bullish about the right players" in the market.

images.alt_text: As Ms Iyer, partner at Rocketship.vc sees it, there is still so much "value creation" in South-east Asian tech for investors to tap on.

site_title: China to encourage banks to lend more to small firms
summary: China's central bank plans to encourage banks to lend more to small firms by stabilizing funding costs and allowing for more bad loans. The goal is to make banks "dare, willing and able" to lend to small businesses. The central bank will also use re-lending and re-discount tools to guide banks to increase lending to small firms, while encouraging special bonds for financing. These measures aim to support China's small businesses, which have been hit harder by the Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: Final four showdown at frenetic Euro 2020
summary: The semi-finals of Euro 2020 kick off, pitting Spain against Italy and England against Denmark. Spain, led by coach Luis Enrique, is eager to end Italy's 32-match unbeaten run, while England seeks to capitalize on their home advantage against a resurgent Denmark. Spain has overcome several setbacks, including the absence of captain Sergio Ramos, but has shown resilience with key players like goalkeeper Unai Simon and winger Pablo Sarabia contributing to their success. Denmark, inspired by Christian Eriksen's return from a cardiac arrest, has achieved a remarkable run, beating the Czech Republic and Finland to reach the semi-finals.

site_title: HSBC grows SME segment; incubates high-growth startups
summary: HSBC is expanding its small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) segment, adding headcount to support growing businesses, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. The bank has seen 15% customer growth and 83% increase in client assets over the past two years, with a 70% increase in SME relationship managers. HSBC aims to incubate high-growth startups, recognizing that many smaller businesses have non-traditional business models. The bank is focusing on digitalization and sustainability, launching a global wallet and an SME green loan, to support its growth ambitions in Singapore.

site_title: Offer for Lian Beng turns unconditional
summary: Lian Beng's offer for acquisition has turned unconditional after securing over 50% of issued shares. Ong Sek Chong & Sons, controlled by the Ong family, is making a cash offer of 50 Singapore cents per share. The acquisition is now set to close at 5:30 pm on July 26, following the announcement.

site_title: Sea Ltd expected to lease majority of office space in Rochester Commons
summary: Sea Ltd, the parent company of Shopee and Garena, is expected to lease the majority of office space in CapitaLand's Rochester Commons development in Singapore. The 200,000 sq ft office space is likely to be used by Shopee and other Sea group businesses. Sea's revenue has more than tripled year on year, driven by its e-commerce and gaming segments, but the company still reported a net loss of US$422.1 million in Q1 2021. The lease is seen as a strategic move to expand Sea's physical footprint in Singapore as it prepares to launch a digital full-bank licence.

site_title: Opec+ crisis deepens as Saudi Arabia refuses to budge
summary: Saudi Arabia and the UAE, key Opec+ producers, are in a diplomatic standoff, forcing the cartel to halt talks and leaving the global economy uncertain about oil production levels for next month. The disagreement, which began on July 4, has led to oil prices surging above $75 a barrel. Saudi Arabia wants to extend the production agreement until 2022 for stability, while the UAE demands a short-term increase and better terms. The standoff risks unraveling the Opec+ alliance and could lead to a free-for-all, potentially crashing prices.

site_title: SME bridging loans extended till March 2022
summary: The Singapore government is extending its loan assistance programs for small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) until March 31, 2022, to provide a critical lifeline even as economic conditions improve. The Temporary Bridging Loan Programme and the Enhanced Enterprise Financing Scheme - Trade Loan will be extended beyond October 1, 2021. The government has already supported over S$22 billion worth of loans to over 25,000 enterprises since 2020, with 99% of recipients being SMEs.

site_title: EDBI invests in logistics provider Legend to power its regional growth and digitalisation
summary: EDBI's corporate investment arm has made a strategic investment in Legend Logistics Group, a Singapore-based integrated logistics provider. The investment aims to support Legend's transformation and regional growth plans, enabling the company to expand its services and accelerate market access in South-east Asia and South Asia. Legend plans to leverage EDBI's support to adopt digital technologies and improve operational efficiency, and to develop new shipping routes and vertically integrate its services. This investment is Legend's second round of institutional funding, following Daiwa ACA's investment in 2019.

images.alt_text: "We are looking to further entrench our position in the region by developing new shipping routes plying emerging and niche markets, deploying our marine assets and equipment, vertically integrating and bringing our services closer to our customers." - C K Than, Legend Logistics.

site_title: Opec+ deal fails, leaving oil market tighter as prices surge
summary: Opec+ failed to reach a deal, abandoning its meeting without an agreement, and leaving the oil market with tight supplies and rising prices. The cartel won't increase production for August, exacerbating global economic concerns. Crude prices surged 0.9% to $76.84 a barrel, the highest since 2018. The breakdown in talks damages Opec's self-image and raises concerns of a destructive price war, similar to last year's unprecedented price swings. The situation remains fluid, with the possibility of reactivating talks at any moment.

site_title: Better crisis response needed for future shocks
summary: A better crisis response is needed for future economic shocks, building on the successful 2020-21 support for individuals and businesses during the COVID-19 crisis. Unlike the 2008 crisis response, which prioritized financial sector help, policymakers should focus on helping those at the lower end of the income distribution. This requires significant investments in social infrastructure, including a central bank digital currency, improved access to healthcare, and better support for small businesses. The US Congress is moving towards this direction, and policymakers should prepare for unforeseeable shocks by investing in people's health and prosperity in good times.

site_title: Interest in S-Reits with China retail exposure set for shake-up
summary: China's retail spending rebounded 34% in the first quarter, with mall owners posting solid Q1 numbers. Sasseur Reit's sales rose 113% and distribution per unit (DPU) increased 32% year-over-year. However, investor interest in S-Reits with China retail exposure is lukewarm, with BHG Retail Reit and Dasin Retail Trust trading below their IPO prices. The competitive landscape is evolving, with online shopping growth in China and increasing competition from e-commerce platforms. Sasseur Reit's focus on luxury and high-end brands, combined with its outlet mall model, may be key to its success.

site_title: Heathrow Airport reopens Terminal 3 ahead of travel pickup
summary: Heathrow Airport has announced the reopening of Terminal 3 on July 15, ahead of an expected surge in traveler numbers. The terminal was closed in May 2020 due to the pandemic, but will now welcome Virgin Atlantic and Delta flights. The reopening marks a significant step in the airport's recovery, with all four terminals set to operate. The move comes as the UK government prepares to scrap quarantine requirements for fully vaccinated passengers to some countries.

site_title: Zico applies for Islamic digital bank licence in Malaysia
summary: Zico Holdings has submitted an application for an Islamic digital bank licence in Malaysia, in partnership with technology unicorn Green Packet and M24 Tawreeq. The application was made on June 30, and a response from Bank Negara Malaysia is expected in the second quarter of 2022. Zico cautioned that there is no certainty of approval, highlighting the competitive nature of the digital banking market in Malaysia.

site_title: Singapore will adjust corporate tax system in due time
summary: Singapore plans to adjust its corporate tax system in consultation with businesses once a global consensus is reached, but this change will impact tax revenues and competitiveness. The city-state will also focus on non-tax measures to maintain its strengths.

site_title: Development works at Pedra Branca, including land reclamation, to begin later this year: MND
summary: Singapore's Ministry of National Development (MND) plans to start development works at Pedra Branca, including land reclamation, by the end of this year. The works aim to enhance maritime safety and security, improve search and rescue capabilities, and provide additional logistics facilities. Land reclamation will be undertaken by the Housing and Development Board (HDB) within 0.5 nautical miles of Pedra Branca and in Singapore territorial waters. An environmental impact assessment has been conducted, and measures will be taken to minimize the impact on marine life and habitats, including coral relocation and habitat creation.

site_title: Development works at Pedra Branca to begin later this year: MND
summary: Development works at Pedra Branca, a Singaporean island, are set to begin by the end of this year. The project aims to enhance maritime safety and security, improve search and rescue capabilities, and provide additional logistics facilities. Land reclamation of about 7 hectares is expected to be completed, with measures in place to minimize the impact on marine life and birds, including coral relocation and habitat creation. The works will be carried out in accordance with Singapore's domestic laws and international law, with a detailed environmental monitoring and management plan in place.

site_title: BH Global cyber security unit wins S$4.2 million in orders; share price spikes 30.6%
summary: BH Global Corp's cyber security unit, Athena Dynamics, secured S$4.2 million in orders for advisory and special technologies to protect sensitive digital assets. The orders come from government agencies, multinational companies, and small to medium-sized enterprises. Despite the orders, BH Global's performance for the current financial year is not expected to be significantly impacted. The company's share price surged 30.6% to S$0.32 after the announcement.

site_title: Russian food retailer apologises for ad that included lesbians
summary: A Russian high-end food retailer, Vkusvill, has apologized for an ad featuring a family with two female partners, in which a mother and her adult daughter both have female partners. The ad, initially defended by the company, was deleted from its website and issued an apology after threats of a boycott. The move was met with criticism from both gay rights campaigners and opponents, with some accusing the company of being hypocritical and others calling the decision to take down the ad "cowardly."

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.99 points to 1,532.36. The trading volume was 6.502 billion lots worth RM3.590 billion. Gainers narrowly outnumbered losers 526 to 503.

site_title: New cluster linked to Malaysian man; more cases added to CGH, Henderson Crescent
summary: A new Covid-19 cluster was declared in Singapore on July 5, linked to a 36-year-old Malaysian man who works as a driver. The cluster has added 13 new cases, bringing the total to 62,630 cases. The cases are distributed among the 105 Henderson Crescent and Changi General Hospital clusters, with one case linked to the 105 Henderson Crescent cluster and two linked to the Changi General Hospital cluster. The number of locally transmitted cases has decreased, with six cases reported, and 24 clusters are currently active.

site_title: Pope in good condition, alert after surgery to remove part of colon
summary: Pope Francis is in good condition and alert after undergoing a three-hour surgery to remove part of his colon at Rome's Gemelli hospital. The 84-year-old pope is expected to stay in the hospital for seven days, barring complications, following a left hemicolectomy procedure for symptomatic diverticular stenosis of the colon. This is the first time the Vatican has disclosed the specific nature of the surgery, and it is unclear if Francis will leave the hospital in time to make his Sunday blessing as usual.

site_title: ESG as a new value creator - welcome to the brave new world
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the importance of Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) considerations for corporations and financial institutions. With the world flush with funds, economists hope for a rapid economic rebound, but ESG has become a critical aspect of creating value. Regulators globally, including in India, Singapore, and the European Union, have introduced frameworks and directives to promote ESG reporting and sustainability. The EU is a leader in ESG, with the Non-Financial Reporting Directive and Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation, while India and Singapore have also implemented their own ESG reporting requirements. Effective governance is crucial to ensure ESG priorities are measured and adhered to, with boards and independent directors playing key roles in course-correcting when needed.

site_title: Nanofilm Technologies International appoints executive director
summary: Nanofilm Technologies International has appointed Gary Ho Hock Yong as its new executive director and member of the board risk committee. He replaces Lee Liang Huang and will oversee commercial strategy and development. Ho, 49, holds a master's in business administration from the University of Roehampton and currently serves as the company's deputy CEO and chief commercial officer. His appointment follows a 0.36% decline in Nanofilm shares on Monday.

site_title: EU biofuels goals seen as cause of deforested area as big as Netherlands
summary: The European Union's biofuel goals have led to the deforestation of an area roughly the size of the Netherlands, mainly in South-east Asia and South America, since 2011. The clearing of 4 million hectares of forests has resulted in the loss of 10% of orangutan habitat and increased planet-warming carbon dioxide emissions. EU demand for biodiesel has driven the cultivation of 1.1 million hectares of palm oil and 2.9 million hectares of soya beans, threatening to displace deforestation from South-east Asia to South America.

site_title: Vaccinate or repent, Russian church says amid hundreds of daily Covid-19 deaths
summary: Russia's Orthodox Church has urged people to vaccinate against Covid-19, calling those refusing "sinners" who will have to atone for the rest of their lives. The church's warning comes as Russia reported 24,353 new Covid-19 cases and 654 deaths in the past 24 hours, pushing the national death toll to 138,579. The church's head, Metropolitan Hilarion, emphasized the importance of considering others when making decisions, stating that the sin is thinking of oneself but not of another person.

site_title: Retired executive chairman of PwC Singapore Yeoh Oon Jin to join SIA board
summary: Singapore Airlines' board of directors will welcome a new member on August 1, as Yeoh Oon Jin, the 60-year-old former executive chairman of PwC Singapore, joins as an independent non-executive director and audit committee member. Yeoh brings over 30 years of experience in auditing to the role, having previously held positions at various regulatory bodies and industry organizations. The appointment comes after SIA shares closed 0.40% higher on Monday, following the announcement.

site_title: 16-year-old suffers cardiac arrest six days after first Covid-19 jab
summary: A 16-year-old Singaporean boy collapsed and is in critical condition six days after receiving his first dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine. The teen had received his first dose on June 27 and was observed to be well after the vaccination. He experienced cardiac arrest after a weightlifting session on July 3, and is currently receiving treatment at the National University Hospital. An investigation is underway to determine if the incident is linked to the vaccine, and the Ministry of Health has recommended that people avoid strenuous physical activity after receiving the vaccine.

site_title: Opec+ shows no sign of healing rift hours before talks restart
summary: Opec+ talks resumed on Monday, but a deal remains uncertain as Saudi Arabia and the UAE continue to disagree on oil-output terms. The UAE wants to extend its quota limits to the end of 2022, but Saudi Arabia sees this as unfair and believes the UAE is cherry-picking its new output target. The disagreement has led to a rift within the Opec+ alliance, with Saudi Arabia painting the UAE as the sole obstacle to an output boost. A failure to reach a deal could leave existing output limits in place, potentially sending crude prices sharply higher, or lead to a production free-for-all and a repeat of last year's Saudi-Russia price war.

site_title: Six new Covid-19 community cases in Singapore, including two unlinked
summary: Singapore reported 13 new Covid-19 cases, with six locally transmitted, including two unlinked cases. The total cases now stand at 62,630, with 36 deaths from Covid-19 complications. The cases are mostly linked to existing cases, and the government will provide more details on Monday night.

site_title: Temasek's Vertex weighs Singapore's first SPAC listing
summary: Temasek's Vertex Holdings, a venture capital firm, is planning to list a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) in Singapore, potentially making it the country's first such deal. The move aims to raise funds for dealmaking and could revive investor interest in Singapore's stock market. Vertex operates six funds with assets over S$5 billion and has invested in notable companies such as Grab Holdings and Binance Holdings. The SPAC listing is subject to Singapore exchange guidelines, which include a minimum market capitalization threshold of S$300 million.

site_title: Covid-19 could look more like flu with vaccines, improved treatments: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore Finance Minister Lawrence Wong suggests COVID-19 could resemble the flu with improved vaccines and treatments. He notes the virus is unlikely to disappear soon. Wong is preparing a roadmap for Singapore to coexist with COVID-19 normally. This comes as countries that have rapidly vaccinated show promising signs.

site_title: SIA's minority investors have a chance to ride air travel recovery under Temasek's wing
summary: Singapore Airlines' minority investors may benefit from the airline's air travel recovery under Temasek's support, as the state investor has spent over S$12 billion underwriting the airline's rights issues. This is more than SIA's market value at the time of its cash calls last year. While some question whether Temasek's involvement would have been better for minority shareholders if the airline were taken private, the current recovery may provide an opportunity for investors to benefit from the airline's turnaround.

site_title: AEM-acquired CEI to delist on July 6
summary: AEM Holdings acquired CEI, a contract manufacturer, in January for S$1.15 per share. After completing the acquisition of dissenting shareholders' stakes on July 5, CEI announced its delisting from the Singapore Exchange on July 6. AEM plans to continue developing the business without major changes. The acquisition was part of AEM's S$99.7 million offer. AEM shares rose 0.26% on the news.

site_title: Dukang renames as China Shenshan Orchard Holdings to reflect move from liquor to kiwi fruit
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED Dukang Distillers has completed its restructuring by acquiring a kiwi fruit business and disposing of its liquor business, renaming itself China Shenshan Orchard Holdings. The company expects a turnaround with a steady revenue stream and sustained profitability, driven by growing kiwi fruit revenue since 2017. China Shenshan will focus on planting, cultivating, and selling kiwi in China, with a total land area of 6.5 million square meters.
