Government policies supporting kiwi cultivation bode well for the industry, and the company expects full exemption of enterprise income tax on its kiwi business profits.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore to provide S$1.2 billion in extra Covid-19 support, financed by reallocation of development expenditure under the Significant Infrastructure Government Loan Act (SINGA). The government-assisted bridging loans for SMEs will be extended until March 31, 2022. The estimated budget deficit remains unchanged at S$11 billion. Retail sales in May rose 79.7% year-on-year, exceeding economists' expectations. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 0.39% to end at 3,141.02, starting the week in the black.

site_title: Growth in China's June services hits 14-month low
summary: China's June services sector growth hit a 14-month low, with a Caixin/Markit services Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) of 50.3, down from 55.1 in May. The slowdown is attributed to a resurgence of Covid-19 in southern China, which has weighed on consumer and business activity. The private survey also showed a marked decrease in new business and staff cuts, with business outlook for the year ahead slipping to the lowest in nine months. Analysts expect a rebound in July, but the findings raise concerns about China's economic momentum.

site_title: SoftBank pays 178.5b yen for Yahoo Japan rights
summary: SoftBank's internet business Z Holdings agreed to pay 178.5 billion yen (S$2.16 billion) to acquire Verizon's Yahoo branding and technology rights in Japan. This move comes as Verizon offloads its media businesses to private equity firm Apollo Global. Yahoo remains a core part of SoftBank's domestic internet business, with a focus on services like PayPay and Line. The deal is set to close in the second half of this year, following a US$5 billion sale of Yahoo and AOL.

site_title: Singapore stocks begin the week in the black; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's benchmark index, the STI, rose 0.39% to close at 3,141.02, following a Wall Street rally after a US jobs report confirmed the economic recovery. Finance Minister Lawrence Wong's mention of easing Covid-19 restrictions also boosted investor sentiment. The best performer was BUOU, gaining 3.5%, while D01 slumped 0.94%. Retail sales in Singapore rebounded 79.7% year-on-year in May, with economists predicting continued growth despite Covid-19 concerns.

site_title: ​​​​​​​BT Money Hacks: How to start a crypto or blockchain-based business (Ep 98)
summary: A recent episode of BT Money Hacks podcast discusses starting a crypto or blockchain-based business. Co-founder of Tokocrypto, Pang Xue Kai, shares his insights on key challenges when starting a cryptocurrency exchange, such as compliance and legitimacy. He also emphasizes the importance of understanding local markets and relating to the community. The episode provides advice for listeners looking to start a crypto exchange or business, with a focus on emerging markets. The podcast aims to educate listeners on the foundational technology of crypto and the factors needed to succeed in this industry.

site_title: Malaysia Parliament to sit for five days starting July 26: PM's office
summary: Malaysia's Parliament will sit for five days starting July 26, according to the Prime Minister's office. The session aims to present a national recovery plan to lawmakers and amend necessary laws for hybrid meetings. This move follows a period of parliamentary recess.

images.alt_text: The Malaysian government has agreed to advise the country's king that Parliament will resume for five days from July 26 to Aug 2, the office of Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin said on Monday.

site_title: Dining-in group size limit expected to increase to five from July 12
summary: Singapore's government plans to increase the maximum group size for dining in at food and beverage (F&B) outlets to five people from July 12, following a two-week easing of restrictions. This comes after the government eased rules to allow dining in groups of two and gatherings of up to five people. The decision aims to curb the spread of Covid-19, with Finance Minister Lawrence Wong stating that measures have been "calibrated based on the severity of the outbreaks" and are not severe enough to warrant a full economic lockdown.

site_title: UAE business conditions improve at slower pace; employment rises
summary: Business conditions in the UAE improved at a slower pace in June, with non-oil business activity inching down to the lowest in four months. Employment rose for the first time since January, at the quickest pace in over two years. Despite this, input prices increased due to raw material shortages, and firms raised charges for the second time in about three years. The outlook for future activity improved for a seventh straight month, but demand growth slowed.

site_title: EDBI invests in logistics provider Legend to power its regional growth and digitalisation
summary: EDBI's corporate investment arm has made a strategic investment in Legend Logistics Group, a Singapore-based integrated logistics provider, to support its regional growth and digitalisation plans. Legend, which has a presence in Asia and Europe, aims to expand its services and accelerate market access in South-east Asia and South Asia. The investment will enable Legend to adopt digital technologies and improve operational efficiency, cost effectiveness, and connectivity. This move is seen as a response to the growing importance of South-east Asia as a global production base and demand driver.

site_title: Metropolitan YMCA Residences at Stevens Road up for sale with S$57m guide price
summary: The Metropolitan YMCA Residences at 58 Stevens Road in Singapore is up for sale with a guide price of S$57 million. The 21,480 sq ft site can be developed into a five-storey residential project, with a gross plot ratio of 1.4. The property features 27 serviced apartments, a swimming pool, and a 24-lot basement carpark. The sale is a rare opportunity in the Singapore market, with the property's price per square foot at S$1,942.

site_title: Singapore will adjust its corporate tax system in time, but in consultation with the industry
summary: Singapore will adjust its corporate tax system in consultation with the industry, guided by three key principles: adhering to international standards, safeguarding sovereign rights, and minimizing compliance burden. The adjustment will be made in response to the Group of Seven's global minimum tax rate agreement, which may limit the effectiveness of Singapore's tax incentives. The impact of the tax changes will depend on the design of the specific rules, and Singapore will only be able to determine the impact once an international consensus is reached.

site_title: Emergence of new Covid-19 variants likely to outpace containment of virus: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong warns that the world may not reach a point where enough people are immune to stop the spread of the Covid-19 virus before new variants emerge. The highly-contagious Delta variant, estimated to be 60% more transmissible than the Alpha variant, is spreading globally, and new strains may be more transmissible, vaccine-resistant, and evade diagnostic tests. However, mRNA vaccines offer excellent protection against severe illness, and Singapore is better equipped to deal with the pandemic due to robust public health defenses and vaccination efforts.

site_title: Estimated budget deficit unchanged at S$11b despite changes in revenue, expenditure
summary: Singapore's estimated budget deficit remains unchanged at S$11 billion (2.2% of GDP) despite changes in revenue and expenditure. Operating revenue is now projected at S$0.1 billion less, while total expenditure is expected to be S$0.5 billion less due to construction delays. However, special transfers are expected to be S$1 billion higher, resulting in a slightly larger deficit. The overall fiscal deficit remains the same as previously announced, S$11 billion.

site_title: Facebook, Google, Twitter could quit Hong Kong over proposed data laws: WSJ
summary: US tech giants Facebook, Google, and Twitter have warned the Hong Kong government that they may quit offering their services if proposed data-protection laws are implemented, citing concerns over liability for malicious information sharing. The laws aim to combat "doxing," a practice of revealing personal information online without permission. The companies are concerned that the rules could put their staff at risk of criminal investigations. A letter from the Asia Internet Coalition, which represents the firms, states that refusing to invest and offer services in Hong Kong is the only way to avoid sanctions.

images.alt_text: US tech giants Facebook, Alphabet's Google and Twitter have privately warned the Hong Kong government that they could stop offering their services in the city if authorities proceed with planned changes to data-protection laws, the Wall Street Journal reported on Monday, citing a letter.

site_title: Government-assisted bridging loans for SMEs to be extended until March 31, 2022
summary: The Singapore government is extending loan assistance programs for small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) until March 31, 2022. The Temporary Bridging Loan Programme and the Enhanced Enterprise Financing Scheme - Trade Loan will be extended beyond October 1. Finance Minister Lawrence Wong stated that access to credit remains crucial for many SMEs despite improved economic conditions. This move aims to provide continued support to the SME sector during the heightened alert period.

site_title: Government to review its crisis response after Covid situation stablises: Teo Chee Hean
summary: Singapore's government will conduct an After Action Review (AAR) on its response to the Covid-19 crisis once the situation stabilizes. Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean announced this in Parliament, stating the AAR will help learn valuable lessons to improve future pandemic responses. A COI was deemed more suitable for singular events, while the AAR is better suited for ongoing situations like Covid-19. The review's purpose is to enhance the government's response for future pandemics, but resources are currently committed to battling the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Extra Covid-19 support to cost S$1.2b, financed partly by reallocation under SINGA
summary: Singapore plans to spend S$1.2 billion on additional Covid-19 support measures during the Heightened Alert period. The cost is financed partly by reallocation of monies previously budgeted, with half coming from capitalisation of development expenditure under the Significant Infrastructure Government Loan Act (SINGA) and the rest from underutilisation of development expenditure. The initial estimated cost was S$800 million, but support was extended due to the prolonged period of the alert.

site_title: Small-cap S-Reits to benefit from global real estate index inclusion: Citi
summary: Citi Research has named Lendlease Global Commercial Reit and Ascendas India Trust as top small-cap Singapore real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) following FTSE Russell's ground rule update on the FTSE EPRA Nareit Global Real Estate Index Series. The updates lower investable market cap thresholds for additions and deletions, potentially considering nine small-cap S-Reits for index inclusion. Inclusion on the index could improve liquidity, investor visibility, and lower costs, with Citi setting target prices of S$0.93 for Lendlease Reit and S$1.82 for a-iTrust.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher after US jobs report
summary: South Korean stocks ended higher on Monday after a US jobs report showed the economic recovery remained intact, despite a slight uptick in the unemployment rate. The Kospi closed up 11.43 points or 0.35% at 3,293.21. The won strengthened, while the benchmark bond yield fell. Foreigners bought 700 million won worth of shares. Analysts attributed the gains to the US jobs report signaling a labor market recovery, but not strong enough to prompt a change in the Federal Reserve's monetary policy stance.

site_title: Europe: Virus worries keep shares below record highs
summary: European shares fell below record highs on Monday due to concerns over the Delta variant's impact on the economy. The Stoxx 600 index declined 0.11% amid fears of new travel restrictions and a potential fourth wave of the pandemic in France. However, mining stocks rose 1.4% and shares of Morrisons jumped 11.6% after a possible takeover offer from Apollo Global Management. The focus shifts to June's business activity data due at 8am GMT, which may influence the market's trajectory.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close with sharp losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 0.59% on Monday, led by tech firms hit by Beijing's crackdown on Didi Chuxing and US-listed Chinese companies, raising concerns about sector moves. The Hang Seng Index fell to 28,143.50, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.44%. The crackdown has sparked worries about further regulatory actions against the sector, causing losses among tech firms.

site_title: Back at the barre, lessons learned
summary: The Royal Ballet School, a 95-year-old institution, adapted to the challenges of the COVID-19 pandemic by transitioning to virtual classes, which initially proved difficult due to time differences and technical issues. However, by the second and third lockdowns, teachers and students had improved their digital settings, allowing for live accompaniment and makeshift dance studios. The school's hybrid training has paid off, with 88 students set to perform at the Royal Opera House's annual summer performance, marking the first time in two years that a sold-out audience will witness their talents.

site_title: Apollo Global joins battle for Britain's Morrisons
summary: US private equity firm Apollo Global Management has joined the bidding war for Britain's fourth-largest supermarket group Morrisons, with a possible offer in the preliminary stages. This comes after a recommended takeover led by SoftBank-owned Fortress Investment Group valued Morrisons at $8.7 billion, exceeding a $5.52 billion proposal from Clayton, Dubilier & Rice. The fate of Morrisons will be decided by its shareholders, with its three largest investors holding significant stakes. Analysts speculate that other private equity groups and Amazon could create a potential bidding war.

site_title: Hot stock: Singapore Myanmar Investco up 148.6% on crypto investments
summary: Singaporean investment company Singapore Myanmar Investco (Y45) surged 148.6% in Monday trading after announcing a pivot to technology-based software-as-a-service (SaaS) businesses and cryptocurrency investments. The company's shares reached an intraday peak of 17.6 cents amid heavy trading. The announcement came on June 30, following the company's decision to shift its focus.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei hits two-week low as virus, political concerns outweigh Wall Street boost
summary: Japanese shares slipped on Monday, with the Nikkei hitting a two-week low, as rising Covid-19 infections and concerns over Japan's upcoming general election weighed on the market. Despite a Wall Street rally after strong US jobs data, cyclical shares were hurt. The Nikkei's decline was also fueled by a disappointing showing by Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's Liberal Democratic Party in a local election.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB raises ST Engineering target price as aerospace sector recovers
summary: CGS-CIMB has raised its target price for ST Engineering to S$4.41 from S$4, citing the recovery of the aerospace sector as Airbus ramps up production and US domestic travel recovers. Analyst Lim Siew Khee attributes the increase to demand for airframe MRO services and ST Engineering's presence in the US. The company expects revenue to reach 86% of pre-pandemic levels in FY2021, driven by global operations in the US, Europe, and China.

site_title: Indonesia turns to telemedicine for Covid-19 as hospitals struggle
summary: Indonesia is providing free telemedicine services to patients with mild Covid-19 symptoms amid a record surge in cases and hospital bed occupancy at 75% nationwide. The health minister announced the move to reduce pressure on hospitals, which are struggling with oxygen shortages and limited production capacity. Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati has increased health spending to combat the pandemic, with hospital bed occupancy expected to remain high. The country is battling one of Asia's worst Covid-19 epidemics, fueled by the highly contagious Delta variant.

site_title: Rebound in global gas demand threatens international climate targets: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) warns that a rebound in global gas demand by 2024, driven by recovering economies, poses a threat to achieving net zero emissions by 2050. Gas demand is expected to rise 3.6% in 2021 and 1.7% annually from 2022-2024, surpassing the IEA's roadmap. The agency urges governments to implement strong policies to reduce fossil fuel use and recommends investors avoid funding new oil, gas, and coal projects.

site_title: Australia: Shares close flat as virus worries offset Sydney Airport's boost
summary: Australian stocks closed flat on Monday as concerns over rising Covid-19 cases in New South Wales offset gains from Sydney Airport's 34% surge after a proposed $22.26 billion buyout bid. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 7,315 points, down from an earlier high. The stock market was influenced by worries about the virus, despite a positive start to the session.

site_title: Halfway through 2021, the hot US stocks are old-fashioned
summary: US stocks are shifting away from tech companies, which dominated the market in 2020, and towards old-fashioned sectors such as oil drillers, metal miners, and financial institutions. The S&P 500 has risen 14.4% through the first half of 2021, led by energy and financial stocks, with companies like Marathon Oil and Nucor experiencing significant gains. Analysts attribute the shift to the economic reawakening, fueled by the recovery from the pandemic, and the resulting surge in commodity prices and consumer finances.

site_title: Glencore names new chairman to complete leadership overhaul
summary: Glencore has appointed Kalidas Madhavpeddi as its new chairman, completing a leadership overhaul at the company. Madhavpeddi, a mining veteran with over 40 years of experience, replaces Tony Hayward, who departed after a decade as chairman. The move comes amid challenges for Glencore, including probes into money laundering and corruption, as well as the future of its coal business. Gary Nagle, who replaced Ivan Glasenberg as CEO, joins the new leadership. Madhavpeddi's extensive experience working in the Democratic Republic of Congo and with China will guide the company's future.

site_title: Malaysia glove makers say virus curbs to hit global supplies
summary: Malaysia's rubber glove manufacturers, which produce 58% of the country's gloves, appealed to the government to allow their factories in Selangor to operate amid tightened movement curbs due to rising Covid cases. The curbs, which took effect on Saturday, are expected to disrupt global supplies of protective gear, with global customers expressing concern over production and delivery delays. The manufacturers, which supply 67% of global consumption, are seeking a meeting with the trade ministry to discuss the impact on their business.

site_title: Australians trapped in vaccine 'Hunger Games', says top official
summary: A top Australian health official, Brad Hazzard, compares getting vaccinated in the country to "The Hunger Games" due to a vaccine shortage during the growing Covid-19 outbreak. Desperate residents are making panicked efforts to secure vaccine appointments, with some turning up at mass vaccination centers multiple times. The shortage has led to a sense of urgency, with officials warning of a chaotic situation.

site_title: Brokers' take: KGI raises ISDN target price, expects stronger FY2021
summary: KGI Securities has raised its target price for ISDN Holdings to S$0.85 from S$0.60, maintaining its "outperform" recommendation due to strong FY2020 and Q1 FY2021 financials. The research house expects revenue growth from the group's hydropower business and side businesses, particularly in China, driven by Sino-US tensions and the growing trend in industrial automation. Full tariff revenue is expected to be recognized in FY2023 after all three plants are completed by end-FY2022.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.75% due to a decline in tech firms following China's cyber watchdog ordering ride-hailing service Didi to be removed from app stores. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also eased slightly.

site_title: Hackers demand US$70m to restore data held by companies hit in cyberattack
summary: Hackers behind a global ransomware attack, suspected to be the REvil cybercrime gang, demanded US$70 million to restore data held by companies affected by the attack. The REvil group, linked to Russia, made the demand on a dark web site and has not responded to a Reuters inquiry. Cybersecurity experts believe the hackers may have bitten off more than they can chew, as the attack's scope and complexity may be more than they anticipated. The attack, which affected hundreds of companies worldwide, began on Friday.

site_title: Fears grow for dozens in landslide-hit Japan town
summary: Rescue teams in Japan's Atami town are searching for dozens of missing people after a landslide destroyed 130 homes and buildings, killing three people. Authorities initially estimated 20 missing but later revised the number to around 113 out of 215 residents. The landslide occurred during Japan's rainy season, and the town is under a non-compulsory evacuation order for over 35,700 people. The Japanese government is verifying the number of missing people and urging rescue workers to continue their efforts to find survivors.

site_title: Asia: Most markets rise after healthy US jobs report
summary: Asian markets mostly rose on Monday following a US jobs report that reaffirmed the country's recovery was on track. The Labor Department report showed a significant increase in employment, with the unemployment rate ticking up slightly. This data provided a positive boost to investors, with most Asian markets extending the rally. However, tech firms in China, such as Didi and Tencent, fell after the Chinese government ordered Didi to be removed from app stores due to data collection regulations. Despite this, the overall market sentiment remains optimistic, with many expecting further gains this year.

site_title: Vitasoy shares plunge after Chinese call online for boycott
summary: Vitasoy shares plummeted 14.6% after a worker in Hong Kong sent a condolence memo to the family of a colleague who stabbed a police officer, sparking online calls for a boycott in China. The company, which generates two-thirds of its revenue from mainland China, has seen a flood of cancellations from mainland Chinese actors, including Gong Jun and Ren Jialun. Authorities have warned against mourning for the attacker, labeling it as supporting terrorism.

site_title: After Didi, China launches cybersecurity probe into more US-listed firms
summary: China's Cyberspace Administration (CAC) launched a cybersecurity probe into US-listed firms Zhipin.com, Huochebang, and Yunmanman, following a similar probe into Didi Global. The move aims to tighten regulations on data security. The probe comes as Chinese tech companies face increasing scrutiny amid their US listings. Full Truck Alliance, the result of a merger between Huochebang and Yunmanman, and Kanzhu, the owner of Zhipin.com, went public in the US stock market last month. The CAC's actions reflect China's growing concerns over data security and its increasing control over the tech sector.

site_title: Oil drops as lack of Opec+ unity hangs over market
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday, with Brent crude down 0.5% to $75.77 a barrel, after Opec+ failed to reach an agreement due to disagreements among major producers. The group had voted to increase production by 2 million barrels a day from August to December 2021, but the United Arab Emirates' objections prevented an agreement. Saudi Arabia's energy minister urged compromise and rationality to achieve unanimity, while energy companies in the US increased oil and natural gas rigs for a third week in a row.

site_title: EU biofuels goals seen behind deforested area as big as the Netherlands
summary: The European Union's efforts to boost biofuel use have led to the deforestation of an area roughly the size of the Netherlands, mainly in Southeast Asia and South America, since 2011. The report found that EU demand for biodiesel required the cultivation of 1.1 million hectares of palm in Southeast Asia and 2.9 million hectares of soybeans in South America. This deforestation threatens to displace palm oil from Southeast Asia to South America, where soy oil is now being used in European biodiesel, resulting in higher carbon dioxide emissions.

site_title: CBD Grade A offices' net demand turns positive, but vacancies rise again
summary: Singapore's Grade A office space in the central business district (CBD) saw a net demand of 68,000 square feet in the first half of 2021, a positive turn from the previous year. However, vacancy rates increased as net supply outpaced demand, remaining relatively weak. Cushman & Wakefield forecasts full-year net demand to be up to six times that of 2020, but still lagging behind supply.

site_title: Singapore retail sales up 79.7% in May from low base of 2020's 'circuit breaker'
summary: Singapore's retail sales surged 79.7% year-on-year in May, rebounding from the low base of 2020's "circuit breaker", exceeding economists' expectations. Online sales accounted for 13.7% of May's takings, up from 11.2% in April. Retail sales remain below pre-Covid levels, with supermarkets and hypermarkets experiencing a 12.1% decline. Experts expect retail sales to continue growing, with OCBC predicting an 11% full-year growth and UOB estimating a 10% growth.

site_title: Getting athletes to pandemic Olympics is logistics nightmare
summary: The Tokyo Olympics face a logistical nightmare as athletes from over 200 countries prepare to descend on the city amidst a global pandemic. Airlines have disrupted flight schedules, and international borders remain closed, making travel impossible without COVID-19 tests and vaccinations. Teams are finding alternative routes, including cargo flights and layovers in cities like Brisbane and Auckland, with some athletes facing over 8,000-mile journeys. Despite precautions, COVID-19 cases are still reported, and athletes are struggling to adapt to the challenges, including limited training time and disrupted qualifying events.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain as Sydney Airport soars on A$22.26b buyout bid
summary: Australian shares rose 0.38% to 7,336.4 points, driven by a 38% surge in Sydney Airport Holdings after receiving a A$22.26 billion takeover bid. Industrial stocks and gold stocks also advanced, with Newcrest Mining and Chalice Mining rising 0.8% and 10% respectively. Investors await the Reserve Bank of Australia meeting on Tuesday, which may discuss benchmark rates and monetary stimulus policy.

site_title: Payment performance of local firms falls slightly in Q2: SCCB
summary: Singapore's payment performance of local firms fell slightly in Q2, with prompt payments decreasing 1.7 percentage points to 40.8% and slow payments increasing 1.5 percentage points to 44.6%. The construction sector saw the highest proportion of slow payments, while retail and consumer services sectors experienced the highest increase in payment delays. CEO of SCCB Audrey Chia attributed the increase to cashflow woes in retail and consumer services subsectors affected by Covid-19 restrictions.

site_title: Australia's New South Wales warns next two days 'critical' as Covid-19 outbreak grows
summary: Australia's New South Wales (NSW) has warned that the next two days will be "critical" in determining whether a two-week lockdown in Sydney will need to be extended due to a growing Covid-19 outbreak. The state reported 35 locally acquired cases on Monday, with 28 in isolation and 7 in the community while infectious. NSW Premier Gladys Berejiklian expressed concern over the number of people still infectious in the community and the potential impact on the next few days. The lockdown, set to end on July 9, is under review.

site_title: Saudi Arabia pushes back on UAE opposition to Opec+ deal
summary: Saudi Arabia's energy minister, Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman, pushed back against UAE opposition to a proposed Opec+ deal, calling for "compromise and rationality" to secure agreement. The UAE had objected to extending the supply pact, citing concerns over baseline production references. The standoff could delay plans to pump more oil, potentially delaying price reductions. Saudi Arabia emphasized the need for a balance between producer and consumer countries to maintain market stability.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.59 points, or 0.04%, to 1,532.76. Trading volume was 225.15 million lots worth RM94.85 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 201 to 117.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ascendas India Trust, UOB, LMIRT, Creative, NutryFarm
summary: Several companies saw notable developments on Monday. Ascendas India Trust's trustee-manager announced a 12 billion rupee investment for a data centre campus in India. UOB restored access to its internet banking services after a disruption. LMIRT closed malls and retail spaces in Java and Bali due to rising Covid-19 cases. Creative expects to report an operating loss for FY2021, while NutryFarm's shares fell after CEO Cheng Meng expressed interest in China's durian market.

site_title: Temasek and HPS Investment sell Cypress Creek Renewables to Sweden's EQT
summary: Stockholm-based private equity firm EQT is acquiring Cypress Creek Renewables of California from Temasek and HPS Investment Partners for an undisclosed price. Cypress Creek, with 300 employees, offers services across utility-scale and distributed solar and storage across 25 US states, having commercialized 11 gigawatts since its inception in 2014. The acquisition is EQT's first in the US renewable energy sector, via its EQT Infrastructure V fund. The deal is expected to close in the second half of 2021, subject to customary conditions and approvals.

site_title: Philippine plane crash kills 47, injures 49; probe ordered
summary: A Philippine Air Force Lockheed C-130 transport aircraft crashed at Jolo airport in southern Sulu province, killing 47 people and injuring 49. All 96 passengers have been accounted for, with three civilians on the ground killed and four injured. An investigation has been ordered, with no signs of an attack. The military has clashed with the militant Abu Sayyaf group in the area, but none have been linked to the incident.

site_title: Japan's service sector activity contracts for 17th month as pick-up stalls
summary: Japan's services sector activity shrank for the 17th consecutive month in June, as the coronavirus dampened demand domestically and internationally. The au Jibun Bank Japan Services Purchasing Managers'Index (PMI) fell to 48.0, below the 50.0 threshold that separates contraction from expansion. Despite a slower contraction in new business, outstanding business saw a slightly faster decline, indicating ongoing pain from the health crisis. The country's economic recovery struggles to pick up, with overall private-sector activity in contraction for a second month.

site_title: Queen to honour UK health workers for Covid service
summary: Queen Elizabeth II will award the UK's National Health Service (NHS) the country's highest civilian honour, the George Cross, in recognition of its service during the pandemic. The award comes amid criticism of pay and working conditions for NHS staff, who have been pushed to breaking point. The Queen praised NHS staff for their "courage, compassion and dedication" and Prime Minister Boris Johnson echoed her sentiments, saying the NHS is essential to Britain's well-being. The award is seen as a long-overdue recognition of the NHS's efforts during the pandemic.

site_title: Ascendas India Trust to invest 12b rupees in first phase of India data centre campus
summary: Ascendas India Trust is investing 12 billion rupees (S$216.6 million) in its first phase of a data centre campus in Navi Mumbai, India. The campus will be one of the largest in Airoli, hosting global technology giants and large enterprise clients. The site, a 6.6-acre greenfield, is expected to be developed into a 575,000 sq ft campus with 90 megawatts of power, with the first phase set to be completed by Q2 2024. The campus will adopt sustainable design principles and feature intelligent energy management systems.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Monday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.1% or 2.83 points to 3,131.78. Gainers outnumbered losers 93 to 40, with Sembcorp Marine being the most active counter by volume. The gains come ahead of upcoming GDP data and amid a global stocks rally, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records.

site_title: Protecting Asia Pacific's CCTV surveillance systems
summary: A recent cyberattack on Verkada, a global IoT security camera provider, exposed the vulnerability of 150,000 surveillance cameras in Asia, revealing sensitive footage from hospitals, banks, and other facilities. As one billion surveillance cameras are expected this year, businesses and governments must prioritize cybersecurity to prevent mass data disclosures. Existing solutions, such as real-time detection tools, behavior-based anomaly detection, and the zero-trust network model, can help mitigate similar incidents. With increasing cybersecurity spending in Asia Pacific, organizations must harness these tools to ensure safe surveillance for citizens.

images.alt_text: With one billion surveillance cameras expected to be watching over the world this year, businesses and governments need to ramp up safeguards to prevent mass, unwarranted public disclosures of sensitive data.

site_title: 'Call of duty': Indonesian bikers brave Covid-19 surge to escort ambulances
summary: Indonesian volunteer bikers, led by Sebastian Dwiyantoro, are escorting ambulances through heavy traffic in Jakarta's Depok to transport Covid-19 patients to hospitals. The team makes up to 20 trips a day, increasing from 3-4 before the surge in cases. With Indonesia reporting over 20,000 new cases and 400 deaths daily, the bikers aim to help while avoiding infection. Their efforts are appreciated by ambulance drivers, who praise the bikers for breaking up traffic and ensuring timely transportation of patients.

images.alt_text: Indonesian volunteer biker Sebastian Dwiyantoro and his team have been particularly busy helping ambulances navigate heavy traffic in Jakarta's satellite city of Depok to get Covid-19 patients to hospital as infections soar in the country.

site_title: Gold eases off two-week high as US dollar firms
summary: Gold prices eased off a two-week high on Monday, falling 0.1% to US$1,785.41 per ounce, due to a slight uptick in the US dollar. Investors await US economic data for clues on the Federal Reserve's monetary policy plans. The dollar rose 0.1% against its rivals, making gold expensive for holders of other currencies. US companies hired the most workers in 10 months, raising wages and offering incentives, and Japan's services sector activity shrank for the 17th straight month.

site_title: Japan's digital yen plan to become clearer late 2022, says ruling party official
summary: Japan is expected to have more clarity on its digital yen plan by late 2022, according to a ruling party official. The Bank of Japan has launched a central bank digital currency experiment, and Hideki Murai, a Liberal Democratic Party panel head, said the BOJ will have a clearer view of what a digital yen would look like by the end of next year. This may lead to a turf war between traditional lenders and online platform operators, and could impact financial institutions and Japan's settlement system.

site_title: Ensuring a sustainable society
summary: Cities must adapt to become resilient to future shocks by incorporating human-centric urban planning, leveraging technology, and prioritizing sustainability. Experts emphasize the need for "smart cities" to balance technology with caution to avoid compromising privacy and systemic bias. Key strategies include investing in digital infrastructure, fostering community spirit, and partnering with the private sector to tackle funding gaps. Cities must also adopt a whole-of-society approach, addressing multiple threats and inequalities, and prioritize sustainability to achieve genuine city-wide resilience.

site_title: Australia's Crown Resorts set to report annual loss, sees 'challenging' fiscal 2022
summary: Australia's Crown Resorts expects to report a loss for the year ended June due to COVID-19 lockdowns and corporate costs. The company has faced scandals, including dealing with organized crime and disregarding staff safety in China. Crown's core earnings are expected to be between A$90 million to A$100 million, with net debt at A$900 million. The company is also facing offers from Star Entertainment, Blackstone Group, and Oaktree Capital, with a potential buyout worth around A$9 billion.

site_title: Job worries, poor mental health afflict pandemic-hit UK youth
summary: Young people in the UK are facing significant challenges with poor mental health and job worries, emerging from the pandemic crisis. Research by the Institute for Fiscal Studies and the Resolution Foundation warns that without policy interventions, they risk permanent damage to their prospects. The UK's lockdown restrictions disproportionately affected young people, and with government support programs ending, they are now at risk of long-term consequences unless policymakers prioritize helping them return to work.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Monday despite US gains
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, despite US gains, as investors sought new cues. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.48% to 28,646.22, while the Topix index fell 0.42% to 1,948.03. The US jobs report lifted Wall Street shares to record highs last week, but investors remained cautious ahead of new US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: After pressuring telecom firms, Myanmar's junta bans executives from leaving
summary: Myanmar's junta has issued a ban on senior executives of major telecommunications firms leaving the country without permission, following pressure to implement spyware technology to track calls, messages, and web traffic. The directive comes after the junta announced its aim to pass a cybersecurity bill requiring telecoms providers to provide data upon request. Telecom companies, including Telenor and Ooredoo, have been warned to implement the intercept technology, with some companies, like Telenor, considering a sale of their Myanmar unit due to the uncertain future of the telecom sector.

site_title: Pandemic drives sea freight prices to record high
summary: Container shipping prices have reached record highs, driven by the ongoing pandemic and supply chain disruptions. The Freightos Baltic Index has more than tripled to nearly US$7,000 for a trip from China to the US West Coast, with prices exceeding US$10,000 for a trip to Europe. Industry experts attribute the surge to a massive shortage of empty containers and overcapacity, compounded by the pandemic's impact on demand. Shipowners are profiting, investing in new fleets and renewable energy programs, and experts warn that prices may remain high due to the need to transport perishable goods.

site_title: Plastic makers reel on soaring oil costs and rising competition
summary: Producers of plastics in Asia are facing lower margins due to rising oil costs and increased competition. Higher crude prices and naphtha costs have led to lower profits from producing ethylene, a key petrochemical used in plastics. Smaller factories are considering reducing production or cutting runs as a result. New plants in Asia, such as those in South Korea and China, are adding to the supply of plastics, further increasing competition and pressure on prices. The market is expected to be tested in the third quarter, with some plants potentially forced to cut production due to high costs.

site_title: What will your finances look like in 10, 20, 30 years? There are apps for that
summary: Financial planning apps have emerged as a way to offer personalized and interactive advice to individuals in Singapore. Many banks, fintechs, and other financial institutions have launched digital tools that leverage data and artificial intelligence to calculate users' net worth, generate interactive simulations, and provide tailored insights. These tools can help users create a personalized plan, track their progress, and make informed decisions. Examples include DBS' NAV Planner, OCBC's digital investments, and Autumn, which offers investment insights from Franklin Templeton. The rise of digital tools has empowered Singaporeans to start financial planning earlier, with 75% of Autumn's users between 25 and 49 years old.

site_title: Didi says app takedown may adversely impact revenue in China
summary: China's ride-hailing firm Didi Global Inc said removing its app from Chinese app stores may negatively impact its revenue due to the removal of the app. The company had illegally collected users' personal data, prompting China's cyberspace regulator to order app stores to stop offering the app. Didi reported 39.2 billion yuan in revenue from its Chinese mobility division, which is expected to be impacted by the takedown. The company will strive to rectify problems and protect users' data security.

site_title: China's local governments roll over more debt to ease risks
summary: China's local governments have more than doubled bond sales to roll over maturing debt this year, selling 1.9 trillion yuan (S$395 billion) in refinancing bonds from 700 billion yuan in 2020 and 660 billion yuan in 2019. This helps ease repayment risk, but economists predict the debt will continue to grow unless policy makers take action to reduce the absolute value of debt. Local governments have also slowed infrastructure investment, citing a lack of quality projects and a focus on debt control.

site_title: Tyson Foods recalls 8.5 million pounds of frozen chicken
summary: Tyson Foods is recalling nearly 8.5 million pounds of frozen chicken due to potential contamination with listeria. The voluntary recall was issued after two people were sickened with listeriosis, with three cases linked to the recalled products, including one death. The affected products were frozen, fully cooked chicken produced between December and April and were sold under various brand names. The USDA urges people to throw away or return the recalled chicken, particularly pregnant women, adults over 65, and those with weakened immune systems.

site_title: Collapsed Florida condominum to be demolished before storm, search to resume
summary: A partially collapsed Miami-area condo, where 24 people are confirmed dead, is set to be demolished before Tropical Storm Elsa's possible arrival. Search-and-rescue efforts for 121 missing people have been suspended. Demolition preparations began on Sunday, with a planned demolition before the storm's arrival. Once the building is down, rescue efforts will resume. The cause of the collapse remains unknown, with a grand jury examination underway.

images.alt_text: Preparations for demolition work were under way on Sunday ahead of the possible arrival of Tropical Storm Elsa at the partially collapsed Miami-area condo where 24 people are confirmed dead.

site_title: 'Learn to live with' the virus, Johnson tells Britons
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson will unveil a plan to lift coronavirus restrictions from July 19, urging the population to "learn to live with" the virus. The decision comes after the Delta variant, now accounting for nearly all new Covid cases in Britain, forced a delay in the initial reopening date of June 21. Johnson's plan will be announced during a press conference on Monday, with Health Minister Sajid Javid addressing parliament on the issue.

site_title: Making wise choices about your finances
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in retail investors, with a four-fold increase in global equity market investments in Singapore, according to DBS Bank. The bank's data shows that 50% of retail customers have holdings in retirement schemes, and more are prioritizing holistic financial planning. However, this increased investment activity also means that more investors have a higher exposure to market risks. To address this, DBS has launched a digital advisory tool, DBS NAV Planner, which provides personalized investment recommendations and education to help customers make informed decisions.

site_title: Home workers questioning jobs, supply-chain havoc weigh on French recovery
summary: France's economic recovery from the pandemic is being hindered by labor shortages, supply-chain disruptions, and doubts about working from home. Companies, including luxury goods makers and energy exporters, are struggling to fill vacancies, with some citing a global recruitment problem. The crisis has also led to concerns about the end of traditional contracted labor and a reevaluation of people's relationship with work. Supply-chain issues, exacerbated by a global shortage of transport ships and metal containers, are causing bottlenecks that could last until 2022, according to business leaders.

images.alt_text: A shortage of qualified workers, doubts raised by working from home and supply-chain havoc are proving problematic for some companies as they try to ride France's recovery from the pandemic but struggle to fill vacancies, business leaders said.

site_title: Megatanker that blocked Suez Canal to be released
summary: A deal has been reached between Egypt and the Japanese owners of the MV Ever Given, a megatanker that blocked the Suez Canal in March, to release the vessel. The ship will be released on Wednesday after Egypt retained it seeking compensation for lost canal revenues and salvage costs. A ceremony will mark the signing of the agreement, with the Suez Canal Authority stating that preparations were underway for its release. The amount of compensation was not disclosed, but Egypt initially sought $900 million.

images.alt_text: The MV Ever Given - a behemoth with deadweight tonnage of 199,000 - got stuck diagonally across the canal during a sandstorm on March 23, blocking the trade artery for six days before salvage teams could dislodge it.

site_title: Sydney Airport gets A$22.3b takeover bid in rebound bet
summary: Sydney Airport received a A$22.3 billion takeover bid from a consortium including IFM Investors, valuing the airport at A$8.25 per share, a 42% increase from the previous day's closing price. The offer aims to capitalize on the airport's slump in value ahead of global travel's expected recovery. The consortium, led by IFM Investors, is seeking to acquire a majority stake, with conditions including UniSuper Ltd agreeing to reinvest its 15% stake for an equivalent stake in the consortium's holding vehicle. The airport is assessing the proposal.

site_title: Canada's Hong Kong diaspora helps new arrivals with jobs, housing, psychotherapy
summary: Canada's Hong Kong diaspora is banding together to support new arrivals fleeing Beijing's tightening grip on their city. Networks across the country offer a range of services, including jobs, housing, psychotherapy, and car rides to the grocery store. This support network is seen as crucial in helping new arrivals adjust to life in Canada, with many members describing it as a "battle" to provide assistance to fellow Hong Kongers. The network is also seen as a way to preserve cultural identity and values.

site_title: Biden marks 'independence' from Covid, but pandemic woes persist
summary: President Joe Biden will host a large Independence Day party at the White House, celebrating the US's progress in defeating Covid-19, with hospitalizations and deaths down 90% since January. However, the event will also highlight lingering concerns over low vaccination rates, particularly with the highly contagious Delta variant. The celebration comes as the White House falls short of its goal of getting 70% of adults vaccinated by Independence Day, and as public health officials warn of rising cases in rural areas.

site_title: Can Opec members keep to cartel's supply management accord?
summary: Opec member nations are under pressure to maintain the cartel's supply management accord, with the UAE's participation crucial to balancing the market and maintaining prices. The cartel's decision will have a significant impact on the oil market, with potential consequences for global energy prices. Opec has already trimmed oil demand forecasts for the next four years, indicating a cautious approach to supply management. The UAE's involvement will be key in determining the cartel's strategy and its potential impact on the oil market.

site_title: Investors don't see end to red-hot equity rally just yet
summary: Global investors expect a continued rise in equity markets in the second half of the year, with many seeking returns outside the US. Major money managers, including BlackRock and JPMorgan Asset Management, anticipate sustained growth. Investors are increasingly looking to international markets for opportunities, as the US rally shows no signs of slowing. The outlook suggests a continued bull run in the global stock market.

site_title: FBI warns of large 'scale' in US ransomware attack
summary: The FBI warned of a large-scale ransomware attack against Kaseya, a US IT company, which could affect up to 1,000 other businesses. The attack occurred on Friday, just before the US Independence Day holiday weekend. The FBI, along with the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency, launched an investigation to understand the scope of the threat and may not be able to work with every victim individually.

site_title: NYC apartment buyers emerge from 'coma' to drive record sales
summary: Manhattan apartment sales reached a record high in the second quarter, with transactions surging 152% from a year earlier. The proportion of deals completed below the seller's asking price also reached a record 92%, driven by opportunity-seekers in a borough still recovering from the Covid-19 lockdown. With mortgage rates near record lows and infection rates declining, city residents are returning to the market, leading to a compression of the Covid discount and a surge in demand for bigger apartments.

site_title: NutryFarm is betting on Asia's love affair with durians
summary: NutryFarm International, a Singaporean mainboard-listed company, is betting on the growing demand for durians in Asia, particularly in China. CEO Cheng Meng aims to stabilize the company's nutrition and health food business while developing a new core business that capitalizes on the group's understanding of food certifications and connections in China. The company plans to expand its trading and distribution business, with a focus on securing new sales contracts with Chinese wholesale customers and targeting the Singapore market as a springboard for further expansion.

site_title: Bearish case from rising wedge in S&P 500
summary: A bearish case has emerged from a rising wedge in the S&P 500, suggesting a potential reversal pattern. The pattern, characterized by higher highs and higher lows with narrowing trading ranges, typically signals a weakening uptrend. A potential price target of around 3850 is possible, but a scenario seems unlikely given current market conditions. Trading volumes are declining, supporting the bearish case, although false breakouts are also a possibility. The rising wedge pattern may also signal a short-term break before the market continues its uptrend, but the balance of probability is in favor of bears in the near-term.

site_title: E-signatures on the rise, but wills and mortgages still call for pen on paper
summary: Singapore's banks are embracing electronic signatures, with 56,000 transactions recorded since the launch of Sign with Singpass in November last year. However, some legal documents, such as wills and mortgages, still require physical signatures due to existing regulations. The Electronic Transactions Act allows for electronic signatures, but lawyers say that digital signatures offer higher security and are more likely to be adopted in critical transactions. Major banks, including UOB, OCBC, and DBS, are piloting and implementing the use of electronic signatures, with plans to expand into overseas markets. Despite challenges, the service is expected to reduce the use of physical documents and save trees.

site_title: Taiwan's red-hot housing defies challenges from Covid-19 to China
summary: Taiwan's housing market has seen a significant surge in prices, with a 5.7% year-over-year gain in the first quarter. Cities like Tainan and Taipei experienced even higher price increases, with 9.9% and 4.9% gains, respectively. Analysts attribute this to buyers' expectations of continued price growth and low affordability. The market may reach new highs by the end of the year, but a soft lockdown and new curbs may slow down the trend.

site_title: Corporate buybacks gain steam with banks poised to boost buying
summary: US corporations are increasing their stock buybacks despite high valuations, with Morgan Stanley and Wells Fargo among the country's biggest lenders to join the trend. The move is expected to boost share prices, as companies are flush with cash following the US economy's rebound from the pandemic. Buybacks rose sharply in the first three months of 2021, with tech companies leading the way, but now banks are stepping up their repurchases, signaling a shift in the market. Experts predict that buybacks will exceed all-time highs.

site_title: UOB restores disrupted UOB Mighty, Internet banking services
summary: UOB has restored access to its UOB Mighty and personal Internet banking services, which were disrupted on Sunday morning. The issue was reported by customers before noon, with services fully restored at 12:30pm and UOB Mighty services restored at 2pm. This is the second time in three weeks that customers have reported issues with a local bank, following a similar issue at DBS in June. UOB clarified that its automatic teller machines (ATMs) were not affected by the issue.

site_title: Changes may be made to how overseas remote working will be taxed
summary: Singapore's tax authority may adapt policies on overseas remote working due to the growing trend of remote work. A KPMG survey of 500 CEOs in 11 key markets found that tax risk has become the second-greatest threat to growth, surpassing cybersecurity risk. Experts warn that tax authorities may become more stringent in enforcing tax laws, particularly for companies with overseas remote working arrangements. To manage growing tax risks, companies are advised to build a tax controversy department and incorporate tax considerations into business strategies. The Singapore tax authority is expected to remain measured and communicative in its approach to tax authorities.

site_title: At Euro 2020, sponsors tussle for attention to cash in on football's allure
summary: At the Euro 2020 tournament, major sponsors and brands are vying for attention, with several making headlines due to their association with high-profile players. Coca-Cola and Heineken experienced a market value drop after Cristiano Ronaldo and Paul Pogba removed their products from the table during press conferences. Meanwhile, Chinese brands such as Hisense, Vivo, and Alipay are also prominent, with some partnering with the tournament's sponsors and officials. The lucrative sponsorship deals for Euro 2020 have generated an estimated €2.5 billion in revenue, with the tournament expected to reach 4.7 billion live event viewers.

site_title: Dollar falls from three-month high after US non-farm payrolls data
summary: The US dollar fell from a three-month high after a mixed US non-farm payrolls report for June, which showed a strong headline number but weak components. Non-farm payrolls increased by 850,000 jobs, beating expectations, but the unemployment rate rose to 5.9% and average hourly earnings rose 0.3%, lower than forecast. Despite this, analysts expect the dollar to continue to strengthen as the report trends in the right direction for the Federal Reserve to start tapering its asset purchases, potentially supporting the dollar.

site_title: Most want more subsidies, stricter criteria for BTO flats in prime areas: Desmond Lee
summary: Singaporean residents overwhelmingly support providing additional subsidies for public housing in prime areas, with over 6,500 participants in a national survey suggesting stricter criteria for first-time buyers and resale buyers. Minister Desmond Lee emphasized the need to balance affordability with equity and fairness, and to find ways to recover additional subsidies. The government is studying measures to include a variety of flat types and to ensure that flats remain accessible to a wide spectrum of Singaporeans. A new housing model is expected to be formulated, taking into account lessons from successful cities and aiming to create inclusive and diverse neighborhoods.

site_title: Cannes' green push faces challenge that's not easy to address
summary: The Cannes Film Festival, known for its lavish red carpet events, has made a concerted effort to go green, reducing plastic bottles, using electric cars, and creating a climate-focused film program. However, the festival's massive carbon footprint remains a concern, with organizers acknowledging that film festivals are an environmental challenge that cannot be addressed overnight. Efforts to offset carbon emissions through a scientific committee and promoting sustainability in the industry are seen as steps in the right direction, but critics argue that the festival's scale and reliance on air travel make it difficult to justify its environmental impact.

site_title: AirAsia Indonesia to stop flights for a month from July 6
summary: AirAsia Indonesia will temporarily halt flights for a month starting July 6 to support the government's efforts to control a spike in Covid-19 cases. Passengers are advised to reschedule, convert tickets to credits, or apply for a refund. The move aims to limit the spread of the virus and is in line with the government's efforts to manage the pandemic.

site_title: Why hasn't value's outperformance persisted?
summary: Late-stage bull markets favor high-quality growth stocks, contradicting predictions of value stocks leading the market. Despite early value stock performance and economic reopenings, value stocks have not outperformed growth stocks. This trend should be a wake-up call for investors, particularly in Singapore and globally, as it challenges conventional investment wisdom.

site_title: Is Sembmarine's rights issue to position it for a cash-depleting merger with Keppel O&M?
summary: Sembcorp Marine has announced a S$1.5 billion rights issue, amid a depressed stock price that has tumbled nearly 35% since the announcement. The move is seen as a cash-depleting merger with Keppel O&M, which was previously discussed but denied by Sembmarine last year. Temasek Holdings, which holds a 42.6% stake in Sembmarine, is putting up to S$1 billion behind the rights issue. Investors are cautious about the merger terms, and some see it as benefiting Keppel and Temasek at the expense of Sembmarine's minority shareholders.

site_title: The multifaceted responsibilities of the IRO
summary: The Investor Relations Officer (IRO) role has evolved significantly since its inception in 1953, requiring new skills and responsibilities to effectively connect corporate strategy with shareholder value. The IRO should articulate strategy, gather intelligence, cultivate the right investors, and sound the alarm on potential issues. Effective IROs need high EQ, strong interpersonal skills, and access to key decision-makers. The author advocates for the Monetary Authority of Singapore to grant recognition to IR as a profession, enabling IROs to upskill and advance their careers, potentially leading to promotions to CFO or business unit heads.

site_title: HRnetGroup's largest shareholder raises stake
summary: HRnetGroup's largest shareholder, SIMCO Global, increased its stake in the company to 77.70% after acquiring 25,838,000 shares for S$16,148,750. The company reported a record-breaking year in revenue at S$433.0 million, with 42,998 people securing employment in contract and temporary roles. Meanwhile, RH Petrogas' executive director Francis Chang Cheng-Hsing exercised 3.5 million share options, and Leader Environmental Technologies' executive director Lin Baiyin disposed of 10 million shares.

site_title: Weary Malaysians flying white flags add pressure on PM Muhyiddin
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin faces mounting pressure after a week of turmoil, including a hospitalization for diarrhea and a statement from the King ordering Parliament to reconvene. The government's handling of the Covid-19 pandemic has sparked frustration and despair among Malaysians, with a growing citizen movement demanding more help. The economy is also struggling, with the government's four-phase recovery plan criticized for lacking a clear strategy to keep infections down. The situation may impact Malaysia's future economic prospects and its relationships with neighboring countries, particularly Singapore.

site_title: China blocks Didi from app stores days after mega US IPO
summary: China's Cyberspace Administration ordered app stores to remove Didi Chuxing, a ride-hailing giant, citing serious violations of personal information collection and usage. The ban comes two days after a cybersecurity review of the company. This decision marks a significant blow to Didi, which had recently completed a massive US IPO. The regulator did not elaborate on the violations, but the swift action suggests a severe concern over data protection.

site_title: Manhattan listings that have lingered
summary: The New York real estate market has experienced a recent surge in demand, but some Manhattan listings have remained unsold for years, defying assumptions about style, location, and cachet. The prolonged situation has caused frustration among sellers, agents, and buyers. Covid-19 is not the sole culprit, as the market's complexities suggest a more nuanced issue. Experts are still grappling with the underlying factors hindering sales, despite the overall market's hot streak.

site_title: Citi Singapore donates more than S$150,000 to ChildAid
summary: Citi Singapore has donated over S$150,000 to ChildAid, supporting financially disadvantaged children through The Business Times Budding Artists Fund and The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund. The donation, made by 11 teams across Citi Singapore, is the sixth consecutive year the bank has raised over S$100,000 for charities. Since 2002, Citi has helped raise S$6.7 million for the two funds, solidifying its commitment to philanthropy and community service.

images.alt_text: Performers at ChildAid 2019. Since 2002, Citi has helped raise S$6.7 million for the The Business Times Budding Artists Fund (BTBAF) and The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund (STSPMF).

site_title: Malaysian glove makers say virus curbs may hurt global supplies
summary: Malaysian glove manufacturers, who produce 67% of global medical gloves, appealed to the government to allow factories in Selangor to operate despite stricter movement curbs due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The curbs, which took effect on Saturday, have disrupted global supplies of protective gear, with global demand expected to remain at 420 billion pieces this year and jump by 15-20% in 2022. The Malaysian Rubber Glove Manufacturers Association (Margma) urged the government to meet with the trade ministry to prevent a shortage of production and delivery of gloves to global customers.

site_title: TikTok back in Pakistan after court revokes ban
summary: TikTok has been reinstated in Pakistan after a provincial court revoked a suspension order, citing the need for the platform to address complaints of objectionable content. The court's decision comes after the Pakistan Telecoms Authority blocked access to the app for a third time. TikTok had previously removed over 6 million videos from its Pakistan service in the past three months, including 15% featuring adult content. The reinstatement is seen as a victory for the app's fans, but also highlights ongoing concerns over government censorship and control in the country.

site_title: Robinhood resolves issue with crypto trading on its platform
summary: Robinhood resolved a brief outage affecting crypto trading on its platform, which lasted about an hour and impacted over 1,000 users in the North America region. The outage occurred on Friday evening, shortly after the company filed for its initial public offering. Robinhood apologized for the disruption and stated that it has resolved the issue.

site_title: Mid-Cap S-Reits continue to lead sector in H1 2021
summary: The Singapore Reits sector experienced an 8.9% total return in H1 2021, with mid-cap S-Reits leading the sector with an average 25.2% total return. The healthcare and industrial sub-segments were the top performers, generating 22% and 16% average total returns respectively. The sector is expected to benefit from vaccination progress and leisure travel recovery in the second half of 2021. The FTSE EPRA Nareit Index Series has also been updated, potentially opening up more mid-cap S-Reits for inclusion in the index.

site_title: White House urges more countries to sign 15% global corporate tax pledge
summary: The US and 130 countries backing a global corporate minimum tax of at least 15% agreed on an overhaul of international tax rules. The deal aims to raise revenue for investments, with the US pushing for higher corporate tax rates at home. Holdout countries, including Ireland, Hungary, and Estonia, have expressed concerns over low tax rates. The OECD plans to finalize an implementation plan by October, with the deal expected to be implemented in 2023. The US and European Union are optimistic about rapid implementation, with the G7 and G20 expected to endorse the plan at upcoming meetings.

site_title: Syngenta's US$10b Shanghai IPO to fund growth and acquisitions
summary: Syngenta Group, a Swiss agrichemical giant, plans to raise US$10 billion through its initial public offering (IPO) on Shanghai's STAR Market, valuing the company at approximately US$50 billion. The funds will be used to fund internal growth, strategic acquisitions, advanced agricultural technology research, and debt repayment. The IPO, set to take place by the end of 2021, will be the world's largest this year, and a secondary listing in Zurich, London, and New York is also being considered.

site_title: Indonesia rolls out tougher curbs as virus cases skyrocket
summary: Indonesia has imposed a partial lockdown in Jakarta, Java, and Bali to combat a surge in coronavirus cases, with over 25,000 new cases and 539 deaths recorded on Friday. The lockdown, set to last until July 20, includes shuttering mosques, restaurants, and shopping malls in virus hotspots. The Delta variant, the most contagious of any Covid-19 variant, is driving the recent wave, accounting for over 80% of new cases in some areas. The measures aim to bring daily infections below 10,000, but experts warn that they may not be enough to contain the outbreak.

site_title: Theme funds: tread with care
summary: A new Morningstar research study casts a skeptical eye on thematic funds, which are typically launched at the peak of markets, suggesting poor long-term performance and survivorship. These funds, often promising disruptive technologies, should be added to an investor's allocation only after thorough research and clear exit targets are set. They are best suited as a "satellite" portion of an investment portfolio, not a primary allocation. The study's findings highlight the need for caution when investing in thematic funds, especially during bull markets.

site_title: Most Singaporeans back more subsidies, stricter criteria for prime area BTO flats: Desmond Lee
summary: Most Singaporeans support additional subsidies for prime area BTO flats and stricter criteria for first-time buyers and subsequent resale buyers. A national survey involving over 6,500 participants found diverse opinions on keeping these flats inclusive. National Development Minister Desmond Lee stated that there is great diversity in opinions on how to make these flats inclusive. The survey aims to inform the government's plans for building new flats in prime areas.

site_title: US to ship four million vaccine doses to Indonesia 'as soon as possible'
summary: The US has agreed to ship four million doses of Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine to Indonesia as soon as possible through the Covax global vaccine sharing program. This donation underscores the US' support for Indonesia's efforts to combat a surge in Covid-19 cases. Indonesia, the world's fourth most populous country, has been battling one of Asia's worst outbreaks, with record new infections and deaths reported in recent days. The move is part of the Biden administration's efforts to increase vaccine assistance to developing countries.

images.alt_text: The US will ship four million doses of Moderna Inc's Covid-19 vaccine to Indonesia as it battles a coronavirus outbreak, the US national security adviser told the Indonesian foreign minister on Friday.

site_title: Cyberattack hits hundreds of US businesses
summary: A US IT company, Kaseya, has reported a cyberattack that has encrypted data on around 200 businesses, with the attackers believed to be from the hacking group REvil. Kaseya, a leading provider of IT and security management services, has limited the attack to a small percentage of its customers using its VSA software. The company has notified affected customers to shut down their servers and is working on a patch to mitigate the vulnerability. The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency is taking action to address the attack.

images.alt_text: A US IT company urged customers to shut down their servers Friday after cyberattackers smuggled ransomware onto its network platform.

site_title: Era ends, uncertainty looms as US forces quit main Afghanistan base
summary: US forces have completed their withdrawal from the main Afghan base, Bagram Air Base, marking the end of the longest war in US history. The Taliban has praised the departure, but many Afghans remain uncertain about the country's future without foreign support. The US military still maintains authority to protect Afghan forces, with some troops set to remain in the country until September. The withdrawal comes as the Taliban ramps up its offensive, with seven districts in Paktia province falling under its control.

images.alt_text: American troops pulled out of their main military base in Afghanistan on Friday, leaving behind a piece of the World Trade Center they buried 20 years ago in a country that could descend into civil war without them.

site_title: Brookfield-backed Clarios reveals swing to annual loss in IPO filing
summary: Clarios International, a car battery maker backed by Brookfield Asset Management and Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec, reported an annual loss of US$399 million in its IPO filing. The company's revenue dropped 11% to US$7.6 billion in the year ended Sept. 30, 2020, due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Clarios confidentially filed for a US$20 billion IPO, which could be one of the biggest US floatations from the auto sector this year, trading on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol "BTRY".

site_title: Audi R8 Spyder and RS 7 review: A tale of two rowdy Audis
summary: Audi's R8 Spyder and RS 7 Sportback are high-performance vehicles that pack a significant punch. The R8 Spyder, with its 610-hp V10 engine, and the RS 7 Sportback, with its 591-hp twin-turbo V8, deliver exceptional speed and agility. Both cars have been involved in high-speed incidents, prompting the author to reflect on their capabilities. The author concludes that while the cars are exhilarating to drive, their raw power may be a double-edged sword, potentially leading to reckless behavior behind the wheel.

site_title: 19 missing in Japan landslide after heavy rain: official
summary: A landslide in Japan's Shizuoka region engulfed houses, leaving 19 people missing after days of heavy rain. Television footage showed a torrent of mud obliterating buildings and burying others. The safety of the 19 missing individuals is currently unknown.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for July 2, 2021, reveals a shift in tanker and dry bulk market sentiment. Rates initially rose, but negative sentiment led to a decline, with the Pacific basin being the early driver of the market. The Capesize 5TC reached $34,299 on Tuesday, but closed the week at $29,106. The Atlantic Basin remained quiet, with Panamax rates reaching their highest value since May 2010 due to supply-demand imbalance. Ultramax and Handysize rates were mostly positive, with some weakening in the US Gulf. VLCC rates to China eased, while Suezmax and Aframax rates declined. The report also notes that the Middle East Gulf market remained relatively static, with MR tonnage rates falling in Asia.

site_title: AMC shares fall after Iceberg Research discloses short position
summary: AMC Entertainment shares fell 4% after short-seller Iceberg Research disclosed a bearish bet against the company's stock. The firm, led by Arnaud Vagner, stated that the stock price has been inflated by call options and predicted a correction. AMC shares have risen over 2,500% year-to-date, but analysts like MKM Partners' Eric Handler warn of a mean reversion, citing a high trading price multiple of 45 times earnings estimates. Handler predicts a correction in AMC's stock price, citing historical patterns.

site_title: Amazon to grant new CEO over US$200m in stock
summary: Amazon plans to award new CEO Andy Jassy over $200m in stock, valued at $214m, to be paid out over 10 years. The grant, worth about $214m, will be recorded on July 5, the date Jassy succeeds Jeff Bezos. Jassy's base salary is $175,000, and he has previously awarded stock that is vesting this year and in 2020. Governance experts have criticized such pay schemes for rewarding executives prematurely, but Amazon aims to stop its prior biannual grants and make the latest award account for most of Jassy's compensation.

site_title: Tech rules not just for a few giants, EU's Vestager says
summary: European Union's antitrust chief, Margrethe Vestager, says draft Digital Markets Act (DMA) rules should cover more than just the top five tech giants, aiming to ensure fairness and a level playing field. The proposed rules target companies with 6.5 billion euros in annual turnover or 65 billion euros in market value, impacting about 10 dominant companies. Vestager is open to giving enforcement powers to national watchdogs, aiming for a single European rulebook, and is willing to debate the revenue threshold, but emphasizes it's not about singling out specific companies.

site_title: Celebrating small businesses by sharing their good ideas with the world
summary: The UN General Assembly has declared June 27 as Micro-, Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises Day to raise awareness of small businesses' contributions to the global economy. In the Asia Pacific region, SMBs comprise 98% of enterprises and contribute 50% of the region's GDP. Despite their importance, small businesses are struggling to be found and are the hardest hit by the pandemic. To overcome this, Facebook has shared three "brilliant basics" for SMBs: being authentic, taking creative control, and connecting across formats. By implementing these basics, small businesses can supercharge their recovery and regain their footing in the market.

site_title: Investors are raising US$100 million to buy unloved antiques
summary: Investors are raising $100 million to buy undervalued antiques, seeing the currently sluggish market as an opportunity to buy low and sell high. According to Clinton Howell, the term "brown furniture" refers to the numerous centuries-old fine antiques that are undervalued due to their drab appearance. This trend is expected to drive growth in the antique market, with Asia being a key driver of dollar asset diversification.

site_title: Google must face Voice Assistant privacy lawsuit: US judge
summary: A US federal judge ruled that Google must face a lawsuit accusing the company of illegally recording and disseminating private conversations of people who accidentally trigger its voice-activated Voice Assistant on their smartphones. The judge allowed the plaintiffs to pursue claims of violating California and federal privacy laws, as well as breach of contract. Google Assistant's "false accepts" feature, which misperceives what users say as hot words, was found to have created a reasonable expectation of privacy. The proposed class action seeks unspecified damages for US purchasers of Google Assistant-enabled devices since May 18, 2016.

site_title: HKEX's new CEO reorganises operations in fifth week on the job
summary: HKEX's new CEO, Nicolas Aguzin, has reorganized the company's operations five weeks into his role. The management team has been shuffled into two new divisions: the markets unit and the operations unit. The original management committee has been split in two, with eight members reporting directly to Aguzin and the rest to COO Calvin Tai. The changes aim to align the company's structure with customer needs. The reorganization takes effect August 1, following a decade of growth under former CEO Charles Li, who doubled the company's revenue.

site_title: Riot Games launches royalty-free album for streamers
summary: Riot Games, the developer of League of Legends, released a royalty-free album titled "Sessions: Vi" featuring 37 ambient tunes to help streamers broadcast their gaming sessions without infringing on copyright protections. The album is available on major streaming services, addressing the growing frustration among gamers who were previously booted off platforms for using protected material. This move follows similar initiatives by other game developers, such as CD Projekt SA, to provide alternatives for streaming copyrighted music.

site_title: Oil steady, traders on sidelines as Opec+ talks drag on
summary: Oil prices steadied on Friday after Opec+ ministers resumed talks on raising oil output, following a UAE block on a deal.
