summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) announced that 130 countries and jurisdictions have agreed to a global tax reform, requiring multinational companies to pay at least a 15% tax rate. The deal follows a G7 endorsement and aims to end the "race to the bottom" in corporate taxation. Germany hailed the agreement as a "colossal step towards tax justice," but Ireland and Hungary declined to sign, highlighting ongoing divisions. The reform is expected to ensure multinationals pay their fair share globally.

site_title: US: S&P 500 begins second half of 2021 at new peak
summary: The S&P 500 index began the second half of 2021 at a record high of 4,300.73, rising 3.2 points or 0.08% at the open. This follows fewer-than-expected weekly jobless claims. The Dow Jones Industrial Average also rose, while the Nasdaq Composite dropped.

site_title: Hopes for a revival as tourists trickle back to Thailand
summary: Thailand's tourism industry is slowly recovering as the country reopened to fully vaccinated tourists on Thursday. Restaurant owner Pimonta Suksaen, who struggled to manage debt during the pandemic, is hopeful that a pilot scheme to lure tourists back with waived quarantine requirements will help revive her business. With about 400 visitors expected on the first day, authorities plan to replicate the "Phuket Sandbox" project in other holiday hotspots, aiming for a 5-10% increase in tourist arrivals. The reopening marks Thailand's biggest step towards rejuvenating its battered tourism industry, which drew 40 million annual visitors before the pandemic.

site_title: Opec+ could add 2m bpd of oil to market by December, says source
summary: Opec+ is set to gradually add 2 million barrels per day to the oil market from August to December, easing back on output curbs amid a recovering global economy. The monthly increases will be less than 0.5 million bpd, and the group is also considering extending its supply restraint pact beyond April 2022. This move is expected to keep the market tight this summer and support oil prices, which have risen to 2-1/2 year highs.

site_title: Security tight in Hong Kong on return to China anniversary
summary: Police in Hong Kong deployed large numbers to prevent protests on the 24th anniversary of its return to Chinese rule, with some areas of Victoria Park shut down. Acting leader John Lee said the national security law had brought order back to the city, but critics claim it has crushed dissent. Three people were arrested for allegedly distributing "seditious" leaflets, and the government has arrested 117 people under the law since its introduction last year. The anniversary marks a significant step towards Beijing's authoritarian path for the global financial hub.

site_title: Time-travel back to Jalan Besar's glorious past
summary: A new ambulatory play, "New World's End," opens in Jalan Besar, taking audiences back to the 1960s and 70s. The story follows cinema projectionist Kiran and cabaret hostess Rosa, set against the backdrop of the now-defunct New World Amusement Park. The play combines audio, multimedia, and spatial design, using the neighborhood's pre-war shophouses, street murals, and alleys to create an immersive experience. The production, directed by Kaylene Tan, aims to engage with Jalan Besar's history and anticipate its future, with regular walking tours running from Fridays to Sundays.

site_title: Malaysia's AirAsia applies for digital banking licence
summary: Malaysia's budget airline AirAsia has applied for a digital banking license through its fintech unit BigPay, in partnership with Malaysian Industrial Development Finance Berhad and private equity firm Ikhlas Capital. The consortium, which also includes a foreign fintech expert, is among several bidders for up to five digital banking licenses set to be issued by the Malaysian central bank in early 2022. Other bidders include Grab, Singtel, and Tencent-backed consortium.

site_title: Tourists start returning to no-quarantine Phuket despite Thailand virus surge
summary: Tourists are returning to Phuket, Thailand, under a quarantine-free scheme, as the country attempts to revive its tourism industry. Despite a surge in coronavirus cases, Phuket welcomed its first international travelers on July 1. The tourism sector accounts for almost 20% of Thailand's economy, which has been severely impacted by the pandemic. The move aims to boost the economy, but the country's worst coronavirus outbreak continues to pose a challenge.

site_title: US pending home sales decline in June as prices climb
summary: US pending home sales declined 1.9% in June, falling to 112.8, as home prices continued to surge. The median price for new and existing homes now exceeds US$360,000. This marks a reversal from the strong rebound in May, with pending sales seen as a forward-looking indicator of the housing market's health. The decline is attributed to record-high home prices causing buyers to retreat, with limited supply and favorable mortgage rates. Existing home sales rebounded moderately in June.

site_title: Covid-19 cluster at Block 506 Hougang Avenue 8 closed; no unlinked cases reported
summary: A Covid-19 cluster at Block 506 Hougang Avenue 8 in Singapore was closed after 28 days with no new cases linked to it. Four locally transmitted cases and six imported cases were reported, with all six imported cases already on stay-home notice or isolation. The number of active clusters decreased to 29, and the number of unlinked community cases fell to eight. Singapore's total Covid-19 cases reached 62,589, with 10 new cases reported, and 127 patients still in hospital.

site_title: Tokyo dining - the return of Little Japan in Singapore
summary: A growing number of Japanese chefs are reviving the Orchard Plaza in Singapore's Little Tokyo. Bistrot Etroit, a notoriously difficult-to-get-into seven-seater eatery, is leading the charge. Run by a temperamental Japanese chef, the bistro serves French omakase from scratch, including signature homemade brioche. The eatery's unorthodox location and edgy vibe are part of a resurgence of Japanese culture in the area, which has become a hotspot for foodies and Instagram enthusiasts.

site_title: Singapore tourism could shift into fast gear soon as it steps up vaccinations
summary: Singapore's tourism sector is expected to recover as the country steps up vaccinations, with Health Minister Ong Ye Kung indicating that residents may soon be able to travel abroad again. Analysts predict a sharp pick-up in arrivals by the fourth quarter, driven by the reopening of international borders and potential travel bubbles with low-risk countries like Australia and Hong Kong. Leisure outbound travel may be allowed by year-end, with the US, Hong Kong, and parts of Europe being considered as possible destinations.

images.alt_text: Passengers at Changi Airport Terminal 3 on June 11, 2021.

site_title: US manufacturing sector grows moderately
summary: US manufacturing activity grew moderately in June, but employment contracted for the first time in seven months due to raw material and labor shortages. The Institute for Supply Management's index fell to 60.6, the lowest reading since January, from 61.2 in May. A global semiconductor shortage and rising raw material costs are driving inflation, with economists expecting prices to remain high until supply catches up later this year.

site_title: US jobless claims fall to 364,000, lowest since March 2020
summary: US jobless claims fell to 364,000, the lowest since March 2020, according to Labor Department data. This decline of 51,000 new jobless claims is better than economists' expectations. However, analysts warn that the figures are volatile and subject to unexpected moves. The four-week moving average for initial claims also decreased to 392,750. Despite this, 14.7 million people were still receiving some form of benefits as of June 12.

site_title: 82-year-old woman will go into space with Bezos
summary: An 82-year-old woman, Wally Funk, will join Jeff Bezos on Blue Origin's first crewed spaceflight on July 20, becoming the oldest person to travel to space. Funk was part of the Mercury 13, the first women trained to fly to space in 1960-1961, but was excluded due to her gender. The 10-minute trip will take place aboard the New Shepard launch vehicle, along with Bezos, his brother Mark, and an unnamed winner of an auction. This marks a milestone for private space exploration, as Blue Origin competes with companies like SpaceX and Virgin Galactic.

site_title: STI declines 0.2% as sessions across Asia end mixed on coronavirus variant concerns
summary: Singapore's STI index declined 0.2% to 3,124.19 due to mixed regional market performance amid concerns over the highly contagious Delta variant of Covid-19. The Delta variant threatens to derail economic recovery, with investors keeping a close eye on risk factors. Meanwhile, regional peers such as the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index and Jakarta Composite Index rose, while Japan's Nikkei 225 and South Korea's Kospi fell.

site_title: Nissan bets big on UK with EV battery plant and new crossover
summary: Nissan has pledged $1.4 billion to build a 9-gigawatt-hour battery plant in Sunderland, UK, with Chinese partner Envision AESC, creating 6,200 jobs and powering 100,000 vehicles per year. The plant will also produce a new electric crossover vehicle, cementing Nissan's wager on Britain despite Brexit threats. The investment aims to secure battery supply close to factories, addressing the auto industry's shift to electric vehicles. British Prime Minister Boris Johnson welcomed the move, citing it as a "major vote of confidence" in the UK.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Q2 flash private home prices rose 0.9% for the fifth straight quarter, sparking debate over cooling measures. Visitor arrivals fell to 14,190 in May, but tourist revival is expected in Q4. Unemployment rates improved to 2.8% in May. The Ong&Ong brothers are in a legal dispute over shares in their family business. Grab-Singtel's venture applied for a digital bank license in Malaysia. The STI declined 0.2% due to coronavirus variant concerns.

site_title: Britain sets out vision for post-Brexit financial services
summary: Britain's finance minister, Rishi Sunak, outlined his vision for the country's financial services sector post-Brexit, aiming to "sharpen" the sector's competitive advantage while maintaining high regulatory standards. He announced reviews of various financial rules and regulations, including prospectuses, capital markets, and insurance capital rules, to simplify the regulatory regime and enhance the sector's appeal. The government also plans to introduce new sustainability disclosure requirements and a public consultation on safeguards for access to cash.

site_title: Mirae Asset Daewoo awarded US$5.1m claim against ex-honestbee CEO Joel Sng
summary: South Korean brokerage Mirae Asset Daewoo has been awarded a US$5.1 million claim against former honestbee CEO Joel Sng. Mirae Asset Daewoo sued Sng for allegedly failing to deliver shares, after the brokerage paid US$5.1 million for some of his shares. The court granted a summary judgment in favor of Mirae Asset Daewoo, moving to a decision without a full trial.

site_title: Euro zone recovery faces risks from virus mutations, ECB's Lagarde says
summary: Euro zone recovery is at risk due to virus mutations, according to European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde. Despite the improved economic outlook from vaccination campaigns, policymakers debate cutting back on massive bond-buying programs. The European Systemic Risk Board warns that EU's most indebted states could struggle with increased borrowing costs if US bond yields rise. A stronger-than-expected rise in European sovereign bond yields could have a negative impact on debt dynamics, particularly for countries already heavily indebted.

site_title: NFT marketplace Mintable raises US$13m in Series A funding round
summary: Mintable, a non-fungible token (NFT) marketplace, has raised US$13 million in Series A funding from investors including Ripple Labs, Metapurse, and Animoca Brands. The funds will be used to develop and launch new products to make NFT buying and trading accessible to the mass market. With backing from Mark Cuban, Mintable has minted over 700,000 items on its platform, and recent collaborations include NFL quarterback Trevor Lawrence and streetwear brand BAPE. The company aims to simplify the NFT experience for a broader audience.

site_title: Singapore to follow up with Binance in wake of global crackdown
summary: Singapore's financial regulator, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), will follow up with Binance Asia Services, the local unit of Binance Holdings, as required after the parent company came under global scrutiny. Binance is seeking a licence to operate in Singapore, along with other crypto firms, amid a regulatory crackdown on the sector. MAS will assess Binance's application and consider factors such as anti-money laundering measures and the fitness of shareholders and key appointment holders.

images.alt_text: Singapore's financial regulator said it would follow up as required with the local unit of Binance Holdings after its parent company came under scrutiny from authorities around the world.

site_title: Investor Elliott puts pressure on GSK leadership
summary: Activist investor Elliott has taken a significant stake in GlaxoSmithKline (GSK), urging the company to review its leadership and consider the outright sale of its consumer healthcare business. GSK plans to separate the business next year, which includes brands such as Sensodyne toothpaste and Advil painkillers. Elliott has proposed five recommendations, including the need for additional biopharmaceuticals and scientific expertise, and has expressed interest in a full sale of the consumer health business. The company's CEO, Emma Walmsley, plans to remain in place until a decision is made regarding future leadership.

site_title: Digital-document platform Dedoco raises S$3.3m seed round led by Vertex Ventures
summary: Singapore-based startup Dedoco has raised S$3.3 million in a seed round led by Vertex Ventures South-east Asia. The digital document and signing platform aims to help enterprises manage digital workflows while issuing trusted documents and credentials. Dedoco's platform offers real-time verification and an audit trail on the blockchain, maintaining transaction integrity. The startup plans to expand into new markets and roll out new features over the next year or two, with a focus on increasing connectivity with cloud and system partners.

site_title: Britons consumed more calories during pandemic, study says
summary: A study by the Institute for Fiscal Studies found that Britons consumed 15% more calories in May 2020, and this remained 10% higher on average throughout the year. The increase was attributed to higher consumption of calories from takeouts and food purchased at supermarkets, with the wealthiest households experiencing the largest rises. The study suggests that increased home working may have driven this increase, potentially exacerbating the challenge of improving population diet and reducing obesity levels.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.60 points to 1,534.23. The index saw 556 gainers versus 373 losers, with a total volume of 7.181 billion lots worth RM3.467 billion.

site_title: Ong&Ong brothers in legal dispute over shares in family business
summary: Former Singapore President Ong Teng Cheong's sons, Ong Tze Guan and Ong Tze Boon, are embroiled in a legal dispute over shares in their family business, Ong&Ong Holdings. Ong Tze Guan is suing his brother and seven others, claiming his shares were undervalued when acquired in 2020. He seeks a court declaration to rescind the transfer and order the defendants to buy back his shares at a fair price. The dispute centers on allegations of oppressive conduct by Ong Tze Boon, including stripping Tze Guan of directorships and loans. The civil case is currently at the pre-trial conference stage.

site_title: Six local firms recognised in Deloitte's inaugural Singapore's Best Managed Companies awards
summary: Six local firms, Cityneon Holdings, KinderWorld International Group, Lian Beng Group, LUXASIA, Nanofilm Technologies International, and OSIM International, were recognized as Singapore's Best Managed Companies in Deloitte's inaugural awards programme. The companies were evaluated for their organizational success, contribution to their industries, and the economy, with a focus on strategy, capabilities, innovation, culture, governance, and financials. The awards programme aims to support and recognize great leadership and tenacity among Singapore-based companies, particularly during challenging times.

site_title: Asia: Stocks fall again as China woes top upbeat recovery outlook
summary: Asia's stocks fell on Friday, setting a volatile week on a negative note, as China's regulatory crackdown continued to spook investors. Despite a positive lead from Wall Street, Asian markets were clobbered by China's measures against private tuition, tech, and property sectors, with Hong Kong losing over 9% in three days. Chinese officials attempted to soothe investor fears, but analysts warned that Beijing might not be finished yet. The US economy expanded 6.5% in Q2, beating expectations, but the global recovery remains on track, with the Federal Reserve unlikely to taper its monetary policies soon.

site_title: German inflation soars to 13-year high as Bundesbank frets about low ECB rates
summary: Germany's annual consumer price inflation accelerated to a 13-year-high of 3.1% in July, surpassing the European Central Bank's target of close to 2%. This is the highest since August 2008. Bundesbank chief Jens Weidmann expressed concern over the prolonged low-interest-rate environment, warning that inflation may reach 5% in Germany later this year.

site_title: Booze and learn
summary: Several companies are offering online classes and masterclasses to enhance the home drinking experience, focusing on wine, beer, and spirits. Vivant, a virtual wine experience platform, allows users to learn about wine through interactive sessions hosted by wine specialists. Bad Decisions Imports, a beer importer, offers curated beer boxes and masterclass events to educate beer enthusiasts. EC Proof, a spirits company, provides private virtual events for spirit tasting and cocktail making. Meanwhile, Spiffy Dapper's online cocktail masterclasses offer flexible timings and prepared ingredients for each cocktail.

site_title: Angliss Singapore wins lawsuit against ex-staff for misappropriation of information
summary: Angliss Singapore has won a lawsuit against former employee Roger Yee Heng Khay, who misappropriated confidential information when he left the company for a competitor, Indoguna. The High Court awarded Angliss S$729,423 in damages after finding that Yee took over 100 files containing confidential information, leading to the loss of a distributorship and S$749,000 in lost profits. Justice Valerie Thean ruled that the documents contained valuable pricing and sales information that was invaluable in the food distribution business.

site_title: Virus surge in US upends plans for getting workers back to offices
summary: The resurgence of COVID-19 cases and the Delta variant in the US is forcing companies to reevaluate their plans for returning workers to offices. Several major corporations, including Google, Lyft, and Twitter, have pushed back their return dates or implemented new vaccination requirements. The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has recommended that fully vaccinated individuals wear masks indoors in areas with high infection rates. The shift in guidance has raised concerns about the feasibility of a full office return and the potential for breakthrough infections and disruptions to economic activity.

site_title: Affordable eco-housing would benefit millions in emerging Asia
summary: Affordable eco-housing is crucial in Asia, where over half of slum dwellers lack proper homes, contributing to 40% of global greenhouse gas emissions. The private sector plays a significant role, but underinvestment in affordable eco-housing is a major challenge due to land, affordability, and financing issues. Governments must address these problems through policies and programs, while technological innovation and partnerships between stakeholders can help replace conventional housing with eco-friendly options, providing jobs and rejuvenating economies. With an estimated $16 trillion needed to replace sub-standard housing, only $1-3 trillion can come from public funding, highlighting the need for concerted effort.

site_title: US: Dow climbs as US stocks open higher
summary: US stocks rose in early trading on Friday, with the Dow climbing above the 35,000 mark. The market rebounded from a rocky start to the week, with positive results from major companies and a stabilizing 10-year Treasury yield. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.3% to 34,928.08, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.3% and 0.2%, respectively. The market appears to be cautiously optimistic about the US economic recovery despite concerns about the Delta variant of Covid-19.

site_title: Can Singapore's fertility business deliver further growth?
summary: Singapore's fertility business is seeking growth amid rising demand for fertility services. The country's fertility rate has been declining, with 15% of couples unable to conceive within a year of trying. Industry players are calling for regulatory changes, education, and corporate support to address the issue. The government has introduced a co-funding scheme for fertility treatments, but more needs to be done to encourage couples to seek help earlier. Social egg-freezing is also becoming increasingly popular, with many Singaporeans opting to freeze their eggs overseas due to the ban on the practice in Singapore.

site_title: Oil prices steady as virus spread counters tight supplies
summary: Oil prices remained steady on Tuesday as investors worried about the spread of the Covid-19 Delta variant, despite tightening supplies and rising vaccination rates. US crude and petrol inventories fell, and global demand is expected to remain strong despite concerns. The International Monetary Fund maintained its 6% global growth forecast for 2021, and analysts remain confident about fuel demand. Oil prices slipped slightly, with Brent futures settling at $74.48 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude settling at $71.65 a barrel.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close more than 4 per cent down
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 4.13% on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 1,129.66 points to 26,192.32. The decline was driven by a China decision to reform the private-education sector, impacting tuition firms, and a fresh crackdown on Tencent, a tech firm. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also fell, with the Shanghai Composite Index down 2.34% and the Shenzhen Composite Index down 2.28%. The declines are attributed to China's regulatory actions and global market uncertainty.

site_title: Sats shows path to diversification for travel-related companies
summary: SATS, a mainboard-listed company, has seen significant growth in its non-travel-related businesses, with revenue increasing 22.6% to S$127.6 million in Q1 FY2022, accounting for 46.3% of its total revenue. The company is diversifying into food solutions, including commercial and institutional catering, and sourcing and distribution, with a focus on logistics and efficiency. CEO Alex Hungate aims for a 50-50 balance between travel and non-travel-related revenue in the medium term, driven by growth in non-travel-related businesses, which have shown resilience despite the travel industry's challenges.

site_title: Psyched for success: Sagi Karni, Israel's ambassador to Singapore
summary: Israel's Ambassador to Singapore, Sagi Karni, emphasizes the country's "startup nation" reputation, built on a culture of risk-taking and innovation, particularly in agriculture and technology. He highlights agritech partnerships with Singapore, aiming to produce 30% of the city-state's food needs locally by 2030. Karni points to protein substitutes, urban farming, and aquafarming as key areas for collaboration. He notes that Israel's entrepreneurial culture encourages taking risks, and the country has seen success with high-tech exits and innovative startups. Karni also praises Israel's COVID-19 vaccination campaign, which has achieved over 60% vaccination rates, and advocates for a political solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

site_title: Femtech: More than periods and pregnancy
summary: Femtech startups in South-east Asia are gaining momentum, addressing various health and wellness issues faced by women beyond reproductive health. Despite being historically underfunded and overlooked, the sector is gaining investor attention. Key areas of focus include chronic condition management, such as polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and menopause, as well as sexual health services, including STI testing and birth control. Startups like Fig Health, EloCare, Ferne Health, and Dear Doc are developing innovative solutions, including digital health platforms, wearable technology, and online consultations. The sector is expected to grow, driven by increasing research and funding, as well as a rise in preventative medicine and holistic health.

site_title: Indonesia's Emtek group invests US$375m in Grab's Indonesian unit
summary: Indonesian conglomerate Elang Mahkota Teknologi (Emtek) is investing $375 million in Grab's Indonesian unit, forming a "strategic alliance". Emtek, which owns stakes in media companies and e-wallets, aims to shake up the digital payments sector and increase Grab's stake in e-wallet OVO, with OVO and Dana previously in talks to merge. The deal follows a similar investment by Thailand's Central Group in 2019, further solidifying Grab's partnerships with major South-east Asian conglomerates.

site_title: Green finance in Asia: Emerging themes and the need for innovation
summary: Singapore aims to become the regional green finance hub, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore leading the charge through the Green Finance Action Plan. Despite recent strides, the Asean region faces a significant green financing gap, estimated at US$200 billion annually from 2016 to 2030. Industry leaders are looking to empower investors with reliable tools to facilitate decision-making, and advanced technologies such as blockchain and AI are being used to collect and validate sustainability data, track carbon emissions, and standardise sustainability reporting. Global collaboration is crucial to establishing a widely accepted impact measurement framework for green investments.

site_title: Turning the world pink: Jakob Angele, CEO of foodpanda APAC
summary: Jakob Angele, CEO of foodpanda APAC, aims to see every household use the app daily. The company has seen success during the pandemic, with food delivery booming as restaurants closed. Angele believes the industry will continue to grow, and pandamart, a cloud grocery store, is a key focus. The service aims to deliver groceries in 10-15 minutes, rivaling in-store shopping. With over 200 cloud stores in eight markets, pandamart is Asia's largest network. Angele plans to double the number of stores within the next year and expand the range of products to 5,000 items. Foodpanda also works with smaller shops, offering them a technology-enabled platform. The company continues to innovate, testing automated vehicles for delivery and working with restaurants to improve efficiency.

site_title: Sats swings back into the black for Q1 but braces for cut in government relief
summary: SATS, a Singapore-based ground-handler and in-flight caterer, has swung back into the black with a net profit of S$6.4 million for Q1, reversing from a loss of S$43.7 million in the same period last year. The company expects government relief grants to be reduced for FY2022, but will focus on reshaping its cost base and building new capabilities. Sats' revenue grew 31.6% year-over-year to S$275.6 million, with non-travel-related revenue contributing 46.3% of total revenue. The company plans to reach a 50-50 distribution between travel and non-travel revenue contributions soon.

site_title: Changing landscape of the Olympics
summary: The Olympics have undergone a significant transformation since professionals were allowed to participate in the late 1980s. The influx of top athletes from around the world, often sponsored by major brands, has blurred the line between professionals and amateurs. This shift has led to increased competition, with many countries relying on star performers to compete at the highest level. The financial aspect of the Olympics has also become a major factor, with increased sponsorship deals and television money contributing to the growing commercialization of the event.

images.alt_text: Philippines' weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz won the first-ever Olympic gold for her country.
Anna Kiesenhofer of Austria, who has not cycled since 2017, overcame the odds to win gold in the women's road race.

site_title: Japan boosts renewable energy targets
summary: Japan has revised its energy policy to boost its renewable energy targets, aiming for 36-38% of power supplies to come from renewables by 2030, double the previous target. The plan reduces coal usage to 19% and leaves nuclear power unchanged at 20-22%. Gas will make up the remaining 41% of the energy mix, with new fuels like hydrogen and ammonia accounting for 1%. The revised plan is considered ambitious in tackling climate change, following Japan's commitment to meet international agreements.

site_title: China tech billionaires ramp up donations as Beijing cracks down
summary: China's tech billionaires, including Lei Jun of Xiaomi, Wang Xing of Meituan, and Zhang Yiming of ByteDance, are donating billions of dollars to charitable causes amid Beijing's regulatory crackdown on technology companies. The donations follow a series of regulatory actions, including the forced IPO cancellation of Ant Group's Jack Ma. The move is seen as a response to China's increasing focus on inequality and the need for "common prosperity." The donations are likely driven by Beijing's regulatory crackdowns, according to analysts.

site_title: Hong Kong court jails seven over train station mob attack
summary: A Hong Kong court has jailed seven government supporters for their role in a violent attack on democracy supporters and commuters at a train station in 2019. The attack, which occurred in Yuen Long, left 50 people injured and was widely condemned. The court described the attack as an "indiscriminate attack" and handed down sentences ranging from 3 years to 7 years in prison. The incident was a turning point in the 2019 pro-democracy protests, further eroding public trust in the government and police force.

site_title: EMA, Shell renew partnership with S$4m funding to grow local energy startups
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) and Shell have renewed their partnership with S$4 million in funding to support local energy startups. The joint commitment now totals S$8 million, supporting 12 startups under the Shell StartUp Engine programme since 2019. The partnership aims to help startups develop innovative solutions and expand their market reach, with ESG providing support under the Open Innovation initiative. This will enable energy startups to build new capabilities and gain a track record for scaling up further.

site_title: What's next for Stamford Land if it pivots away from hotels?
summary: Stamford Land, a Singapore-listed property player, is considering pivoting away from hotels due to the challenges posed by the Covid-19 pandemic. The company has appointed JLL and CBRE to sell six high-end hotels in Australia and New Zealand, valued at over S$1.02 billion. The potential sale would boost earnings and net assets, but it's unclear if the proceeds will be reinvested in the hospitality business or expanded into investment properties and development. Stamford Land's shares have surged 40% since the announcement, but still trade at a discount to the latest reported net asset value.

site_title: China frictions steer electric automakers away from rare earth magnets
summary: China's dominance in rare earth magnet production is causing Western electric vehicle manufacturers to limit their reliance on these key components. Major automakers, including Toyota, BMW, and Volkswagen, are cutting back on rare earths due to supply concerns, price swings, and environmental damage. China controls 90% of the supply, and prices have more than doubled in the past year. To mitigate risks, companies are exploring alternatives, such as non-rare-earth electric motors and recycling of existing magnets. Analysts expect global consumption of rare earths to climb to $15.7 billion by 2030, but innovations may help balance demand growth.

site_title: Samsung reports 73.4% surge in profit in Q2
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 73.4% surge in net profits to 9.6 trillion won (S$11.4 billion) in the second quarter, driven by higher chip prices due to pandemic-led demand. Operating profit increased 54.3% to 12.6 trillion won. The company attributed the growth to favourable market conditions for memory chips, with shipments exceeding previous guidance. Despite a decline in smartphone earnings, Samsung expects favourable market conditions for the remainder of the year, with continued demand for memory chips. The company also warned of persisting uncertainty associated with the pandemic.

site_title: Blaze defies US firefighters, power firm under scrutiny
summary: A large wildfire in Oregon's Bootleg Fire has grown to over 121,400 hectares, forcing 2,100 evacuations and destroying 67 homes. The fire, linked to a California power company, has emerged as a challenge for firefighters, with only one quarter of its perimeter contained. Climate change is being blamed for the fire's early start and explosive growth, with similar trends observed in California. The same power company, PG&E, was linked to a deadly fire in 2018, and the company has faced criticism for its role in sparking several massive California fires.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares fall at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with losses on Monday, following a sell-off on Wall Street due to renewed worries about inflation and the virus. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.78% to 27,786.54, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The losses were fueled by global market uncertainty.

site_title: Yen, US dollar rise as Covid spurs rush to safety
summary: The yen and US dollar rose to near multi-month highs against the Australian dollar and British pound, driven by fears of a rapid coronavirus variant threatening the global economic recovery. The yen traded at 80.09 per Aussie dollar and 149.48 to the pound, while the US dollar touched an almost eight-month high of US$0.7317 per Aussie. The rapid spread of the Delta variant has led to surging infections in areas with low vaccination rates, potentially delaying the global recovery.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit bumps up H2 DPU to 2.07 Singapore cents
summary: Starhill Global Reit (SGReit) has announced a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.07 Singapore cents for the second half, including a deferred amount from the previous year. Distributable income rose 67.3% to S$44.9 million, driven by property tax refunds and a capital allowance claim. The full-year DPU is 3.95 cents, up from 2.96 cents. The company's commercial portfolio saw a 20.2% increase in net property income to S$69.8 million, despite a slowdown in shopper traffic due to worsening Covid-19 outbreaks.

site_title: US, UK allies blame Chinese government for Microsoft hack
summary: The US, UK, and allies formally attributed the Microsoft Exchange hack to actors affiliated with the Chinese government, escalating tensions between the two countries. The US and other nations have joined in assessing the Chinese government's involvement in malicious cyber-attacks, including ransomware, data theft, and cyber-espionage. UK Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab stated that the Chinese government must end its "systematic cyber sabotage" or face consequences. The attribution marks a significant escalation in the diplomatic rift between the US and China over cybersecurity concerns.

site_title: Sembcorp opens solar-powered EV charging hub; to be available for public use by 2022
summary: Sembcorp Industries has opened Singapore's first solar-powered electric vehicle charging hub at its Tuas depot, serving its fleet of waste and recycling electric trucks. The hub, powered by 472 kWp of rooftop solar, can conduct about 100 charging cycles per day. Plans are to open the facility for public use by other industrial vehicles in the Tuas region, supporting Singapore's transport decarbonisation efforts under the Singapore Green Plan.

site_title: Floodwaters still rising in western Europe with death toll over 110
summary: Floodwaters continue to rise in western Europe, particularly in Germany, Belgium, and the Netherlands, with over 110 deaths reported. Thousands are missing, and more than 1,000 homes have been destroyed. Germany's death toll is its highest in years, with 103 fatalities, while Belgium reports at least 14 deaths. Power and mobile phone networks have collapsed in affected regions, hindering rescue efforts. The European Commission has linked the flooding to climate change, and the German government aims to provide financial support to affected areas as quickly as possible.

site_title: Hot stock: Raffles Medical up 6.6% after release of H1 results
summary: Raffles Medical Group announced its H1 results, reporting a net profit of S$39.4 million, more than double the S$17.2 million in the same period last year. The stock rose 6.6% to a high of S$1.29, with 3.4 million shares changing hands. No married deals were recorded.

site_title: Singapore to donate Covax allocation to other countries: PM Lee
summary: Singapore plans to donate its Covax vaccine allocation to other countries, said Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong at the Apec Informal Leaders' Retreat. This move aims to support middle-income and poorer countries in accessing vaccines. Lee emphasized the need for multilateralism to strengthen pandemic security, including a global surveillance system for emerging outbreaks. He also highlighted the importance of trade liberalization, digital vaccine certificates, and cooperation on new economic growth areas such as the digital and green economies.

site_title: The instability in stablecoins is unnerving regulators
summary: Regulators are growing concerned about the stability of "stablecoins," dollar-pegged crypto tokens that have grown 18-fold to over $100 billion. The use of commercial paper, bills, bonds, and loans as reserves to back their value is unsettling, with Fitch warning of potential asset contagion risks. The Federal Reserve is focused on this issue, with Boston Fed chief Eric Rosengren highlighting the risks of stablecoins being used in times of financial stress. Regulators are considering regulation and capital requirements, but clarity on the progress and timeline for these moves is lacking.

site_title: Second skin
summary: Hermès' latest high jewellery collection, Lignes Sensibles, is an intimate ode to the human form, inspired by the sensuality of the body and its sensory systems. Designed by Pierre Hardy, the 45-piece collection features sensual necklaces, bracelets, and earrings that move with the body, often resembling a second skin. Gemstones in flesh colors and cloudy materials are used to create unique, quietly confident pieces that fit closely around the body. The collection's five lines showcase a range of designs, from harmonious colors to dramatic and fluid textures, all aimed at achieving a symbiosis between the body and the jewellery.

site_title: Saudi, UAE reach compromise to unlock more oil supply: source
summary: Saudi Arabia and the UAE have reached a compromise on Opec+ policy, which should unlock a deal to supply more crude oil to a tight market and cool soaring prices. The agreement allows the UAE to have a higher production baseline, paving the way for extending the overall pact to the end of 2022. Brent oil prices fell by up to $1 per barrel, reaching $75 per barrel, after the news. A final decision on output policy is still needed from Opec+, but the compromise is seen as a positive step in addressing the tight oil market.

site_title: Thai hospital tycoon sticks to guns on vaccine claims
summary: Thai hospital tycoon Thonburi Healthcare Group Pcl's chairman Boon Vanasin claims to have secured a deal for 20 million Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines, despite Pfizer-BioNTech denying the claim. The company stated it is in the process of filing documents with overseas dealers, but no deal has been signed. THG's shares rose 1.59% after the statement, adding 1.5 billion baht to its market capitalisation. Thailand's government agency filed a defamation suit against Boon on Thursday, and it remains unclear whether the claim is genuine or a scam.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at open, tracking Wall Street rally; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.5% on Wednesday, tracking a Wall Street rally, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,126.11. Gainers outnumbered losers 99 to 55, driven by gains in Marco Polo Marine, Singtel, and Sanli Environmental. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also traded higher. The rally follows a rebound in US stocks, which rose 1.6% on Tuesday after a worst session of the year.

site_title: An irrational, emotive bias
summary: Racial issues have surfaced recently due to pressures from the pandemic and job insecurity, exacerbating existing prejudices and stereotypes. Businesses can reduce racial divides by promoting a positive workplace culture with clear values and behaviors, zero tolerance for discrimination, and embedding desirable behaviors across the organization. Experts emphasize the importance of education, awareness, and inclusivity, as well as recognizing and valuing human similarities. Leaders must take decisive actions to address racism, including conducting anonymous audits, promoting diversity and equity, and creating safe spaces for discussions.

site_title: ecoWise shareholders intend to convene EGM after company said it will not do so
summary: Three ecoWise Holdings shareholders intend to convene an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) despite the company initially stating it would not hold one. The shareholders, Tan Swee Boon, Tan Jin Beng Winston, and Sunny Ong Keng Hua, had sent a requisition in May requesting the removal of director Cao Shixuan and the appointment of three new directors. The company's board had initially agreed to convene the EGM but later reversed the decision, citing the proposed resolutions as "not meaningful" and claiming the removal of Cao would cause "unnecessary disruptions."

site_title: Singapore stocks little changed at Friday's open; STI dips 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.1% on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling to 3,156.39, as cautious trading prevailed. Gainers outnumbered losers 77 to 53, with AnAn International and Marco Polo Marine being among the most actively traded counters. In contrast, US stocks edged up, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index rising 0.1%, 0.2%, and 0.4% respectively. European stocks also rose for a third consecutive session, driven by strong corporate earnings and the European Central Bank's pledge to keep interest rates at record lows.

site_title: The special power of watches
summary: Lung Lung Thun, a 31-year-old Singaporean, is a renowned watch collector with a passion for horological complexity. She began collecting watches after graduating from Warwick University in 2010, initially buying trendy pieces without knowledge of their mechanics. As she delved deeper into the world of watches, she developed a curated collection showcasing her evolving tastes. Thun now manages a securities brokerage in Hong Kong and believes her watch collection reveals her personality, with each piece chosen for its unique characteristics and ability to convey her style.

site_title: Passion over possession
summary: Chan Kok Weng and his wife Elaine Lim-Chan are a couple who collect luxury items, including cars, watches, and fine art, driven by passion rather than investment strategy. The couple, who own a Lamborghini, Jaguar E-Type, and two Rolls-Royces, value their leisure time and enjoy spending their disposable income on their favorite things. They have no method to their acquisitions, going for what makes each item unique, and have no intention of selling their prized possessions. The couple credits their shared love for automobiles and driving holidays as a turning point in their collecting journey, and emphasizes that true value lies in experience, love, and passion.

site_title: Seeking solidarity: EU Ambassador Barbara Plinkert
summary: EU Ambassador to Singapore Barbara Plinkert's term is ending next month, marked by milestones such as the signing of the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement and the European Union Film Festival. A sinologist and European, Plinkert has been working to strengthen EU-Singapore ties, promoting free, open, and rules-based trade. She believes the EU remains a project, despite the UK's exit, and that solidarity among EU member states has increased during the pandemic. The EU has also launched its Indo-Pacific Strategy, aiming to work with all partners in the region. Plinkert will be heading to Brussels, taking with her experiences in Singapore's management of its small space to make it livable.

site_title: HK's booming IPO market set for boost from China curbs
summary: Hong Kong's booming IPO market is expected to receive a boost from China's tightening regulations on overseas listings and cybersecurity oversight. Companies such as Lalamove and Neusoft Medical Systems are considering Hong Kong listings as an alternative to the US market. The city's relatively streamlined listing procedures and financing flexibility are attractive features, with Chinese companies seeking to raise at least $5 billion in a planned second listing. The move follows China's proposal to block Chinese firms from listing overseas, making Hong Kong a safer alternative.

site_title: Mind-bending design
summary: Architect Aamer Taher creates unique, mind-bending tropical spaces that defy description. He started his eponymous firm after leaving a corporate job and has since gained international recognition for his unconventional designs. A recent example is a 10,980 sq ft house on a steep, odd-shaped hill in Singapore, featuring five floors with a meandering facade that diverts around mature trees. Taher's approach is to "sculpt spaces in the tropics," taking into account the site, context, and brief, and often incorporating voids for natural light and ventilation. His goal is to create a unique, art-like space that speaks to his creativity and clients' desires.

site_title: All that glitters
summary: The reality TV show "Bling Empire" offers a glimpse into the lives of affluent Asian Americans, showcasing their complex personalities and struggles. Despite their lavish lifestyles, cast members like Cherie Chan and Kevin Kreider reveal relatable issues such as unrequited love, marital frustrations, and toxic friendships. The show highlights the characters' deep respect for Asian cultures and values, and their experiences serve as a commentary on the Asian-American community's struggles with racism and identity. As the show progresses, characters like Chan and Kreider open up about their personal struggles and aspirations, humanizing the often-glamorized world of the wealthy.

site_title: Sweet pearls of gold
summary: Van Cleef & Arpels has introduced six new sweet clovers creations to its iconic Perlée collection, featuring golden beads and diamonds. The new pieces, including bracelets and rings, incorporate the traditional gold beading technique and offer a fresh take on the collection's rounded style. The designs draw inspiration from the original Perlée clovers, but with a more light-hearted feel. The new additions are designed to be worn in twos or threes, creating a "happy dance" around the wrist, and can be paired with other Van Cleef & Arpels jewelry lines for a personal style statement.

site_title: A new dining chapter
summary: Alain Ducasse, the renowned chef, has reimagined the iconic Bar & Billiard Room at Raffles Hotel Singapore with his new Mediterranean-inspired eatery, OSTERIA BBR. Opening on July 23, the restaurant pays homage to Italian gastronomy, with a menu featuring produce-driven dishes, wood-fired pizzas, and seafood. Chef Francesco Soletti, an Italian native with Michelin-starred credentials, helms the kitchen, offering a curated selection of seven signature creations and various menu options. The eatery also features a preprandial cocktail tradition and an Italian wine program, with a cozy indoor bar and al fresco patio.

site_title: Flying the Singapore flag of cuisine
summary: Singapore's Marina Bay Sands has been a breeding ground for local culinary talent, grooming chefs for successful careers in the industry. The integrated resort's approach to creating good jobs and long-term employment for Singaporeans has led to the development of a tight-knit community of local chefs. Alumni such as Jason Tan, Sun Kim, and Gwern Khoo have gone on to achieve success in their own restaurants, with Marina Bay Sands continuing to nurture and mentor the next generation of chefs through internships and mentorship programs.

site_title: Diamonds are forever
summary: Rolex has unveiled its latest gem-set timepieces, the Oyster Perpetual Day-Date 36 and Oyster Perpetual Lady Datejust, featuring 817 diamonds each. The watches, priced 10 times higher than tool pieces, have been met with high demand, with waiting lists stretching into years. The limited nature of the watches is attributed to the scarcity of precious stones and the expertise required to set them. The new models boast advanced features, including automatic movements and precision rates, and are set to become a symbol of luxury and craftsmanship.

site_title: Wooing of listings with dual-class shares yields fuzzy gains but definite pain
summary: The UK has proposed changes to its listing rules to allow dual-class shares, sparking debate on the principle of "one share, one vote". The move aims to attract more listings and boost competitiveness. However, it has raised concerns about giving up cherished doctrines in the pursuit of business. Other jurisdictions will likely respond to the competition, with Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer being 9.8 times oversubscribed, indicating growing demand for listings. The UK's plans will likely be closely watched globally, with potential implications for companies and investors.

site_title: Food as medicine
summary: A growing body of research suggests that gut health plays a crucial role in overall well-being, influencing symptoms such as mood swings, insomnia, and low energy. The human gut microbiome, comprising trillions of good and bad bacteria, affects the immune system, metabolism, and brain health. Experts, including Jeremy Lim and Tiffany Wee, advise individuals to adopt a balanced diet rich in whole foods, plant-based foods, and avoid additives to promote a healthy gut microbiome. By making conscious food choices and practicing mindful eating, individuals can take control of their gut health and overall well-being.

images.alt_text: Eat well at COMO Shambhala Cuisine with dishes such as toast with avocado crush, heirloom tomatoes and cucumber, and zucchini carpaccio with crab, preserved lemon, pine nuts and mint.
Dr Jeremy Lim, CEO and co-founder of AMILI.

site_title: Messi's Argentina trophy odyssey ends in Brazil
summary: Lionel Messi led Argentina to a 1-0 victory over Brazil in the Copa America final, ending a 16-year wait for international success. The win marked Messi's first major trophy with his country, following a glittering career with Barcelona. Messi was named player of the tournament and finished as top goalscorer and assist provider, capping a remarkable performance after shedding blood in the semi-final win over Colombia. The victory marked Argentina's first major trophy in 28 years and was hailed as a testament to Messi's enduring dedication and talent.

site_title: The bling effect
summary: Rolex's gem-set collection watches require a skilled team of gemologists and gem-setters to select and affix precious stones, elevating the brand's iconic models while retaining their technical features. Only natural stones meeting Rolex's demanding quality criterion are used, with diamonds undergoing X-ray imaging and rubies, sapphires, and emeralds undergoing rigorous procedures to ensure authenticity. The placement of stones is carefully studied to balance aesthetic and technical requirements, with gem-setters working with precision to set each stone onto the watch, adhering to Rolex's strict tolerances of 0.2mm.

site_title: WhatsApp targeted in EU consumer complaints over privacy changes
summary: WhatsApp faced EU consumer complaints over a privacy policy update that allowed data sharing with Facebook and other group firms. The European Consumer Organisation and others criticized the changes, citing undue pressure on users and a lack of clear explanation. The groups filed complaints with the European Commission and urged EU data protection authorities to address concerns. The move led to a global outcry, with some users switching to rival apps Telegram and Signal. WhatsApp claimed the changes did not affect personal conversations, but critics argue the company breached EU consumer law with ambiguous terms.

site_title: BlackRock's Fink urges World Bank, IMF overhaul for green era
summary: BlackRock CEO Larry Fink urged the World Bank and IMF to overhaul their roles to support sustainable development in emerging markets. Fink proposed a "first-loss" guarantee model, where the institutions absorb initial losses to reduce risk for private investors, allowing trillions of dollars in investment to flow into clean energy projects. The proposal aims to address the challenge of creating long-term, durable returns in developing economies. Fink's plan, similar to a crisis-fighting tool used in the US Treasury's Public-Private Investment Program, could help mobilize private capital for low-carbon investments, reaching a mid-century target of net-zero emissions.

site_title: Northern US Plains drought shrivels spring wheat crop to smallest in 33 years, USDA says
summary: The US spring wheat crop is expected to be the smallest in 33 years due to severe drought in the northern US Plains, according to the USDA. The crop is projected to be 345 million bushels, a 41% decline from last year, and will lead to tighter supplies and higher prices for wheat used in bread and pizza dough. The drought also threatens Canada's spring wheat supplies, with the USDA rating just 16% of US spring wheat in good-to-excellent condition, the lowest early-July level since 1988.

site_title: MAS launches global challenge to promote AI adoption in financial sector
summary: MAS launches the Global Veritas Challenge to promote AI adoption in the financial sector, focusing on fairness, ethics, accountability, and transparency (Feat) principles. The challenge invites fintech companies and institutions worldwide to submit AI solutions for problem statements, with up to 10 finalists selected to develop customised prototypes and pitch their solutions. The winners will receive a cash prize of S$50,000 and showcase their projects globally. The challenge aims to accelerate the development of AI and data analytics solutions, strengthening trust in AI technologies among users and the public.

site_title: Leader Environmental Tech CEO, deputy CTO in CAD probe on insider trading
summary: Leader Environmental Technologies CEO Lin Yucheng and deputy CTO Guo Chenghong are under investigation by the Commercial Affairs Department in Singapore for alleged insider trading. The investigation was triggered by a letter from the Singapore Police Force and Monetary Authority of Singapore. Despite the probe, the company's business operations remain unaffected, and its leaders are allowed to continue their duties normally. The company's share price dropped 27.27% on Friday following the announcement.

site_title: Euro 2020: Italy beat Spain on penalties to set up final with England or Denmark
summary: Italy beat Spain 4-2 on penalties after a 1-1 draw in the Euro 2020 semi-final at Wembley, advancing to the final against either England or Denmark. Italy's Federico Chiesa scored the opening goal, and Alvaro Morata equalized with 10 minutes left. Italy won the penalty shootout, with Jorginho converting the decisive kick. The win marked Italy's 10th major tournament final appearance and ended Spain's hopes of a record fourth European crown.

site_title: Singapore's Janio bags US$8m investment from fintech company Choco Up
summary: Singapore logistics platform Janio has secured a US$8 million investment from fintech company Choco Up, alongside funding from Innoven Capital and existing shareholders. The investment will support Janio's growth, expansion plans, and entry into emerging markets. Janio, founded in 2018, provides cross-border e-commerce logistics solutions in Southeast Asia, backed by Sequoia Capital and other venture capital firms. The funding will provide a quick influx of capital for Janio to execute expansion plans with confidence.

site_title: World's billionaire factory shudders as China cracks down
summary: China's crackdown on its ultra-rich has led to a significant decline in their combined fortunes, with the world's 10 wealthiest people adding $209 billion to their net worth in the first half of 2021, but China's richest tycoons saw their combined fortunes shrink by $16 billion. Regulators have tightened regulations on financial services, internet platforms, and data, and are targeting companies like Didi Global and Ant Group, forcing them to undergo cybersecurity reviews before listing abroad. This marks a new era for China's billionaires, with a focus on more deference to the Communist Party, charitable donations, and employee wellbeing.

site_title: China bans tallest skyscrapers after safety concerns
summary: China has banned construction of skyscrapers taller than 500 meters due to safety concerns over the quality of some projects. Local authorities will also limit towers over 250 meters tall. The National Development and Reform Commission cited quality problems and safety hazards, including the closure of a 72-storey tower in Shenzhen after reports of unexplained wobbling. The ban aims to ensure safety and prevent signature projects for mayors from being inefficient.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS upgrades Starhill Global Reit to 'buy', raises target price to S$0.75
summary: DBS upgraded Starhill Global Reit to 'buy' with a target price of S$0.75, citing improved operational results and a high occupancy rate at Wisma Atria mall. The research team expects distribution per unit to return to pre-pandemic levels earlier than anticipated, driven by increased tenant sales and traffic. DBS also notes the Reit's resilience on Wisma Atria's 97% occupancy rate and plans to reposition the mall as a premier lifestyle destination.

site_title: Pound in spotlight for traders gauging vaccine success
summary: The UK pound is in focus as traders gauge its resilience to highly transmissible virus variants, with the country's first major economy to meet a widely vaccinated population. Despite Covid cases reaching their highest since January, hospitalizations and deaths remain contained, suggesting vaccines are working. The Bank of England's decision to postpone economic reopening has led to a decline in the pound, but some analysts expect it to recover by the end of the year, with a median call predicting a price of US$1.42.

site_title: Why young Singaporeans are ready to go back to the office
summary: Young Singaporeans, primarily Gen Zs and young millennials, are returning to the office despite having experienced flexible work arrangements during the pandemic. The group prioritizes job security over work-life balance and believes that productivity can be accurately measured regardless of location. Many prefer hybrid working arrangements, where they spend a few days a week in the office. Employers, including Singapore banks, have adopted flexible working models to accommodate the needs of young workers. Despite concerns about missed opportunities for collaboration and training, the majority of Gen Zs and millennials believe that flexible work arrangements will have a positive impact on their careers.

site_title: Brokers' take: Maybank KE positive on semicon manufacturing suppliers as Lam Research expands in Asia
summary: Maybank KE has upgraded its rating on semiconductor manufacturing suppliers, citing Lam Research's expansion in Asia as a growth opportunity. Analysts predict UMS Holdings, Frencken Group, and Venture Corporation will benefit from the expansion, citing their strong track records and local presence. The analysts maintain "buy" ratings on the companies, with target prices ranging from S$1.80 to S$22, and predict partnering Lam Research could help suppliers cushion negative cyclicality. Successful localisation appears key to Lam's Asia expansion, with potential for supply chain buildout in Malaysia.

site_title: US: Jobs data push Wall Street stocks to new highs
summary: US stocks surged to fresh records on Friday, driven by a solid jobs report that added 850,000 jobs in June, beating expectations. The unemployment rate ticked up to 5.9%, considered a "Goldilocks" outcome. Tech firms like Apple, Microsoft, and Amazon rose, while IBM fell 4.6%. The dollar retreated after the report, which was seen as not accelerating a monetary policy shift. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq also edged to fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Fire rages, mass evacuation after Thai factory blast
summary: A factory explosion in Samut Prakan province, Thailand, killed one rescue worker and wounded 29 people, prompting a mass evacuation of nearby residents. The blast, which occurred in the early hours of Monday, also damaged 70 houses and left fires burning 15 hours later. The cause of the explosion has yet to be determined, and authorities are warning people to avoid drinking potentially contaminated rainwater. The nearby Suvarnabhumi international airport was not affected by the incident.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB raises Silverlake target to S$0.35 on tech investment appetite
summary: Singapore-listed Silverlake Axis may see its earnings recover as demand for its technology solutions from banks recovers. Analyst Andrea Choong from CGS-CIMB raised the target price to S$0.35 from S$0.31, citing the company's first order win from a top-tier bank in Thailand and its core banking system provider status for several digital bank licence applicants in Malaysia. Choong expects Silverlake to record a net profit of RM45 million in its fourth quarter, driven by software licensing order wins and investment appetite from banks bottoming out.

site_title: ecoWise will not convene EGM to vote on requisition notice resolutions
summary: ecoWise will not convene an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to vote on resolutions proposed by three members in a requisition notice due to concerns over the resolutions' meaning and the potential impact on the company's governance. The company's board determined that appointing new independent directors as required by the Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) would be more beneficial and address the concerns of the requisition members. The board will instead appoint at least two new independent directors to the audit committee.

site_title: Asia merger and acquisition bonanza fuelled by South-east Asia, private equity deals
summary: Asian merger and acquisition activity surged to its second-highest level in the first half, driven by South-east Asian and private equity deals. Announced deals involving Asian companies reached US$707.7 billion, a 75% increase from the same period last year. South-east Asia deals jumped 83% to a record US$124.8 billion, fueled by blockbuster transactions like Grab's US$40 billion merger with Altimeter Growth Corp. Private equity-backed deals more than doubled to a record US$102 billion, with Asia-focused PE funds raising US$80.5 billion.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei gains as SoftBank, Uniqlo owner rebound
summary: Japan's Nikkei ended modestly higher on Tuesday, closing 0.16% higher at 28,643.21, despite concerns over a potential spike in coronavirus infections during the Olympics. Shares of SoftBank Group and Fast Retailing rebounded, with SoftBank rising 1% and Uniqlo adding 0.45%. The broader Topix gained 0.28%. Investors are waiting for the government's decision on extending a state of quasi-emergency in Tokyo and three nearby prefectures, which may impact gains.

site_title: Brokers' take: RHB raises Raffles Medical's target price to S$1.35 on Singapore's reopening plans
summary: RHB raised its target price for Raffles Medical Group to S$1.35 from S$1.29 due to plans to reopen borders in Singapore and easing restrictions. The research team expects the group to post strong growth amid an aggressive vaccination programme and frequent Covid-19 testing. Raffles Medical is also expected to benefit from the resumption of overseas travel and local patient load returning to pre-pandemic levels. The research team maintains a "buy" call on the stock, citing its compelling valuation and strong estimated earnings growth.

site_title: Three new Covid-19 community cases in Singapore, including one unlinked
summary: Singapore reported 10 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 62,592. Three cases are locally transmitted, including one unlinked, while seven are imported. The locally transmitted cases are linked to existing cases, and all imported cases are on stay-home notices or isolated. This brings Singapore's total deaths to 36 and cases of other causes to 15.

site_title: IMF chief warns of 'dangerous divergence' in Covid-19 recovery
summary: IMF Chief Kristalina Georgieva warns of a "dangerous divergence" in Covid-19 recovery between wealthy and developing countries. Wealthy nations are recovering quickly, while developing countries are hindered by slow vaccination rates. Georgieva calls for the G20 to increase dose-sharing and urges the G7's 1 billion dose pledge to be more substantial. She also expresses concerns over a "K-shaped recovery" with regions experiencing slow growth, threatening global stability and security.

site_title: One new Covid-19 case from dormitory, first since June 14
summary: Singapore reported 10 new COVID-19 cases, with one linked to a dormitory and the others unlinked. The total cases now stand at 62,640. The Ministry of Health (MOH) also closed two clusters, including one linked to a barber shop. The number of active clusters remains at 22, with 99 hospitalised patients, and the number of new cases in the community has decreased from 76 to 24 in the past week.

site_title: Painting the skyline: Lee Polisano, PLP Architecture president
summary: Architecture president Lee Polisano of PLP Architecture believes that cities must rethink the blend of technology and green spaces. He cites Singapore's Changi Airport as an example of a society that values openness and comfort. Polisano aims to design a building in downtown Singapore that incorporates a mix of indoor and outdoor spaces. He disagrees with the notion that the office building is dead, but believes it will evolve to prioritize social, health, and environmental needs. Polisano advocates for a holistic approach to urban planning, combining technology, environmental sustainability, and community well-being.

site_title: US service industries expand at slower pace than expected
summary: The US service industries expanded at a slower pace than expected in June, according to the Institute for Supply Management's services index, which fell to 60.1 from a record 64 in May. Despite this, demand for services like restaurant dining and travel remains solid, while employment contracted to the lowest level this year. Sixteen of 18 service industries reported growth, led by arts, entertainment, and recreation. Challenges with materials shortages, inflation, and logistics continue to impact business conditions, according to the ISM's chair.

site_title: Everything must go: Behind the scenes at the Robinsons liquidation
summary: Liquidator Cameron Duncan of KordaMentha oversaw the liquidation of Robinsons department store, achieving better-than-expected outcomes for creditors. Duncan maximized asset value by selling inventory in-store, using a specialized discounting strategy, and partnering with Gordon Brothers. The liquidation resulted in 21% returns on stock value, exceeding forecasted 10% losses. Landlords were paid with certainty through guaranteed minimum stock value, and employees and the taxman received priority claims. Customers with prepaid goods received commercial arrangements, and gift vouchers were used with conditions to maximize returns. The liquidation process highlighted common misconceptions among creditors regarding their rights and claims, emphasizing the importance of understanding contract terms and seeking professional advice.

site_title: Hot stocks: Jardine C&C up 5.9%, Dairy Farm falls 4.2% after H1 results release
summary: Shares of Jardine Cycle & Carriage (Jardine C&C) rose 5.9% to S$20.87 after releasing its first-half underlying profits, which more than doubled to US$346.5 million. In contrast, Dairy Farm International fell 4.2% to US$3.82 after its H1 results missed consensus forecasts, with underlying net profit down 69.5% to US$32.1 million. The results were attributed to lower contributions from the grocery segment and persistent health and beauty weakness.
